webTitle: Zola faces Chelsea test of strength

fields.headline: Zola faces Chelsea test of strength
fields.trailText: Gianfranco Zola's 150th appearance for Chelsea was delayed on Wednesday when his place in the squad was taken by George Weah, and should the Italian miss out again today when the team is picked to face Leicester at Stamford Bridge, Gianluca Vialli could face a serious test of his man-management skills.
fields.body:
Gianfranco Zola's 150th appearance for Chelsea was delayed on Wednesday when his place in the squad was taken by George Weah, and should the Italian miss out again today when the team is picked to face Leicester at Stamford Bridge, Gianluca Vialli could face a serious test of his man-management skills.

Zola was told that his absence from Chelsea's squad - he has never before been left out - for the Premiership victory over Tottenham was a one-off, but Vialli will have to drop two from Weah, who scored the only goal of the game on his debut, Chris Sutton and Tore Andre Flo if Zola is to start.

Flo is expected to partner Weah up front against Leicester, after the Liberian's successful introduction as a substitute on Wednesday, with Zola confined to the bench, a situation that would increase the speculation on the future of Sutton, a £10m signing from Blackburn in the summer.

Weah's dramatic introduction to the Premiership was a big surprise to Arsène Wenger, Arsenal's manager admitted yesterday. Wenger, who was Weah's manager at Monaco, said that he had been unaware of the striker's availability when the deal was concluded on Tuesday. Wenger is likely to be without the Nigerian Nwankwo Kanu and Dennis Bergkamp until mid-February, putting extra pressure on the strikers Thierry Henry and Davor Suker to keep Arsenal's season on track. Weah would have eased Wenger's worries.

"I know he would love to play for Arsenal but when I looked at the transfer market two weeks ago there was nothing to interest me," Wenger said. "Then when I looked again this week it was too late. He had signed already for Chelsea.

"I am sure he will do well for Chelsea because he wants to show that he's still a top player despite being left out by Milan. I don't know what the financial terms were for his loan - not exactly cheap, I expect - and it is not usually the kind of thing we would do but we are very short of strikers at the moment, especially now that we know Davor Suker will miss the Manchester United game a week on Monday through suspension."

Should the surplus of strikers at Chelsea lead to the offloading of Sutton, Tottenham's manager George Graham admitted that he would be interested in buying him. Graham was keen to buy Sutton in the summer, but was put off by the size of the fee.

If Chelsea were ready to cut their losses on the striker, who has scored only three goals for the team, then Tottenham are likely to renew their interest, but Graham said yesterday that he thought this eventuality was unlikely.

"At the moment I cannot see Chelsea wanting to part with any of their four strikers with the Champions League coming up again soon. So I am not going to get involved," he said.

However, Tottenham's inability to turn their territorial domination into goals against Chelsea in midweek suggested that a new striker is a priority.

webTitle: Towering job for a tough guy

fields.headline: Towering job for a tough guy
fields.standfirst: Steve McMahon comes from Sky with a mission to elevate Blackpool: The Seasiders' slide
fields.trailText: For the time being the work on his back swing will have to wait. From Bootle to Bermuda, Steve McMahon has paced the fairways of some of the world's finest golf courses in the past 12 months, reducing his handicap to 11. But now the irons are back in the garage and the 38-year-old has gone back to basics.
fields.body:
For the time being the work on his back swing will have to wait. From Bootle to Bermuda, Steve McMahon has paced the fairways of some of the world's finest golf courses in the past 12 months, reducing his handicap to 11. But now the irons are back in the garage and the 38-year-old has gone back to basics.

After leaving Swindon Town 15 months ago he bided his time and recharged his batteries, and this week he ended his sabbatical by taking charge at Blackpool Football Club. Battered and beleaguered, Blackpool come complete with a government health warning. So it is fortunate that McMahon has never been greatly concerned about the hazards of his occupation.

Few have crossed him and come out on top, certainly not without bruises to show for it. And when you have taken on mother nature and survived to tell the tale, as he once did on the 14th hole at Wallasey, the prospect of taking over a club whose fortunes have nose-dived more spectacularly than the town's big dipper holds little trepidation.

"I was playing in a testimonial golf day for Alan Hansen and the weather was terrible," McMahon says, recalling the day he came close to meeting his maker. "Playing in weather like that is just about the worst possible thing to do, but for some reason we carried on regardless. "All of a sudden this flash of lightning came out of the sky and, bosh!, it hit me. It was quick, just a big 'whoosh' and then it was gone. Those were the days when I had some hair, and I looked like Bart Simpson with it all stood in the air. None of the other players could believe what they were seeing, and I wasn't best pleased either. I wasn't really injured but it was quite scary all the same."

"Scary" is not usually a word predominant in the McMahon vocabulary and he knows it. "I wasn't as scared as the lightning. I soon frightened it off."

His current mission is to halt a downward spiral that has left Blackpool's diminishing fan base afflicted with a severe case of vertigo in recent years. They have been a club in decline for longer than they would care to remember, the victims of unfulfilled promises on a downstream tide which has left them washed up and hung out to dry.

Blackpool's main reception doubles as the club shop. The terraces are strewn with moss. Old posters flap from dilapidated stands, and what is left of the tangerine paintwork hangs away from crumbling walls engulfed by the unedifying stench of years of neglect. The repair job will be immense in a town where the youthful supporters of tomor row prefer to spend their Saturday afternoons in the gaudy amusement arcades on the Golden Mile rather than the wind-buffeted terraces of Bloomfield Road.

When Blackpool beat Cambridge United in November, the visiting manager Roy McFarland did not attempt to hide his embarrassment with the damning verdict: "Blackpool are the worst side I have seen in two years - and we still lost."

But this is a more experienced McMahon than the one who at Swindon had his fingers so badly burned. He guided them to the Second Division championship in 1995-96. They led the First Division in November 1997. He was talked about as a future Liverpool manager - and then it all went horribly wrong.

Before his appointment Swindon's leading players had negotiated Premiership wages for themselves, and the financial burden was too much for a club of humble means. With the red bills gathering, McMahon was ordered to break up his side. Another day, he arrived at work to be told that five of his backroom staff would have to go.

Sanctuary

The team went into free fall and McMahon was blamed. His wife Julie was verbally abused outside the ground, and supporters invaded the pitch after a 4-1 home defeat by Watford. Finally he decided enough was enough and moved his family back to Merseyside.

Since then he has joined the labour-exchange-for-out-of-work managers that is Sky Sports, as well as working with the under-16s at Everton, where his son Stephen is on the books.

As he opens a generous pile of good-luck messages in his less-than-palatial office, he composes his argument for leaving the sanctuary of Sky's studios to succeed Nigel Worthington in charge of a team at the wrong end of the Second Division, where supporters have taken to providing hand-outs for new transfers and the owner Owen Oyston has a rape conviction on his curriculum vitae.

"The media work is enjoyable but I never thought of it as a long-term thing," he says. "Some people get into that comfort zone, but not me. I took my coaching badges long before I stopped playing and management has always held something for me.

"They were difficult times at Swindon, but don't forget I am in their history books as one of only two managers who have won them a championship. They never wanted me to leave. In fact they begged me to stay. But losing my staff because of all the cost-cutting was the last straw. They told me on a Friday and I had to make sure it was done before the weekend. It was like cutting off my right arm.

"I did well there and I knew that whoever took over could not do as good a job. When you look at the club now, it hasn't kicked on since I left, has it?"

Privately McMahon still harbours ambitions to manage Liverpool but, like the golf, that has been put on the back burner. Now his priority is today's visit of Luton Town. "No manager gets a job in January if everything is hunky-dory," he concluded. "The club are in big trouble but at least I know where we stand."

Blackpool: The last 30 years

1971 Relegated from the old First Division (average crowd 20,472). Jimmy Armfield retires after 568 league games.

1977 Board resigns after failing to raise modest sum to buy Malcolm Smith from Middlesbrough.

1978 Relegated to the old Third Division for the first time in their history.

1981 Relegated to the old Fourth Division with Alan Ball as player-manager (average crowd 5,863).

1986 Capacity of the Bloomfield Road ground reduced to 13,000.

1987 Owen Oyston becomes chairman.

1992 Promoted to Second Division after a further two-year spell in the basement.

1996 Oyston jailed for rape. Wife Vicky takes over. 40,000-seat football and events stadium proposed for nearby Wyndyke Farm, costing £100m.

1999 Oyston released on parole.

2000 Steve McMahon the 13th manager since 1970; Blackpool in bottom three, crowds below 3,500.

fields.headline: Keegan turns back on Thatcher
fields.standfirst: The England coach was going to call up the Wimbledon left-back - until he saw that elbow
fields.trailText: Ben Thatcher's chances of breaking into England's Euro 2000 squad have suffered a serious setback. Kevin Keegan has quashed his international call-up after the Wimbledon left-back elbowed an opponent in the face.
fields.body:
Ben Thatcher's chances of breaking into England's Euro 2000 squad have suffered a serious setback. Kevin Keegan has quashed his international call-up after the Wimbledon left-back elbowed an opponent in the face.

Keegan had planned to include Thatcher in the England squad for the first time for the friendly at home to Argentina on February 23, even dubbing him the new Stuart Pearce.

The England coach watched Thatcher's assault on Sunderland's Nicky Summerbee during a Premiership game on January 3, then took the rare step of placing the former Under-21 captain's senior debut on hold.

The Football Association used video evidence to charge the 24-year-old Thatcher with misconduct over an incident missed by the match officials, and on Wednesday gave him a two-match suspension.

Now Keegan has added to his misery. "I think Thatcher, until last week, was someone we were looking at. I thought, there is one who probably would be in the next squad and probably will not now.

"There was no pressure from within here [the FA] about that. But that is how I feel just looking at the incident."

However, Keegan added that it should not have any effect in the long term. "I think that what he did would not necessarily jepoardise an England career," he said. "He is one we have looked at because he can play left-sided centre-back and left full-back. He is, in my opinion, the nearest thing we have to Stuart Pearce."

This is not the first time that Thatcher has been in trouble with England. He was sent off playing for the under-21s in Italy in 1997 and was one of five players disciplined over an off-the-field incident on the same trip.

Though Keegan has come down hard on Thatcher, he is prepared to exercise understanding elsewhere: towards David Beckham and his red card in the World Club Championship, for example.

"The way I saw the tackle was that David Beckham turned blind and saw a guy coming who also had his leg raised pretty high.

"You get to the point of no return. I think David Beckham got to that point and then thought 'Oh' and he protected himself."

There was also understanding from Keegan of Michael Owen's struggle to regain his form and fitness. "People were too quick to say that he had got three goals in four games and that he was back after his injury lay-off. In truth he probably needs 20 games, especially after a hamstring injury."

Keegan expects at least another 20 games as coach. He has no intention of quitting, even if England fall some way below his expectation of a place in the Euro 2000 final. "It is my intention not only to see out my contract but hopefully to get another one."

He is particularly relieved that his captain Alan Shearer is back on song, and for that thanks the departure of Ruud Gullit and the arrival of Bobby Robson at Newcastle.

"You want Alan Shearer coming into your England squad fetching a confidence from club level and that was not happening early season at Newcastle because of results and the way the club was going," he said. "But Bobby has realigned him a bit - like with the wheels on your car - and I think Alan needed that. He has gone from what could have been a real nightmare to finding everything he wants at Newcastle."

Finally Keegan, mindful of the lack of midfield creativity in his side, offered this message of hope to young Joe Cole of West Ham United: "Euro 2000 is not too early for him if he continues the way he is going. He has got to make progress and make it rapidly, but Michael Owen did."  England have booked 54 suites in the luxury Balmoral hotel in Spa, near the venue for the Belgian grand prix, to serve as their base during Euro 2000.

fields.headline: Goldbaek grabs Fulham chance
fields.standfirst: Dane drops a division as Bracewell buys more experience
fields.trailText: Fulham have again invested in experience, paying £650,000 to their neighbours Chelsea for the Danish international Bjarne Goldbaek.
fields.body:
Fulham have again invested in experience, paying £650,000 to their neighbours Chelsea for the Danish international Bjarne Goldbaek.

The 31-year-old midfielder, who rejected a drop to the First Division with Nottingham Forest early this season, this time agreed and his move to Craven Cottage hinges only on a medical next week.

Goldbaek has made only four first-team appearances for Chelsea this season after joining from FC Copenhagen for £300,000 early last campaign. His Fulham fee will rise to a maximum £800,000 depending on appearances for Paul Bracewell's side.

#&149; Tony Pulis's departure to Portsmouth leaves Bristol City searching for their fourth manager in 15 months, with three men, Leroy Rosenior, David Burnside and Tony Fawthrop, taking temporary charge.

Pulis had failed to sign the five-year contract offered at Ashton Gate and last night fans were angrily asking whether he had ever intended to stay. His seven months at the club, after an acrimonious departure from Gillingham - with litigation still going on - brought little success and he said at the annual meeting that there were players "overrated, overpriced and overpaid here".

Pulis, who had kept on his home on the south coast from his days with Bournemouth, has signed a 3-year contract at Fratton Park and met the Portsmouth players for the first time yesterday morning in training before today's home game with Wolves.

Despite Portsmouth's relegation fight he said: "With the plans for the new stadium, the support of the players and staff and our excellent supporters I really believe that there is no limit to what we can achieve here." He takes over from Bob McNab, who was in temporary charge after Alan Ball's sacking before Christmas.

#&149; Manchester United were the biggest beneficiaries of the top flight's record turnover of last season. United, Arsenal and Chelsea all exceeded £10m in domestic television payments from the Premier League.

Turnover exceeded £200m for the first time, largely because of the rise in broadcasting income. United received £10.88m in TV money compared with relegated Nottingham Forest's £5m.

#&149; West Ham's captain Steve Lomas escaped a ban but was warned and fined £6,000 by the Football Association yesterday. The midfielder had been charged over comments made on his way off the pitch after the goalless draw at Chelsea on November 7, when he was booked and his team-mate Javier Margas was sent off.

#&149; Ian McCall has left Clydebank to become Morton's manager.

webTitle: Bould aims to avoid an Arsenal curtain call

fields.headline: Bould aims to avoid an Arsenal curtain call
fields.standfirst: Veteran defender faces day of mixed emotions against old club
fields.trailText: Steve Bould is not what you would call the sensitive type, but the veteran defender is worried that today's trip down south may reduce him to tears.
fields.body:
Steve Bould is not what you would call the sensitive type, but the veteran defender is worried that today's trip down south may reduce him to tears.

Not because of the thrashing he expects at the hands of his former Arsenal team-mates, but rather because, on his first game back at Highbury since moving to Sunderland in the summer, he will be presented with a token of Arsenal's gratitude for 11 years' loyal service at the back.

"Of course I will be moved," he said yesterday at Sunderland's windblown training ground, a North Sea gale making practice impossible. "But if I get a great reception at the end, it will mean we have been beaten and I'd find that even harder to swallow."

When Bould moved to Wearside he summed up his task as "stabilising" the club; in other words, ensuring their survival in the Premiership. But in fact life in Sunderland has become so stable that even after a run of four winless games they go to Arsenal in fourth place.

As a result they are bound to show more ambition than they did when the two sides met at the Stadium of Light in August. Then they played for and achieved a goalless draw thanks in no small measure to Bould's immaculate display, and on the whistle embraced one another as if they were lottery winners.

Since then they have lost only one game on Wearside, and in total have conceded the same number of goals at home this season (eight) as the Arsenal defence Bould left behind. But they will be wary too: last time they played at Highbury in the Premiership - in September 1996 - they were reduced to nine men.

"People wonder if the bubble will burst, and I would hope not," Bould said in reply to suggestions that Sunderland were going to ape Middlesbrough's performance of last season. Newly promoted, Bryan Robson's team were fourth in December and relegation material by March.

He added, not unfairly, that Sunderland had had "very little luck of late," meaning the Ben Thatcher elbowing incident at Wimbledon 12 days ago and the farcical last few moments at Tranmere last Saturday.

It is a dozen years since George Graham took Bould to Highbury to form with Tony Adams what, at its peak, Graham believes was the best central defensive partnership in Europe - one admired from the stands by a certain would-be full-back and Arsenal fan named Kevin Phillips, who will lead Sunderland's attack this afternoon. Bould was, said Graham, "always one thought and deed ahead of his opponent".

But Bould's ability to keep on top of the opposition for so long was in the main due to the man who expanded Graham's legacy at Highbury, Arsène Wenger.

When Bould was signed by Peter Reid, the one thing most of Wearside knew about him was that he was old - although at 37 his longevity has surprised even himself. "When I first came to Arsenal I had no inkling my career would last this long," he said. "I owe Arsène Wenger a massive thank-you for that. "It is the whole package that makes him special. I am glad I met him when I did and was able to study the way he works. He is a manager you want to play for, and when I was at Arsenal I didn't meet anybody who disliked the man. The best way I could repay him is by keeping a clean sheet tomorrow."

There have been plenty of those. Reid first tried to sign Bould in 1988 when he was a player-coach at Everton under Colin Harvey. "It was a source of major disappointment to me that I failed, but one I've cured 12 years down the line," the Sunderland manager said. "Before a game I look round the dressing room, see Steve Bould and Thomas Sorensen and think to myself: 'They've got to get past both of them to score.' That gives me a real source of confidence."

Adams, who will be missing this afternoon because of a stress fracture of the right foot, believes Bould won only two international caps because he was regarded, especially by Graham Taylor, as simply a "stopper". He is, as Reid will confirm, much more than that.

"He has this wonderful, calming touch about him," Reid said. "Everyone knows about his last-ditch tackles but to me it is the smoothness with which he plays the ball out of defence that makes him special. It's for those sort of reasons that I made him team captain, although not club captain because he doesn't like the speeches and presentations which go with that."

But Bould will not mind the presentation Arsenal will make to him this afternoon. The only other time he has been back to Highbury was in November for Lee Dixon's testimonial, though he was unable to play because of suspension.

"I have kept in touch with the Arsenal lads, they are good mates and part of my life," he said. "We talk but not always about football, and they are too well-drilled to give much away."

Arsenal will, however, be without Wenger's first-choice attacking pairing of Dennis Bergkamp and Nwankwo Kanu, which may give Sunderland hope.

"They will just have to make do with Suker and Henry then," Bould laughed. "I think Arsenal honestly have a stronger squad now than when I was there. Whoever they play, we will have our hands full."

webTitle: Sheffield MPs demand Wednesday sack Wilson

fields.headline: Sheffield MPs demand Wednesday sack Wilson
fields.standfirst: Blunkett claims that club has 'virtually capitulated' this season
fields.trailText: Ministerial intervention into British sport reached a new level yesterday when David Blunkett headed a group of four Sheffield MPs calling for the immediate dismissal of the Sheffield Wednesday manager Danny Wilson.
fields.body:
Ministerial intervention into British sport reached a new level yesterday when David Blunkett headed a group of four Sheffield MPs calling for the immediate dismissal of the Sheffield Wednesday manager Danny Wilson.

Less than 24 hours after the home secretary, Jack Straw, ended the debate about Mike Tyson by granting the boxer permission to enter the country, the secretary of state for education and employment insisted that relegation-threatened Wednesday must act equally decisively to kick Wilson out of his job.

Even allowing for New Labour's obsession with football, it is unparalleled for a minister to mount such a public display of dissatisfaction on the running of a club.

Blunkett, along with three other Sheffield Labour MPs - Joe Ashton, Clive Betts and Bill Michie - has held talks with the investment group Char terhouse, which paid £15.6m for a 36% stake in Wednesday three years ago, over the company's future role in the club.

"It would seem to us that the club has virtually capitulated this season, started downsizing and is resigned to dropping down into the First Division," said Blunkett, in whose constituency Hillsborough stands.

"That is wrong. They should be trying everything they can to try and turn things around. I believe that this sort of situation would probably have been addressed back in November at most other Premiership clubs. We feel that it is necessary we intervene for two reasons - to lift and motivate the team and to re-engage the supporters.

"The four of us feel that this football club belongs to the fans and to the community and that its future is a matter for that community. The demise of Sheffield Wednesday would greatly affect the local community," he added. "In my opinion it would be best for the club if Danny Wilson was to leave."

Although Blunkett could best be described as an irregular visitor to Wednesday's senior games, Betts and Michie are season-ticket holders and Ashton was one of five Wednesday vice-presidents until he resigned that post yesterday afternoon, declaring it was time to "return to the terraces where I come from and where I can express my opinions in an open way".

Betts was equally forthright in his criticism. "Any other Premiership club would have sacked the manager by now," he said. "He has had some money but he hasn't spent it well. I don't dislike Danny Wilson; I was in favour of his appointment. But you judge people on results."

After the poorest start to a season since the Premiership was formed in 1992 Wednesday are currently four points adrift at the foot of the table, having won two of their 20 league games. However, Wilson remains popular with a high percentage of his club's long-suffering support.

Most criticism has been levelled at a board of directors which has overseen a fall from grace on the pitch and an almost unparalleled descent into debts estimated at £15m.

Last night the row even prompted a split within the Labour Party when Roy Hattersley, the former deputy leader and arguably the club's most celebrated fan, insisted that Wilson should keep his job. "It is not my view that he should be sacked," he said. "I share the MPs' concern but I don't think he should go."

Wilson declared himself to be more concerned with the timing of the MPs' comments rather than their message.

"I just think it is pathetic timing," he said. "I would have thought people of their stature would have known better. If they want to keep blasting their mouths off, I can't do anything about that. I've got broad shoulders."

This afternoon Wednesday play host to their fellow-strugglers Bradford City, a match which could well shape their destiny.

While the dismissal of the 40-year-old Wilson has, for several weeks, been regarded as an inevitability rather than a mere possibility, the beleaguered Wednesday board of directors handed him a third vote of confidence in two months yesterday.

"I am staggered and saddened to learn of the MPs' brutal attack on Danny Wilson and their call for him to be sacked," said the Wednesday secretary Alan Sykes, speaking on behalf of the club's directors. "This shows a total lack of respect for Sheffield Wednesday and for everyone involved with the club."

The chairman Dave Richards said: "My initial reaction is to tell them to get on with the business of politics while we get on with the business of football."

Ashton's final stand

Letter from Joe Ashton MP to Alan Sykes, Secretary, Sheffield Wednesday FC

Dear Alan, Further to our telephone conversation this morning I am formally, by fax, submitting to you my resignation as a vice-president of Sheffield Wednesday. Having been a season-ticket holder for 40 years and a shareholder for 25 years, it is something I do with great regret, especially following the newspaper revelations of a private meeting four Sheffield-area MPs had at the Charterhouse Bank in the City of London yesterday. However, as you know following the heated exchanges I had with the chairman at Stamford Bridge and Villa Park and other games recently, I can no longer support the board in its current policies, either financial or football.

Following the 8-0 defeat at Newcastle I told several members of the board that drastic action was necessary to stay in the Premier League and I have continued to say so ever since. Unfortunately no sign of any action was forthcoming. Consequently, it is better if I return to the terraces where I came from and where I can express my opinions in an open way in a genuine debate on the future of Sheffield Wednesday. I hope you will communicate this letter to the board of directors.

Yours sincerely,

Joe Ashton MP

webTitle: Amateurism still the creed at Hampden Park

fields.headline: Amateurism still the creed at Hampden Park
fields.standfirst: Scots' national stadium in limbo because of over-budget revamp
fields.trailText: The motto of Queen's Park football club, founded in 1867, is ludere causa ludendi - the game for the game's sake. Last week their tiny bunch of members must have been wishing it was still that simple and romantic.
fields.body:
The motto of Queen's Park football club, founded in 1867, is ludere causa ludendi - the game for the game's sake. Last week their tiny bunch of members must have been wishing it was still that simple and romantic.

This week this anachronism of a club, the only amateur side in the senior reaches of the professional game in Britain, called in administrators and effectively put a block on the future of their home, the national stadium Hampden Park.

Queen's have found themselves in a situation which would be impossible to invent. They are owners of a stadium which once held 149,415, and their own attendance record is 95,772 for a cup tie against Rangers in 1930. Last week, thanks to a good run which has carried them to the top of the Third Division, there were 630 people in the 52,000-capacity stadium watching the Jolly Old Spiders, as they are known for their black-and-white hooped jerseys. And they lost to Berwick Rangers.

But that is incidental. As the possessors of Hampden's freehold, Queen's were the vital element in the refurbishment of the ground, which has turned out to be a seriously ill-fated scheme. The building work was going to cost about £50m but there was an overrun of £16m, and the major contractor was part-paid with debentures.

A rescue package worth £4.4m was mounted at the end of last year and it seemed to satisfy the various partners, including the Scottish Football Association, which had agreed to pay £1m rent for the next 20 years, and the new Scottish Executive, working on a major capital project for the first time and with the help of a millennium grant.

That rescue collapsed last week as the administrators arrived to consider the estimated £85,000 shortfall to the £4.4m. It prompted Scotland's sports minister Sam Galbraith, not the most confrontational of politicians, into a rare outburst.

"If this is an attempt by Queen's to bluff more money out of the executive, they have badly miscalculated," he said.

Of course nobody can really allow Hampden Park to rot, but a project which has been on the agenda for 30 years stands as a testimony to three decades of muddled thinking and a complete lack of vision.

The new Hampden has none of the down-at-heel grandeur of the old. The famous roar has become a squeak in a ground completely lacking in atmosphere and which is also badly situated, with no direct road or rail links to support the conference and hospitality businesses needed to sustain its operation.

Hampden will probably be used for only about half a dozen big games a year, and will be by no means full on all those occasions.

Queen's - who appointed a member of their own committee, Austin Reilly, to head the company running the stadium; not the most obvious choice - have been promised £200,000 annually, index-linked for the next 20 years, to run their club, and they will also play on the hallowed turf for nothing.

The political imperatives demand a solution but the cynics will wonder how a new millennium can possibly have been entered with so much baggage still lying around from the 19th century, let alone the 20th.

fields.headline: Fiction
fields.standfirst: Long John Silver by Bjrn Larsson | Everybody Smokes In Hell by John Ridley | The Season Ticket, by Jonathan Tulloch | Walking On Ice by Alba Branca | Frieda and Min by Pamela Jooste
fields.trailText:
Long John Silver
Björn Larsson
(Harvill, £6.99)
Buy it at BOL
fields.body:
Long John Silver
Björn Larsson
(Harvill, £6.99)
Buy it at BOL

The peg-legged pirate- king has washed up on Madagascar. His wife is dead and his parrot, Flint, has croaked his final "Yo-ho-ho and a bottle of rum". What has Long John Silver's life as a Gentleman of Fortune and the British Navy's Most-Wanted amounted to? How will history remember him? Silver wants to set the record straight so he embarks on a voyage into his past. As an act of piracy on fiction's high seas, Larsson carries off his booty with panache. There is swashbuckling adventure, plausible seafaring lore and a characterisation of Silver which owes much to Hemingway's ideal of man testing himself against the elements as well as an instinctive democrat's sense of equality.

Everybody Smokes In Hell
John Ridley
(Bantam, £9.99)
Buy it at BOL

Bring together a bunch of American losers in a LA 24/7 store and watch as the mistakes of a night end in a whole lot of pain and running-scared for all involved. Ridley's plot is simple enough: Paris, a guy who wants to prove to his ex-girlfriend that he amounts to something; Ian, a washed-out stadium-rock hero; Buddy, dragged into a drugs heist; and his soon-to-be-dead friend, Alf, get pulled into a vortex of death, dope and confusion which spills its guts across LA. Ridley knowingly mixes Chandler with Tarantino, but what makes for something better than an exercise in noir is Ridley's language, which crackles with inventiveness like an electric storm over the Hollywood Hills.

The Season Ticket
Jonathan Tulloch
(Cape, £10)

Gerry and Sewell are not bad lads, though Jack Straw would probably put the pair under curfew. They know what they want - a season ticket to Newcastle United - and scheme to realise their dream. Tulloch, a teacher, portrays their odyssey through post-industrial Gateshead estates, alternating the boys' rough, tough speech with a lyrical evocation of a landscape which, though blighted, can be beautiful. Tulloch cannot quite free himself of his didactic aim - writing a story which will convince his year eights that literature is relevant to their lives - but this is a tender book, a Kes for our times, which carefully measures out its humour and its sympathy.

Walking On Ice
Alba Branca
(Pan, £6.99)

Composed of 11 vignettes hung on the realisation that a relationship, a marriage or a casual affair has run its course, Walking On Ice is deeply pessimistic cycle of short stories. From a birthday party at which a six-year-old discovers that her mother is having an affair, to a honeymoon couple's encounter with a fortune teller in Jerusalem, Branca dissects unsettling epiphanies and exposes the fragility of sexual desire and the misplaced expectation of compatibility. Although the descriptions of the glamour, professional fulfillment and material prosperity of her female characters is sometimes clumsy, Branca is brutally honest in her exposure of the myth that love and sex can be managed rationally.

Frieda and Min
Pamela Jooste
(Black Swan, £6.99)
Buy it at BOL

Jooste's second novel deals with apartheid-era South Africa through a teenage friendship built on a sense of alienation. The personal comes before the political and the thrust of her novel - an enduring friendship - has a universal theme, albeit one set in a country warped by the perversion of apartheid. That South Africa's barbarous history can be reflected in the soft focus of the relationship between Frieda, a Jewish girl from a Johannesburg suburb, and Min, whose upbringing in the bush has taught her that skin colour is irrelevant, without seeming trite or superficial, is to be welcomed. Through Frieda and Min, Jooste allows us to slip in through the back door to South Africa's past.

Frieda and Min Pamela Jooste (Black Swan, £6.99) Buy it at BOL Jooste's second novel deals with apartheid-era South Africa through a teenage friendship built on a sense of alienation. The personal comes before the political and the thrust of her novel - an enduring friendship - has a universal theme, albeit one set in a country warped by the perversion of apartheid. That South Africa's barbarous history can be reflected in the soft focus of the relationship between Frieda, a Jewish girl from a Johannesburg suburb, and Min, whose upbringing in the bush has taught her that skin colour is irrelevant, without seeming trite or superficial, is to be welcomed. Through Frieda and Min, Jooste allows us to slip in through the back door to South Africa's past.

fields.headline: Audio
fields.trailText:
The Godfather

Mario Puzo

(Random House, £12.99, 480min)
fields.body:
The Godfather

Mario Puzo

(Random House, £12.99, 480min)

Wheezing through cottonwool-packed chipmunk chops in the film, Brando established the voice of Don Corleone. Joe Mantegna doesn't argue with the older star. He shows proper respect. Like Brando's, his Don speaks in a hoarse upper register as if struggling to talk to a doctor digitally probing for his prostate.

In the wonderful film, the Corleone clan were sympatico . On the page, and in this reading of Puzo's own abridgement, the Corleones can't command the same support, Who cares which of these cut-out hoods and their silly molls ends up on the slab? It's a fine low-life yarn, nonetheless, and the mafia will always fascinate.

Mantegna's delivery is appropriately deliberate, but suffers from some rather brutal interruptions. At least one tape suddenly ends mid-paragraph. Producers, please don't forget to tell listeners the side has ended.

A Year in a Small Country
ed John Gower
(Gomer Press, £8.95)
Buy it at BOL
fields.body:
A Year in a Small Country
ed John Gower
(Gomer Press, £8.95)
Buy it at BOL

Three diarists - farmer Patrick Dobbs, poet Christine Evans and the late William Condry, a Guardian Country Diary regular - take us gently through twelve months in the Welsh countryside, gannets and all. Gomer Press of Llandysul specialises in just this sort of thoughtful, tightly focused book. Sixty-five per cent of Gomer's output is Welsh-language, including children's books; in fact everything they print has a "feel of Welshness". Now that Scotland and Ireland have had their turn, Gomer feels, it's time for Cool Cymru.

fields.headline: Dish out of water
fields.standfirst: Nicholas Lezard  on what women really want
fields.trailText: Nicholas Lezard on what women really want
fields.body:
The Emigré by Joan Brady (Vintage, £6.99)

Buy it at BOL

One night, having forgotten to take my normal minimum sleeping-draught, ie 1 (one) bottle of red wine, I found myself tired but gripped by insomnia, and picked up this book. This would have been around 11.30pm. By about 3.30 in the morning, I'd finished it. This despite a couple of interruptions when I'd put the book down, turned out the light, and then lain awake for a few minutes, wondering what was going to happen next (in the book that is), turned the light on again and carried on.

So, then, clearly a contender for the coveted Paperback of the Week award; but a deserving contender? Does the fact that a book is unputdownable make it better than one that isn't? There are people, after all, who have experienced the same thing with a John Grisham. I am one of them. And just think of the number of indisputably great works, from every epoch of creative endeavour, that you could have by your bedside as a kind of infallible literary Mogadon. (From the catalogue of ships in The Iliad to, erm, let's be honest here, pretty much anything by Salman Rushdie.)

But just as you know why a book can be both dreck and a page-turner at the same time, so you can allow for a book with deeply suspicious qualities to be praiseworthy nevertheless. Okay, so its very readability makes it suspect; so does the fact that Joan Brady is the kind of female novelist whom male critics like (she was the first woman to win the Whitbread outright); and so, in this novel, does her subject matter.

Which here is the pianist Nikolas Strakhan, the wild and amoral son of a Russian nobleman. Nikolas steals first his musical gift from his piano teacher, then from his father. He runs away and embarks on a career as, alternately, a con-man, a fleecer of the wealthiest and best- connected woman in Britain apart from the Queen, a pianist, blindfold exhibition chess player, drug-smuggler, money-launderer - you name it, especially if it's dodgy. It should also be added that everywhere he goes he sweeps women right off their feet and onto their backs.

It is intriguing that here, finally, after so many female characters who are nothing more than the walking wet dreams of their male inventors, we finally have a fantasy from the other side, and one, moreover, which isn't witlessly formulaic. (You could tell, blind, that Nikolas is a woman's creation and not a man's, as he is not only very capable of genuine love, but does not seem to be too hung up on facial appearances.)

This is an almost camp, sprawling story, one that moves from London to Brighton to Switzerland to Illinois to Paris to . . . oh, anywhere that an emigré pianist con-man might end up. (His character allows Brady to include a catalogue of snobberies in the novel, which she obviously enjoys wickedly. For example: "we were drinking Cointreau out of jade saki cups that she said Nikolas had given her while he was working on the designs for her house." Did I mention that he is also a preternaturally gifted interior designer?)

So this, then, is the answer to Freud's despairing question about what it is women want. This is, of course, a fantasy - rich, intelligent and entertaining; the difference between men's and women's fantasies being (I've checked up on this) that women know they're fantasies. Besides, I've always wanted an alternative explanation for the Brighton bombing of 1984, which this book delivers.

fields.headline: Blair's McChancers
fields.standfirst: Andrew Marr enjoys Tom Nairn's blast at New Labour, After Britain
fields.trailText: Andrew Marr enjoys Tom Nairn's blast at New Labour, After Britain
fields.body:
After Britain: New Labour and the Return of Scotland
Tom Nairn
Granta, £15.99, 305pp
Buy it at BOL

Everything is new, and fine and dandy, in this New Britain of New Labour. We are reborn as a modern people, brisk and self-sure. We have forgotten socialism, we have forgotten the Tories. New? We are "new" squared. So wouldn't it be a joke, World History at her most satirical, if Britain was actually in her very last death-throes, and the person who noticed it most clearly was an old Marxist theoretician?

How can we describe Tom Nairn? The sly Caledonian shaman of the New Left? The premature prophet, who famously described "The Break-up of Britain", though a little early, in the Seventies? The famous enemy of the House of Windsor? The man who said Scotland would only be free when the last Presbyterian minister was strangled with the last copy of the Sunday Post? Whatever, Nairn is certainly a beast seen as fleetingly in these northern islands as the Arctic char or the wild cat - a genuine native intellectual.

This is, at one level, an old-fashioned book of theoretical argument, a collection of essays, which occasionally overlap, about the collapse of the British state. His theme can be summarised, in his own words, when he turns to the question of whether devolution is a slippery slope: "All slopes are now slippery, in fact. The Constitution of old England-Britain once stood like a mighty dam, preserving its subjects from such a fate; nowadays, leaking on all sides, it merely guides them to the appropriate slope or exit. Blairism has reformed just enough to destabilise everything... As if panicked by this realisation, his government has then begun to run round in circles groaning that enough is enough."

Nairn is devastatingly critical of New Labour. His most effective essay swings around the fulcrum of a merciless comparison of the current government and the Hapsburgs' Austro-Hungarian empire just before the first world war. New Labour is merely last-gasp Britishness, and its curious court of smirking promoters and bullies, with their theories of the third way, can be explained as a substitute for the old busted British ruling class - "a permanent-seeming elite which makes the end-time bearable". For them, devolution is merely an event, not a process. And they are wrong.

The place he stands upon to make these attacks is Scottish nationalism, at times curiously sentimental. Later in the book, he argues entirely persuasively that the Edinburgh Parliament will be forced to grapple with a proper Scottish constitution and that, far from being a gift from Tony Blair to Scotland, home rule has been wrested by the Scots from a Westminster state in crisis.

Nairn marshalls many of the best of contemporary Scottish thinkers, from the poet Douglas Dunn to the journalist Ian Bell, on his side. And he mows down the enemy. His prose is craggy and compacted and full of allusive wit, but it has, paragraph after paragraph, exhilarating long views, breathtaking sudden vistas of clear-sightedness which let you see for miles. He is sharply critical of those who claim that Scotland's revived sense of herself is in any way sinister; and wickedly funny about the "McChancers" who have sallied south to prosper. ("I laughed till it hurt" suddenly meant something to this expatriate reviewer.)

Those of us, a diminishing crowd, who do feel British, will be disturbed by him. He discards too sweepingly and perhaps too cruelly the New Labour idea of reviving Britain around a liberal agenda, though I concede that this may be a doomed project. He is too quick also to chuck aside dual or multiple identities as depending upon "a simultaneous denial or curtailment of democracy". This may be historically true but is wrong now. He is insufficiently critical of the European road to modernity. Publishers' deadlines mean that he sounds too gloomy about the Irish Peace Process and too perky about the SNP's electoral performance. Things are not quite so "given" as he implies.

But on what matters most Nairn is in vintage form, shaking and sharp. He sees the coming English parliament clearly. His descriptions of New Labour are uncomfortably acute, particularly in a month when voting reform has been mugged and the cosy fix of Lords "reform" is leaking from another direction.

It is not a book many politicians will read, though I suspect Gordon Brown will, late at night, be mouthing silent responses page by page. But they ought to. If New Labour fails it will be for reasons lucidly described here.

After Britain concludes with an epilogue about the rain-soaked first day of voting for the new Scottish Parliament, during which Nairn visits a dying friend, a staunch Unionist and Tory woman from Fife whom he describes as "like having a small, bullying angel on one's side". It is a dense, brilliant piece of writing which should be given to every school-leaver in the new Scotland to study and understand.

This is, in short, the most intelligent book on the future of our states. Tom Nairn dedicates it to Anthony Barnett, the dauntless John the Baptist of Britain's democratic revolution, who has been so promptly denied by New Labour (party motto: "Next Time"). And it is quite a gift.

 Andrew Marr's The Day Britain Died, a BBC series and book, appears later this month.

fields.headline: Backlash against the brand
fields.standfirst: Hate the firm - buy its products.  Andy Beckett looks at the trademarks that rule the world
fields.trailText: Hate the firm - buy its products. Andy Beckett looks at the trademarks that rule the world
fields.body:
No Logo by Naomi Klein 490pp, Flamingo, £14.99

Two years ago, in a cash-strapped state school in Evans, Georgia, someone came up with an adventurous fundraising notion. One day in late March, when spring was bright and rising across the American South, the school would hold an official Coke Day. All the pupils would wear Coca-Cola T-shirts. They would sit in seminars given by Coca-Cola executives. Afterwards, against the pines and blue sky, the teenagers would pose for photographs, in a formation that breezily spelled out their benefactor's logo. For these services to modern capitalism, the school would receive $500.

Coke Day came. The corporation swamped the campus. Except for one tiny corner: a single student, one of the older ones called Mike Cameron, came to school in a Pepsi T-shirt. He was immediately suspended. "I know it sounds bad," said the school principal afterwards. "But we had the regional president here and people [from Coca-Cola] flew in from Atlanta to do us the honour . . .".

It is not recorded here whether the school ever got any money. But the twin themes of this sharp and very timely book - that business is growing ever more ambitious and ubiquitous, and so are the revolts against it - are illustrated with characteristic neatness. Naomi Klein, who is a 29-year-old Canadian journalist, wants, in summary, to explain to us critically how our current, market-driven world of multimedia mergers and malls and sponsors' tentacles came into being, and how, for those inclined, this frantic and unfeeling state of affairs might be challenged. And she intends to do all this at a brave moment - just when most writing about business has turned breathless and uncritical. Marx and Orwell at least managed to catch capitalism at unsteady moments; Klein has to compete with e-commerce and all-absorbing conglomerates and what seems like the longest boom for decades, perhaps even centuries. A quick glance at the spine of this book suggests the scale of her task: Klein's publisher is owned by Rupert Murdoch.

Sensibly, she does not attempt straight polemic. Instead, the book begins obliquely, almost like a memoir, with a lingering gaze out of the windows of her Toronto apartment. Klein describes the old brick warehouses, the faded commercial murals, the "smokestacks holding their breath" across the city's former garment-making district. She lets a little nostalgia for the industrial past, for the stable jobs and striving immigrants and labour struggles, soften her focus. She depicts her own building, owned by an old local coatmaker, full of writers and artists, untouched by the area's encroaching gentrification, as a kind of oasis, a hold-out against the new billboards and apartment blocks crowding round. And then, just as your objections start to form, Klein's gaze suddenly hardens. Her little local utopia, she reveals, is built on cheap labour: her landlord began taking tenants when he moved his coat production to Indonesia.

This book is a vast mesh of such connections. In Canada and America and Britain, using corporate histories and her own investigations and sly interviews with company directors, Klein draws a picture of unprecedented materialism. She meets a seven-year-old boy who marks his homework with Nike symbols instead of ticks. She cites the successful teenage TV show Dawson's Creek, which is sponsored by the clothing range J. Crew, where characters appear in nautical settings just like the brand's advertisements, and say lines such as "He looks like he stepped out of a J. Crew catalog". She examines the conversion of Michael Jordan, the former basketball star, into a celebrity endorser of sports goods; he is now so powerful that he, in turn, has his own "JORDAN" brand, and a chain of "retail concept shops", and receives commercial endorsements from other retired sportsmen.

A couple of chapters in, your mind is already reeling. Klein can write - she favours informality and crispness over jargon, and her asides can be droll ("The eternal urge for escape has never enjoyed such niche marketing"). But, like many North American journalists, she does sometimes pile up her facts like skyscrapers. There are graphs here, and pie charts, and relentless climbing lines showing store numbers at Wal-Mart and revenues at Starbuck's. At first, this book feels a bit like Backlash , Susan Faludi's vast study of the reaction against feminism: convincing, and necessary, yet so dense with evidence and thought that the sheer effort and authorial ambition make more of an impression than the arguments.

These, once extracted from all the bustle, are quite clear and fresh. The most publicly successful modern businesses, Klein writes, are those that have abandoned making things in favour of making images. Clothing empires like Nike and Tommy Hilfiger are her purest examples: by having all their manufacturing done abroad, in factories they do not own, but belong instead to near-anonymous sub-contractors and sub-sub-contractors, such conglomerates can save hugely on labour costs. Yet, more importantly perhaps, this arrangement - which selling over the internet will most likely consolidate - leaves these companies free to concentrate on more pleasant and undefined tasks, like "building the brand", and dreaming up idealistic slogans, and thinking of new products to put their logo on, between cups of coffee, as the air-conditioning murmurs.

And while headquarters, and the rest of these corporations' employees in the rich world, approach business as a sort of conceptual game - the dream, perhaps, of capitalists down the ages -their distant grey sheds in the Far East and Central America offer work boiled down to a sort of brutal essence. Halfway through the book, Klein makes a trip to the Cavite Export Processing Zone in the Philippines.

Her reportage is calm but unsparing. Outside the walls and checkpoints of the factory compound, she notes the noise and decay and overcrowding of the surrounding town. Inside, she slips between windowless, identical halls, piled high with training shoes, entirely unmarked by the names of the companies being supplied. In such closed-off places across the world, where taxes and unions and regulations and the attentions of local politicians barely reach at all, 27 million people are currently at work, estimates the International Labour Organization. In Cavite, Klein meets some of them; in their workplaces, they undramatically tell her, the ventilation is so poor that the night-time condensation gives them pneumonia.

Klein holds her temper. Her style is more Noam Chomsky than John Pilger: she condemns by quotation and accumulation, not finger-pointing. What is more, she devotes substantial sections here to the shortcomings of the Left in the face of this new economic order. She is particularly scolding about Political Correctness and the identity-fixated leftwing politics of the Eighties and early Nineties. She and many others were too busy "fighting about women's studies and the latest backlash book", she says, to notice the advertisements going up inside toilet cubicles, the professors growing cripplingly deferential towards research-funding corporations, the whole stealthy creep of private-sector influence into what had once been the public realm.

Even worse - and this is a bitterly perceptive insight - identity politics ultimately aided the conglomerates. Ethnic and gender categories, long fought for, were almost instantly converted into target markets during the mid-Nineties. Watch MTV or go to Benetton; their diversity of musicians and models, which once seemed pretty admirable, now looks like nothing more than globalised sales talk.

In the last third of the book, Klein looks for more genuine resistance to the dominant money-making order. She uncovers billboard vandals, subversive customisers of advertisements, internet-linked activists of every leftish persuasion. Some seem cartoonish: like Agent Blueberry of the Biotic Baking Brigade, who specialises in throwing pies at tycoons and economists ("To their lies, we respond with pies"). Others appear as smoothly international as their targets: Klein quotes dispatches from Reclaim The Streets, the impromptu barricaders of traffic-choked cities, sent out from actions in Tel Aviv and Darwin.

Such diverse forces, she argues, are beginning to turn the power of the corporations back on themselves. The more that Shell, say, widens its operations and seeks to fix its brand in the world's consciousness, the more it becomes vulnerable to criticisms and revelations, from any of its far-flung territories, which can loom like chilly shadows behind its every bright billboard and logo. The wall of euphemism between the grey sheds and the grand corporate mission statements can be more and more damagingly breached. Klein excitedly lists - her usual distance disappearing somewhat - all the recently-publicised embarrassments: Shell's forced retreat from sinking the Brent Spar oil platform at sea; the squall over the death of Ken Saro-Wiwa, the activist who opposed Shell's oil extraction in Nigeria; and "Nike's sweatshop scandals", which "have been the subject of over 1,500 news articles and opinion columns".

The trouble is, most people seem to keep buying such companies' products regardless. They may hear about these cruelties, they may disapprove of them, but, with a pragmatism perhaps related to Klein's preparedness to publish with Murdoch, they may feel in the end that they have little choice. Her suggested counters to this vicious circle, which range from "raising the bar" for corporate standards by better regulation to "building a resistance" through public stunts and the internet, feel slightly automatic. Maybe the value of this book lies more in its diagnosis than its cures. There aren't too many perfect formulas for social justice in Orwell, either.

Naomi Klein, who is a 29-year-old Canadian journalist, wants, in summary, to explain to us critically how our current, market-driven world of multimedia mergers and malls and sponsors' tentacles came into being, and how, for those inclined, this frantic and unfeeling state of affairs might be challenged. And she intends to do all this at a brave moment - just when most writing about business has turned breathless and uncritical. Marx and Orwell at least managed to catch capitalism at unsteady moments; Klein has to compete with e-commerce and all-absorbing conglomerates and what seems like the longest boom for decades, perhaps even centuries. A quick glance at the spine of this book suggests the scale of her task: Klein's publisher is owned by Rupert Murdoch. Sensibly, she does not attempt straight polemic. Instead, the book begins obliquely, almost like a memoir, with a lingering gaze out of the windows of her Toronto apartment. Klein describes the old brick warehouses, the faded commercial murals, the "smokestacks holding their breath" across the city's former garment-making district. She lets a little nostalgia for the industrial past, for the stable jobs and striving immigrants and labour struggles, soften her focus. She depicts her own building, owned by an old local coatmaker, full of writers and artists, untouched by the area's encroaching gentrification, as a kind of oasis, a hold-out against the new billboards and apartment blocks crowding round. And then, just as your objections start to form, Klein's gaze suddenly hardens. Her little local utopia, she reveals, is built on cheap labour: her landlord began taking tenants when he moved his coat production to Indonesia. This book is a vast mesh of such connections. In Canada and America and Britain, using corporate histories and her own investigations and sly interviews with company directors, Klein draws a picture of unprecedented materialism. She meets a seven-year-old boy who marks his homework with Nike symbols instead of ticks. She cites the successful teenage TV show Dawson's Creek, which is sponsored by the clothing range J. Crew, where characters appear in nautical settings just like the brand's advertisements, and say lines such as "He looks like he stepped out of a J. Crew catalog". She examines the conversion of Michael Jordan, the former basketball star, into a celebrity endorser of sports goods; he is now so powerful that he, in turn, has his own "JORDAN" brand, and a chain of "retail concept shops", and receives commercial endorsements from other retired sportsmen. A couple of chapters in, your mind is already reeling. Klein can write - she favours informality and crispness over jargon, and her asides can be droll ("The eternal urge for escape has never enjoyed such niche marketing"). But, like many North American journalists, she does sometimes pile up her facts like skyscrapers. There are graphs here, and pie charts, and relentless climbing lines showing store numbers at Wal-Mart and revenues at Starbuck's. At first, this book feels a bit like Backlash , Susan Faludi's vast study of the reaction against feminism: convincing, and necessary, yet so dense with evidence and thought that the sheer effort and authorial ambition make more of an impression than the arguments. These, once extracted from all the bustle, are quite clear and fresh. The most publicly successful modern businesses, Klein writes, are those that have abandoned making things in favour of making images. Clothing empires like Nike and Tommy Hilfiger are her purest examples: by having all their manufacturing done abroad, in factories they do not own, but belong instead to near-anonymous sub-contractors and sub-sub-contractors, such conglomerates can save hugely on labour costs. Yet, more importantly perhaps, this arrangement - which selling over the internet will most likely consolidate - leaves these companies free to concentrate on more pleasant and undefined tasks, like "building the brand", and dreaming up idealistic slogans, and thinking of new products to put their logo on, between cups of coffee, as the air-conditioning murmurs. And while headquarters, and the rest of these corporations' employees in the rich world, approach business as a sort of conceptual game - the dream, perhaps, of capitalists down the ages -their distant grey sheds in the Far East and Central America offer work boiled down to a sort of brutal essence. Halfway through the book, Klein makes a trip to the Cavite Export Processing Zone in the Philippines. Her reportage is calm but unsparing. Outside the walls and checkpoints of the factory compound, she notes the noise and decay and overcrowding of the surrounding town. Inside, she slips between windowless, identical halls, piled high with training shoes, entirely unmarked by the names of the companies being supplied. In such closed-off places across the world, where taxes and unions and regulations and the attentions of local politicians barely reach at all, 27 million people are currently at work, estimates the International Labour Organization. In Cavite, Klein meets some of them; in their workplaces, they undramatically tell her, the ventilation is so poor that the night-time condensation gives them pneumonia. Klein holds her temper. Her style is more Noam Chomsky than John Pilger: she condemns by quotation and accumulation, not finger-pointing. What is more, she devotes substantial sections here to the shortcomings of the Left in the face of this new economic order. She is particularly scolding about Political Correctness and the identity-fixated leftwing politics of the Eighties and early Nineties. She and many others were too busy "fighting about women's studies and the latest backlash book", she says, to notice the advertisements going up inside toilet cubicles, the professors growing cripplingly deferential towards research-funding corporations, the whole stealthy creep of private-sector influence into what had once been the public realm. Even worse - and this is a bitterly perceptive insight - identity politics ultimately aided the conglomerates. Ethnic and gender categories, long fought for, were almost instantly converted into target markets during the mid-Nineties. Watch MTV or go to Benetton; their diversity of musicians and models, which once seemed pretty admirable, now looks like nothing more than globalised sales talk. In the last third of the book, Klein looks for more genuine resistance to the dominant money-making order. She uncovers billboard vandals, subversive customisers of advertisements, internet-linked activists of every leftish persuasion. Some seem cartoonish: like Agent Blueberry of the Biotic Baking Brigade, who specialises in throwing pies at tycoons and economists ("To their lies, we respond with pies"). Others appear as smoothly international as their targets: Klein quotes dispatches from Reclaim The Streets, the impromptu barricaders of traffic-choked cities, sent out from actions in Tel Aviv and Darwin. Such diverse forces, she argues, are beginning to turn the power of the corporations back on themselves. The more that Shell, say, widens its operations and seeks to fix its brand in the world's consciousness, the more it becomes vulnerable to criticisms and revelations, from any of its far-flung territories, which can loom like chilly shadows behind its every bright billboard and logo. The wall of euphemism between the grey sheds and the grand corporate mission statements can be more and more damagingly breached. Klein excitedly lists - her usual distance disappearing somewhat - all the recently-publicised embarrassments: Shell's forced retreat from sinking the Brent Spar oil platform at sea; the squall over the death of Ken Saro-Wiwa, the activist who opposed Shell's oil extraction in Nigeria; and "Nike's sweatshop scandals", which "have been the subject of over 1,500 news articles and opinion columns". The trouble is, most people seem to keep buying such companies' products regardless. They may hear about these cruelties, they may disapprove of them, but, with a pragmatism perhaps related to Klein's preparedness to publish with Murdoch, they may feel in the end that they have little choice. Her suggested counters to this vicious circle, which range from "raising the bar" for corporate standards by better regulation to "building a resistance" through public stunts and the internet, feel slightly automatic. Maybe the value of this book lies more in its diagnosis than its cures. There aren't too many perfect formulas for social justice in Orwell, either.

fields.headline: Downwind of John Wayne
fields.standfirst: Aliens like it, but who else, wonders  Stephen Amidon, loves Nevada
fields.trailText: Aliens like it, but who else, wonders Stephen Amidon, loves Nevada
fields.body:
In Nevada: The Land, The People, God, and Chance
David Thomson
Little, Brown, £20, 330pp
Buy it at BOL

Canaries on the Rim: Living Downwind in the West
Chip Ward
Verso, £20, 228pp

In 1954, John Wayne travelled to the empty desert of the Utah/Nevada border to portray Genghis Khan in the hilariously awful costume drama, The Conqueror. Because the heady paranoia of the Cold War was in full bloom, no one seemed very concerned that the location was just downwind from the notorious atomic bomb test site of Yucca Flat. Indeed, director Dick Powell was so enamoured of the sand's vibrant hue that he ordered sixty tons of it shipped back to Hollywood for interior shots.

Within the next few decades, that infected sand would take a toll worthy of the terrible Khan himself - 91 of the 220 people working on the picture developed cancer, half of them dying of it, including Powell, star Susan Hayward and Wayne himself.

This is just one of the trenchant anecdotes that illuminate David Thomson's In Nevada, an engaging if mercurial journey through America's weirdest state. Thomson, a brilliant film commentator, is drawn to Nevada as one might be to the work of Peckinpah or Goddard. "Nevada," he explains, "is on the edge, on the wire, off to one side, in the empty quarter... America has used Nevada as a testing ground, not just for weapons and their destructiveness but also for new social ideas, and their explosiveness."

This cultural volatility expresses itself in two seemingly diverse domains: weapons testing and gambling. Ever since the advent of the Cold War, America has used Nevada as a radioactive scratch pad in its quest to build the perfect bomb, creating an unpredictable toxic legacy for the state's often voiceless inhabitants.

The thinking, Thomson suggests, has always been that even if the fallout proved hazardous, the odds were good that the scant and idiosyncratic locals - known as "downwinders" - wouldn't be able to raise much of a stink. The result has not simply been a heritage of lingering death and disease, but also one of social upheaval that has created such phenomena as easy divorce, legalised prostitution, New Age desert bacchanalia and a road officially named The Extra-Terrestrial Highway.

It has also enabled Las Vegas. Thomson's account is at its best when describing how America's fastest growing city has served as a sort of national id, where the dark side of capitalism and celebrity culture are provided rare - but perhaps essential - airings. Only in Las Vegas could a gangster like Bugsy Siegel become a town father, while the mainstream entertainers Frank Sinatra, Dean Martin and Sammy Davis Jr. could play at being gangsters with their pathetic Rat Pack incarnation. And it was to Las Vegas, after all, that Howard Hughes travelled to get seriously weird, cultivating his long fingernails, drug habit and paranoia atop the casino he bought for his hermitage.

While Thomson's account is always entertaining and insightful, you come away wishing his book was less episodic, that he'd found some sort of unifying narrative behind this strangest patch of American soil. That said, this remains one of the best recent books about a place where "the government launched a large, irreversible gamble with the fate of many people, without even telling the people that they were players".

For an eyewitness account of what it is like to be one of those punters in the government's nuclear/ biological/ chemical sweepstakes, it would be hard to find a better book than Chip Ward's Canaries on the Rim. Ward, seeking the solace and redemption the West has always promised, moved his growing family to the rim of the Great Basin Desert on the Utah/Nevada border in the 1970s. Taking a job as the local mobile librarian, he at first thought he'd found a paradise where salt-of-the-earth neighbours looked after each other in a subtly beautiful desert environment.

The truth, however, soon emerged. Ward's community was in fact "the most extensive environmental sacrifice zone in the nation", not only downwind from countless nuclear weapon tests but also the site of ageing munitions dumps and several incinerators used to "clean-up" America's degrading chemical weapons arsenal. Ward and his neighbours were like canaries loosed from the coal mine into a far more hazardous open air. The author was transformed from a private citizen into a public campaigner dealing with such Orwellian topics as "bioaccumulation", "agent migration" and "endocrine disruptors".

While it is hard to forget his image of locals recounting how they frolicked as children in the bright falling ash after hydrogen bomb tests, most terrifying is his account of the filthy magnesium processing plant whose owner is using his profits to build a Long Island mansion of such grotesque proportions that it offends even the mega-rich of the Hamptons. Although Ward's prose can be a bit rote at times, there is no denying the power of his story and his anger as he details how "our environment was sacrificed to protect our way of life".

 Stephen Amidon's novel, The New City, is published next month by Doubleday.

fields.headline: Jaw wars
fields.standfirst: Has travel writing run out of puff?  Giles Foden finds Edward Marriott's Wild Shore is a story with teeth to it
fields.trailText: Has travel writing run out of puff? Giles Foden finds Edward Marriott's Wild Shore is a story with teeth to it
fields.body:
Wild Shore: Life and Death with Nicaragua's Last Shark Hunters
Edward Marriott
Picador, £16.99, 283pp
Buy it at BOL

It is commonplace to remark that the boom in travel-writing started in the 1980s - with the emergence of writers like Bruce Chatwin, Redmond O'Hanlon and Jonathan Raban - and ended with the departure from Granta in 1995 of an editor who placed himself at the centre of that boom, Bill Buford.

These writers - along with three who had been longer at the game, Paul Theroux, Norman Lewis and Colin Thubron - drew considerably on the techniques of the novel for their power. In his introduction to Granta's seminal Travel issue of 1983, Buford praised his writers for "sheer glee of storytelling... a narrative eloquence that situates them, with wonderful ambiguity, somewhere between fiction and fact".

It is true that things have moved on; there is a sense of exhaustion about travel writing - about its casualness, its fancifulness, its sheer lack of depth. As the current editor of Granta, Ian Jack, pointed out in a recent essay for Condé Nast Traveller magazine: "The focus of curiosity has moved from 'I wonder what Ruritania is like'... towards the question of why Ruritania came to be like it is".

Narrative history, in other words (in forms as different as Dava Sobel's Longitude and Antony Beevor's Stalingrad, both bestsellers), is the new boom. But the real point is that the edges of all genres are blurring. The old advice for tyro authors used to be: "make sure you know what type of book you want to write". Booksellers (so the insulting wisdom went) would then know where to place it in the shop. These days, however, booksellers know better than anyone that books which alter our perspective on a genre can do better than ones which don't. What these mixed-marriage books do, when they work, is actually expand the market, creating readerships that didn't previously exist.

It is in this context that Edward Marriott brings us Wild Shore, his stirring, capacious tale of Nicaraguan shark-hunters. It still has the wandering, slightly untrustworthy narrator of those Granta romps of old, but adds to it a wealth of fascinating information about the British pirates and imperialists of the 17th and 18th centuries - including a callow, malarial Horatio Nelson.

At that stage, Marriott tells us, Nicaragua was being fought over by the British and Spanish, with the United States too beginning to lick its lips. In 1780, the future hero of Trafalgar gathered his forces and set off to conquer the country. It did not go well. One of his men was taken by a jaguar, another bitten on the face by a tree-snake. " 'He was found dead,' Nelson's physician recorded, 'with all the symptoms of putrefaction; a yellowness of body; and the eye, near to which he was bitten, all dissolved.' "

For mestizos - Nicaraguans of mixed Spanish and Native American extraction - Nelson is just one of the pirates, and the failure of his expedition (only eight out of an original 200 survived), a source of national pride. The Spanish garrison was eventually able to stroll back into the citadel unhindered - the same one in which, two centuries later, the Sandinistas kept captured Contra guerrillas. It is in such links that Marriott's approach excels: as the manicured lawns of El Castillo today give up the rough secrets of the past, you realise how how much the travel writer has learned from the historian.

Northeast of El Castillo, on Nicaragua's Atlantic coast, lies the starting-point for Marriott's journey proper: the rusty town of Bluefields. Settled by British pirates in the 1630s, it has ever since been a melting pot for Creole, Black Carib and mestizo culture. From there, after a spell with dugout fishermen on the ocean, he undertakes a Heart of Darkness-style journey to the interior: on a coconut barge up the San Juan river to Lake Nicaragua. Marriott hopes (though the narrative hook is not so very barbed as to be off putting) to track the passage of Carcharhinus leucas, the bull-shark.

This "most wilful and aggressive of tropical sharks", hunted on an industrial scale during the Somoza dictatorship, is Marriott's ostensible quarry. Like all such subjects (cf Samantha Weinberg's recent book about the coelacanth), it has the requisite ecological peculiarity: "Like no other shark, it possessed the ability to cross from salt- to freshwater, hunting far upriver to the lake beyond, cruising the coast, the bar mouth and the San Juan's brackish lower stretches."

And, for local inhabitants, totemic value. "The coastal and river people hunted the shark for its fins and for its oil, feared it and revered it; every village had had family taken in its jaws. It was shark where shark should not be - in freshwater, on human territory."

In fact, the question of territory is the theme that runs throughout this exciting, but thoughtful book, giving it coherence and allowing Marriott to associate - though always with judgment and perspective - depredations of varying orders: the imperialists and pirates of old, Cold War support for both Sandinistas and Contras, the brutal lives of ordinary people today, and (not least) the ever diminishing stock of bull-sharks, preyed on by fishermen and pesticides alike.
