fields.headline: Best in the language
fields.standfirst: On Monday the TS Eliot Memorial Prize will be presented by Valerie Eliot to the finest poet published in English last year. Robert Potts profiles CK Williams, one of the least-known contenders. Plus his rivals for the coveted award
fields.trailText: On Monday the TS Eliot Memorial Prize will be presented by Valerie Eliot to the finest poet published in English last year. Robert Potts profiles CK Williams, one of the least-known contenders. Plus his rivals for the coveted award
fields.body:
Repair
CK Williams
Bloodaxe, £7.95, 70pp
Buy it at BOL

CK Williams writes bigger books than most poets. It is not that they are longer than anyone else's, nor that they are epics covering eras and epochs. They are bigger in format; wider, taller books. This is to accommodate a far longer line than most poets employ; a Whitmanesque line that Williams has made very much his own.

In these extended, apparently discursive lines, he has the elbow-room to try out this word or that, and then sometimes reject both for another; he has the space to take an impression and then revise it, or to describe a reassessment, whether contemporaneous or retrospective, of an event or emotion. The work of this 63-year-old American, who lives in Paris when he is not teaching creative writing at Princeton, is almost an enactment of Wallace Stevens's idea of "the poem of the mind in the act of finding / what will suffice".

He has been published in this country by the Northern publisher Bloodaxe, who have not only had the good judgment to take on his work, but the diligence to present it properly. His latest volume, Repair, is one of ten collections short-listed for the prestigious T S Eliot Prize, and must be a strong contender. Meditating on hurt and loss, both personal and political or historical, the volume finds ways towards reconciliation, recovery, healing.

The opening poem recalls the experience of taking an ice pick (of the domestic variety) to a large block of ice, and its images of fissuring and splintering run through the volume. The memory is real, dating back to a job Williams had as a boy, but by the time the poet has himself finished chipping and tapping at it, it might stand for the act of memory, or the divided self, or even his own poetic process: "Imagine how even if it shattered and began to liquefy / the hope would still remain that if you quickly gathered up the slithery, perversely skittish chips, / they might be refrozen and the mass reconstitute, with precious little of its brilliance lost, / just this lucent shimmer on the rough raised grain of the water-rotten floor, / just this single drop, as sweet and warm as blood, evaporating on your tongue."

What Williams does, in his apparently langorous yet tensely focused poems, is to enact processes as much as he describes them. Repair, as much as any of the work he has produced, is about the excavation of memories, the stripping down of his subjects to approach the essence of an event or an emotion, and in doing so to build on it and benefit from it.

"House" is almost like a Rachel Whiteread sculpture in its description of this endeavour, with a building as a metaphor for the constructed self, and its tenderness towards the conflicting demands of that self: "Down under all to the ancient errors, indolence, envy, pretension, the frailties as though in the gene; / down to where consciousness cries 'Make me new', but pleads as pitiably 'Cherish me as I was.' "

Some of the poems in Repair deal with very old wounds indeed, such as "After Auschwitz" (much of the finished volume was written during a seven-month stay in Germany). As Williams remarked when I interviewed him, "you can't be a Jew in the 20th century without what happened being part of your intimate experience".

His Jewishness is mentioned in the other big political poem of the volume, "King", about Martin Luther King's funeral, and the harassment by the police of a black friend who was on his way to meet Williams that day: the racial divide had become unbridgeable, and the poem contains the terse reported line, "And please, please don't tell me again you can understand because you're a Jew."

The poem has taken thirty years to write faithfully, and is a sad piece because it suggests that resolution of the race problem in America has not been reached in the intervening years. "Isn't that what we're supposed to do in our country; / aren't we given to believe our wounds will heal, our scars fade, our insults be redeemed?" Williams asks, impotently in the poem. Yet, as he tells me, "things have moved on, but race still matters; things haven't been resolved as much as we assumed they would be by now, when we were in the 1960s and passionately believed we were 'on the way'. In some ways, we've learned that things can get worse."

Repair is a spiritual book, though not a religious one. Williams left Judaism "the day after my Bar Mitzvah", losing "not just a religion but a community". He wrestled with the question of what a relationship with God might be for years afterwards. "It's only recently that I was willing to take on the identity of an atheist," he remarks. "Before I was a shilly-shallying agnostic. Maybe this is part of my release into something else." Interestingly, the poet he was reading most while writing Repair was George Herbert, who was unparalleled as a poet of religious doubt until Hopkins and Geoffrey Hill.

Herbert's influence is discernible at times, in the restless tussling of the poetry; but the two poets agonise to very different theological conclusions. "Herbert's is relentless. He's really the hardest person on himself who ever lived," Williams remarks, charmingly unaware that he is also hard on himself - rigorous, scrupulous, moral.

He is not as austere as that description suggests, however. Passionate, engaged, alert, always watching people, he is as attuned to joy, amusement and love as he is to undercurrents of pain, or the tragedies and comedies of shame and embarrassment. There's even an epiphanic little poem about farting near the end.

Autobiography of Red
Anne Carson
Cape, £10
Buy it at BOL

Certainly the oddest book on the shortlist, Autobiography of Red concerns Geryon, a monster with red wings, written about by the poet Stesichoros (who slandered Helen of Troy, and was blinded by the Gods until he composed a palinode, or retraction). Fragmentary, long-lined, often barely punctuated and flipping between the classical and the modern, it's a remarkable creation, funny and philosophical.

Approximately Nowhere
Michael Hofmann
Faber, £7.99
Buy it at BOL

Elegies for his late, famous father, and reflections on an adulterous relationship, written in a stylish, calculatedly off-hand manner. Impossible to question Hofmann's intelligence, nor his pushy erudition, but not everyone will warm to the chilly vacuum at the heart of many of these poems. The lack of motivation can make individual poems unappealing and unsatisfying, but the collection has some virtuoso moments.

Greetings to Our Friends in Brazil
Paul Durcan
Harvill, £9.99
Buy it at BOL

Paul Durcan's quirky poems offer both a sparky enjoyment of the quotidian alongside a lively surrealism that highlights the absurdity of life, love and politics. This hefty volume is part diary and part a collection of postcards, letters and mad telegrams. Subjects range from the Catholic missions to the poor of Brazil to Ireland under Mary Robinson to the Troubles. His extended piece on the Omagh bombing combines vituperation for the IRA in the wake of Gerry Adams's first ever condemnation of a bombing; litanies to the dead, and gestures to the life that continues. Its agonised refusal to forgive is wrought from a dignified anger which is properly moving.

Billy's Rain
Hugo Williams
Faber, £7.99
Buy it at BOL

Hugo Williams's latest volume is an account of an extramarital affair, though many of the pieces could be about any relationship's excitements, obsessions and dismays. Williams has never demonstrated breathtaking breadth of technique or linguistic resource; what he does best, in his columns and poems, is to offer anecdotes with a little style and a lot of charm.

He is a lyric poet, and there are moments in Billy's Rain where a recognisable feeling or event is encapsulated with wit and economy: "checking my smile / in the mirror in the hall / against my chances of being liked". Over a whole volume, though, the limitations of the one-club golfer are exposed. Williams's wife apparently read Billy's Rain and remarked "Five years' work then?", which, as practical criticism goes, is also witty and economical.

The Wind Dog
Tom Paulin
Faber, £7.99
Buy it at BOL

A strange, experimental volume, wrestling with the author's childhood and the relationship between nationalism and language. Paulin's political hobbyhorses and favourite paintings get the treatment in a jazzy, slangy style with a deliberately unfinished feel to it. The fruits of Paulin's academic career are evident in every allusion, and his combative critical approach informs many of his little battles over language, literature and the unappealing politics of great writers in this ambitious and flawed collection.

Jizzen
Kathleen Jamie
Bloodaxe, £6.99
Buy it at BOL

Jizzen is an old Scots word for childbed. In this collection, Jamie welcomes her country's newfound independence and the birth of her child. In a precise, vivacious language, whether English or phonetic Scots, she writes an intense and celebratory poetry with good humour, a lightness of touch, and a sense of music and economy; the poems about childbirth are delicious, being both sharply physical, and warmly spiritual. Jamie has always been a highly talented writer, and here she is at her strongest.

The Tightrope Wedding
Michael Laskey
Smith/ Doorstop, £7.99 Tel: 01484 434840
Buy it at BOL

Smith/ Doorstop have been quietly pushing new or developing talent for years now (rewarding the winners of a yearly competition with volume publication; it is a delight to see their efforts rewarded with Laskey's nomination, the only small press volume to make it onto a shortlist traditionally stuffed with work from the major publishing houses. "Home Movies", from this collection, exemplifies Laskey's originality of thought and quality of execution: a home movie of his parents wedding day is played backwards, initially for sheer hilarity, and then, as signatures vanish into pens and rings are pulled off fingers, the atmosphere is choking: "He stood so still / we didn't exist. There was nothing real / but that slither of negatives at his feet."

The World's Wife
Carol Ann Duffy
Picador, £10
Buy it at BOL

Carol Ann Duffy's warm, vivacious takes on the flipside of mythic and historical figures have been appearing for years now, and are especially successful at her excellent readings; Mrs Midas, Delilah, Circe, Elvis's Twin Sister, Frau Freud. Here they are finally gathered in one volume.

At their best they demonstrate the skills that have made Duffy one of the most successful and best-loved poets of her generation; fiercely driven rhythms, crackling with assonance, alliteration and rhyme, neatly turning cliches, proverbs and demotic phrases back into concrete images.

"The Devil's Wife" is a four-section suite about Myra Hindley that doesn't need to name its protagonist, and is a brave attempt to go into some dark places. Other pieces are little more than Clerihewesque squibs, and, with a few exceptions, the idea of viewing Dead White Males through their sceptical and more sensible spouses throws up one joke over and over again. This is the second intermezzo since Duffy's brilliant collection, Mean Time: one is now quite hungry for its proper successor.

Here Nor There
Bernard O'Donoghue
Chatto, £8.99
Buy it at BOL

The author's finest collection to date. Elegies for the characters of his Irish childhood, and reflections on his distance from both childhood and homeland, these tender, scupulous, honest, musing and affecting poems are a real pleasure to read. O'Donoghue writes with a crisp precision and the attractive style of a story-teller, but it is in the unfussy details that he gets to the heart of the significance of the smallest gestures and the quietest lives. O'Donoghue has an unerring knack with the precise yet unshowy word or phrase; this volume confirms him as a considerable and unegotistical talent.

 The shortlisted poets will read from their work at the Almeida Theatre, London (0171-359 4404) tomorrow at 7.30pm.

fields.headline: Dodgy drizzle, or burned lasagne?
fields.standfirst: Bibi van der Zee  weighs up two women novelists with very different views of love
fields.trailText: Bibi van der Zee weighs up two women novelists with very different views of love
fields.body:
Jenny Colgan's favourite comic novels

Before You Sleep
Linn Ullmann
Picador, £12.99, 272pp
Buy it at BOL

Amanda's Wedding
Jenny Colgan
HarperCollins, £5.99, 374pp
Buy it at BOL

Linn Ullmann, as we realise within a few lines of her book (all present tense and jagged grammar), wants to write Serious Literature. Jenny Colgan, as we realise within a few paragraphs of hers, wants to write Popular Fiction. Both have chosen weddings as the centres of their plots, both are female, and both have been splashed all over the papers, Ullmann for being the daughter of Ingmar Bergman and Liv Ullmann, and Colgan for being paid a million pounds for her first novel. Both books are expected to be hits, and both have the advantage of good PR, and in this world, that counts for a lot.

I don't know what it says about the Norwegian and British book markets that the Norwegian hit starts with a woman lying in bed with a child waiting for his mother to call, while the British one starts with a woman jumping out of bed with an accountant while waiting for her boyfriend to call.

Ullmann is heading down that Smilla path, filling her pages with odd tangential relationships and conversations, a defensive, independent female narrator, and a precious child at the heart of it all, not a man. Colgan has no truck with all this. Straight to the gusset of it all she goes: scheming social-climbing blondes marrying titled good guys, while one-for-all chums get drunk, burn lasagne, and plan to save their male friend from the blondy's evil clutches.

What is Ullmann's novel about? It's difficult to tell, to be honest. It's like reading a cloud of drizzle: you come out of the other end damp and blinking, but dry off pretty fast. We're led through it by the narrator, mid-thirties Karin, with her infuriating habit of just making things up completely (sometimes things like this work, sometimes they don't), and slowly introduced to members of her family.

The centre of the narrative is the wedding of her sister Julie, and what happens to the marriage, but dozens of entirely unconnected things and people arrive inexplicably all round this. Sometimes they are wonderful, such as Karin's grandfather Rikard, who emigrated to America and set up a costume hire shop. But mostly they are buried in thoughts, and sighs, and dodgy images. This may be the translation's fault, in which case I apologise, but few things in life are as irritating as sentences like: "Her voice has a dark resonance to it, a kind of music, a merry promise of good things to come". Do you know someone with a voice like that?

Meanwhile Colgan does funny as hard as she can. She doesn't worry about transcending anything, or de-familiarising us, or tuning into universal themes. She just produces lines like "You see, I'm keeping my name and taking his name. It's a feminist statement really. Didn't you see me in Tatler?" There will be no critical appraisal, no one will debate the semiotics of this novel, and boyfriends will sneer, quite frankly, if they catch you reading it. It's a girls' book, pure and simple, in the great tradition of Jilly Cooper and Bridget Jones, and it doesn't try to be anything else.

The odd thing is that these are both books about love (of course they are, they're written by birds aren't they?). But these two kinds of love wouldn't recognise each other on the street: Ullmann's dour love doomed or false to start with, Colgan's bright and shining and true. The end of a love: Ullmann's narrator's sister describing her marriage as "Two defeated soldiers who shake hands and say: Had enough death yet? Maybe it would have been easier if love hadn't been part of the plan." And the beginning of a love: Colgan's heroine declaiming to a restaurant that actually "I do believe in all that crap. Well, not all of it. But some of it. The actually being in love with someone stuff. Ehm, yeah."

Well, of course, harrumph, it's a terrifically naive point of view, and obviously love fades and we grow old, blah blah blah. But, to be honest, most of my favourite writers seem to quite like the idea of love as well. Perhaps if Ullmann's prose succeeded in stirring up the melancholy that her point of view does, instead just getting on your nerves, it wouldn't be quite so irritating. This is obviously not the basis for literary criticism, but, if you were locked in the bathroom with six bars of Dairy Milk, some nice bubble bath, and an endless supply of hot water, which would you choose?

 Jenny Colgan discusses her top ten comic novels on www.booksunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: More than black and white
fields.standfirst: Anita Krog tells Melanie McFadyean about truth and reconciliation
fields.trailText: Anita Krog tells Melanie McFadyean about truth and reconciliation
fields.body:
Country of My Skull by Antjie Krog 464pp, Vintage, £7.99

Antjie Krog is a poet and a journalist, a combination that underscores Country of My Skull , her horrifying and compelling account of South Africa's Truth and Reconciliation Commission. In the book, Krog the poet articulates visceral emotions, recreates the moment, puts images together in an original, iconoclastic way. Krog the journalist, who spent two years at TRC hearings reporting for South African radio, records testimonies verbatim and provides the broader context.

Krog, an Afrikaner, was asked to write Country of My Skull on the strength of an article she had produced about the TRC for a South African newspaper. "The response to the article," says Krog, "was overwhelming. It was in the Christmas edition after a year of the TRC hearings. I put in the incongruity of celebrating Christmas on the one hand and the TRC on the other."

This apparent incongruity, the poetic licence within the journalist's prose, is integral to the subsequent book's power. "I realised that 'flat reporting' of facts made it hard for readers to find an entry point into the process," she says, and so she decided to introduce herself - "I" - into the narrative, that person journalists are supposed to leave at home. "I brought in the personal 'I' on which the reader could piggyback into the hearing. When it was too much for the reader, it was also too much for me - then I would ask myself why can't I go on, finding words for the reader and myself to deal with the horror." In her radio journalism Krog never used the "I". "As a journalist I worked under my married surname, Samuel, deliberately to separate the poet from the journalist. The act of creativity is in essence to disobey, to undermine. The act of reporting as a journalist is to carry out your duty, to report as best you can to keep listeners (in my case for radio) informed to make their own informed choices."

The dutiful journalist collected the material, the disobedient poet wrote it. "The idea of objectivity or neutrality is laughable - one can only be fair or give as many sides to a story as are available. Poetry is subjective. When I wrote the book, it was no longer necessary to split the two. The book was not to be a report of the TRC - it was my own journey through a process."

The result, according to one critic, was "one of the most remarkable books to come out of South Africa". It was "a major, lasting work of non-fiction," wrote another. But one influential critic, RW Johnson, went for the jugular: "Krog is no sort of journalist at all and her emotional stream of consciousness style is innocent of all notions of factual reporting, balance , evidence or even handed reporting. . . like most white lefties, [Krog] is so paralysed by guilt she can't say boo to a goose if it's black." Krog, like any writer, finds negative criticism hard to take but divides it into "negative criticism which pulls you out of a something you are trapped in, and hurts but helps," and the other sort - "the negative criticism which deliberately distorts your work to assist in a private agenda". RW Johnson's fell into the latter category. "He made factual mistakes such as that the TRC requested that I be appointed as reporter because I'm an ANC lackey. If he read the book at all he would have seen that I was appointed long before the TRC - in fact I reported on the prospective candidates. He advises readers how to pronounce my name - and then does it incorrectly. He has the right-wing liberal kind of image that he has to uphold and nothing irritates that kind more than Afrikaners who maybe like to live in the new South Africa and feel responsible for the past."

Krog's use of fictional devices may have irritated Johnson but others applauded the device of amalgamating different people's perceptions to create composite truths. "The testimonies weren't changed at all, nor my interviews with the people whose real names I use. The composite stories deal with fictitious people. Some of those I call my colleagues do not exist, their words are a combination of a variety of arguments I picked up around me. Instead for instance of having a long rambling solo on guilt, I have a conversation with a lover. I have three brothers, not two. I initially did that in an effort not to censure myself right from the beginning - thinking my brother, neighbour, colleague or friend will be furious about this, or I will have to consult with people and find out whether they are OK with this."

Krog wrote the book in three months. "I took unpaid leave - that was all I could afford. I drew up a tight schedule of chapters and worked out the precise amount of words I had to do per day. The latter chapters happened over weekends and at nights after a ten- to twelve- hour workday."

How did Krog fit such long, hard, working days around her four children's lives - all were under 21 at the time, the youngest still at school. "I sat down at 8.15 every day, broke for tea 10.30 to 11am, sat in the sun just melting. Worked until two and child gets home. Lunch with him, lie down and discuss homework, check things. Start working again at 3.30 until five when husband comes home. Cook. Go back at nine and work out the content of the next day so that the subconscious could start working." As Krog reported on the hearings during the TRC years, her husband learned to cook - "and he gave two 21st birthday parties at home, because I wasn't here. But my absence took a big toll from him and the youngest child."

Krog is now working on a volume of poetry and that, she says is a "totally different kind of discipline - it is actually not a discipline but a full time effort to create space and silence in your head to hear."

fields.headline: Non-fiction
fields.standfirst: Never Marry a Girl With a Dead Father by Helen Hayward | Dictionary of Imaginary Places, by Alberto Manguel and Gianni Guadalupi | The Art of Sleepy Hollow
fields.trailText:
Never Marry a Girl With a Dead Father by Helen Hayward | Dictionary of Imaginary Places, by Alberto Manguel and Gianni Guadalupi | The Art of Sleepy Hollow
Buy it at BOL
fields.body:
Never Marry a Girl With a Dead Father
by Helen Hayward
(IB Tauris, £9.95)

Buy it at BOL

English lecturer analyses heroines of certain 19th century realist novels as if they were real, and is most censorious about their psychological failure to become mature, independent women. Such a Victorian moralistic approach, as if the object of every novelist must be not to show life as it is and was lived, how circumstances and personality and time interact, but as an exemplar of how it should be, as lived within the current definition of mental health. No allowances made for the circumscribed lives of authors and fictional females then - or for the fashions in sensibility which laced in their behaviour. Interesting insights, though.

Dictionary of Imaginary Places
Alberto Manguel and Gianni Guadalupi
(Bloomsbury, £20)

Buy it at BOL

Revised, as guide books must be as dream destinations change; tourists of the imagination now have to increase their travel insurance since "neither the Jurassic park administration nor the government of Costa Rica will assume any liability in case of an accident". Update hasn't quite caught up with the fall of Eastern Europe- "travellers who wish to visit Kravonia are best advised to do so by coach" - no, you just drive there via Zagreb, though expect a long wait on the border. Droll entries, witty illustrations and wicked mock mini-maps - can't wait to take a 48-hour break in the youth hostel in Strelsau, capital of Ruritania.

The Art of Sleepy Hollow
(Faber, £14.99)

Buy it at BOL

Long wondered what goes on inside Tim Burton's mind as he devises a cinematic fantasy like this (not his cracking best) movie. Unsure that this vol, one of the many Art-Ofs around at present, shows you: storyboards and production sketches by various hands look like downmarket 40s book-jackets or naff comic frames, only the odd doodled vignettes of imagined early scientific kit intrigue. And any photo of an actor's face is fanzine stuff. But the vista stills of the haunted village of Sleepy Hollow, of its perfect American white clapboard church with a headless horseman rearing up before it, are ace. So Burton crucially thinks within the camera - risky, terrific.

fields.headline: Lacey
fields.standfirst: Cup half empty and replays now out of favour
fields.trailText: Cup replays may soon belong to the past. As it is, they are living on borrowed time. Drawn Worthington Cup ties already go straight into penalty shoot-outs, as does the FA Cup final. If the third round of the FA Cup is returned to its normal New Year slot it will probably be at the expense of replays in the competition as a whole and, should there ever be a mid-winter break in England, the effect will be the same.
fields.body:
Cup replays may soon belong to the past. As it is, they are living on borrowed time. Drawn Worthington Cup ties already go straight into penalty shoot-outs, as does the FA Cup final. If the third round of the FA Cup is returned to its normal New Year slot it will probably be at the expense of replays in the competition as a whole and, should there ever be a mid-winter break in England, the effect will be the same.

This would be a profound shame, just as it was a pity when the principle of ties going to penalties after one replay was adopted nine years ago. Had there been no replays last season a sterile scoreless draw between Manchester United and Arsenal in the semi-finals would have been settled by a shoot-out instead of Ryan Giggs's unforgettable dash through the Arsenal defence.

Some ties need a second match to get going. Add extra-time and penalties to the first game and, while there may be no lack of excitement - witness the extraordinary fluctuations on Wednesday night when Leicester City and Fulham met in the Worthington Cup quarter-finals - the idea of living to fight another day, which is part of the essence of cup football, will disappear altogether.

Take away replays, moreover, and more small clubs will be inclined to switch venues when they are drawn at home to wealthy opposition just to be sure of getting a share of the gate receipts. The FA Cup might continue to enchant and enthral but it would be reduced to the sideshow status of national knockout competitions in other countries.

A watershed of a sort was reached this week when the Football Association decided that Tranmere Rovers' 1-0 victory over Sunderland in the fourth round of the FA Cup would stand despite the fact that the winners had briefly had 11 men on the field when they should have had only 10, Clint Hill having been sent off in stoppage time.

As Hill left the field Tranmere brought on a substitute, Steve Frail, but did not withdraw another player. Frail was then instrumental in denying Sunderland their last chance of saving the tie, preventing Jody Craddock from reaching Nicky Summerbee's centre, so his presence was far from incidental.

Eventually Andy Parkinson, who should have given way to Frail, did go off but the form confirming the intended substitution which had been filled in by Kevin Sheedy, Tranmere's assistant manager, went missing.

The FA Challenge Cup committee ruled that Tranmere "did not knowingly and deliberately distort the rules of the game in its final minutes", adding that "we have had to be aware of the difference between the rules of the competition and the laws of the game".

Yet the FA Cup rules state clearly that substitutes can be used "except to replace a player who has been suspended from the game by the referee". So the rules of the competition were broken, in which case the tie should have been played again.

Instead the FA has suspended the referee, Rob Harris, and his assistant. While the blunder-prone Harris may well be to football refereeing what Rolf Harris is to Beethoven's fifth, the standard of officiating should have been a separate issue.

So much can happen in stoppage time at the end of a cup tie - Manchester United proved as much at the Nou Camp last spring - that it is not enough to argue that Frail was on the pitch for only a matter of seconds and that Hill's dismissal, for a second bookable offence, was harsh anyway. Sunderland might have scored against 10 men.

In any case what happened to the interests of fair play which 11 months ago persuaded the FA to accept Arsenal's offer to replay a fifth-round tie against Sheffield United after Marc Overmars' decisive goal in a 2-1 win at Highbury had been scored after the United goalkeeper, Alan Kelly, had kicked the ball into touch for an injured colleague to have treatment?

When play was resumed Nwankwo Kanu, making his first appearance for Arsenal and apparently unaware of what to do in such circumstances, gathered Ray Parlour's throw-in and set up the chance for Overmars. In that instance no law had been broken nor had any FA Cup rule.

There was no justification for a replay but the FA, then as now, acted out of expediency. Had Sunderland kicked up the sort of fuss made by Aston Villa when they learned that West Ham had fielded a cup-tied player in the Worthington Cup quarter-finals, things might have been different.

At the time, however, Villa's season was clutching at straws. The Football League quite rightly ordered the tie to be played again and this week Villa won 3-1 at Upton Park.

Sunderland are not so blasé that they would pass up a chance of reaching Wembley but a Champions League place next season is their priority. Had a similar muddle denied them the possibility of a point in the Premier League their reaction might have been different.

If it comes to that, Arsène Wenger would surely be less inclined to offer opponents a rematch in the league just because his team had scored an unsporting winner. And, since Arsenal's FA Cup tie with Leicester has already produced 10 yellow cards and a red, it would be as well if the benches do not lose their substitution forms when the teams meet again at Filbert Street on Wednesday.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.standfirst: Anelka's joint is a complete mess
fields.trailText: The internet revolution is all very well, but some things on the worldwide web are just too disgusting for a family audience. Dial up www.marca.es and see what we mean.
fields.body:
The internet revolution is all very well, but some things on the worldwide web are just too disgusting for a family audience. Dial up www.marca.es and see what we mean.

The Spanish sports paper Marca has managed to get hold of exclusive pictures inside Nicolas Anelka's joint and we are not talking about his apartment.

We are talking about gory shots of the Real Madrid striker's recent exploratory knee operation. Which is surely taking investigative journalism too far.

The newspaper thinks not. It splashed details of the operation all over page two and three of Thursday's edition, including graphic stills and diagrams of what exactly went when on during the endoscopic procedure.

On Marca's website we can actually watch the operation as it happened inside the knee. And David Beckham complains that he can't go anywhere without being photographed.

The only suggestion the Diary can offer is that given Anelka's strange behaviour during and after his time at Arsenal, it would surely have been more worthwhile to find out what goes on inside the Frenchman's head than his knee.

 This week's Beckham underwear joke: did the BBC commentator really mean to describe Manchester United's Spice boy as "the best crosser in the game"?

 A reader suggests that the people calling for full-time referees should remember that it was professionals who built the Titanic and amateurs who built the Ark - though they did only have to count up to two.

 Subtle or what? On the way to Wednesday's game at Chelsea, a woman was spotted wearing a Tottenham away shirt with the word Arsenal printed on the back. Heresy? No. Underneath was the number 8 and next to it the letters ER.

 Despite his cherubic appearance, Dennis Wise may be even older than he looks. Asked recently by the Chelsea programme what got him dancing at the school disco, the captain replied: "Bill Haley doing Rock Around The Clock and Elvis doing Blue Suede Shoes. I'm telling my age now."

Well, if that's true, Wise must be more than 45. Rock Around The Clock was a hit in 1954 and Blue Suede Shoes in 1956.

 Not everyone in Watford loves Elton John. In the local market the old girl's 1975 album Rock of the Westies was spotted on sale at 20p.

 The Iranians are accusing Budweiser of bad taste. Nothing new, say those who have drunk the stuff. But this is a religious gripe.

Several Iranian groups are upset that beer ads will appear around the pitch for Iran's friendly against the United States at the Rose Bowl tomorrow.

Of course the Americans understand. "We have tremendous respect for Muslim tradition, and understand that abstinence is an Islamic tradition," says the US Soccer Federation.

So has it got the bottle to do anything about the ads? "However, because the game is being played in the US... Budweiser will remain one of several event sponsors."

 Fifa has confirmed that Manchester United's presence in Brazil has made no difference to England's World Cup bid. Which must come as a huge relief to the government and the Football Association.

 Quote of the week: Wigan's Gareth Griffiths, when asked by a journalist which player was favourite to forget that the kick-off for today's game against Millwall had been brought forward to 1pm: "Has it?"

webTitle: Jarman calls for big screen curbs

fields.headline: Jarman calls for big screen curbs
fields.standfirst: Match referees must do more to protect men in middle
fields.trailText: The announcement by Barry Jarman, the match referee for this series, that he wants the use of big-screen television replays restricted during Test matches was intriguingly timed.
fields.body:
The announcement by Barry Jarman, the match referee for this series, that he wants the use of big-screen television replays restricted during Test matches was intriguingly timed.

The release of Jarman's impending recommendations to the International Cricket Council coincided with the reappearance in this series of the South African umpire Rudi Koertzen, who had a shocking match in Port Elizabeth in the second Test. It looked, therefore, like a pre-emptive effort to defuse a potentially awkward situation in this Centurion Test.

Who would be a modern-day umpire? They have a split second to make a decision, unlike the commentators and TV-viewing public who are able to view replay after replay and so are never wrong.

Jarman believes player confrontations should not be highlighted by the cameras, and neither should poor umpiring decisions be replayed incessantly on the large screens, to avoid "unfair pressure" being put on the men in the middle.

"I would suggest this situation could be improved if the ground TV screen shows only one slow-motion replay and only one normal-speed replay," he said, adding that he was disappointed to have been criticised in the media for not reporting or acting upon controversial incidents during the fourth Test at Newlands last week.

He claimed he had no chance of seeing or hearing some of the things that went on, and that he was privy only to the local broadcaster's coverage and not BSkyB's, which is seen throughout the UK and various other parts of the world.

In particular, Jarman alluded to the Mike Atherton-Darryl Cullinan confrontation, which became animated and overheated. Atherton had stood his ground on appeal for a catch and Cullinan took exception, trampling petulantly up the pitch towards the umpire, BC Cooray. The incident was unseemly and unnecessary but was highlighted by the cameras, as confrontation of any sort between players is an obvious talking point.

Pressure on umpires is no new concept. Players have always made it their business to know their man, and bowlers in particular have been adept at this. Given a choice of bowling at Dicky Bird's end, who was a known "not outer", and Ray Julian's, the bowler's friend and profligate giver of lbws, there was no option, even if it meant bowling uphill into the wind.

But in the past couple of years players have begun not to trust one another. There used to be an unwritten law that if the fielder said he had caught a catch, it was good enough for the batsman and off he went. This happens no more and leaves the umpire nowhere to turn; the saddest aspect of the modern game.

Certainly it would be grossly unfair to blame umpires for this degeneration of standards, but it would also be wrong to blame TV coverage. We do, however, urgently need a general tidying up of the behaviour of players and a better performance by umpires - and the responsibility for this is the match referee's.

It is, after all, his brief to take control of the players and their discipline, and of the umpires and their performance. A more critical and emphatically authoritative approach by match referees is a must. After all, it is why they were appointed in the first place.

 Glenn McGrath and Andrew Symonds took four wickets apiece yesterday as Australia bowled India out for 100 in 36.3 overs in the triangular series one-day international in Sydney. The hosts were then reduced to 59 for five before recording their second win in the competition, by five wickets.

Glamorgan have confirmed that the Australian Test batsman Matthew Elliott, 28, will replace Jacques Kallis as their overseas player this season, subject to formal approval from the Australian Cricket Board.

"I would suggest this situation could be improved if the ground TV screen shows only one slow-motion replay and only one normal-speed replay," he said, adding that he was disappointed to have been criticised in the media for not reporting or acting upon controversial incidents during the fourth Test at Newlands last week. He claimed he had no chance of seeing or hearing some of the things that went on, and that he was privy only to the local broadcaster's coverage and not BSkyB's, which is seen throughout the UK and various other parts of the world. In particular, Jarman alluded to the Mike Atherton-Darryl Cullinan confrontation, which became animated and overheated. Atherton had stood his ground on appeal for a catch and Cullinan took exception, trampling petulantly up the pitch towards the umpire, BC Cooray. The incident was unseemly and unnecessary but was highlighted by the cameras, as confrontation of any sort between players is an obvious talking point. Pressure on umpires is no new concept. Players have always made it their business to know their man, and bowlers in particular have been adept at this. Given a choice of bowling at Dicky Bird's end, who was a known "not outer", and Ray Julian's, the bowler's friend and profligate giver of lbws, there was no option, even if it meant bowling uphill into the wind. But in the past couple of years players have begun not to trust one another. There used to be an unwritten law that if the fielder said he had caught a catch, it was good enough for the batsman and off he went. This happens no more and leaves the umpire nowhere to turn; the saddest aspect of the modern game. Certainly it would be grossly unfair to blame umpires for this degeneration of standards, but it would also be wrong to blame TV coverage. We do, however, urgently need a general tidying up of the behaviour of players and a better performance by umpires - and the responsibility for this is the match referee's. It is, after all, his brief to take control of the players and their discipline, and of the umpires and their performance. A more critical and emphatically authoritative approach by match referees is a must. After all, it is why they were appointed in the first place.  Glenn McGrath and Andrew Symonds took four wickets apiece yesterday as Australia bowled India out for 100 in 36.3 overs in the triangular series one-day international in Sydney. The hosts were then reduced to 59 for five before recording their second win in the competition, by five wickets. Glamorgan have confirmed that the Australian Test batsman Matthew Elliott, 28, will replace Jacques Kallis as their overseas player this season, subject to formal approval from the Australian Cricket Board.

fields.headline: Figures lie for woeful England
fields.standfirst: South Africa 155-6
fields.trailText: Nasser Hussain had insisted that on a pitch that promised to make life difficult for batsmen and profitable for bowlers he wanted his men to stand up and be counted.
fields.body:
Nasser Hussain had insisted that on a pitch that promised to make life difficult for batsmen and profitable for bowlers he wanted his men to stand up and be counted.

Yesterday afternoon, after he had won a toss almost as vital as that in the first Test at the Wanderers, he went back into his dressing room and reiterated that statement. "Make them play," he said. "Bowl straight and make them play."

Well, perhaps the dressing room stereo was on too loud or maybe Messrs Gough, Caddick, Mullally and Silverwood were indulging in some prematch meditation. Clearly they had not heard. This particular character test proved too much for the lot of them.

On the face of it the figures would seem to indicate a job well done after dank, cold, drizzly rain had prevented any play until two o'clock. By the early close to a day curtailed at the start and disrupted slightly in the middle the South African innings had been reduced to 155 for six and, one might reasonably think, well done England.

Which just goes to show how figures can conceal the truth, for this was a pitch on which McGrath, Ambrose, Hadlee, Srinath or Pollock, indeed any pace bowler who could exhibit the rudiments of control, would have embarrassed the opposition. Instead Hussain, rather than coaxing the definitive performance from his four-man pace attack, received a slap in the face.

Excuses will be proffered - damp footholds, moist ball, too cold - anything indeed to divert attention from the truth which is that in conditions in which all of them should have revelled, they were appalling.

The straight ball, far from being the nagging norm, was used sparingly, as a surprise alternative to that which drifted feet outside off-stump or wide down the leg-side to keep Alec Stewart on his toes.

The macho short ball was used at the expense of the more sassy length delivery. The principal culprit was Alan Mullally, whose first 10 overs cost only as many runs purely because the majority of his deliveries were out of range.

But Darren Gough sprayed it and Andy Caddick could not quite make the fine adjustment in line and length required. As for Chris Silver- wood, he may have a big heart but this pitch required skill as well. He was clattered unmercifully in his seven overs. South Africa, who had aimed for 200, were off the hook and, as the day drew to its end, Lance Klusener once more was biffing out his familiar tattoo on or beyond the boundary boards with a hooked six and a couple of fours.

All this came after England had received the best possible bonus before play when it was announced that Allan Donald had been forced to withdraw because of gout in the big toe of his right foot, a condition he has suffered from in the past.

His replacement, Nantie Hayward, having flown back to Port Elizabeth yesterday to rejoin Eastern Province, was warming up at St George's Park when he was summoned back to Centurion. England, as had been expected, brought in Mullally for Phil Tufnell (did they give a moment's thought to Alex Tudor, who outbowled Mullally in the last match and could not have failed to do so yesterday?) while Darren Maddy will bat at seven instead of Andy Flintoff.

It was during the first session that England set the tone; 102 deliveries were bowled, of which almost 50% were flagged through by the batsmen with little more than a cursory nod. It was arbitrary bowling, a matter not of taking wickets when the ball landed in the right area but only if it ever did. Wickets fell but only in the same way as someone running backwards and forwards across the M1 will eventually get hit by a car. In only the first over, for example, Gary Kirsten, mesmerised by Gough's inaccuracy, suddenly found a straight ball coming his way and was helpless. Herschelle Gibbs too was am bushed by a straight one from Caddick that bounced and followed him.

After tea the first ball of a new spell, floated unnaturally full by Caddick, found Jacques Kallis driving with no discernible movement of his feet and his middle stump pegged back. Hansie Cronje followed soon after, edging Gough to short-leg via his front pad, but these days he hardly counts as a wicket. It was the South African captain's second successive nought and left his side at 55 for four.

Now, though, Daryll Cullinan and Pieter Strydom, on his debut, took hold of the wayward bowling, adding 47 in an hour for the fifth wicket before Strydom, a touch of Allan Lamb about him as he stands at the crease, was caught at the wicket off Silverwood for 30.

Cullinan, however, is a terrific player now, and he went on to hit five fours in his 46 before he top-edged a pull and was caught by the bowler Mullally. Four overs later the light closed in. If England retired to celebrate they were deluding themselves. This was a bad day.

 Daryll Cullinan ended the day by announcing his retirement from one-day internationals. Cullinan, 33 in March, has played in 122.

webTitle: Controversy at every stop as cricket goes off the rails

fields.headline: Controversy at every stop as cricket goes off the rails
fields.trailText: In South Africa recently there have been signs of growing animosity between Darren Gough and the Sky commentator Bob Willis. During the last Test the Yorkshire paceman was reported to have made a pointed and sarcastic remark to the stump microphone. Which may seem a rather unkind way of describing a man who took 325 wickets for his country, but nevertheless serves to illustrate the kind of crisis that is currently gripping cricket.
fields.body:
In South Africa recently there have been signs of growing animosity between Darren Gough and the Sky commentator Bob Willis. During the last Test the Yorkshire paceman was reported to have made a pointed and sarcastic remark to the stump microphone. Which may seem a rather unkind way of describing a man who took 325 wickets for his country, but nevertheless serves to illustrate the kind of crisis that is currently gripping cricket.

What has happened to the dear old summer game? At one time the chocolate cake in the Test Match Special commentary box was about the only unsavoury thing on the international scene.

True, there were some well documented incidents. One thinks of the Bodyline crisis of 1932-33 in which the England captain Douglas Jardine employed leg-theory to unnerve Don Bradman. The plan had apparently come to the English skipper when he caught sight of The Don anxiously inspecting the width of his calves in a mirror at Old Trafford and from then on the England fast bowlers Harold Larwood and Bill Voce carried out a vicious and single-minded attack on the Boy from Bowral, aimed constantly at his body.

The sight and sound of the Nottinghamshire pair in full cry ("How do, lardy thighs?", "Bet you can't get a bike between them two, sunshine" and such) raised a storm from the start, but when Bill Woodfull was struck on the heart when trying to fend off a wicked Larwood remark about the size of his feet, things blew up into a full scale diplomatic row.

The early 60s saw the situation between the two nations reversed when the so-called "dragging" problem was swiftly followed by the even more pernicious "dragging-up" problem. Several burly Australian fast bowlers were accused by the MCC of cynically exploiting the old back-foot-to-the-wall rule and playing on PBH May and his team's psychosexual fears of big hairy blokes in silky underwear.

Upsetting though they were, however, these were very much isolated cases. Cricket generally featured less controversy than a Cuban election. Not so nowadays when the game seems to lurch from one imbroglio to the next.

This month, for example, Shoaib Akhtar has returned to the international scene what seems like a mere five minutes after he had been banned from it because of doubts about his action. Perhaps the hope was that after sorting out his bouncer the Rawalpindi Express would suddenly look as though he had been taken over by Virgin Trains. If so, the theory was given early credence when, during the first over of the one-day match in Brisbane, he announced that he was unable to stop at fine leg because of engine problems.

The young Aussie tyro Brett Lee also came under scrutiny. Lee has apparently been coached in the art of bowling by Dennis Lillee. He has clearly attacked the task with the same exuberant relish that Barry Davies brings to his thrilling, jazz-style improvisation on the theme of Ole Gunnar Solskjaer.

The result is a more or less perfect rendition of the old Lillee war dance appeal that sees the paceman whirling round, arms in the air and legs akimbo before sinking slowly into an unsteady crouch like a man perching above an alien toilet of suspect cleanliness. Despite this unpalatable behaviour he was swiftly cleared of any wrongdoing by an ICC committee.

England, meanwhile, found themselves in a throwing storm of their own after video evidence showed they constantly throw away any chance they have. An England and Wales Cricket Board spokesman denied any wrongdoing, saying: "The players have a kink in their character which is genetic. They cannot straighten it even if they want to."

Until this series the South African players have projected an image so wholesome that just watching them constituted a high-fibre diet. With their humble godliness they seemed the perfect antidote to the Barmy Army - the Smarmy Army.

Not so any more after the Test umpire Barry Duddleston accused today's players of engaging in behaviour that is "unbelievably childish" and cited the actions of Daryll Cullinan after an appeal was turned down against Michael Atherton. The South African swiftly hit back at the allegation, refusing to eat any tea and saying, "I'm going to starve myself to death and when I'm dead you'll be sorry, poo-pants."

Poor Chris Adams came under verbal attack from South Africa's wicket-keeper Mark Boucher, who apparently greeted his arrival at the wicket in the second innings of the Cape Town Test by saying, "Welcome to the end of your Test career." Adams has admittedly had a thin time of it, largely due to the fact that he uses his bottom hand more heavily than a Venetian lothario during the tourist season. But even so.

As Richie Benaud said last weekend: "It's a shemozzle. Not just an ordinary shemozzle, but a straight-out full-blown shemozzle." I'm sure I am not alone in thinking that for the good of cricket it is high time we folded up our shemozzles unblown and tucked them away where they belong.

fields.headline: Corinthians rejoice as Edmundo misses
fields.trailText: Corinthians of Sao Paulo are the first Club World Champions after beating Vasco de Gama on penalties. Edmundo's miss in the last spot-kick sent ripples of frenzy to the flag-waving Paulistas in the Maracana stadium last night.
fields.body:
Corinthians of Sao Paulo are the first Club World Champions after beating Vasco de Gama on penalties. Edmundo's miss in the last spot-kick sent ripples of frenzy to the flag-waving Paulistas in the Maracana stadium last night.

At times BBC viewers were treated to a football feast. The ball rarely rose above the deck. Penetrating passing, first touches that defied physics and combination play that incorporated skill, positional awareness, anticipation and well-worked out patterns were the ingredients of a truly memorable encounter.

Vasco de Gama were the slight favourites as they were playing at home. They lived up to their billing in the first half when the outstanding dribbling of Felipe, the deft touches of Ramon and the explosive duet of Edmundo and the evergreen Romario tore their defence apart.

Only Edilson's darting runs offered scope for optimism for Corinthians but Marcellinho had a bad day and Luziao and Ricardinha were either unlucky or well-guarded and could not capitalise.

It looked tight from the outset. Vasco went very close seconds after the kick-off when Rincon tried to clear Ramon's corner only for the ball to miss the far post by a whisker. In the next minute Edilson charged down the right but his pacy, low cross narrowly missed the diving Luizao.

Chances came and went as both teams had refined build-ups but the finishing was not of the same quality. Miranda came close with an angled drive on 18 minutes. Two minutes later a mesmerising run by Felipe ended with Edmundo letting fly only for the shot to be deflected wide.

Juninho's free-kick narrowly missed on the half hour and Marcellinho came close when he accepted Ricardinho's through ball but his shot met the fingertips of the stretching Helton.

Corinthians had a simple strategy of soaking pressure and hitting on the break exploiting the quality of Rincon's range and Ricardinho's runs. It worked better in the second half when they had the better of Vasco for long spells.

Five minutes after the interval Edilson charged down the right and his shot from an acute angle whizzed past Helton's upright. Then Gilberto missed the chance of the match when his scorching volleigh from 10 yards flew inches wide.

On 61 minutes a triangular combination between Edmundo, Romario and Juninho ended with the latter just failing to deliver to the ready-to-pounce "animal".

Rincon went close with a shot on 81 minutes and again two minutes later. Marcellinho could have settled it with a shot from 40 yards right at the death but it just missed the bar.

Extra time was boring with both teams dreading the golden goal and neither creating a chance.

Corinthians' keeper Dida is notorious as a penalty-saver. He did save one from Gilbert but Corinthians' star Marcellinho missed his shot to settle it. Helton saved and up stepped Edmundo to level things up but he missed the goal completely.

Corinthians: Dida, Indio, Adilson, Vampeta, Kleber, Marcelinho, Rincon, Luizao, Edilson, Ricardinho, Luciano. Subs: Mauricio, Yamada, Carlos, Costa, Baiano, Dinei, Augusto, Edu, Senna, Gilmar, Mario.
Vasco de Gama: Helton, Odvan, Galvao, Amaral, Felipe, Juninho, Ramon, Edmundo, Romario, Gilberto, Miranda. Subs: Germano, Marcio, Jorginho, Donizete, Torres, Pedrinho, Junior Baiano, Valber, Viola, Oliveira, Nasa, Alex.

Referee: Dick Jol (Holland)

webTitle: Pace ace forced to take a rest

fields.headline: Pace ace forced to take a rest
fields.standfirst: South Africa's heavy schedule has compelled Allan Donald to throttle back as the tank starts to run dry
fields.trailText: Allan Donald must be cursing the gout, not just because it's an extremely painful condition. If ever there was a chance for him to pick up 10 wickets in a Test match, it was here in moist 'English' weather on a pacy pitch. And 10 wickets are all he needs to reach the magical 300, a landmark he has set his heart on.
fields.body:
Allan Donald must be cursing the gout, not just because it's an extremely painful condition. If ever there was a chance for him to pick up 10 wickets in a Test match, it was here in moist 'English' weather on a pacy pitch. And 10 wickets are all he needs to reach the magical 300, a landmark he has set his heart on.

He would have loved bowling at Centurion Park. Instead he spent much of the first day in earnest conversation with Dr Ali Bacher to determine the direction of his cricketing future. Donald had promised Warwickshire, whose coach, Bob Woolmer, is now ever-present in South African press boxes rather than their dressing rooms, that he would reveal his future plans during this Test. Yesterday he sat alongside Dr Bacher and announced that he would take a break from international cricket, missing South Africa's tour to Sri Lanka in June. He is, however, available for the triangular one-day series that begins this week. He hoped to resume his Test career in the 2000/01 season in South Africa when New Zealand and Sri Lanka are the visitors.

The equation was a tricky one for all concerned; it's also one that will become increasingly prevalent as the international calendar becomes ever more congested. Donald's case is especially complicated. He knows that at 33 there is, as Graham Gooch used to say, 'not much petrol left in the tank'. Donald, unlike Dennis Lillee in his dotage, has to bowl fast to be effective. The body - even before the onset of gout - is beginning to rebel and the heart is not quite so willing. Donald is more sensitive than our caricature of a fast bowler. For him Test cricket saps the mind as well as the body.

Yet he is desperate for that 300. On the surface this might appear a selfish pursuit born of vanity. But anyone who has seen Donald play cricket over the past decade would dismiss that theory immediately. The manner in which he has hurled himself at the Englishmen in this series is sufficient evidence. Donald has been the man to take the vital, match-winning wickets, sometimes, as in Cape Town, on unresponsive pitches. By sheer force of personality he has willed the most experienced of Englishmen, Mike Atherton and Alec Stewart, into fatal indiscretions. By winding them up and straining every sinew for the extra zip in that bouncer, he has dispatched them.

Donald, like Richard Hadlee, is conscious of the statistics, but he uses them as motivation, to will himself on even when the body's aching, even when his rhythm has been elusive, which has often been the case in this series. Yet he still snaffled 22 wickets in four Tests.

However, there are other concerns beyond the 300. If the 300 was all pervasive in Donald's mind he would definitely be touring India with the South Africans this February. Dr Bacher has asked him to consider making himself available for the two Tests in Mumbai and Bangalore but 'there's no pressure on him'. Donald will dutifully consider that proposition when he returns to Bloemfontein this week but it remains highly unlikely that he will go. He's had enough for the moment.

Donald is devoted to his adopted county Warwickshire and, it should be noted, he's well paid by them as well. Warwickshire had made two demands of Donald before offering him another one-year contract: that he should be fit to start the county season and that he should be available throughout. To satisfy them Donald feels a need to rest while his compatriots are in India and he therefore had to withdraw from South Africa's commitments in Australia and in Sri Lanka next summer as well.

There is one other factor. Donald's daughter is due to start school in Birmingham this spring and he wants to be around when that happens. Like most international cricketers he is in danger of missing out on his children's formative years. Hence the compromise hatched with Dr Bacher. So he will be back with Warwickshire this summer and compared to with the demands of the international calendar this represents something of a holiday. 'I can relax more there and I know that Bob [Woolmer] will use me sparingly,' he said. All being well he has the chance to notch his 300th Test wicket when New Zealand tour South Africa in the autumn of this year.

Donald is not alone among the South Africans in seeking some respite. Jonty Rhodes has pulled out of the Indian tour so that he can be present when his wife gives birth, and on Friday Darryl Cullinan announced that he would no longer play one-day cricket at international or domestic level. Although Cullinan put forward the noble idea that his absence would allow an opportunity to groom one of their youngsters for the 2003 World Cup (the South Africans are aiming to have a squad who have all played 50 one-day internationals by the time the next World Cup comes around), Cullinan also conceded that family pressures were uppermost in his mind. He added that he hoped this decision might prolong his Test career.

The South Africans, under the omnipotent guidance of Ali Bacher, are in the throes of the most punishing of schedules and are fraying at the edges - you only have to watch Hansie Cronje bat at the moment to recognise that. Bacher is asking a lot of his men - arguably too much - but at least he's been able to manage these setbacks adroitly. The announcements involving Donald and Cullinan, which might have been deemed disasters, have been deftly handled after long discussions between Bacher and the players involved. Compromises have been reached and 'positives' identified. Bacher was at pains to point out how 'flexible' the United Cricket Board had been and Donald duly expressed his gratitude. Contrast that with way in which Graham Thorpe's perfectly reasonable decision to withdraw from this tour came to pass - a hurried conversation with David Graveney prior to a Sunday paper 'exclusive'

Administrators around the world have to be wary of the danger of burn-out. The pursuit of the extra dollar is liable to abbreviate more international careers. The side-effect this might have on county cricket is intriguing. This summer Shane Warne and Glenn McGrath will be playing for Hampshire and Worcestershire respectively though not quite so as frequently as the counties first thought. Both must return to Australia during the English season for some one-day games under a roof in Melbourne.

Shoaib Akhtar will no longer go to Trent Bridge because of Pakistan's ever expanding commitments (Nottinghamshire deny that his replacement by Chris Cairns has anything to do with 'throwing'), while Muttiah Muralitharan may yet withdraw from his contract with Lancashire because of Sri Lanka's schedule. In the future international players will increasingly be faced with a dilemma similar to Donald's; to play for their country or to be equally well rewarded - in some cases better rewarded - by playing county cricket in England. The gut feeling may be that they should play for their countries, but, if they are pushed too hard, who can blame them if they take the softer option?

webTitle: Dawn of the age of the e-manager

fields.headline: Dawn of the age of the e-manager
fields.standfirst: On-line transfers could cut out illicit agents
fields.trailText: All Premiership and Football League managers will return to the classroom over the next few weeks to try to master the art of the internet, in an audacious move to improve communication within the game and revolutionise the way player transfers are conducted.
fields.body:
All Premiership and Football League managers will return to the classroom over the next few weeks to try to master the art of the internet, in an audacious move to improve communication within the game and revolutionise the way player transfers are conducted.

In a scheme costing hundreds of thousands of pounds, every manager of the 92 clubs in the four divisions has been issued with his own laptop computer by the League Managers Association (LMA), which is hoping to use modern technology to lessen the influence of football agents on the game.

Using a specially adapted security system, managers will be given secret access codes to a classified LMA website and will be able to email one another regarding player availability, tactics and other aspects of the game.

Laptop computers have also been issued to Howard Wilkinson, Kevin Keegan, David Pleat and other technical advisers with the aim of improving communication throughout professional football. The system is expected to be up and running by the end of this month.

Starting next week, managers will begin internet training as the LMA tries to convince them that using modern technology is not a case of swapping tracksuits for anoraks but will enhance their monitoring of the game and make buying players a less stressful affair.

The LMA's John Barnwell said: "It's not exactly rocket science and we are trying to convince managers that this is the future of football. Once managers have the discipline, they will be able to log on on a daily basis and communicate with each other privately. Once managers are convinced of the security of the system then I'm sure they will make use of it."

Use of the internet is increasing within professional football. Almost all Scandinavian players available for sale have their own personal websites where they advertise their services, and Teddy Sherringham, whose contract concludes at the end of the season, recently emailed his CV to leading clubs in Europe. Many South American players have also been using the internet in their search for clubs.

The LMA hopes that giving managers easy and direct access to one another and advertising the availability of players on the internet will make football agents redundant. A public website includes a section on the availability of out-of-work managers, complete with CVs. Former managers who are advertising on the site include Terry Fenwick and Roy Evans.

Barnwell said: "Ultimately, modern technology may help to cut out the football agent. If you are a manager who is interested in a player then you will be able to email a manager to inquire about him. Communication between managers is very difficult at the moment, it's impossible to take 40 telephone calls. But if you have come in from training and receive 40 emails on your laptop you can answer the ones you want. Managers will just have to get into the habit of logging on every day."

A pilot group of nine managers has undergone initial internet training. One of them was Sheffield Wednesday's Danny Wilson who, given his club's precarious position, may have cast an anxious eye at the LMA website's section for unemployed managers.

"The system is excellent," Wilson said. "It's a secure and safe way of communicating. I'm sure that it will have a huge impact on managers throughout the country.

"I can see a day when transfers will be conducted on-line. Already a lot of the ground work has been done. Of course there's no substitute for watching a player in a live game, but everybody is aware that this is the future of football. We have to make sure we keep up with the technology that's available."

The LMA points out that although managers and scouts will still need to watch players before buying them, use of the internet will help in negotiations and initial approaches, bypassing agents.

However, the International Association of Football Agents (Iafa) is proposing to set up its own system for transfers on the internet.

The Iafa president Dennis Roach believes it would make transfers more transparent and reduce the chances of bungs being paid. He also estimates that an open transfer system on the internet would help to reduce the number of illicit agents.

Roach has approached the Premier League with his internet transfer idea and believes that it could be up and running by March or April.

He said recently: "The plan is to have improved communications between clubs and for the clubs to deal directly on the finances involved in the transfer transaction."

A Premier League spokesman said that it was considering Roach's idea and that the internet would become an important part of the modern game.

Increased use of the internet would also benefit fans, who pioneered football websites. The LMA is proposing a weekly guest spot on its website which would allow fans to have on-line sessions with a manager. The organisation also wants managers to communicate their views on games directly via its website.

Professional football is gearing up for a new cyberspace dawn. The term "net" may come to have completely different connotations within the game as managers and players alike prepare to surf.
