fields.headline: Thai breakers
fields.standfirst:
The crash of the tiger economies has seen tourists flocking to Thailand for bargain exotic holidays. Expect another rush when the film of Alex Garland's book The Beach opens next month.
The Beach
fields.trailText: The crash of the tiger economies has seen tourists flocking to Thailand for bargain exotic holidays. Expect another rush when the film of Alex Garland's book The Beach opens next month.
fields.body:
One of the first things you see when you arrive in Bangkok is a poster. "Thailand", it reads at the top, and underneath are four boxes showing weather forecast symbols and dates. 1997 shows a thunderstorm, 1998 heavy rain. By 1999, sun is peeping through the cloud. And the box for 2000 shows the beaming sun usually stuck over Malaga on a weather map. In big capitals along the bottom it reads simply: "INVEST NOW!"

You barely notice the poster at first, too distracted by the exotic chaos of the city, the monks and the tuk-tuks and the temples and the smells you at first assume are the drains, and later realise are in fact the food. But by the time you leave, the poster has come to read more like the country's national mission statement. Travel agents and travellers love to coo about the mystical holiness of Thailand, but Thailand is actually much more interested in money, and will do almost anything to make it. And if Westerners were honest about it, that is precisely why they come here.

For those of us who don't fully grasp global economic complexities, Bangkok is like an idiot's guide to the tiger economies. From a hotel balcony high above the city, it looks like a gleaming first-world forest of hi-tech skyscrapers, emblazoned in neon with the names of multinationals. Down at street level, the shiny hauteur gives way to an anarchy of dust and rubbish and food stalls and stinking slums - but the slums aren't sultry ponds of lifelessness, they're frenzies of industry. It is a bewilderment of enterprise - clothing sweat shops crammed in next to computer shops, then a jewellery emporium next door to a store selling safes - and the traffic is a judder of gridlock and mayhem, steered by drivers in face masks, cheeks smudged with oily pollution.

Bangkok lies along a river, and from 6am this takes on the appearance of the M25. The water churns with boats ferrying the city to work, and office girls in short skirts, old women with groceries, young monks and startled tourists all leap as the vessels come careering on and off the landings, navigated by nothing more than a man on the bow whistling instructions to a driver who can't see a thing. There is a glorious and universal disregard for order - it is as if there are no rules as long as you're making money, and as if the entire city is on speed.

Which isn't too far from the truth. Amphetamines are abundant in Thailand, as is political corruption; the latest scandal to emerge during our stay were photographs of the prime minister with one of the country's leading dealers in speed pills. If a spirit of enterprising lawlessness accounted for Thailand's manic growth before the tiger crash of 1997, it is making a more orderly recovery difficult, and the city is tangled in poverty and confusions of desires. You can't move for temples or monks, and devotion to the King is extravagantly traditional - but after a rush of first-world wealth, Bangkok's profit impulse is so strong you can almost taste it in the air. And to judge from the tipsy grins that spread across the tourists' faces as they pile off the planes, it rather looks as if they have.

"You've just got to be hard," the woman in the hotel foyer informed us through pinched lips. She'd arrived from Yorkshire with her husband that morning, and straight off they'd gone shopping. She showed off her fake Prada handbags with grim satisfaction, while her husband talked us through the details of their haggling strategy like an angler reliving how he landed a shark. They'd not slept yet, but they'd been straight to the market; other activities on their itinerary were to get suits hand made by one of Bangkok's million tailors, and to bag some cheap jewellery. They'd dropped by the King's Palace ("very interesting") but not stayed long; they'd like to have seen some temples, of course, but time was short, what with all the shopping to be done.

They had also found time to have a look at Patpong, Bangkok's red light district, home of the internationally renowned ping-pong shows. If there is one thing even cheaper in Bangkok than a tailor-made suit, it's sex, and the streets around Patpong are clogged with tour buses depositing middle-aged tourists curious to go and see go-go girls eject ping-pong balls from their vaginas. It is an odd phenomenon. Thais may be in a state of some confusion about their morality, and their dual enthusiasms for Buddhism and vice may be puzzling. But Thais have nothing on the Western tourists who'd turn the telly over if EastEnders got too steamy back home, but who flock cheerfully to Patpong for a cocktail and a Kodak moment.

To the north of Patpong and the grand tourist hotels lies the Khao San Road, where the backpackers of South East Asia congregate, and their numbers have swelled to such an extent now that the Khao San Road itself has become a kind of sightseeing attraction for tourists. What was a cheap and cheerful dusty strip of budget hotels has ballooned into a rowdy clamour of shops and bars servicing the backpacker economy. So there are rucksack stores and sarong trolleys and a thousand internet cafés and travel agents and women braiding hair, and the travellers heading out of Thailand casually flaunt their tans and their confidence at the nervier, whiter new arrivals, who can soon be spotted anxiously buying up the traveller uniform of sarongs and sandals.

They come from all over the world, and the conversations in the cafés are all about how cheaply they're hoping they can live when they get south to the islands. Travellers like to consider themselves a different breed to tourists, but they are alike in at least one respect. The new backpack arrivals can't contain their excitement either, at the thought of how little money they're going to have to spend.

And the Thais, of course, can't contain their excitement at how much money they're going to get out of all these Westerners. Until relatively recently, visitors to Thailand tended to be sex tourists or travellers, but the collapse of the Baht has encouraged everyone else in between to make their way here, and the impact of mass tourism on parts of the country has been sudden and dramatic.

Less than a decade ago, the island of Koh Samui was a backpacker's private idyll of empty white sands and simple beach huts, undeveloped and largely unheard of in an average branch of Thomas Cook. If Bangkok was a mildly suggestive byword for vice, Koh Samui was the very opposite, but backpackers in beach huts are notoriously unextravagant, and it hasn't taken the island very long to refashion itself into a more lucrative commodity. If couples from Yorkshire will suspend their normal behaviour and pay money to see a ping-pong show, it can't have been hard for Koh Samui to work out what Western men would pay for a fortnight of tropical sexual favours.

"Hello, welcome! Where you from! Come, come!" is the fetching shriek that follows every tourist who makes his way through Koh Samui's main resort, Chaweng. The strip that runs parallel to the coconut-lined beach is a concrete and neon row of bars, each one fronted by a collection of beautiful, nubile, glamourous young Thai women, all executing a convincing performance of uncontrollable romantic desire. "Come, come!" they beckon prettily, staying just the right side of insistence, thus ensuring that the effect is girlishly charming rather than sluttish. And come the men do, with faces full of wolfish delight at the joy of this amazing arrangement which lets them make believe that they are sexually appealing.

The system is straightforward enough. Every bar and club in Chaweng, with a tiny handful of exceptions, employs "bar girls". If you call them prostitutes, everyone looks shocked and slightly offended. It is their job to entice customers to the bar, and the bar will pay them a small cut of the price of every drink the customer buys. The girls swoon charmingly over the men, who can grope and fondle them, sit them on their lap, and bore them to tears with conversation; wisely, the girls have come up with an inventive deterrent to the latter by playing endless games of Kerplunk with them instead.

The men enjoy the happy fantasy that these women are not prostitutes at all. That said, of course, if any of the men would like to take a girl off and have sex with her, all he must do is pay the bar about £4, and take her away. He then agrees a price with the girl for sex - but a more popular arrangement is not a one-off transaction but instead the beginning of what the men laughably refer to as a "relationship". For the duration of his holiday, the girl becomes his "girlfriend".

And so Chaweng is a resort town full of largely fat and unattractive European men driving around on mopeds with beautiful young women on the back. They are not doing anything sordid, they will tell you, like paying a poor, third-world prostitute to have sex with them. They are having a relationship! They buy lots of things for their girlfriend, of course, and generously give her money "for her family", but it has nothing to do with money. And the men strut about, beaming like little boys at Christmas, effortlessly able to enjoy the delusion, and having the time of their lives.

There are a lot of men in Koh Samui. An astonishing number, actually, and the ones too embarrassed to enter into the "girlfriend" pretence during the day generally find themselves able to suspend disbelief by 3am, after 14 pints, so the clubs are full of alluring freelance girls dancing hopefully. Their stamina is prodigious, and their smile never fades, although many of them are assisted by small pills which the Thais call Yabba, a kind of nuclear amphetamine which, if smoked in silver foil, will keep you going forever.

There are other things to do on Koh Samui besides pay women for sex. There is elephant trekking, and diving, and there are waterfalls to visit, and temples to see, and all the bars show European football on TV, and the restaurants screen movies you can watch while you eat. If you didn't manage enough shopping in Bangkok, you can buy more fake designer watches and bags and clothes, and you can haggle to your heart's desire, bellowing and waving your arms about over a matter of 10 or 20 pence, and the Thais will accommodate all these activities smilingly. You can get so drunk you drive your moped smack into an old woman's kebab stall, and she will smile gracefully and wave it away as nothing as she inspects the damage. And you can do all of this at a cost so small, it makes you feel like a king.

What you cannot do, of course, is ever know that a smile on Koh Samui is real. The smiles on the faces of the Western men mauling bar girls are real enough - but even if you never grope a bar girl, never invest in a "girlfriend", never crash your moped into an old woman, never scream at a shopkeeper over 20 pence, you would have to be supremely thoughtless or arrogant to assume that the Thai smiling at you is smiling because he or she likes you and not your traveller's cheques.

People come to Thailand because it makes them feel rich - and, just like rich people, most of them behave badly. But, also like rich people, they can never trust the motives of others' friendliness. This doesn't appear to bother too many Westerners here, it must be said. But if you don't care to feel like a whore's client for a fortnight, you might come to find it bothers you a lot.

The practicals

British Airways (0345 222111), Qantas (0345 747767) and THAI (020 74999113) fly direct to Bangkok from London. Expect to pay around £500 for a direct flight. Cheaper flights mat be available through a consolidator, such as Trailfinders (020 79383366), Quest Worldwide(020 8547 3322) or Bridge the World (020 79110900). There are 14 flights a day from Bangkok to Koh Samui with Bangkok Airways - buy tickets from teh airport on 00 66 425029 for around £50. More info from www.tourismthailand.org

From a hotel balcony high above the city, it looks like a gleaming first-world forest of hi-tech skyscrapers, emblazoned in neon with the names of multinationals. Down at street level, the shiny hauteur gives way to an anarchy of dust and rubbish and food stalls and stinking slums - but the slums aren't sultry ponds of lifelessness, they're frenzies of industry. It is a bewilderment of enterprise - clothing sweat shops crammed in next to computer shops, then a jewellery emporium next door to a store selling safes - and the traffic is a judder of gridlock and mayhem, steered by drivers in face masks, cheeks smudged with oily pollution. Bangkok lies along a river, and from 6am this takes on the appearance of the M25. The water churns with boats ferrying the city to work, and office girls in short skirts, old women with groceries, young monks and startled tourists all leap as the vessels come careering on and off the landings, navigated by nothing more than a man on the bow whistling instructions to a driver who can't see a thing. There is a glorious and universal disregard for order - it is as if there are no rules as long as you're making money, and as if the entire city is on speed. Which isn't too far from the truth. Amphetamines are abundant in Thailand, as is political corruption; the latest scandal to emerge during our stay were photographs of the prime minister with one of the country's leading dealers in speed pills. If a spirit of enterprising lawlessness accounted for Thailand's manic growth before the tiger crash of 1997, it is making a more orderly recovery difficult, and the city is tangled in poverty and confusions of desires. You can't move for temples or monks, and devotion to the King is extravagantly traditional - but after a rush of first-world wealth, Bangkok's profit impulse is so strong you can almost taste it in the air. And to judge from the tipsy grins that spread across the tourists' faces as they pile off the planes, it rather looks as if they have. "You've just got to be hard," the woman in the hotel foyer informed us through pinched lips. She'd arrived from Yorkshire with her husband that morning, and straight off they'd gone shopping. She showed off her fake Prada handbags with grim satisfaction, while her husband talked us through the details of their haggling strategy like an angler reliving how he landed a shark. They'd not slept yet, but they'd been straight to the market; other activities on their itinerary were to get suits hand made by one of Bangkok's million tailors, and to bag some cheap jewellery. They'd dropped by the King's Palace ("very interesting") but not stayed long; they'd like to have seen some temples, of course, but time was short, what with all the shopping to be done. They had also found time to have a look at Patpong, Bangkok's red light district, home of the internationally renowned ping-pong shows. If there is one thing even cheaper in Bangkok than a tailor-made suit, it's sex, and the streets around Patpong are clogged with tour buses depositing middle-aged tourists curious to go and see go-go girls eject ping-pong balls from their vaginas. It is an odd phenomenon. Thais may be in a state of some confusion about their morality, and their dual enthusiasms for Buddhism and vice may be puzzling. But Thais have nothing on the Western tourists who'd turn the telly over if EastEnders got too steamy back home, but who flock cheerfully to Patpong for a cocktail and a Kodak moment. To the north of Patpong and the grand tourist hotels lies the Khao San Road, where the backpackers of South East Asia congregate, and their numbers have swelled to such an extent now that the Khao San Road itself has become a kind of sightseeing attraction for tourists. What was a cheap and cheerful dusty strip of budget hotels has ballooned into a rowdy clamour of shops and bars servicing the backpacker economy. So there are rucksack stores and sarong trolleys and a thousand internet cafés and travel agents and women braiding hair, and the travellers heading out of Thailand casually flaunt their tans and their confidence at the nervier, whiter new arrivals, who can soon be spotted anxiously buying up the traveller uniform of sarongs and sandals. They come from all over the world, and the conversations in the cafés are all about how cheaply they're hoping they can live when they get south to the islands. Travellers like to consider themselves a different breed to tourists, but they are alike in at least one respect. The new backpack arrivals can't contain their excitement either, at the thought of how little money they're going to have to spend. And the Thais, of course, can't contain their excitement at how much money they're going to get out of all these Westerners. Until relatively recently, visitors to Thailand tended to be sex tourists or travellers, but the collapse of the Baht has encouraged everyone else in between to make their way here, and the impact of mass tourism on parts of the country has been sudden and dramatic. Less than a decade ago, the island of Koh Samui was a backpacker's private idyll of empty white sands and simple beach huts, undeveloped and largely unheard of in an average branch of Thomas Cook. If Bangkok was a mildly suggestive byword for vice, Koh Samui was the very opposite, but backpackers in beach huts are notoriously unextravagant, and it hasn't taken the island very long to refashion itself into a more lucrative commodity. If couples from Yorkshire will suspend their normal behaviour and pay money to see a ping-pong show, it can't have been hard for Koh Samui to work out what Western men would pay for a fortnight of tropical sexual favours. "Hello, welcome! Where you from! Come, come!" is the fetching shriek that follows every tourist who makes his way through Koh Samui's main resort, Chaweng. The strip that runs parallel to the coconut-lined beach is a concrete and neon row of bars, each one fronted by a collection of beautiful, nubile, glamourous young Thai women, all executing a convincing performance of uncontrollable romantic desire. "Come, come!" they beckon prettily, staying just the right side of insistence, thus ensuring that the effect is girlishly charming rather than sluttish. And come the men do, with faces full of wolfish delight at the joy of this amazing arrangement which lets them make believe that they are sexually appealing. The system is straightforward enough. Every bar and club in Chaweng, with a tiny handful of exceptions, employs "bar girls". If you call them prostitutes, everyone looks shocked and slightly offended. It is their job to entice customers to the bar, and the bar will pay them a small cut of the price of every drink the customer buys. The girls swoon charmingly over the men, who can grope and fondle them, sit them on their lap, and bore them to tears with conversation; wisely, the girls have come up with an inventive deterrent to the latter by playing endless games of Kerplunk with them instead. The men enjoy the happy fantasy that these women are not prostitutes at all. That said, of course, if any of the men would like to take a girl off and have sex with her, all he must do is pay the bar about £4, and take her away. He then agrees a price with the girl for sex - but a more popular arrangement is not a one-off transaction but instead the beginning of what the men laughably refer to as a "relationship". For the duration of his holiday, the girl becomes his "girlfriend". And so Chaweng is a resort town full of largely fat and unattractive European men driving around on mopeds with beautiful young women on the back. They are not doing anything sordid, they will tell you, like paying a poor, third-world prostitute to have sex with them. They are having a relationship! They buy lots of things for their girlfriend, of course, and generously give her money "for her family", but it has nothing to do with money. And the men strut about, beaming like little boys at Christmas, effortlessly able to enjoy the delusion, and having the time of their lives. There are a lot of men in Koh Samui. An astonishing number, actually, and the ones too embarrassed to enter into the "girlfriend" pretence during the day generally find themselves able to suspend disbelief by 3am, after 14 pints, so the clubs are full of alluring freelance girls dancing hopefully. Their stamina is prodigious, and their smile never fades, although many of them are assisted by small pills which the Thais call Yabba, a kind of nuclear amphetamine which, if smoked in silver foil, will keep you going forever. There are other things to do on Koh Samui besides pay women for sex. There is elephant trekking, and diving, and there are waterfalls to visit, and temples to see, and all the bars show European football on TV, and the restaurants screen movies you can watch while you eat. If you didn't manage enough shopping in Bangkok, you can buy more fake designer watches and bags and clothes, and you can haggle to your heart's desire, bellowing and waving your arms about over a matter of 10 or 20 pence, and the Thais will accommodate all these activities smilingly. You can get so drunk you drive your moped smack into an old woman's kebab stall, and she will smile gracefully and wave it away as nothing as she inspects the damage. And you can do all of this at a cost so small, it makes you feel like a king. What you cannot do, of course, is ever know that a smile on Koh Samui is real. The smiles on the faces of the Western men mauling bar girls are real enough - but even if you never grope a bar girl, never invest in a "girlfriend", never crash your moped into an old woman, never scream at a shopkeeper over 20 pence, you would have to be supremely thoughtless or arrogant to assume that the Thai smiling at you is smiling because he or she likes you and not your traveller's cheques. People come to Thailand because it makes them feel rich - and, just like rich people, most of them behave badly. But, also like rich people, they can never trust the motives of others' friendliness. This doesn't appear to bother too many Westerners here, it must be said. But if you don't care to feel like a whore's client for a fortnight, you might come to find it bothers you a lot. The practicals British Airways (0345 222111), Qantas (0345 747767) and THAI (020 74999113) fly direct to Bangkok from London. Expect to pay around £500 for a direct flight. Cheaper flights mat be available through a consolidator, such as Trailfinders (020 79383366), Quest Worldwide(020 8547 3322) or Bridge the World (020 79110900). There are 14 flights a day from Bangkok to Koh Samui with Bangkok Airways - buy tickets from teh airport on 00 66 425029 for around £50. More info from www.tourismthailand.org

fields.headline: Tales from the tabs
fields.trailText: ARSENAL, CHELSEA JOIN DUTCH RACE
fields.body:
ARSENAL, CHELSEA JOIN DUTCH RACE

PSV have told Leeds, Arsenal and Chelsea to make offers of no less than £30m for genius striker Ruud van Nistelrooy - he's up for grabs this summer.

SPURS CHASING £2M MYKLAND

Tottenham have made a £2m approach for Norwegian Panathinaikos star Erik Mykland. The bearded 28-year-old is 'desperate' to move to London.

AND THE REST Brazilian midfielder Felipe is chasing a move to Old Trafford after his on-off switch to Roma fell through: 'Man United are a great football club with great players - I like the way they attack. It's my job to attack too.' Liverpool have refused to pay £5m for Bolton's Eidur Gudjohnsen, but a deal for Moroccan striker Kamel Ouejdide could go through; Arsenal have blocked an attempt by Atletico Madrid to snatch Emmanuel Petit; Ipswich are set to sign Newcastle keeper Shay Given as replacement for Chelsea-bound Richard Wright; Tottenham are new favourites to land Chris Sutton; Leicester have ruled out a move for Crewe's Rodney Jack; Coventry are lining-up a £1m deal for Hull City's highly-rated midfielder Theodore Whitmore; Sunderland have made Southampton's James Beattie their number one target; Newcastle have postponed a deal for Paraguayan prodigy Diego Gavilan until the summer, but may move again for Argentinian international Christian Bassedas; Birmingham boss Trevor Francis is watching Derby's Deon Burton; Portsmouth have taken Arsenal's Paolo Vernazza on a three month loan; Fulham have completed a £650,000 move for Chelsea's Bjarne Goldbaek; Wimbledon are watching Danish international Peter Moller; Injury-hit West Ham are ready to take Dean Holdsworth from Bolton on loan; Xavier Gravelaine's move from Watford to Marseille has collapsed; Sheffield Wednesday are chasing Dutch goalie Arno Van Zwam; and Becks has bought baby Brooklyn a £2,000 bottle holder.

fields.headline: Dome roamin'
fields.standfirst:
Abstract, unfocused and naff. Sculptor Tom Allan finds very little to celebrate in the Millennium Dome
The millennium: special report
fields.trailText: Abstract, unfocused and naff. Sculptor Tom Allan finds very little to celebrate in the Millennium Dome.
fields.body:
Our first sight of a dome in London came as our coach passed the Regents Park mosque - a building with a definite sense of identity. We were heading for a more dubious structure: the Millennium Dome. A special British party to celebrate the year 2000AD? It reminds me of Alan Jackson's short poem, A Young Politician Looks at the Moon: "What a lovely moon./And it's in the constituency too!"

The home of GMT has no relevance to events in Roman Palestine, yet I was keen to see what form the celebration would take, and how it would treat sculpture. The prospect of a mid-winter break at the four-star Holiday Inn was also persuasive.

The Richard Rogers' Dome is a magnificent venue - it harmonises with its surroundings, as do the "outbuildings", especially the Pier and the Pavilion. But what is being celebrated seems at first to be nothing more than the British passion for queuing. On the first normal Saturday of the year, all zones that looked even vaguely interesting were queued out of sight. Queues snaked among queues and we spoke to queuers who didn't know what they were queuing to see.

I adopted a selective agenda, which you'd be well advised to do since it's impossible to see even half of the Dome in a day. The New Millennium Dome Experience Company should obviously introduce a season ticket. Another obstacle was the lack of clear guidance. The preview leaflet made the cut-away Dome look like a pizza with exotic toppings. And it was about as useful as a pizza for locating things.

In fact, walking round the perimeter to see the outdoor sculptures turned out to be the best part of the day in many ways. The riverside is a great location for an event of this kind and, although it hasn't been fully exploited, it could rival Glasgow's Garden Festival site, with more landscaping and planning. The broad swell of the Thames is a superb elemental backdrop.

Anthony Gormley's Quantum Cloud erupts like a static explosion, a humanistic totem of angled metal, beside the Pier. According to the Piermaster, many of its sections were assembled the wrong way round, which may explain why the figure within is hard to spot. Its fascination is in the changing shape from each angle, and it is certainly art that people can relate to, even though it's "abstract" and challenging.

Moored alongside the Dome is what at first appears to be a tanker. You see only the bridge, then as you approach you realise that the bridge is all there is. Or rather, it is a complete section of the boat, top to bottom, sliced straight down through the funnel and in front of the bridge, by Richard Wilson, entitled Slice of Reality. Is this all the reality we can bear?

The huge open space between this and the Dome is occupied by one sculpture only, a large triple form in glassfibre, looking like a pile of old car wheels, a misshapen spinning-top, a deformed crankshaft, or three piles of dirty dishes. It is perhaps rescued by its plinth, and the space between its components: people love having their photo taken there.

As you move indoors, the Faith Zone attracts by having no queue. Some of its presentation is questionable: who is going to read the little scrolls of "prayers for the millennium" that children intently write and push into metal waste bins? Who is the woman between Gwynedd and Martin Luther King? She looks like Margaret Thatcher, but is Barbara Castle. Why? The central feature of this zone, however, puts questions to rest: James Turrell's Night Rain, a light space, is like an illuminated walk-in Mark Rothko, and evokes either a contented return to the womb, or contemplation of interstellar space.

The adjacent Mind Zone, however, is less focused. I had been anticipating something special in the Crouching Boy sculpture. He is large and skilfully realistic, with perhaps some feeling and expressiveness. But he is still a let-down. As they passed, some youths made farting noises, unfortunately apt for the squatting posture.

The rest of this zone was frustrating. The Richard Deacon overhanging structure - interlinked wooden shapes suggesting the folds of the brain, under the "largest unsupported cantilever building in Europe" - show how much effort and expense have been lavished here. Suffocating in spaces crammed with crowds, we escaped via the fire exit.

Some of the zone structures could themselves be viewed as sculpture, and are interesting shapes. The cerise stalagmites of Our Town Stage stretch dramatically for the ceiling. The Rest Zone is a simple but effective idea, a rainbow striped vertically. Journey looks exciting, though brutal - a tank, battleship, or space-rocket, with lights flashing the whole length.

The remainder are poor: Talk conveys the feeling of a particularly boring office; Timekeepers of the Millennium is literally hellish - a Heath Robinson caged structure where people fight a strange, pointless battle, shuffling through like obedient cannon-fodder, to be bombarded with missiles and inane electronic voices, yet queuing for hours for the privilege.

Many zones look anonymous, though they may contain wonders. But you can't escape the Body. Perhaps it's so popular because it's immediately recognisable, and people have heard some of the hype about its contents. As a sculpture, though, it strikes me as more a balloon than a human figure. It is bulbous and pink, a feat of engineering perhaps, but appallingly naff.

Maybe ambiguity and split personality were forced on it, but that's no excuse. A strange silver homunculus is trapped in a spinning perspex globe near the breast of the giant. Rays of light emanating from this feature appear comically to make possible erogenous areas of the Body vibrate. An accident, but the only amusing thing about this monstrous overblown figure. Sadly, there is no Erogenous Zone in the Dome.

What finally gave us the nearest thing to a Wow Factor were two very different contributions. First a live entertainment, a robot interacting with spectators on the concourse, approaching in apparent friendship, then dousing you with water. All ages were enthralled, and the party almost came to life. Looking like a homemade R2D2, it was the work of Matthew Pullen, who was controlling it surreptitiously from the sidelines. Much more of this kind of lively creativity would give the Dome a boost.

The other showstopper has to be Gerald Scarfe, who, tucked away in the self-satisfied Self-Portrait zone, whipped the rug out from under all the dubious political posturings. The British are "creative, honourable, and brave", says the pompous wall-slogan as you enter. But Scarfe shows that we are also the Racist, the Thug, the Couch Potato; a nation where the ordinary person is crushed under tiers of Fat Cat, egotistic Politician, unbelieving Cleric, repressive and vindictive Judge - like the peasant under the Ancien Regime.

British Comedy is a raucously laughing toilet-pan-headed figure, constructed out of all the stock-in-trade jokes - condom, lavatory-brush, tits, dropped trousers, phallic sausage. We are ruled by Traditional Cool Britannia, a handbag-toting royal lion with Tony Blair as a posturing, grinning unicorn. This is all swingeing satire, yet oddly heartening, the most encouraging statement about Britain in the place.

The day before, we had visited the British Museum to see the Elgin Marbles. An honourable millennial gesture would have been for Britain to return these pillaged treasures to Athens. I wondered if the Dome would even minimally approach the grandeur of the Parthenon as a national statement. In the next room at the museum, the superhuman statues of Rameses evoked Shelley's sonnet about vanished rulers with misapprehensions of their own significance. At least the inclusion of Scarfe shows that the Dome is not entirely the work of an Ozymandelson of Greenwich. We can look on Scarfe's works, and not despair, just yet.

The practicals

Tom Allan booked a Millennium Dome Weekend with Leisuretime (0990 6606070). Two nights B&B at the Holiday Inn, Nelson Dock, costs £119 per person, including a Dome ticket. A retrun flight fromn Glasgow to Luton costs £80pp

fields.headline: Rites of spring
fields.standfirst: Halki is known for its hushed, slightly weird atmosphere. Ben Mallalieu uncovers some dark secrets
fields.trailText: Halki is known for its hushed, slightly weird atmosphere. Ben Mallalieu uncovers some dark secrets.
fields.body:
I met Judas on the quay. He was sitting defiantly, all alone at a table with his back to the sea. He wore a straw hat, dark glasses, yellow washing-up gloves and a pale jacket, much too tight.

Someone had put a can of Heineken in his hand and an unlit cigar in his mouth. It was better unlit as his body was stuffed with straw and gunpowder. He looked as though he was trying to brazen it out, but it was clear the game was up.

He was not the first to have sat by the taverna, waiting for the men to drag him away and hang him from the tree by the church. During the war, a group of British paratroopers were captured on Halki's satellite island, Alimnia, and shot as spies. The Gestapo exacted their usual reprisals on the civilian population, and, after the war, collaborators must have suffered a similar fate.

Halki is a small arid rock, only an hour on the ferry from Rhodes. The guidebooks call it an 'unspoilt island', but the reality has been 2,000 years of destruction and betrayal at the hands of Romans, Arabs, Turks, pirates, Italians and Germans, and the experience has left deep scars in the island's psyche.

All islands are slightly peculiar. Cut off from the mainstream, they evolve in strange directions, with their own peculiar customs and a collective memory that stretches back further than in mainland communities. Greek islands are more peculiar than most, with what John Fowles called their 'sinister-fascinating, Circe-like quality'. And even by the standards of most Greek islands, Halki is decidedly odd. The Lonely Planet guide mentions its 'hushed, slightly weird atmosphere', which is putting it mildly.

It doesn't get mentioned in the history books, and no one stopped off here on their way back from Troy. There was once a marble acropolis on the top of the hill, but the crusaders pulled it down and used the stone to build a castle, itself now a ruin. Occasionally, you can see pieces of older stone in the neoclassical villas round the harbour, and lying in an alleyway, half hidden among the daisies, is a fragment of marble with a bas-relief of Apollo Helios.

The sponge industry led to a brief prosperity in the 19th century, but then a virus killed the sponges and the island began to die. The population dwindled from more than 4,000 in the last century to fewer than 300. The men of the island are not, at first sight, an attractive lot. Spoilt as children and macho as adults, it is only in old age, when the testosterone has dropped below the radioactive level, that they become accessible human beings. Once, late at night, I couldn't find my five-year-old son and went down to the harbour to see him chatting earnestly in a cafe with a group of old men. They were sitting round in a circle nodding their heads wisely. I can't imagine what they were talking about.

The women are a different matter: disconcertingly pretty when young, although probably best treated with care if you value your life. In old age, even after a lifetime of largely unappreciated toil, they still have a sense of fun.

In the days before Easter, the island is full of the the sound of bleating lambs. On Saturday, the noise stops and, every time you turn a corner, you find an animal being skinned and dismem bered for the Sunday feast.

At night, islanders parade round the town banging on the doors to drive away demons. You could be woken up at 3am by someone crowing like a cock just outside your window. You may think this is a quaint example of local colour. Or possibly not.

On Easter Sunday, even the island's drunks put on suits and go to the church and sit among the candles, icons, gilt and clouds of incense. At the end of a seriously long service, the priest announces: 'The Lord is risen,' and you go out blinking into the sunlight where Judas is hanging from a makeshift scaffold.

Someone has pinned a 5,000 drachma note to the front of his jacket and placed a sheet of corrugated iron under his feet to protect the pebble mosaic. The men of the island throw lighted torches at his body until he catches fire and explodes.

This is not a piece of bonfire-night jollity: the crowd is silent, sombre and deadly serious. There is an unmistakable undercurrent of paganism: Tammuz/ Adonis, the god who dies each year and whose rebirth brings life to the island and fertility to the crops. Only the names have been changed. Judas is not just the betrayer of Jesus. He is the Lord's dark twin, his doppelgänger, his secret sharer, consigned to take his place in the Underworld for the duration.

At some point, the ominous thought occurs to you that, not that long ago, it was not an effigy but a real person who was sacrificed.

One afternoon, I sat in the shade of the taverna in the bay by the beach, drinking retsina with an old man called Pepe. He told me in broken English the story of how once - I couldn't make out when - the islanders had been playing by the beach when pirates arrived unnoticed and took away all their women.

He said that, years later, the 'spongimen' went off to Egypt to hunt the 'spongi', and there they found the women and brought them home and built the small shrine at the edge of the bay as an act of thanksgiving.

It might have happened 400 years ago but, from the way Pepe spoke, it was still a painful memory.

It sounded like something from Edward Lear: spongimen, the Yonghy-Bonghy-Bo, the Dong with the Luminous Nose searching for his lost Jumbly love. I wondered if Lear ever made it to Halki on his travels, but the same story could be told on many Greek islands, although without the happy ending.

I wanted to ask Pepe about the war, and particularly the British paratroopers. I had heard that their death warrants were signed by someone who later earned a worldwide reputation as a statesman.

I asked what it was like here during the occupation, but it seemed as though he hadn't heard. After a long pause, he said, staring fixedly out into the bay: 'We like the British. If you were German or Italian, I would not be sitting here.' And that was all he was going to say.

I tried to fish it out with a stick, but it kept slipping off. My wife, who is clearly much braver than I am, was going to pick it up with her hands until I dissuaded her: it was hooped yellow and black, colours that do not usually signify a benevolent disposition, and even in death, it was not something to treat lightly. After many failed attempts, I had nearly lifted it clear of the water, when it suddenly came back to life and sank its teeth deep into the stick.

We didn't go swimming that day.

2 No pizza parlours. Taverna food is high-quality, authentic and cheap.

3 No cars. Although you could be run down by a moped.

4 No watersports. The view from the beach taverna hasn't changed in centuries.

5 No water. Supplies have to be shipped in once a week by tanker, so no major tourist developments are likely.

fields.headline: Village people
fields.standfirst: Entrepreneur Rocco Forte built his empire from budget hotels and motorway services. Then he created a fantasy in the Med for the seriously rich.  Sarah Boseley enjoys life in the slow lane
fields.trailText: Entrepreneur Rocco Forte built his empire from budget hotels and motorway services. Then he created a fantasy in the Med for the seriously rich. Sarah Boseley enjoys life in the slow lane.
fields.body:
It is five in the afternoon and the heat of the day is beginning to wane. Nothing moves. There is perfect quiet around the low white villas dotted among palms and thick sub-tropical greenery. Figures emerge from the nearest bungalow a little distance down the red-brick path, but too far away to hear voices. Then a small chinking sound begins, and a black-and-white-clad waiter comes into view, carrying buckets of chilled wine and trays of canapes to every patio.

It feels like a Merchant-Ivory impression of India under the Raj, except it's not India. This is a corner of Sardinia that is not even like Sardinia. It is an extraordinary hedonistic haven offering sanctuary to the stressed and relaxation to the rich - a family resort built by Rocco Forte, the Italian entrepreneur who brought budget hotels to the M1 but let his imagination and his purse strings go in this corner of the Mediterranean.

"Welcome to paradise," said the courier as the coach turned through the gates of Forte Village. It is an extravagant claim, but those who built the place and the hundreds who run it do their absolute best to justify it. There are teams of hard-working young men painting kerbstones with all the earnestness of the playing-card soldiers whose roses were the wrong colour in Alice in Wonderland. The red-brick roads are scrubbed daily. The towels seem to be changed more often than that. It was only after three or four days of wandering through lush vegetation, watered every morning by sprinkler systems set in the grass, and sitting half naked in the warm evenings on the patio that we realised we had not seen, let alone been bitten by, a mosquito. Correction - we had not even seen an insect.

There are five hotels here, each a cluster of bungalows, artfully positioned with their own space, light, greenery and copious bougainvillea. The colours are off-white, terracotta and sun-bleached pinks. Inside they are air-conditioned and seriously tasteful. Immaculate bathrooms have powershowers, and thick pink towelling robes are provided. Pink figures proliferate morning and evening, wandering in and out of bungalows, but when everybody's got the right idea, who cares about uniformity?

Much of the Sardinian coastline is sunbaked sand and rock, but Forte Village was built in natural woodland. Some of the trees are huge. It has a long beach to itself, which is less beautiful than some of the white sands and brilliant turquoise waters we found elsewhere, but many of the visitors have come for sport rather than contemplation.

For the seriously pampered, there is the Therme del Parco health and beauty spa, just a stroll away through the palms. For the seriously sporty, there are 17 tennis courts, sailing, windsurfing, water-skiing, scuba-diving and all the other wet sports imaginable. There are several huge swimming pools with chutes and fountains. There is volleyball, five-a-side football, aerobics and a go-kart track, while horse riding and golf are a short excursion away.

The seriously rich come here. No money changes hands - nothing so vulgar or inconvenient. You have a plastic card for the duration. By the end of a week or two, you can have clocked up a seriously large bill, even though dinner, bed and breakfast are all in. But within this little paradise, the only shops are designer boutiques that open around the entertainment in the central piazza every evening.

You pick up a small bottle of water from the minibar in your room for £3. You buy lunch from a restaurant by the beach - another £3 each for the cheapest sandwich, but many more sit down to a midday meal. One of the less-expensive Sardinian wines at your five-star restaurant in the evening is £20. And that's before you've paid for your water-skiing.

The children's club, Funny Joe's, is open all day. It has a large adventure playground expanse to itself, separated from the beach by a hedge. The staff take the children around the whole village on a small train, go to the pools and play games on the beach. They are liable to turn up at your breakfast table, dressed in costumes and masks to beguile the reluctant tot into having fun with them and leaving the parents in peace.

The entertainment was not everybody's glass of chianti - it was a bit strident, a bit too happy-camperish for our taste. But there were a lot of people to please, and plenty of warm scented air to enjoy if you wanted peace, with karting and bowling and a nightclub into the early hours for those who wanted something heavier.

We lingered long over our dinner. It was worth it. Forte Village is a gastronome's delight. To be shown to the table at the Belvedere at the end of the balcony nearest the sea, with the pines below and the mountains behind, was sheer joy.

The staff could not have been more delightful, indulging children's demands for dishes that were not on the menu ("I'll go and ask the chef..."). Oysters arrived without asking, and there were at least four courses to every meal. Everything was fresh and exquisitely presented. It made you feel bad not to be able to eat it all, but we never managed it.

The Belvedere was delight fully peaceful but surprisingly empty. Busier was the huge open-air self-service buffet called the Cavalieri, where live music pounded and you could fill your plate a hundred times over with hot or cold anything you can imagine - lobsters and steaks with tables piled high with profiteroles and gateaux. And there is free wine on the tables for the grown-ups.

There are plenty of other restaurants to choose - Brazilian, Mexican, Thai, Lebanese, Sicilian and a fish restaurant by the sea. In a week, I had eaten more than my stomach was happy with. The huge amount of conspicuous waste - the laden buffet tables nobody was interested in - also gave me a slight feeling of discomfort.

The warmth, comfort and peace were fantastic, but wandering down the red paths, moving out of the way of a small, humming electric car carrying eager domestic servants to change more sheets, I was reminded of the TV series The Prisoner, set in that other fantasy village, Portmeirion on the Welsh coast. The sense of unreality was the same - the feeling of the gilded cage. But I have to say, I didn't notice anybody trying to escape, pursued by an outsize rubber ball.

The practicals

Prices at Forte Village start from £2577 for two adults and two children (aged between 2-11) staying for one week on half board in one double and one twin room. This covers children's club, watersports, return flights from Heathrow or Gatwick and transfers. Details from Magic of Italy on 020 87487575.

fields.headline: Fjord escort
fields.standfirst: The lifeline of the fjords has been relaunched for tourists. Nigel Fountain heads north
fields.trailText: The lifeline of the fjords has been relaunched for tourists. Nigel Fountain heads north.
fields.body:
One Saturday lunchtime in Alesund, I sat on a stone bench between the austere old woman, Sildekona, and the young sailor. The old woman was hunched, grey, preoccupied, back turned from the the sea, taking fish from a barrel. The sailor stared out across a narrow waterway.

The waterway was dominated by splendid two-storey apartment houses and even more splendid yachts and motor-cruisers. From atop a shopping-mall bandstand, a younger Teresa Gorman-lookalike was earning rapturous murmurs and muffled applause. The local radio station's Wet T-shirt competition was underway by the harbour. The Norwegians are indeed a hardy lot; the temperature was struggling to make 50F.

Not that Sildekona, or the young sailor knew about that; they were unmoving stone statues, providing the romance that comes to commerce after its practice has ended.

Norway's northern coastal towns are full of statues, but I never found the one I was after. That was of the late Kaiser, a gift from a land whose romantic dreams and nightmares once hugely affected Norway. Wilhelm holidayed in 1/8Alesund. He loved the fjords and, after the town was accidentally burned down in 1904, he gave generously to its fine art-nouveau rebuilding.

More usual choices for the plinth treatment are Sildenkona's kin, the common fisherfolk. The monuments are usually women, grouped in socialist-realist style, eyes fixed across sounds, beyond mountains, out to sea; waiting for fishermen to return, waiting for food, waiting through winter darkness for the sun.

Steam changed their world completely. In July 1893, Captain Richard With, aboard the Vesteraalen, set off from Trondheim for Hammerfest. The regular Hurtigruten - the Norwegian coastal steamer - was born. A postal service that could take five months suddenly took five days. By 1898, the ships were starting from Bergen, by 1914 they had reached as far north as Kirkenes, border of the Russian empire.

Eighty-five years later, that was my route, 2,400km, a distance greater than London to Warsaw, on the diesel-powered, computer-guided Polarlys, past towns and villages and settlements, gliding between mountains, past the country's second largest glacier, the Svartisen, into the Arctic Circle and on to Kirkenes, about which I had enjoyed Harry Palmer-style fantasies, but which was to prove an anti-climax.

There was a rust-encrusted freighter out of nearby Murmansk in the harbour, a vast and recently-closed open-cast iron-ore mine-cum-wasteland and, at the crossing with Yeltsin's kleptocracy, a poignant sign. No workers of the world featured, instead 'No admittance,' it proclaimed, 'except on business.'

The Hurtigruten that was the lifeblood of the coastal civilisation has itself changed too. Huge in the 1930s, decimated in the war, booming in the 1950s, by the end of the 1980s it was losing money. From the deck of Polarlys - one of 11 Hurtigruten ships - its problem was evident all along that coast: bridges, splendid, elegant pay-offs from Norway's oil money, wisely, publicly invested by prudent governments (see Thatcher, M). Structures that leap headlands and turn islands into suburbs arc over the Polarlys, and make a coastal drive to Kirkenes a scenic, if seasonal possibility. So, the service was revamped and marketed as 'the world's most beautiful sea voyage'.

Bergen is splendid, Trond heim boasts a fine cathedral, the setting of Tromso is magnificent, Saturday night in Henningsvaer in the Lofoten Islands is starkly beautiful with its boulevards of water - if apparently devoid of population - but the Polarlys's schedule meant that the time I spent in any of them was brief.

It did not rain all the time. But it certainly rained in Risohamn. A market-day band played Rhythm of the Rain and two couples danced in a state of grace.

I got lost in the seascape. The first night, the water was dark green, the sky overcast. Past Alesund, at Molde, the sea was the colour of diamond slate, the distant mountains were covered in snow. It was the stuff of 19th-century German romantic painters, Caspar David Friedrich's solitary dreamer far away on the peaks.

One afternoon, beyond Trondheim, with the sea fluorescent green, the blue sky filled with Magritte dream clouds, but by then I was slipping out of the 20th century and scratching around in my memory junkyard of Norse myth. No wonder the Kaiser headed up here, I thought, the neurotic warlord dreamt of a watery path to Valhalla, or perhaps that he would just fall off the edge of the world, and indeed he did.

The sun came out at Stamsund, the first stop in Lofoten. That coast, that sea, was the location for violent pay-offs on 19th-century romantics, provided by that admirer of Friedrich, Adolf Hitler, sometime painter, the romantic as psychopath. Those other great grey behemoths, the Tirpitz and the Scharnhorst went to their doom having sought sanctuary amid the mists and crags of Aaltfjord. And in 1944, the Nazi general in northern Norway created Gôtterdâmmerung. He burned down every settlement from Tana to Lyngenlinja creating, in that Arctic winter, 75,000 refugees.

One night in the Lofotens, close to midnight, the Polarlys performed its party piece. It edged up the almost vertical sides of Trollfjord, plunging into darkness, mists, mountains and upended rock formations, leaving whirlpools in its wake. It was magnificent. It enticed a large crowd on to the bow. There we, inhabitants of the new post-romantic Europe, stood in wonder, lone millennarial dreamers all, with only ancient gods, diesel engines and Japanese digital cameras breaking the silence.

That was of the late Kaiser, a gift from a land whose romantic dreams and nightmares once hugely affected Norway. Wilhelm holidayed in 1/8Alesund. He loved the fjords and, after the town was accidentally burned down in 1904, he gave generously to its fine art-nouveau rebuilding. More usual choices for the plinth treatment are Sildenkona's kin, the common fisherfolk. The monuments are usually women, grouped in socialist-realist style, eyes fixed across sounds, beyond mountains, out to sea; waiting for fishermen to return, waiting for food, waiting through winter darkness for the sun. Steam changed their world completely. In July 1893, Captain Richard With, aboard the Vesteraalen, set off from Trondheim for Hammerfest. The regular Hurtigruten - the Norwegian coastal steamer - was born. A postal service that could take five months suddenly took five days. By 1898, the ships were starting from Bergen, by 1914 they had reached as far north as Kirkenes, border of the Russian empire. Eighty-five years later, that was my route, 2,400km, a distance greater than London to Warsaw, on the diesel-powered, computer-guided Polarlys, past towns and villages and settlements, gliding between mountains, past the country's second largest glacier, the Svartisen, into the Arctic Circle and on to Kirkenes, about which I had enjoyed Harry Palmer-style fantasies, but which was to prove an anti-climax. There was a rust-encrusted freighter out of nearby Murmansk in the harbour, a vast and recently-closed open-cast iron-ore mine-cum-wasteland and, at the crossing with Yeltsin's kleptocracy, a poignant sign. No workers of the world featured, instead 'No admittance,' it proclaimed, 'except on business.' The Hurtigruten that was the lifeblood of the coastal civilisation has itself changed too. Huge in the 1930s, decimated in the war, booming in the 1950s, by the end of the 1980s it was losing money. From the deck of Polarlys - one of 11 Hurtigruten ships - its problem was evident all along that coast: bridges, splendid, elegant pay-offs from Norway's oil money, wisely, publicly invested by prudent governments (see Thatcher, M). Structures that leap headlands and turn islands into suburbs arc over the Polarlys, and make a coastal drive to Kirkenes a scenic, if seasonal possibility. So, the service was revamped and marketed as 'the world's most beautiful sea voyage'. Bergen is splendid, Trond heim boasts a fine cathedral, the setting of Tromso is magnificent, Saturday night in Henningsvaer in the Lofoten Islands is starkly beautiful with its boulevards of water - if apparently devoid of population - but the Polarlys's schedule meant that the time I spent in any of them was brief. It did not rain all the time. But it certainly rained in Risohamn. A market-day band played Rhythm of the Rain and two couples danced in a state of grace. I got lost in the seascape. The first night, the water was dark green, the sky overcast. Past Alesund, at Molde, the sea was the colour of diamond slate, the distant mountains were covered in snow. It was the stuff of 19th-century German romantic painters, Caspar David Friedrich's solitary dreamer far away on the peaks. One afternoon, beyond Trondheim, with the sea fluorescent green, the blue sky filled with Magritte dream clouds, but by then I was slipping out of the 20th century and scratching around in my memory junkyard of Norse myth. No wonder the Kaiser headed up here, I thought, the neurotic warlord dreamt of a watery path to Valhalla, or perhaps that he would just fall off the edge of the world, and indeed he did. The sun came out at Stamsund, the first stop in Lofoten. That coast, that sea, was the location for violent pay-offs on 19th-century romantics, provided by that admirer of Friedrich, Adolf Hitler, sometime painter, the romantic as psychopath. Those other great grey behemoths, the Tirpitz and the Scharnhorst went to their doom having sought sanctuary amid the mists and crags of Aaltfjord. And in 1944, the Nazi general in northern Norway created Gôtterdâmmerung. He burned down every settlement from Tana to Lyngenlinja creating, in that Arctic winter, 75,000 refugees. One night in the Lofotens, close to midnight, the Polarlys performed its party piece. It edged up the almost vertical sides of Trollfjord, plunging into darkness, mists, mountains and upended rock formations, leaving whirlpools in its wake. It was magnificent. It enticed a large crowd on to the bow. There we, inhabitants of the new post-romantic Europe, stood in wonder, lone millennarial dreamers all, with only ancient gods, diesel engines and Japanese digital cameras breaking the silence.

webTitle: Set the controls for the heart of the sun

fields.headline: Set the controls for the heart of the sun
fields.trailText: Winter breaks: where to go.
fields.body:
Morocco

Marrakesh may only be three hours from London, but you will suddenly find yourself thrown into an exotic feast of colour, sounds and scents. It's perfect for a weekend break but, if you have more time, head to the desert at Erfoud, where Lawrence of Arabia and The Mummy were filmed among the rippling Merzouga sand dunes. Across a plain criss-crossed by dirt tracks, Chez Michel appears like an oasis, the only colour in a barren landscape. It has a few simple rooms and is frequented by ambassadors to Rabat. A double room at Chez Michel costs £40 per night.
Cadogan Holidays 023808 28303
Best of Morocco 01380 828533
Morocco Made to Measure 0171-235 2110

Mexico

Fly to Cancun, and try to ignore the eyesore of tourism, great towers of concrete hiding the Caribbean sea. Immediately take the rickety ferry boat to Isla Mujeres and paradise. The small island has been inhabited since pre-Columbian times and still maintains the culture of its Mayan past. It is an excellent base for exploring the Mayan cities of the Yucatan. Stay at the romantic Na Balam Beach hotel, which is small - 31 rooms - but has extensive grounds and a long stretch of private beach with hammocks among the palm trees. A double room costs £85 per night.
Trips Worldwide 0117 987 2626

Bermuda

For a touch of colonial life with moderate temperatures (20C in February) and a flying time of seven hours from Britain, Bermuda offers rural England in the sun. The best accommodation are traditional Bermudan cottages. One of the best is Cambridge Beaches, a remote resort on the western tip of Bermuda attracting couples into serious hedonism. It has the rare combination of stunning private beaches, a state-of-the-art spa and good food. There's tennis, croquet, bicycles, a marina and private dock. For a romantic one-off, this is the place to get out your credit card and don't think about the bill until later. Cambridge Beaches' rooms start at £280 per night for a garden room including breakfast and dinner for two people.
Lotus Supertravel 0171-962 9494
Prestige 01425 480400

The Canaries

Guaranteed sun and favourable prices have made the Canaries the first port of call for Brits who want winter basking. The big tour operators are there en masse with bargain price breaks starting from £250 or less for seven nights, with half-term being very busy indeed. All the main islands - Lanzarote, Gran Canaria, Tenerife and Fuerteventura - offer very different holidays and landscapes. Tenerife, for example, which has some of the least enticing beaches, has the spectacular Mount Teide National Park with stunning scenery and walks. For complete isolation try the small Hotel Punta Grande on El Hierro (00 34 922 559081, £732 per night for a double room).
Virgin Sun 01293 432100
Lanzarote Leisure 0181-449 7441

Dubai

This is the destination for a quick winter fix. Dubai is the land of beach resorts and all-inclusive packages. If you want to play golf and swan around in luxury, the newly-opened Royal Mirage, opposite the Emirates Golf Club, will impress. It was originally an Arabian fortress and has been gutted and remodelled to five-star perfection. A deluxe room at the Royal Mirage costs £928 per person for five nights, including flights.
Elegant Resorts 0870 33 33 390
Magic of the Orient 01293 537700.

fields.headline: The great turtle race
fields.standfirst: It's standing room only on Ostional beach. It's not tourists fighting for space but half a million turtles looking for somewhere to lay their eggs. Matthew Brace witnesses one of the great mysteries of the sea
fields.trailText: It's standing room only on Ostional beach. It's not tourists fighting for space but half a million turtles looking for somewhere to lay their eggs. Matthew Brace witnesses one of the great mysteries of the sea
fields.body:
A black-sand beach on the Pacific coast of the Central American isthmus hosts a rarely-seen biological wonder. For it to occur, the moon must be in its third quarter, on the wane, the tides high and the sand warm enough to incubate life beneath its surface. Only when the natural elements are so aligned - for five days between November and January - will small heads begin appearing out of the crashing surf. A couple at first, then scores, then hundreds, then so many it seems like an invasion.

Prompted by some secret signal that the world's most distinguished marine biologists and naturalists have yet to fathom, up to half a million female Olive Ridley turtles stumble out of the waves, heave themselves up the beach, dig awkwardly with their inadequate flippers, lay 40 or more eggs and then make their way back to the ocean, exhausted.

Ostional in Costa Rica is one of only four beaches where an 'arribada' (or arrival) of this magnitude happens. The others are in India, Mexico and another Costa Rican beach a few miles north towards Nicaragua, although that has all but been abandoned by the turtles in favour of Ostional. That this natural wonder occurs in Costa Rica is no surprise given the country's phenomenal diversity - 850 species of bird, more than 160 species of snake and a number of butterflies. Staggering, as it is only the size of Scotland.

Costa Rica is the southern extent for many northern species and the northern extent for those from the southern hemisphere - the ecological bridge of the Americas. The tropical rainforests and rice fields of the lowlands harbour deadly terciopelo (or fer-de-lance) snakes, and iridescent blue morpho butterflies as big as an out-stretched hand.

A few thousand feet up lie cloud forests, permanently draped in mist, where toucans shelter from the drizzle under papaya leaves. One evening, I left my wooden cabin in the Ostional village not long after the sun had nose-dived into the Pacific and hit the beach for my first long night.

By dawn, I had trudged the 5km stretch of beach more than once for a tally of only two short turtle tracks. A couple had emerged, realised the moon was too large or the tide too low, turned on their flippers and headed back to sea. Maybe this was the advance guard, the scouts who check the state of the beach and report back. Such a hypothesis is as good as any other because we really don't know how the arribada is organised.

The turtles must know that mass-laying gives their species a better chance of survival, but as to the timing and co-ordination - those secrets are still locked away deep beneath the oceans. One Ostional turtle was fitted with a transmitter in a bid to find out how far they migrate to lay here. She swam more than 2,500 miles into the ocean before the trackers lost her signal.

My second night yielded more tracks and on the third there was no question the arribada was in full swing. I sat on a driftwood log a half-mile north of the village at midnight, beneath a rising moon, pointed myself out to sea and waited. The woods behind me were aglow with fireflies and the sky was full of stars as a multitude of Olive Ridley turtles began to flood the beach.

Scores of them shambled past me, their shells squeaking as they rubbed against the leather of my boots. They crashed into one another, clambering over each other's backs and covering each other with sand. They dug determinedly, flicking flipperfuls of sand over my trousers and into my hair and the top pockets of my shirt.

Then they patted down the sand to seal their precious cargo by raising their hefty bulk on one flipper and letting it thump down on the sand with a thud. Their drumming reverberated along the beach.

Dawn came quickly. The pale light revealed a beach so churned it looked as if gangs of roughnecks had held an illegal stock-car race. The pungent stench of eggs had lured flocks of black-headed vultures from miles away. They swooped in from the forests to the south, silhouetted against a watery sky. Silently, they wheeled above the beach, like sharks circling prey, and dropped en masse to feast on the eggs.

Then came the villagers. A crocodile of people, newly awake, walked through the salt spray mist along the shore carrying small net bags. For the first two dawns of the arribada, locals can dig up a million eggs under an annual, temporary suspension of the international ban on turtle-egg taking.

It sounds criminal after the turtles' efforts, but the haul is only about 5% of the total laid on a large arribada, and the village spends the rest of the year clearing the beach preparing it for the next mass-laying.

It is not everyone's idea of conservation, and some people want the collection banned. A gringo with a couple of cameras and notebook on the beach at dawn could be assumed to be one of them, so I took my leave as the village approached, retreating through the woods back to my cabin for tea and sleep.

webTitle: I lost my heart in... Rio Gregori

fields.headline: I lost my heart in... Rio Gregori
fields.standfirst: Tony Annis
fields.trailText: Tony Annis.
fields.body:
The area I went to in Brazil is 16 hours by plane from Rio and then two weeks by dugout canoe. It was just as I imagine travelling was like 100 years ago. Drifting between the green canopy of the Amazon forest down a tributary as big as the Thames was a magical feeling.

I'd never been on a river that had sand beaches. There is jungle on either side and trees floating down the river. A dug-out canoe is very heavy but when it hits something it doesn't get holed. With only about an inch of freeboard, however, it is forever getting wet.

I found the Indians very sharp. Although they didn't want much of what the modern world has to offer, they tap rubber, they have the odd rifle, they even have a solar-powered radio to speak to other groups in Canada and America to join together to protect their rights.

All the stories you hear about Amazon Indians are about tribes that have had virtually no contact with the outside world, but what I liked was that this one had been in contact, was surviving and was taking what it wanted from the modern world and leaving the rest.

fields.headline: The art of good living
fields.standfirst:
Between the Goya and the Dali, the cava and the tapas, Simon Hoggart is serenaded over a suckling pig and sees the good sense in a siesta
Madrid Tourist Authority
The Prado
fields.trailText: Between the Goya and the Dali, the cava and the tapas, Simon Hoggart is serenaded over a suckling pig and sees the good sense in a siesta.
fields.body:
We arrived at our hotel, the excellent Villa Real, just after midnight on the Friday. Adela Gooch, the Guardian's Madrid correspondent, had told us that midnight was the perfect time for a grand entrance, since the city was just getting ready for the night's drinking and revelry. Revelry? We were late and tired and totally whacked. So we went to bed and slept through what is, they say, the wildest part of the week in Madrid.

The advantage was that we woke up feeling terrific and ready to go to the Prado, possibly the greatest art gallery in the world. Nothing prepares you for the Prado, or for even the length of the queues that snake right round the building on weekends, including at the beginning and start of the day. The received wisdom is that you can't take it all in, and should make several trips, each perhaps devoted to a particular artist - Goya or Velásquez, for example. But a 48-hour tripper can't afford all that time, and after waiting half an hour or so in the queue, we plunged on and in, determined to see as much as we could.

It's worth the price of admission (a mere 500 pesetas, about £2 a head) for the Black Paintings of Goya alone. They are weird, schizophrenic and terrifying, so surreal it's almost impossible to believe they were created nearly 200 years ago. But, of course, they have the Majas, as well, both naked and clothed, the celebrated Third of May 1808 showing the French executing prisoners in Madrid. (Funny how the Spanish see themselves as an innocent, colonised nation, when, of course, they were one of the most ferocious colonisers.) And there are the portraits - golly, the Spanish royals were so ugly in those days that even Goya's skill could not rescue their features - and those other pictures that linger in the mind, some suitable for chocolate boxes (The Swing) and others from nightmares (Saturn Devouring One of His Children).

Onwards we rushed, past Velásquez, El Greco, Murillo, Botticelli, Poussin, Rembrandt, Van Dyck and Breugel, then on to the astounding Hieronymus Bosch room, where we were brought to a standstill by the Garden of Earthly Delights, a picture so startling, so resonant, so arresting and somehow so apt for the 21st century that it wouldn't stand a chance of winning the Turner Prize.

By now, it was past 2pm, and though early for a Spanish lunch, we dragged our flat and weary feet off to La Trucha, at 6 Calle Nunez de Arce, which is famous for its smoked fish, and where the trout was, as the name of the place would imply, absolutely excellent. The joy of Spanish restaurants is that you don't have to choose the entire meal in advance. You pick and choose from the dishes on the menu, they're brought as and when they're ready, and if you fancy something the next table is eating, you can simply point.

Back to the hotel for the siesta. No point in flogging round the city if none of its citizens are. Later, Adela came round - "we'll meet early," she'd said, "around half past eight." The shops were open and packed. We went to Madrid's main department store, El Corte Ingles ("the English Cut"; it started life as a tailors). We were on the lookout for a Real Madrid shirt - which cost much the same as it would in the UK - and for other things which might be cheaper. Most were.

Next, we popped back to Adela's flat for a bottle of chilled cava, fastened with what appeared to be a rusted chastity belt. She had to take it to her neighbourhood bar to find how to open it (answer: with a small quantity of Semtex).

She'd booked us in at the Casa Botin, founded in 1725. By the time we arrived, at about 10.45pm, most of the tourists had gone, and we could enjoy the gorgeous panelled and tiled rooms, the elderly waiters who had clearly spent several lifetimes working there, and the extraordinary aroma of their specialities: roast Aranda lamb, and suckling pigs from both Avila and Segovia. Gourmets can tell the difference. I had a quarter suckling pig from one place or the other. It's a dish that can be tricky for British visitors, since some restaurants like to display the little piglets, lying on the counter like dead corgis. Happily, I conquered any lingering, atavistic distaste, and scarfed down the lot - utterly delicious. And a bunch of students with doublets and stringed instruments came and serenaded us. At home, we would have cringed. There, it worked. Rather like drinking retsina in Greece. The bill for three was an amazingly low £44.

By now, it was around 1am and Madrid was waking up for the night. We went bar-hopping. Everyone was full, everywhere was loud, everyone seemed pleasantly pissed but good-humoured, as unlike the West End as it's possible to be. No point in recommending one bar or another; stroll by and try whichever appeals. We sampled a jazz bar, the Café Pueblo, but there are hundreds of others.

Next day, we headed for the celebrated Rastro flea market, which sells everything - clothes, toys, furniture, cookery equipment, knick-knacks of every kind, saddles, even vicious-looking military equipment. By noon, it was almost impossible to move through the crowds, for the most part local people.

Next stop was one of the branches of the Museo del Jamón which are scattered around the city. The Spanish take their ham with incredible seriousness. These "museums" - actually big delis - sell a vast range of hams which hang on great hooks from the ceiling, not unlike a Hieronymus Bosch painting. The cost ranges from about 2,000 pesetas a kilo (about £8) to 12,000 pesetas (£48). The latter are made from small, black-trottered pigs fed on acorns. Only an expert can tell the difference, but the thing to look for are streaks of fat flecking the lean bits.

This just left time for a trip to Madrid's superb main square, the Plaza Mayor, where we sipped coffee in the wintry sunshine. Adela had suggested we join her and her friends for a Sunday aperitivo. You meet in a bar, naturally, and since it's pre-lunch drinks and snacks, you meet very early - at 2pm, practically the crack of dawn. Fresh anchovies, grilled prawns, mushrooms with ham, hot asparagus with garlic mayonnaise, meat bruchetas and fried whitebait, were washed down with cold beers, colder manzanilla sherry, and lively chat as people move round the bar as if at a cocktail party. Most tapas come with little paper frills to keep your fingers clean and you drop them on the floor; Madrilenos will stand by the door and rate a bar's food by the depths of white detritus on the floor. By 4pm we felt stuffed to the gills and the other customers were leaving. We asked where - the answer was home for their real Sunday lunch, probably another five courses.

By this time, the weekend was beginning to seem like a grand bouffe . And so it was. Guilt alone drove us to Madrid's other great art gallery, the Museo Thyssen-Bornemisza, once a private collection, now open to all. There's an amazingly eclectic range of works, from Italian primitives, through Titian and Caravaggio to Dali, Hopper and Bacon. By the end, I felt a better person, and in urgent need of a nap.

That night, we finished by gliding past scores of restaurants and were finally enticed into one by a huge bowl of paella, roughly the size of a cartwheel. It sat by the door, steaming fragrantly.

We left first thing the next day having had a fine Madrid weekend, eating too much good food, drinking too much good wine, sleeping too long, and gazing at too much great art. It worked for us.

10 of the best

Restaurants
Prices pounds 20-40pp with wine, unless otherwise stated.

1 Casa Botin Cuchilleros 17. Tel: 91 366 4217/ 3026
Traditional; the oldest restaurant in Madrid.

2 Lhardy Carrera de San Jeronimo 8. Tel: 91 522 2207
Madrid's answer to Rules. A delightful place to savour Cocido, Madrid's speciality. Or pop into the 19th-century deli on the ground floor for a light tapa of kidneys in sherry sauce.

3 Champaneria Gala Huertas
