fields.bodyText: We arrived at our hotel, the excellent Villa Real, just after midnight on the Friday. Adela Gooch, the Guardian's Madrid correspondent, had told us that midnight was the perfect time for a grand entrance, since the city was just getting ready for the night's drinking and revelry. Revelry? We were late and tired and totally whacked. So we went to bed and slept through what is, they say, the wildest part of the week in Madrid. The advantage was that we woke up feeling terrific and ready to go to the Prado, possibly the greatest art gallery in the world. Nothing prepares you for the Prado, or for even the length of the queues that snake right round the building on weekends, including at the beginning and start of the day. The received wisdom is that you can't take it all in, and should make several trips, each perhaps devoted to a particular artist - Goya or Velásquez, for example. But a 48-hour tripper can't afford all that time, and after waiting half an hour or so in the queue, we plunged on and in, determined to see as much as we could. It's worth the price of admission (a mere 500 pesetas, about £2 a head) for the Black Paintings of Goya alone. They are weird, schizophrenic and terrifying, so surreal it's almost impossible to believe they were created nearly 200 years ago. But, of course, they have the Majas, as well, both naked and clothed, the celebrated Third of May 1808 showing the French executing prisoners in Madrid. (Funny how the Spanish see themselves as an innocent, colonised nation, when, of course, they were one of the most ferocious colonisers.) And there are the portraits - golly, the Spanish royals were so ugly in those days that even Goya's skill could not rescue their features - and those other pictures that linger in the mind, some suitable for chocolate boxes (The Swing) and others from nightmares (Saturn Devouring One of His Children). Onwards we rushed, past Velásquez, El Greco, Murillo, Botticelli, Poussin, Rembrandt, Van Dyck and Breugel, then on to the astounding Hieronymus Bosch room, where we were brought to a standstill by the Garden of Earthly Delights, a picture so startling, so resonant, so arresting and somehow so apt for the 21st century that it wouldn't stand a chance of winning the Turner Prize. By now, it was past 2pm, and though early for a Spanish lunch, we dragged our flat and weary feet off to La Trucha, at 6 Calle Nunez de Arce, which is famous for its smoked fish, and where the trout was, as the name of the place would imply, absolutely excellent. The joy of Spanish restaurants is that you don't have to choose the entire meal in advance. You pick and choose from the dishes on the menu, they're brought as and when they're ready, and if you fancy something the next table is eating, you can simply point. Back to the hotel for the siesta. No point in flogging round the city if none of its citizens are. Later, Adela came round - "we'll meet early," she'd said, "around half past eight." The shops were open and packed. We went to Madrid's main department store, El Corte Ingles ("the English Cut"; it started life as a tailors). We were on the lookout for a Real Madrid shirt - which cost much the same as it would in the UK - and for other things which might be cheaper. Most were. Next, we popped back to Adela's flat for a bottle of chilled cava, fastened with what appeared to be a rusted chastity belt. She had to take it to her neighbourhood bar to find how to open it (answer: with a small quantity of Semtex). She'd booked us in at the Casa Botin, founded in 1725. By the time we arrived, at about 10.45pm, most of the tourists had gone, and we could enjoy the gorgeous panelled and tiled rooms, the elderly waiters who had clearly spent several lifetimes working there, and the extraordinary aroma of their specialities: roast Aranda lamb, and suckling pigs from both Avila and Segovia. Gourmets can tell the difference. I had a quarter suckling pig from one place or the other. It's a dish that can be tricky for British visitors, since some restaurants like to display the little piglets, lying on the counter like dead corgis. Happily, I conquered any lingering, atavistic distaste, and scarfed down the lot - utterly delicious. And a bunch of students with doublets and stringed instruments came and serenaded us. At home, we would have cringed. There, it worked. Rather like drinking retsina in Greece. The bill for three was an amazingly low £44. By now, it was around 1am and Madrid was waking up for the night. We went bar-hopping. Everyone was full, everywhere was loud, everyone seemed pleasantly pissed but good-humoured, as unlike the West End as it's possible to be. No point in recommending one bar or another; stroll by and try whichever appeals. We sampled a jazz bar, the Café Pueblo, but there are hundreds of others. Next day, we headed for the celebrated Rastro flea market, which sells everything - clothes, toys, furniture, cookery equipment, knick-knacks of every kind, saddles, even vicious-looking military equipment. By noon, it was almost impossible to move through the crowds, for the most part local people. Next stop was one of the branches of the Museo del Jamón which are scattered around the city. The Spanish take their ham with incredible seriousness. These "museums" - actually big delis - sell a vast range of hams which hang on great hooks from the ceiling, not unlike a Hieronymus Bosch painting. The cost ranges from about 2,000 pesetas a kilo (about £8) to 12,000 pesetas (£48). The latter are made from small, black-trottered pigs fed on acorns. Only an expert can tell the difference, but the thing to look for are streaks of fat flecking the lean bits. This just left time for a trip to Madrid's superb main square, the Plaza Mayor, where we sipped coffee in the wintry sunshine. Adela had suggested we join her and her friends for a Sunday aperitivo. You meet in a bar, naturally, and since it's pre-lunch drinks and snacks, you meet very early - at 2pm, practically the crack of dawn. Fresh anchovies, grilled prawns, mushrooms with ham, hot asparagus with garlic mayonnaise, meat bruchetas and fried whitebait, were washed down with cold beers, colder manzanilla sherry, and lively chat as people move round the bar as if at a cocktail party. Most tapas come with little paper frills to keep your fingers clean and you drop them on the floor; Madrilenos will stand by the door and rate a bar's food by the depths of white detritus on the floor. By 4pm we felt stuffed to the gills and the other customers were leaving. We asked where - the answer was home for their real Sunday lunch, probably another five courses. By this time, the weekend was beginning to seem like a grand bouffe . And so it was. Guilt alone drove us to Madrid's other great art gallery, the Museo Thyssen-Bornemisza, once a private collection, now open to all. There's an amazingly eclectic range of works, from Italian primitives, through Titian and Caravaggio to Dali, Hopper and Bacon. By the end, I felt a better person, and in urgent need of a nap. That night, we finished by gliding past scores of restaurants and were finally enticed into one by a huge bowl of paella, roughly the size of a cartwheel. It sat by the door, steaming fragrantly. We left first thing the next day having had a fine Madrid weekend, eating too much good food, drinking too much good wine, sleeping too long, and gazing at too much great art. fields.headline: Some like it hot
fields.standfirst: The biggest street party in the world kicks off with a nocturnal orgy of dancing and music. From then on, you will see things in public at Carnival that would make you blush in your own bedroom, says  Brian Logan
fields.trailText: The biggest street party in the world kicks off with a nocturnal orgy of dancing and music. From then on, you will see things in public at Carnival that would make you blush in your own bedroom.
fields.body:
It starts at two in the morning. I've been to bed - I'm a visitor, after all, unused to the rigours of Carnival. Perhaps it's because the hands on my body clock are spinning in contrary directions that what follows seems faintly unreal: dancing - "chipping" - en masse through Port of Spain in pursuit of a steel band making stately progress to nowhere in particular; smearing and being smeared in mud and paint by muddy, painted devils; limbo dancing badly at sunrise. This is J'Ouvert, the nocturnal orgy that kick-starts the biggest street party in the world.

The devils are "jab-jabs", one of few remaining traditional Carnival characters. It's a tradition, too, that if you're clean, they'll splatter you with a tankard of goo scooped from tin baths wheeled behind the monolithic sound systems that pass through Port of Spain's avenues ripping the air with dins that rasp "stampede!" or "bacchanal!"

"Chipping" is the loose-limbed tramp with which that pageant's disciples give chase. It resembles an exhausted stagger, which is convenient, because even after four hours of "jumping up" and downing Carib beer, I don't look out of place. At daybreak, my gyrations - I call it limbo at the risk of besmirching a cornerstone of Trinidadian culture - clumsily denote an epiphany, that moment when dancing and music have eclipsed and express everything.

"Dance!" novelist Earl Lovelace wrote of calypso and Carnival, "If the words mourn the death of a neighbour, the music insists that you dance; if it tells the troubles of a brother, the music says dance. Dance to the hurt! It is in dancing that you ward off evil. Dance!"

He is true to his word: I saw him at Carnival, dancing. The breadth of commitment to the event is astonishing: that the literati, like Lovelace, and politicians - last year, finance minister Brian Tung was snapped in wild abandon - should want and are able to muck in speaks of a cultural democracy we can only dream of. Compare and contrast to William Hague at Notting Hill.

But Carnival isn't an appendage to Trinidadian life, it is the culmination of Trinidadian life. Here's Lovelace again: "This is the guts of the people, their blood; this is the self of the people that they screaming out they possess, that they scrimp and save and whore and work and thief to drag out of the hard rockstone and dirt to show the world they is people".

I was struck, reading local papers for a week before Carnival, by its monopoly on the news. Who won the Calypso Monarch title (Singing Sandra), whether Trinidad's very own Miss Universe would sacrifice Fashion Week for Carnival (she did), why Carnival gets the army's goat (revellers in uniform) - the Trinidad Guardian held its front page.

You can also gauge the obsession by the preparation: Carnival begins at Christmas. I arrived in Port of Spain at midnight and found the town's social life by cocking my ear to the wind. Follow that tinkling noise to one of many ramshackle panyards; here, the city's numerous steel bands rehearse for Carnival nightly - and all night - to crowds of drinkers and fans. There are plenty of both: the Trinidadian's capacity to enjoy himself is admirable. You know you're in the right place when the keys of your hire car come with bottle-opener attached.

The island's steel-band culture resembles football culture in Britain, except - and this is characteristic of Trinidad - it is creative and participatory. Steel bands, like football, sprang from working-class communities, an expression of their identity and - frequently - rage. Flare-ups between bands form Carnival legend: Invaders versus Tokyo in 1950 (nine injured); Desperadoes versus San Juan All Stars in '59 (30 injured). Recent years have seen Carnival's maverick tradition diluted; like our national sport, it's been gentrified and corporatised. Invaders are sponsored by the national airline. "Play mas", the billboards say, "Drink Coca-Cola". "Mas" means masquerade. J'Ouvert is "dirty mas", the relic of satirical, subversive Carnivals gone by.

At J'Ouvert, the past slings gunk at the present, or "pretty mas", which dominates Carnival Tuesday. It's pretty because Carnival has been inherited - some might say hijacked by powerful designers. It costs the price of a costume - industriously produced in mas camps in the months preceding Carnival - to participate; some banks advertise loans for the purpose. In the words of Peter Minshall, mas designer and orchestrator of the opening ceremony at the Barcelona Olympics, "In most countries, people pay to see others perform; in Trinidad, they pay to perform."

While there are isolated instances of preposterous sartorial extravagance - 10ft tall costumes, supported by wheels, fashioned to evoke flowers, or witch doctors, or frogs - these are exceptions to the prevailing rule, which states: it's Carnival, wear a bikini. On Tuesday, one phalanx after another of flesh-baring men and many more women charge across a vast stage traversing the Queen's Park Savannah, the city's lung and hub of Carnival. Purple knickers wink and sequinned silver thongs thrust; golden bras bulge and fiery red headgear blooms, tropically. Bands keep passing and colours keep intensifying, until your eyes ache, and still it won't stop. The year before last, the biggest band, Poison, had 10,000 members. They took two hours to cross the stage.

I pop outside. Half a mile from the grandstand's cocktail-tinted chaos, I still hear the same incessant tunes.

There's a competition (Carnival is a series of contests) for a song to be crowned "Road March" - usually soca, which is a mix of soul and calypso driven by a heavy beat. Carnival's soundtrack comprises a handful of insistently catchy refrains, looped, and to even suggest what it's like to be there, I'd have to persuade the Guardian to attach an accompanying CD. The pre-eminence of sound systems, at the expense of steel bands - whose involvement peaks at the Panorama competition two nights before Carnival begins - is a symptom of this event's sometimes painful evolution from home-spun fête to international post-modern extravaganza. Even calypso is undergoing an identity crisis.

Veterans worry that wry reflection is giving way to venom: when, at last year's Carnival, calypsonian Sugar Aloes lyrically ribbed the prime minister's wife, both Sugar Aloes' legendary forebear The Mighty Sparrow and the PM, Basdeo Panday, both leapt to the stricken damsel's defence.

By way of personalising that schism between what Trinidad was and is becoming, a local artist named Kathryn Chan - who is curating an exhibition of Carnival artefacts at London's Horniman Museum later this year - introduced me to several neglected figures from Carnival's past.

By the candy-coloured shanty towns of suburban Port of Spain, she drove me to the collapsible house - it was held up by a cactus - of Cito Velazquez. He was the Minshall of his day; his work so impressed Dr Eric Williams that the then PM commissioned him to adorn Port of Spain with sculptures to mark independence in 1962. We later met Leighton James, an unheralded grass-roots artist who has carved an incredibly expressive tableau of figurines representing Velazquez's 1959 Carnival presentation, Flowers and Fruits.

Both men's work is simultaneously poignant and inspiring. While James's fancy-dressed maquettes depict a Carnival that's more specific than today's "bacchanal" to the Caribbean's unique folklore, the circumstances of their creation testify again to Trinidad's trademark: this is a culture that's fearless in the face of creative expression. Its front rooms can be galleries, its backstreet courtyards concert halls, and at its parties, everyone dances.

Do

Play mas

Carnival is for flexing the party muscles, not the eyeballs.

Let rip

"If your parents told you not to do it," says the guidebook, "J'Ouvert is an excellent place to try it."

Drink the rum

When in Trinidad, do as the Trinidadians do.

Don't

Fill your pockets

Bags, wallets, jewellery - all are under threat from Carnival's light-fingered brigade.

Wear white on J'Ouvert

Unless you want to make an invitation of yourself to the mudslingers.

Be prudish

You'll see things in public that would make you blush in your own bedroom.

The practicals

Brian Logan flew to Trinidad with BWIA (www.bwee.com), as a guest of the Trinidad and Tobago tourist board, TIDCO (020 83501009, or www.visittnt.com) Flights to Trinidad cost aboput £450, rising to £750 during carnival season. A single room at the Cascadia Hotel in St Anne's, Port of Spain (001 868 6233511) cotst £58 a night, a double £66. Trinidad Carnival is on March 6 and 7.

fields.headline: Don't call her Mrs Cage
fields.trailText: Husband of Nic Cage and sister to a host of arthouse superstars, indie fave Patricia Arquette breaks into the mainstream with religious horror movie Stigmata
fields.body:
Husband of Nic Cage and sister to a host of arthouse superstars, indie fave Patricia Arquette breaks into the mainstream with religious horror movie Stigmata

Not that Patricia Arquette has exactly been overshadowed by her Oscar-winning husband Nicolas Cage. Even if she hasn't had the blockbuster action movies to boast about, she has given a series of performances - in True Romance, Flirting With Disaster, Lost Highway, Ed Wood, The Indian Runner as daring and indelible as any young actress can claim.

But last year she was box-office champ for the first time. Stigmata, a wacky, religioso horror movie in which Arquette plays a party girl who suddenly and inexplicably finds herself suffering Christlike agonies, was the last big summer movie hit in the States.

Up to now, Arquette hasn't been the type who even looks for, let alone expects, box-office success - her choices have been driven by intellectual stimulation and emotional challenge. Then again, there is an Adam Sandler picture in her future, Little Nicky, but at least she picked the one that acknowledges he's the spawn of hell. This girl obviously knows a winning trend when she sees one.

It looks like you really are possessed in Stigmata.

Yeah, it was so physical. I was so glad that people picked up on that because I was so flung around. I thought, no one's gonna know the troubles I've seen! Nobody's going to realise how banged-up and bruised I was.

Has Stigmata's success changed Hollywood's perception of you? .

Well, I'm mostly offered a lot more art movies, which you wouldn't think. I don't know what the repercussions will be, long-term, but it's not like some Cinderella movie, where it's like, "I opened the door and a fur coat fell on me! And champagne bottles, and buckets of jewels." It didn't happen like that.

So what is next? .

Well, after shooting Stigmata back-to-back with Martin Scorsese's Bringing Out The Dead, I'm like, gimme a goofy girl! And I have one. I'm doing this movie that was written by Charlie Kaufman, who wrote Being John Malkovich, called Human Nature. My character is a woman who has a medical condition of excess body hair, so she's sort of furry.

What was it like to work with Nic for the first time in Bringing Out The Dead? .

It was a different way of connecting. It's interesting; even though you look at each other in real life, when you're acting you look in someone's eyes a lot more.

So what do you two do in everyday life? .

We just tell jokes, watch TV and zone out like everyone else.

Considering all the weird movies the two of you have made, that sounds surprisingly sedate. .

Yeah, I guess we look like troublemakers.

You're not only married to an actor but all four of your siblings are actors too. Any idea why? .

I really believe that it's a gene. Because all of us kids are actors, and my parents were both actors. Then my grandparents, and my great-grandparents. So to go back that far, you kind of have to say, well, you're either very unimaginative or there's some gene.

Does that mean it feels like second nature, acting? .

No. I feel like a fraud sometimes, but I think everybody does. Especially if you're in a creative endeavour, at the end of the day you've got to ask yourself, "What am I doing? Is this good? Is it crap? Do I have talent or am I full of it? Is this my true work or should I just get a construction job?" That's probably just part of the process of creating. I'm actually surprised that I've worked as much as I have. But I don't feel, like, entitled.

fields.headline: Books in advance
fields.standfirst: Ros Taylor leads us to the best in online guidebooks
fields.trailText: Ros Taylor leads us to the best in online guidebooks
fields.body:
Do you really need to buy a guidebook for every holiday? It entirely depends where you're going. A trip to the US can be planned largely in advance (or on the road, if you stop at cybercafes) if you make judicious use of the web. But more remote destinations still demand a trip to the bookshop.

Rough Guides
The Rough Guides series republishes the contents of their guides on the web, but at a fairly basic level. Unless you're interrailing - in which case you probably haven't planned your trip in great detail, and might as well buy the book - the Rough Guide to Europe is often cursory, and that's the extent of the European information you'll find on the site. North America and Thailand are better covered.

Lonely Planet
Lonely Planet allows you to update your existing guidebooks for free. More radically, it offers downloadable city guides - San Francisco, Las Vegas and Sydney are the only cities available at the moment, and the downloads aren't free, but it's a commendable initiative.

Michelin
French guides Michelin are still much more protective of their paper business. Their recommendations are available online, but you'll have to pay for a subscription first. Time Out's restaurant and hotel listings for major cities are free but less comprehensive than in the paperback format.

Fodors
The undoubted and somewhat surprising winner is Fodors. The site lets you create a 'customisable miniguide' for 110 destinations, and its coverage of US national parks and restaurants is exemplary. Fodors has also provided an online talking phrasebook in French, Spanish, German and Italian - clicking on a phrase enables you to hear it spoken.

Insiders' Guides
The Insiders' Guides are not well known in Britain but are an excellent guide to US nightlife and restaurants. Try Cityspin, too.

Round the Bend
Should you be visiting upstate New York, Round the Bend will provide invaluable advice. Enthusiastic local residents have compiled the listings, and the site is easy to navigate.

Salon
Sadly, there are few online rivals to the idiosyncratic Blue Guide: the web is strong on practical travel details but weak on authoritative opinion. However, online magazine Salon's travel section contains some of the most irreverent reports to be found anywhere.

webTitle: Prescott eases ban on hi-tech sector's move into green belt

fields.headline: Prescott eases ban on hi-tech sector's move into green belt
fields.trailText: Restrictions preventing "clusters" of hi-tech companies moving on to protected greenfield sites could be lifted if regional agencies present strong economic cases for development, it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
Restrictions preventing "clusters" of hi-tech companies moving on to protected greenfield sites could be lifted if regional agencies present strong economic cases for development, it emerged yesterday.

John Prescott's department of the environment, transport and the regions is under growing pressure from the department of trade and industry, the treasury and Downing Street to give job creation a higher priority than protecting the countryside.

Pressure has increased following Mr Prescott's decision to turn down plans by the Wellcome Trust for a £100m extension to its genetic research centre at Hinxton Hall, in the Cambridge green belt, which could have created 1,000 jobs. This was seen by some as a crucial component in East Anglia's biotechnology cluster.

Other ministers were outraged by Wellcome's threat to take the project abroad rather than take up Mr Prescott's offer of a smaller development.

But, at a regional summit held in Chesterfield, Mr Prescott told the chairmen of England's eight regional development agencies (RDAs) that he will be more flexible when ruling on other contentious planning issues.

Revised planning guidelines, drawn up after the Hinxton Hall refusal should make it easier for councils - supported by the RDAs - to approve the growth of hi-tech clusters.

Mr Prescott faces a further test over the next two weeks when he is expected to rule on the merits of an 1,100-acre housing and business development in former green belt north of Newcastle upon Tyne. Last week the fast-expanding north-east software firm Sage announced it was planning a large project on the site, called Newcastle Great Park.

The science minister, Lord Sainsbury, attended the Chesterfield summit, which ended yesterday. Last year he recommended changes in planning regulations to encourage biotechnology clusters.

"John Prescott now seems more aware of the broader issues and getting the whole planning regime on a more flexible footing where there is a real need to encourage regional growth and jobs," one RDA chairman said.

The latest moves come amid concern that some ministers favour relaxing the ban on more out-of-town superstores. Fears were further raised this week in a report from the Commons environment select committee. Members are concerned that Downing Street is giving privileged access to supermarket chains, notably the US group Wal-Mart, which recently acquired Asda.

The competition commission is examining restrictions on supermarket trading caused by the planning system. Members of the environment committee are alarmed that the inquiry was set up without reference to the department of the environment.

webTitle: Jane Wilson-Howarth: A deet-based insect repellent | A sarong | A Buddha

fields.headline: Jane Wilson-Howarth never travels without
fields.trailText: A deet-based insect repellent | A sarong | A Buddha
fields.body:
A necessity: A deet-based insect repellent because I suffer quite badly from mosquito bites and it is also good for keeping off ticks and leeches.

A luxury: A sarong or a large bath towel so that I could wash easily. Sometimes you have to wash in a public square, but a sarong means you can wash everything underneath it, get nice and clean and sit in the sun drying off.

A memento: I don't take good luck charms, but one memento which I really like is a Buddha who is about a foot tall and quite heavy. I brought him back from Katmandu. He is a medicine Buddha and should cure all ills in the house if given the right chat-up line. I'm not a Buddhist, but I like to hedge my bets.

If only: I've stopped taking a huge medical kit with me as can usually buy whatever I need in a chemist, but I get very cross when I find that some common-place medicine isn't available in the country I'm visiting, so I would like a book that translates all trade names into generic names so that I can work out related drugs that will do the job just as well. I do take the British National Formularly but it is not all-inclusive.

 Dr Jane Wilson-Howarth will be giving advice and tips on how to stay healthy while travelling at Independent Traveller's World 2000 on Saturday January 29 at 2.30pm in Talk Room 4, part of the Safe Travel 2000 area.

webTitle: Skiing made accessible by low cost flights

fields.headline: Off the cuff
fields.standfirst: A weekend on the slopes should no longer be the preserve of minor royals thanks to low-cost flights. Stuart Millar puts it to the test
fields.trailText: A weekend on the slopes should no longer be the preserve of minor royals thanks to low-cost flights. Stuart Millar puts it to the test.
fields.body:
Sometimes it's hard to be a Briton. For most of the year, we can get away with feeling a certain quiet, though misguided, superiority over our European neighbours. But come winter, as soon as the French, Italians, Swiss and Austrians start nipping up to their local hills to steal a cheeky weekend on the snow, our sophisticated pop culture and quirky sense of humour don't seem quite enough.

Now all that may be changing. Having an Alp on our doorstep will remain an elusive dream, but the increasingly ferocious battle between low-cost cost airlines is having the happy side-effect of bringing Europe's best mountains closer to these shores. Dashing over the Channel for a spontaneous couple of days of high-quality riding could soon no longer be the preserve of minor royals and rock stars.

Taking advantage of Go's new bargain service to Lyon, I decided to test this utopian theory. The plan was to catch a bus from the airport into the Alps for a cheap weekend of early-season boarding. The resort wasn't important, the accommodation a trivial concern; the only consideration was that we got on snow for the lowest cost possible. How naive.

The details had come together nicely enough. La Plagne, one of the original 1960s resorts and tradition ally one of the most popular in France, had affordable rooms available. We jumped at the chance.

Then there was a slight hiccup with transport. The Satobus service runs direct from Lyon airport and takes two-and-a-half hours to get into the mountains at Aime, the small town at the base, from where shuttles transfer skiers and boarders around the various resort centres that make up La Plagne.

Because we were tied to returning early on a Sunday morning, however, the transfer times did not tallly. Yet, even that obstacle was easily overcome: we simply hired a car through specialist broker Holiday Autos, which, even complete with snow chains and ski rack, costs only a touch more than the #163;50-a-head return bus fares. This, I thought smugly to myself, was too easy.

That feeling of self-satisfaction rocketed off the scale as we twisted up the mountain towards the resort on the Thursday afternoon. The sky was unbroken blue. Soft, dry snow was piled high on both sides of the snaking road, and the weather was not forecast to close in until later on Saturday.

But after a fun first morning beneath bluebird skies, we began to realise that when it comes to spontaneous ski trips, the Europeans still hold all the best cards. Most important of all is local knowledge: with only two days on the mountain, we had little chance to explore and find the best riding. And with heavy cloud moving in, we just had to take what we found.

La Plagne is superb for families, beginners and lower-intermediates, but the juicier riding is much harder to find, and that was time we just didn't have. At least we had a final bout of apres to look forward to. But even with cheap airfares, bargain car hire and discount half-board accommodation, we proved it is still a fundamental rule of nature that cheap weekends in a ski resort do not exist. In two-and-a-half days, I still managed to get through almost #163;200. On nothing in particular: lunches, a few beers in the evenings and pizza on the last night.

Driving back through thick snow to Lyon the following morning, I was a man humbled. The snow had been great, the riding lovely while it lasted, but it will be a long time before the European ideal of equality is a reality for British skiers and boarders.

The practicals

Go has one flight a day, each way, between London and Lyon and two each way on Saturdays, for #163;60 return inc taxes. Book on 0845 6054321 or go-fly.com for a #163;2 discount. Accommodation through Erna Low (0171 584 2841). Weekend car rentals in France start from #163;69 between midday Friday and 9am Monday with Holiday Autos' (0870 400 0011 and www.holidayautos.co.uk).

fields.headline: Worried sick
fields.standfirst: All travelling entails risk, but are we spoiling our holidays by overestimating the dangers?
fields.trailText: All travelling entails risk, but are we spoiling our holidays by overestimating the dangers?
fields.body:
It is the sorry lot of a health correspondent to bear tidings of misery, death and disaster most of the time. True, we tell of the occasional miracle breakthrough - and usually get slammed by scientists for calling it a miracle breakthrough - but the greater part of our days is spent alerting the world to ominous increases in infectious diseases and unpleasant new viruses.

So perhaps it is our fault. Maybe we are responsible for the rise of the anxious-traveller syndrome and the whole new industry that has built up on the back of the health worries of holidaymakers abroad: the telephone hotlines, such as NHS Direct, to comforting, English-speaking nurses who will tell you whether to take an aspirin or find a doctor, pronto; the soaring sales of totally unnecessary anti-snake serum and dubious herbal remedies; the obsession with security; the proliferation of websites listing all the things that could go wrong.

Now I used to think - and still want to think - that travel is fun. Part of the attraction is the unknown, which inevitably means risk. The only real way to be rid of the risk is to cocoon yourself in a cultural enclave, as indeed you can on a Mark Warner or Club Med site. But the real abroad - with its different food, interesting hygiene and varying road safety standards - is not, fundamentally, safe.

I would not for a minute advocate that you should always leave your malaria tablets at home, and a basic first-aid kit is obviously sensible even for holidays in the UK. But before getting anxious and packing half a ton of remedies and potions and spending your entire holiday boiling water, it is worth looking at the real risks.

Dr Peter Barrett, senior medical adviser to the highly respected Masta (Medical Advisory Services for Travellers Abroad), believes there is 'overemphasis on certain aspects of risk'.

He cites a study in the World Health Organisation publication International Travel and Health, which found that some 50% of travellers staying for a month in the developing world are likely to suffer from something, which could range from a common cold to a fatal car crash. But only about 8% will be sick enough to feel that they want to see a doctor. About 5% will at some point be confined to bed. Three in 1,000 will be hospitalised during or after their trip and one in 2,000 will have to be air-evacuated. One in 100,000 is likely to die.

But what do UK travellers most often die of? Malaria? Dysentery? No - cardiovascular disease. They are felled by a heart attack, just as they could have been in the UK. Maybe the stress or excitement of the trip brought it on; possibly they might have stood a slightly better chance of recovery here but, nonetheless, the chief cause of death is pre-existing ill-health, not some vicious disease picked up abroad.

The next highest cause of mortality is accidents. Those who die are likely to be doing something reckless, but not necessarily taking risks with other cultures. They are much less likely to be stabbed in a street fight than to drown in the hotel swimming pool with a bellyful of lager in the early hours. Or they will be racing round an island's gravel roads on a substandard motorbike without a helmet.

We don't read about stories like these because they occur too often. Instead, we hear of the young man torn to pieces by lions on safari, because he left his tent flap open, or the young woman climber who died of altitude sickness. In fact, information about the place you are going to is far more likely to keep you in good health than a suitcase of medicines.

'It is at least as important to give sound advice to people as stick needles in them,' said Dr Barrett. Masta runs the British Airways travel clinics, whose staff try to make sure people understand the basic precautions needed - what to eat and drink to avoid getting traveller's diarrhoea, how to protect against insect bites and sunburn, and the folly of casual sex in some parts of the world.

Immunisation is important, of course, but not blanket immunisation. You can still come across ancient, out-of-date charts recommending malaria prophylaxis for Thailand. 'Yes, there is malaria, but the risk to travellers is practically non-existent,' says Dr Barrett. 'Given that some people react badly to one anti-malarial drug, it is not sensible to hand tablets out when they are not needed.'

All right, if you are genuinely going on an expedition to the back of beyond, living rough and eating whatever you can find, it may be worth taking specialist advice and packing the antibiotics - if you know how to use them. For the rest of us, the more ordinary things in life, such as plasters, bandages, aspirins, insect repellent and Calpol for the kids, will probably do.

True, we tell of the occasional miracle breakthrough - and usually get slammed by scientists for calling it a miracle breakthrough - but the greater part of our days is spent alerting the world to ominous increases in infectious diseases and unpleasant new viruses. So perhaps it is our fault. Maybe we are responsible for the rise of the anxious-traveller syndrome and the whole new industry that has built up on the back of the health worries of holidaymakers abroad: the telephone hotlines, such as NHS Direct, to comforting, English-speaking nurses who will tell you whether to take an aspirin or find a doctor, pronto; the soaring sales of totally unnecessary anti-snake serum and dubious herbal remedies; the obsession with security; the proliferation of websites listing all the things that could go wrong. Now I used to think - and still want to think - that travel is fun. Part of the attraction is the unknown, which inevitably means risk. The only real way to be rid of the risk is to cocoon yourself in a cultural enclave, as indeed you can on a Mark Warner or Club Med site. I would not for a minute advocate that you should always leave your malaria tablets at home, and a basic first-aid kit is obviously sensible even for holidays in the UK. They are much less likely to be stabbed in a street fight than to drown in the hotel swimming pool with a bellyful of lager in the early hours. fields.headline: Pardon my accent
fields.standfirst: The Readers' Editor on...attempts to cross the language barrier
fields.trailText: The Readers' Editor on...attempts to cross the language barrier
fields.body:
Alle Menschen werden Brüder - a reasonable sentiment, you might think, for a liberal newspaper to profess, but it would almost certainly be better if we skipped the German of Schiller's An die Freude and expressed our joy, even roughly, in English as, say, "We are all in this together."

We like to use foreign words, terms, phrases, but we often get them wrong. We even trip on common names, such as Giuseppe who regularly becomes Guiseppe - Gwee-seppy.

Not long ago, to illustrate a point, we introduced a purely fictional Venezuelan maid into a story and called her Consuela. This brought a sharp note from a woman called, like thousands of other women in the Spanish-speaking world, Consuelo.

"I really have had enough of show-off ignoramuses messing up my name. Consuelo is a Spanish abstract noun, masculine, invariable. Pilar and Mercedes are also Spanish female names derived, like Consuelo, from titles of the Virgin Mary." It would be equally silly, she said, to stick an "a" on them.

Names requiring accents seem to pose even greater difficulties. Extreme, and one has to say transparent, efforts are sometimes made to ensure that accents appear in the correct position. Alas, these efforts sometimes fail. They have caused us to refer to the soprano Christine Schäfer as Christine Schumlautafer, and a work by Liszt became Funacuteerailles. The latter prompted a witty but wounding one-word rejoinder from a reader, "Imbacuteeciles!"

Accent-induced anxiety is common among British journalists who find it difficult to understand why anyone should bother with such things. Foreign words that come into the English language bearing accents are stripped of them when the opportunity arises. Thus when I devoted a recent column to the cliché, you would have found when you picked the paper up on Saturday that I had been writing about the cliche, a deprivation let us concede more acute than grave. The tendency that it represents, although it may be seen by some as betraying our accents, is perhaps a good one. It is intended not as a slight - an act or omission indicating supercilious neglect or indifference (Collins) - aimed at a word's foreign origins, so much as an embrace or friendly adoption.

Paradoxically the same anxiety I have mentioned often leads us to use accents like a condiment and to pepper foreign words with them more or less at random, so that readers who know about these things - a large, cosmopolitan and long-suffering congregation - have to ask us to desist. Here are just a couple of examples: The French word for a cluster of racing cyclists is peloton, not péléton (It has nothing to do with a famous Brazilian footballer, this reader added, rather unnecessarily); Congratulations on getting Länder right, another wrote, but the singular is Land not Länd ... and so on.

A recent article on French menus was returned marked in red ink by a reader with an indigestible total of more than 30 errors, most of them relating to missing or misplaced accents.

We get worse as we move farther from Britain. We sometimes manage the diacritical tilde on Spanish words - mañana, for example - and sometimes not. For instance, a native or inhabitant of Madrid is a madrileño/a, not a madrileno.

During the World Cup coverage of 1998 a reader wrote to inquire why, since the Germans generally carried their umlauts proudly on to the pitch, and the French sometimes sported their accents, players of almost all other nationalities left theirs in the dressing room. Møller was always Moller, the Argentine Verón and the Colombian Rincón stepped similarly naked on to the field.

The Czech composers Janácek and Dvorák may get their acute accents but the chances of parading the caron, the little v carried above the c and the r respectively, in the pages of the Guardian are practically nil because of technical difficulties.

If you are Finnish, then, well, I am tempted to say forget it. We once misspelt the Finnish word for dyslexia (lukihäiriö). A few years ago we carried an article in translation from the Finnish daily newspaper Helsingin Sanomat. The article was fine but the byline turned out to be not the name of the author but the Finnish for "Continued on the next page".

Does any of this really matter? I think it does. I tend to agree with those readers who see it as a kind of parochialism detracting from their view of the Guardian as a paper with an unlimited horizon. Our style guide advises us only to keep all accents on French words and umlauts in German. Beyond that we are on our own. Neglecting to get it right may be due to carelessness. It can look like prejudice.

fields.headline: Great escapes
fields.standfirst: Finding a family skiing holiday for February half-term  may be a tad ambitious, but there are planty of other ways to dodge the dog days of winter. Nicky Holford reports.
fields.trailText: Finding a family skiing holiday for February half-term may be a tad ambitious, but there are planty of other ways to dodge the dog days of winter.
fields.body:
When the world is your oyster, where do you start looking for the pearl? Is your ultimate mid-winter treat to ride the rapids of the Zambezi or learn to cook an exquisite soufflé in a Scottish retreat? Will you treat the kids to Disney World or tee off in Dubai? Whatever your desire, the choice for getting away mid-winter has never been greater.

If your dates are flexible, you can save substantially by waiting for last-minute offers. But if you are planning a family ski holiday for the February half-term, it may already be too late. Destinations in Europe are often substituted for hotter climes, but winter is an excellent time to explore cities that are overcrowded in the summer.

Venice is particularly moody. Uncrowded churches, art galleries and fine restaurants easily compensate for the damp days of winter. A visit to Venice can even be combined with a ski holiday. Some tour operators with ski weeks to resorts such as St Moritz, Bormio, Madonna di Campiglio and Cortina d'Ampezzo offer day trips to the city.

The Italian and French Riviera may not be warm enough to tempt you into the sea, but they often have clear, sunny days. Treat yourself to the Hotel Splendido in Portofino, an elegant and understated former monastery where Ava Gardner used to stay. Or book into its sister hotel, the Splendido Mare, which opened for its first winter this year.

For thinning down or chilling out, there are health spas and yoga retreats. The ultimate rejuvenating experience, which will also leave your wallet a little on the thin side, is the US "holistic wellness spa" Miraval near Tucson, Arizona (001 520 825 4000). With the motto "Life in balance", the philosophy here is new age and based on Eastern concepts. Expect a timetable of massages with warm lava rocks, meditation, yoga and Tai Chi. For the more physical, there's also horse riding, a climbing rock and challenge course, kayaking, hiking and skating. The setting is magnificent - 130 acres of desert below the Santa Catalina mountains with adobe-type buildings set amid the sage bushes and cacti. At night, you can hear the baying of coyotes.

For the more adventurous, there are tiger safaris in India, desert camel trekking in Morocco, floating down the Nile in a felucca, or mixing with the animals in Africa 's game reserves.

Dubai has some of the finest golf courses in the world, but if you require something a little more active you will find as much adrenaline as you can cope with in Queenstown, New Zealand, one of the capitals for extreme junkies.

The home of bungee-jumping has marked the map by developing other adrenaline sports such as base-jumping and sky-surfing - jumping out of a plane with a board attached to your legs to ride the thermals.

Equally active are some of the clubbing holidays dreamed up by radio station Kiss FM, such as the first weekend cruise to Hamburg. The itinerary goes something like this: leave Harwich, club all night Friday, arrive Hamburg, four hours in town, return to boat for all-night clubbing while sailing back to the UK. (February 11-13, with four sharing a standard cabin costs £79 each. For details, telephone 01255 244377.)

webTitle: Has compensation culture gone too far?

fields.headline: Has compensation culture gone too far?
fields.trailText:
Dear John,
I'm sure that you and I agree on one thing: that it's quite wrong for employers to dismiss their employees unfairly, or to discriminate on grounds of race or gender. The system of employment tribunals is a good one and, in many cases, can right situations where employers have breached the rules. So why am I worried about the developments in compensation payouts that are now taking place?
fields.body:
Dear John,
I'm sure that you and I agree on one thing: that it's quite wrong for employers to dismiss their employees unfairly, or to discriminate on grounds of race or gender. The system of employment tribunals is a good one and, in many cases, can right situations where employers have breached the rules. So why am I worried about the developments in compensation payouts that are now taking place?

Employees already bring many frivolous cases against employers. Taking average figures for recent years, I understand that about 45% of cases are either withdrawn before reaching the tribunal, or fail at the tribunal. In other words, nearly half of all the cases are frivolous, if not capricious. But, whether frivolous or not, the employer has to prepare his or her case, frequently incurring legal costs, in order to defend himself or herself. This can be hugely time-consuming, expensive and damaging, especially for small businesses. And there's no compensation for the employer if he or she "wins": today's compensation culture is strictly one-way.

Given the explosion in employment regulations, media coverage of huge compensation payments and increasing litigiousness, I fear these frivolous cases will rise dramatically. How are employers - especially small employers - going to cope?

Yours sincerely,
Ruth Lea
Head of Policy
Institute of Directors

Dear Ruth,
You're right! I do agree that employers should obey the law. You're troubled by the burden on employers of frivolous employment tribunal cases. You have perhaps forgotten that an employment tribunal can and will order the costs of one side to be paid by the other where the latter has acted "frivolously, vexatiously, abusively disruptively or otherwise unreasonably". But two things trouble me about the special exemptions granted to employers, especially in the area of unfair dismissal. First, no matter how unfair the dismissal, an employee dismissed within a year of starting work with an employer is barred from bringing an unfair dismissal claim. Second, an employer cannot be obliged to take back an unfairly dismissed employee where a tribunal has ordered it.

You refer to "today's compensation culture", but surely employers and their insurers must be rejoicing in the government's decision to abolish legal aid for personal injury cases? This will mean that thousands of workers will no longer be able to sue their employers for injury or death caused by breach of health and safety laws. True, unions will take these cases for free - as in the case of the Gypsy site worker who received damages this week - but most workers aren't in unions. Lawyers can do these cases on a no-win, no-fee basis, but they will only take the risk in the very strongest cases.

You can rest assured that the courts and tribunals are assiduous in throwing out frivolous cases. The real injustice is not a compensation culture, but a culture in which innocent people suffer injury and loss by lawbreaking employers and yet cannot get compensation for it.

Yours,
John Hendy QC
Institute of Employment Rights

Dear John,
I hadn't forgotten that costs can be awarded to employers in some very specific circumstances, but such costs can never meet the damaging disruption to businesses - especially to small businesses - that frivolous cases cause. There is no adequate compensation for such damage. And the fact that tribunals are "assiduous" in throwing out frivolous cases does not invalidate this point.

But the "compensation culture" is all too vigorous. Recent estimates suggest that it costs the country £7.5bn a year, and some recent payouts have been extraordinarily inflated. Moreover, there has been an explosion of tribunal cases faced by employers. In 1998/99 there were 136,000; 31% higher than the previous year. As Acas has acknowledged, the rapid rise reflects increased litigiousness and extended employment rights, and there are more to come. Small employers feel powerless in the face of such an onslaught.

As for industrial injuries cases, lawyers can do them on a no-win, no-fee basis, as indeed you say, insofar as public funding has been withdrawn for them. If lawyers believe a case has a good chance of winning then they would surely take it on. If not, it shouldn't go to court. If lawyers are responsible and rational people - and, in my experience, they are - then no innocent person who has suffered injury and loss by a lawbreaking employer should fail to get his or her compensation.

Yours sincerely,
Ruth

Dear Ruth,
You accept that tribunals throw out frivolous claims and that employers can get costs orders; remember also that tribunals can strike out vexatious claims at any stage. Employers are well-protected against the costs and disruption of fighting vexatious cases. What you're really seeking, it seems, is the removal of unfair dismissal claims altogether: that would certainly stop vexatious ones, but it would stop justified ones, too.

I hope the lawbreaking of employers doesn't cost the country £7.5bn a year! That cost should fall fairly and squarely on the shoulders of employers who flout the law. The real significance of this figure - and of the increase in the number of cases fought and won- is that it shows the massive extent of bad employers. And don't forget that because of limits on compensation for unfair dismissal, redundancy, failures to consult and the like, £7.5bn is nowhere near the total financial losses caused to employee victims. What your figure reveals is not a compensation culture, but a culture of lawlessness among employers.

As for injury cases - yes, lawyers are rational people: they will not take on cases where they think there is a significant chance of not being paid. So injured people with good but not overwhelming cases - people, that is, with a 50-70% chance of success - will find it difficult, and in some cases impossible, to get compensation.

Yours,
John

Dear John,
May I start by repeating that there is no adequate compensation for the damaging disruption caused to businesses, especially small ones, by frivolous tribunal cases. Every case has to be dealt with, and until the tribunal makes a decision, no businessman or woman knows whether or not it will be stopped. Coping with such cases can have huge opportunity costs, and almost cripple small and vulnerable firms. Incidentally, you imply I am seeking the removal of all claims. Not so.

Concerning the £7.5bn, I'm afraid you misunderstood the nature of the figure. It refers to the total costs to the country of the compensation culture, and includes £4bn paid by the NHS, emergency services and local government. Legal fees totalled £1bn - a nice little earner! - and less than 20% was attributed to the private sector, hardly a culture of lawlessness among employers.

I was surprised, if not amazed, that you implied that only dead cert cases - or near as dammit dead cert - would be handled by lawyers. Such a stance seems quite extraordinarily restrictive and unjust. Some people may think lawyers should adopt a less risk-averse - and more generous - approach.

Yours,
Ruth

Dear Ruth,
You complain of inadequate compensation for employers faced with frivolous cases, but I've spent nearly 30 years doing employment cases and I just do not believe there are many frivolous ones. The fact that many cases are withdrawn before hearing is because settlement is often reached, frequently when the employer agrees to pay because the employee's case is strong. And the disruption caused by claims against employers is nowhere near comparable to the distress caused to employees who are unfairly treated.

I don't understand your figure of £7.5bn as the cost of the "compensation culture". Compensation is only payable when someone has broken the law; if you break the law and someone else suffers loss, or is injured, why shouldn't you pay compensation? I find it hard to believe that the NHS, emergency services and local government have paid out £4bn in compensation and costs for their own wrongdoing. Maybe you are referring to the cost of attending to accidents in which compensation has later been recovered by victims; if so, I agree that the wrongdoer should compensate those bodies too.

In 1994, the health and safety executive estimated that the net cost to individuals of work-related accidents and ill-health was £5bn; the cost to employers £1.5bn. The cost to society was between £11bn and £16bn. It would be much better economics for employers to comply with law than to whinge about frivolous tribunal cases. Many lawyers take many deserving cases in tribunals and courts free of charge, but you can't expect them to run their businesses at a loss. Wasn't your starting point the need to protect small businesses from irrecoverable costs?

Yours,
John

Join the debate

The real injustice is not a compensation culture, but a culture in which innocent people suffer injury and loss by lawbreaking employers and yet cannot get compensation for it. Yours, John Hendy QC Institute of Employment Rights Dear John, I hadn't forgotten that costs can be awarded to employers in some very specific circumstances, but such costs can never meet the damaging disruption to businesses - especially to small businesses - that frivolous cases cause. There is no adequate compensation for such damage. And the fact that tribunals are "assiduous" in throwing out frivolous cases does not invalidate this point. But the "compensation culture" is all too vigorous. Recent estimates suggest that it costs the country £7.5bn a year, and some recent payouts have been extraordinarily inflated. Moreover, there has been an explosion of tribunal cases faced by employers. In 1998/99 there were 136,000; 31% higher than the previous year. As Acas has acknowledged, the rapid rise reflects increased litigiousness and extended employment rights, and there are more to come. Small employers feel powerless in the face of such an onslaught. As for industrial injuries cases, lawyers can do them on a no-win, no-fee basis, as indeed you say, insofar as public funding has been withdrawn for them. If lawyers believe a case has a good chance of winning then they would surely take it on. If not, it shouldn't go to court. If lawyers are responsible and rational people - and, in my experience, they are - then no innocent person who has suffered injury and loss by a lawbreaking employer should fail to get his or her compensation. Yours sincerely, Ruth Dear Ruth, You accept that tribunals throw out frivolous claims and that employers can get costs orders; remember also that tribunals can strike out vexatious claims at any stage. Employers are well-protected against the costs and disruption of fighting vexatious cases. What you're really seeking, it seems, is the removal of unfair dismissal claims altogether: that would certainly stop vexatious ones, but it would stop justified ones, too. I hope the lawbreaking of employers doesn't cost the country £7.5bn a year! That cost should fall fairly and squarely on the shoulders of employers who flout the law. The real significance of this figure - and of the increase in the number of cases fought and won- is that it shows the massive extent of bad employers. And don't forget that because of limits on compensation for unfair dismissal, redundancy, failures to consult and the like, £7.5bn is nowhere near the total financial losses caused to employee victims. What your figure reveals is not a compensation culture, but a culture of lawlessness among employers. As for injury cases - yes, lawyers are rational people: they will not take on cases where they think there is a significant chance of not being paid. So injured people with good but not overwhelming cases - people, that is, with a 50-70% chance of success - will find it difficult, and in some cases impossible, to get compensation. Yours, John Dear John, May I start by repeating that there is no adequate compensation for the damaging disruption caused to businesses, especially small ones, by frivolous tribunal cases. Every case has to be dealt with, and until the tribunal makes a decision, no businessman or woman knows whether or not it will be stopped. Coping with such cases can have huge opportunity costs, and almost cripple small and vulnerable firms. Incidentally, you imply I am seeking the removal of all claims. Not so. Concerning the £7.5bn, I'm afraid you misunderstood the nature of the figure. It refers to the total costs to the country of the compensation culture, and includes £4bn paid by the NHS, emergency services and local government. Legal fees totalled £1bn - a nice little earner! - and less than 20% was attributed to the private sector, hardly a culture of lawlessness among employers. I was surprised, if not amazed, that you implied that only dead cert cases - or near as dammit dead cert - would be handled by lawyers. Such a stance seems quite extraordinarily restrictive and unjust. Some people may think lawyers should adopt a less risk-averse - and more generous - approach. Yours, Ruth Dear Ruth, You complain of inadequate compensation for employers faced with frivolous cases, but I've spent nearly 30 years doing employment cases and I just do not believe there are many frivolous ones. The fact that many cases are withdrawn before hearing is because settlement is often reached, frequently when the employer agrees to pay because the employee's case is strong. And the disruption caused by claims against employers is nowhere near comparable to the distress caused to employees who are unfairly treated. I don't understand your figure of £7.5bn as the cost of the "compensation culture". Compensation is only payable when someone has broken the law; if you break the law and someone else suffers loss, or is injured, why shouldn't you pay compensation? I find it hard to believe that the NHS, emergency services and local government have paid out £4bn in compensation and costs for their own wrongdoing. Maybe you are referring to the cost of attending to accidents in which compensation has later been recovered by victims; if so, I agree that the wrongdoer should compensate those bodies too. In 1994, the health and safety executive estimated that the net cost to individuals of work-related accidents and ill-health was £5bn; the cost to employers £1.5bn. The cost to society was between £11bn and £16bn. It would be much better economics for employers to comply with law than to whinge about frivolous tribunal cases. Many lawyers take many deserving cases in tribunals and courts free of charge, but you can't expect them to run their businesses at a loss. Wasn't your starting point the need to protect small businesses from irrecoverable costs? Yours, John Join the debate

webTitle: Race claims inquiry put on hold

fields.headline: Race claims inquiry put on hold
fields.standfirst: Race issues in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: The commission for racial equality announced yesterday that it is putting a threatened formal inquiry into claims of race discrimination at the crown prosecution service on hold, pending the outcome of an independent inquiry set up by the CPS and headed by a leading black academic lawyer.
fields.body:
The commission for racial equality announced yesterday that it is putting a threatened formal inquiry into claims of race discrimination at the crown prosecution service on hold, pending the outcome of an independent inquiry set up by the CPS and headed by a leading black academic lawyer.

In a move revealed by the Guardian a month ago, the CPS asked Sylvia Denman, a former member of a CRE predecessor, the race relations board, to investigate allegations that ethnic minority lawyers were passed over for promotion. She is due to report by the end of April.

The CRE, the government's race watchdog, said it believed the CPS was now willing to co-operate on addressing the issue and was giving the body three months to deliver a programme of reform.

The CPS plan includes setting up an independent internal inquiry, setting targets to recruit, retain and promote staff from ethnic minorities, and new anti-discrimination and bullying guidelines. The body is also to consider introducing "integrity testing" for managers and look at ways to tackle "isolation and lack of peer support" felt by staff.

David Calvert-Smith, director of public prosecutions, said: "We are determined to create a working environment that is fair to all and free from discrimination, harassment, victimisation and bullying."

The CPS last year lost two industrial tribunal cases when senior Asian crown prosecutors successfully alleged they had suffered discrimination.
