fields.headline: Public sector pay boost
fields.trailText: Ministers are set to unveil pay rises above inflation for all health workers as they hit back at criticism of Labour's stewardship of the NHS.
fields.byline: David Brindle, Kevin Maguire, Rebecca Smithers  and  Nicholas Watt
fields.body:
Ministers are set to unveil pay rises above inflation for all health workers as they hit back at criticism of Labour's stewardship of the NHS.

Half a million nurses, doctors and therapists will get increases of more than 3% when the government announces on Monday that it is accepting the recommendations of the professions' pay review bodies.

Most nurses will get 3.3% in April, but some - particularly experienced staff on the wards - are expected to receive more in response to pressure for the ironing out of anomalies in the salary structure.

Almost 400,000 other health workers, including ambulance crew and porters are also being offered 3.3% as part of a three year deal designed to take the NHS into a new era of industrial relations. Inflation is 2.2%.

Ministers believe the deals will help get the government back on course after a week in which the flu outbreak has exposed critical failings in the hospital system and Lord Winston, the Labour peer and fertility treatment pioneer, has made devastating criticisms of his party's handling of the NHS.

Teachers in England and Wales are also expected to get pay rises of more than 3%, it emerged last night, although a decision on their review body report is due later this month. That should help the government shore up its reputation for running public services.

Tony Blair will make a 30-minute appearance tomorrow on BBC 1's Breakfast With Frost programme, in which he will speak of his passionate commitment to the NHS. He will argue that Labour had to keep a tight rein on spending during its first two years in office, but that he is now living up to his commitment to increase funding.

Earlier this week, Mr Blair told MPs that, provided the economy remained stable, the health service could look forward to extra resources for "a good three years" after the end of the current, three-year spending programme.

The official announcement on Monday will also help to spike the guns of the Conservatives, who have called a commons debate on Tuesday on the government's "mismanagement" of the health service.

The nurses' pay award is expected to go some way towards addressing the complaints of experienced staff who say that their main salary scale, from £15,395 to £17,830, has fallen out of line since the starting rate for a qualified nurse was last year boosted by 12% to encourage recruitment.

There may also be recognition of the midwives' long-fought case for a common minimum rate - some are paid on the same scale as staff nurses - and possibly reform of the discretionary points system for highly skilled nurses on top clinical grades.

The proposed three year deal for non-review body health workers would give 3% or £250, whichever is greater, for the still unresolved 1999-2000 pay round; 3.25% or £300 for next year; and inflation plus a minimum 0.5% for 2001-02, when a new pay system for the entire NHS is planned.

Bob Abberley, the head of health for Unison, the biggest health union, last night endorsed at least the principle of the offer when he said: "Real increases need to be made year after year if NHS workers are to be paid what they are worth."

The teachers' award is expected to fall between 3% and 3.5%, with many staff also in line for further cash through the new system of performance related pay being introduced in April. Those who demonstrate that they meet new standards will qualify for a one-off rise of about £2,000 and access to a new pay scale.

A spokesman for the Association of Teachers and Lecturers said the expected award, while above inflation, would fall below the rate of increase of average earnings - running at 4.9% - and would be insufficient to make teaching a more attractive profession.

But local authority employers warned that anything above 3% would put intolerable strain on their budgets, hitting plans for school repairs and curbing their ability to comply with initiatives being tabled by David Blunkett, the education secretary.

Graham Lane, of the Local Government Association, representing councils, said: "David Blunkett should realise that in the run up to the next general election, class sizes will go up. The whole thing is dire."

Expected average pay rises

Nurses 3.3%

Doctors 3%+

Therapists 3.3%

Teachers 3-3.5%

webTitle: The NHS: a suitable case for treatment?

fields.headline: The NHS: a suitable case for treatment?
fields.standfirst: The plight of an elderly woman whose son is a top doctor and Labour peer has highlighted the healthcare debate
fields.trailText: If Robert Winston is right, Britain's health service has been in such a parlous state for so long that we barely even notice it any more. At the Labour peer's own hospital in west London, these views were borne out by the experiences of those at the receiving end of the service.
fields.body:
If Robert Winston is right, Britain's health service has been in such a parlous state for so long that we barely even notice it any more. At the Labour peer's own hospital in west London, these views were borne out by the experiences of those at the receiving end of the service.

The Hammersmith is home of Imperial College's medical school and is one of the biggest hospitals in the city. It is also one of the most highly regarded.

But, like every other NHS hospital, its resources are clearly stretched. In the cramped public lobby yesterday, the harassed receptionist struggled to field calls and deal with visitors' inquiries; the corridors throng with doctors and porters bustling between wards. As Lord Winston suggested in his New Statesman interview, there is an air of "just getting by". It is a situation, he suggests, that cannot be allowed to continue.

Jan Smith, from Chelsea, visiting an elderly friend in hospital, said the staff appeared overworked, yet remained highly committed.

"The care my friend is getting is pretty good. They are doing the best they can. You get the impression, though, that they never have quite as much time with each patient as they would like."

Andrew Roberts, from Harrow, described how his aunt had received "impeccable" care at the hospital after she had suffered a heart attack.

"But I think Lord Winston is right. There is a make -do-and-mend mentality in the health service these days - it started under the Tories and it's continuing now. I heard on the radio that he was backtracking. I think that's a shame because someone has to say the sort of things he is saying."

Lord Winston's comments appear to have been prompted by the experience of his own mother at an unnamed NHS hospital in London.

Throughout her life, Ruth Winston-Fox had been committed to improving care services for some of the most vulnerable groups in society: in 1961, she founded one of Britain's first daycare centres for the elderly. Now, at 87, she requires those services herself, and the story of her distressing experience at the NHS frontline has caused a political storm.

Some weeks ago, Mrs Winston-Fox, who suffers from diabetes, required urgent treatment. Lord Winston was on hand to take his mother to hospital; in the New Statesman interview he revealed how she spent 13 hours in a casualty department before being placed in a mixed-sex ward - an environment Labour has pledged to abolish. Drugs were not dispensed on time. She missed meals, and was found lying on the floor one morning after having fallen out of bed during the night.

Mrs Winston-Fox caught an infection and came out of hospital with a leg ulcer. "It is normal. The terrifying thing is that we accept it," Lord Winston said.

To the charity Help the Aged, this sad tale is all too familiar. Inundated with desperate accounts of neglect and poor treatment of the elderly, it recently launched a Dignity on the Wards campaign. All too often old people are left to one side, a low priority for busy doctors and nurses. They miss meals because they cannot reach the plate left on their bedside table and nobody is around to help. They lose weight. Because they are frail and vulnerable, they pick up infections on the ward. Among some staff, there is sometimes an assumption that they have come to die.

Some health economists argue that it is not a correct use of hard-pressed NHS funds to keep very elderly people with chronic diseases alive. But what their relatives perceive as neglect contributes to the public perception of a deteriorating NHS.

Modernisation

It is not a view that the health secretary, Alan Milburn, shares. He talks of modernisation and has funded popular initiatives such as NHS Direct, the telephone call service that may take some of the pressure off GPs. He has put money into the priority areas of cancer and heart disease. He has promised more hospital doctors and is determined to cut waiting lists. All this is upbeat and forward looking, but it can only be achieved at a cost. Something has to give, and although the national institute for clinical excellence has been set up to rule on cost-effectiveness in treatment and should save the NHS money, it will not be enough. Unless the government is prepared to put substantially more money into the NHS, the sad experiences of those such as Lord Winston's mother will continue as hospitals try to grapple with the logistics of providing healthcare for all on a tight budget.

Mrs Winston-Fox was reluctant to talk about her experience yesterday without consulting her son first. She had not read the New Statesman article and had not seen the extensive press coverage of her case, but she confirmed that she regularly received treatment at the Hammersmith.

Had Mrs Winston-Fox been any other 87-year-old, her tale of woe at an underfunded London hospital would have gone unremarked upon, like so many others that barely merit a mention even in the local press any more. But because her son is one of Britain's best known doctors, and a Labour peer, this ordinary story of everyday suffering is now at the centre of the raging debate over the future of health services in this country.

But because her son is one of Britain's best known doctors, and a Labour peer, this ordinary story of everyday suffering is now at the centre of the raging debate over the future of health services in this country. fields.headline: The view from the inside
fields.trailText: Bob Masterton, clinical microbiologist and medical director at Lothian University Hospitals NHS trust, Edinburgh
fields.body:
Bob Masterton, clinical microbiologist and medical director at Lothian University Hospitals NHS trust, Edinburgh

I disagree with Lord Winston. I think the NHS does in general a wonderful job for its patients, particularly when you consider the resources it has available to it.

I would not use the word underfunded. You could never produce enough funding to provide everybody's healthcare needs. I do think he is correct in the sense that there needs to be a very real debate between government, medical and other clinical professions, and, most importantly, the patients, about exactly what the NHS should be. I'm not pretending that everything in the garden is rosy.

I think we have to consider issues around what the NHS should be providing and how it should be funded. For 6% of our GNP we provide a service that is the envy of almost every country in the world.

What should be free within the NHS? We have to face the fact that as new drugs come in, as technology increases, costs increase. We cannot fund an open-ended, free-for-all NHS in the current way. This is something that the public has to address.

Sir George Alberti, professor of medicine at Newcastle University and president of the Royal College of Physicians

We have a lot of good ideas, we are giving more treatments and we have the power to do more than we could.

This has left us with frustrated staff because there are not enough of us. We need more doctors, more nurses, more assistants and more beds.

If we went to the level of funding that exists in Scotland, which is about 25% higher than in England and Wales, we could deal with most problems. The question of higher taxes needs to be put to the public. If people don't want that, we will have to look at one of the better insurance systems. They would be means-tested and help fund the health service properly.

I'm optimistic. I know that several members of the government realise what is needed. It's worth remembering that Frank Dobson secured more money for the health service and I cannot believe the government will not put in a real increase.

David Stott, professor of geriatric medicine at Glasgow University and Glasgow Royal Infirmary

We spend less on health services than virtually any developed country. We can't expect to have anything other than the difficulties we have. The flu outbreak shows how little reserve there is in the system.

Many of us would be sympathetic towards Lord Winston's concerns but I think successive governments should carry some blame for the difficulties. Some of the things the Labour government have done I would feel very positive about. Getting rid of the internal market is very important. I work in a major teaching hospital in Glasgow which should be providing cutting edge care. There are some things that we do that we do very well but there are some we don't. Outpatients are getting a very poor deal. There are major delays. That is very frustrating for patients and for us.

We need public debate on what we want our health service to be and how to fund it.

fields.headline: With flying colours
fields.standfirst: Michael O'Leary, chief executive, Ryanair
fields.trailText: Ryanair, Europe's largest low fares airline, yesterday tried to steal a march over its competitors with the offer of a million seats at prices that make a return rail fare from London to Birmingham look like daylight robbery.
fields.body:
Ryanair, Europe's largest low fares airline, yesterday tried to steal a march over its competitors with the offer of a million seats at prices that make a return rail fare from London to Birmingham look like daylight robbery.

Travelling with only a suitcase and a small bag, Ryanair's energetic chief executive, Michael O'Leary, spent yesterday revealing his bag of riches. The most ridiculous example is what amounts to a net fare of £4 from Stansted to Dublin, plus the compulsory £20.68 airport taxes, making the fare a snip at £24.99.

The return fares are available from Monday either on Ryanair's web site or through travel agents until February 17, and will be valid for travel until April 12. They are offered on 21 of the company's low fare European routes, ranging from £29.99 to Frankfurt and £39.99 to Stockholm.

The economics of the operation appear to defy explanation, although Mr O'Leary, dressed as though for summer in an open necked shirt, jeans and boots, says it is very simple.

Unlike many other low cost carriers, Ryanair is profitable. Its accounts show that it made profits of more than £40m last year and, according to Mr O'Leary, will make around £50m this year. Not much perhaps, in terms of the airline business, but more profit, for instance, than British Airways will achieve this year.

Mr O'Leary has no problems getting personal. "BA have been going downhill for years. I don't think they have the right management. Bob Ayling has long stopped pulling his weight," he says.

"It is ridiculous you have to pay £200 on a BA flight to have a gin and tonic. It has been overcharging for years. Especially on its overseas flights."

He is however kinder to another rival, Richard Branson. "I think Virgin have good PR, but they are a tiny airline with only 2m passengers. Branson got a great deal by selling out [for £600m] to Singapore."

Sail trimming

There is clear evidence in the industry to show that too many seats are chasing too few customers. Recent traffic growth has been brought about by selling seats well below cost. For the survival of operators, flights have to be trimmed to the numbers of seats required for passengers who are willing to pay sensible prices for their journeys. What marks Ryanair out over its competitors is how many people opt to fly the carrier.

BA will make a substantial loss this year and has taken the lead by reducing seat capacity by 12% over the next three years. Among the other large European operators, KLM and SAS are both feeling the financial pinch and among the recent low cost operators, Debonair's insolvency surprised no one.

The problem of unwanted capacity is not restricted to operators near home. Perhaps the most significant is the case of Canadian Airlines, which despite a creditable load factor of 76%, is insolvent. Why? For selling seats too cheaply.

For the brash and breezy Mr O'Leary, is low fares is the only policy and it is work ing. Some 40% of Ryanair's customers are business travellers, who are not sniffy, and 55% of the company's 7m users originate within the UK. Before Ryanair took a grip, flying from London to Dublin was a big deal. The minimum return fare was £212 if you booked three months in advance.

The profiles of Mr O'Leary describe him as an accountant, but he never finished his accountancy exams. He did join the accountants KPMG in the early 80s, but worked as a tax consultant before setting up on his own. His activities ranged from property development to buying and selling newspapers. He was a born entrepreneur and was about to rescue a small ailing Irish airline.

One of his tax clients was Tony Ryan, who had started an airline to compete with Aer Lingus. It had a business class section and served meals, but it charged lower fares than Aer Lingus. The results were disastrous. In the late 1980s, Ryan's company lost copious amounts of money and went through five chief executives in four years.

Mr Ryan asked Mr O'Leary what he should do. "I said close it down. You couldn't give it away."

But Mr Ryan had another idea. He knew Herb Kelleher, who ran Southwest Air lines in the United States. "We went to look at Southwest. It was like the road to Damascus. This was the way to make Ryanair work," recalls Mr O'Leary.

The Southwest formula was to serve no meals, offer no frills and charge the cheapest fares in town. Mr O'Leary tried it at Ryanair, launching low cost services between London and Dublin. He soon discovered that he did not have to lure passengers away from the established airlines.

By charging low fares, he could expand the market, selling tickets to people who might not previously have considered flying. The number of passengers flying between Dublin and Stansted has more than quadrupled over the past decade, turning Dublin into one of the most sought after capitals in Europe for weekend breaks.

Summer holiday

Ryanair has probably managed to cut its overheads even more than other low cost carriers. It serves only drinks, which saves staff clearing up biscuit and crisp crumbs between flights. Turn round is only 25 minutes which means, says Mr O'Leary, that the company's aircraft are 25% more productive than a large carrier or even other low cost airlines.

The company is going into the summer season with six new European routes which it has yet to announce. It has ordered five new Boeing 737s, and is carrying more passengers than Aer Lingus and the Belgian carrier, Sabena. Mr O'Leary admits that potential passengers are kept hanging on the telephone for far too long, but argues that booking on the internet will soon remove this problem.

Why has Ryanair been so successful? For one thing it refrains from intensive market research. Mr O'Leary produces a Reader's Digest map of Europe and says: "We look for the signs which show there's an airport somewhere and go and talk with them."

The company flies only to airports that agree to low landing charges. This usually means avoiding airports used by most other carriers. For Paris, for example, Ryanair flies to the relatively unknown Beauvais airport, rather than Charles de Gaulle or Orly. For Brussels, it flies in to Charleroi, 35 miles south of the city.

At 38, Mr O'Leary is the youngest and one of the most engaging of airline tycoons. He is "depressingly single and living in hope that a woman will find me suf ficiently attractive to settle down."

Out of work, his main love seems to be his home, a 250-acre farm an hour's drive from Dublin, where he breeds cattle and horses. He is a very wealthy man, but says that his main concern is the well-being of his staff, due to rise from 1,300 to 1,500 later this year.

Some of them may regard that as a tongue in cheek remark since he does not recognise trade unions and recently engaged in a bloody dispute with baggage handlers during which he effectively faced them down. But he stresses that he is not anti-union. His staff are all shareholders and have share options varying from £4,000 to £20,000 depending on length of service.

He does not count himself as part of the Irish establishment, being currently involved in a tussle with Dublin airport to prevent an increase in its charges. He has also been accused of "tooth and claw capitalism" by the Irish prime minister, Bertie Ahern, but laughs it off as a "political speech made to a trade union audience, so what would you expect?"

There is no sign that the upward surge in Ryanair's fortunes will be dented, since unless some internal catastrophe is waiting, the airline's plans are for development rather than retrenchment.

But Mr O'Leary is not convinced that many low cost carriers will be functioning five years from now. He thinks that Go, BA's low cost carrier will be struggling, and wonders whether Easyjet will eventually over-reach itself. He would say that of course. Mr O'Leary's forecast is that by the middle of the decade there will only be two cheap no-frills airlines left. Naturally, Ryanair will be one of them.

Useful links: www.ryanair.ie

fields.headline: Lord Fixit
fields.standfirst: His troubleshooting skills won over Margaret Thatcher, the palace, the press and Tony Blair. But his seamless rise had almost ended with the Brighton bomb, which killed his wife.  Anne Perkins  on the consummate deal-maker in charge of reforming the House of Lords
fields.trailText: His troubleshooting skills won over Margaret Thatcher, the palace, the press and Tony Blair. But his seamless rise had almost ended with the Brighton bomb, which killed his wife.  Anne Perkins  on the consummate deal-maker in charge of reforming the House of Lords
fields.body:
There are politicians who think politics is a crusade. And there are those who see it as something altogether more subtle, a tale of deal-making and negotiation, cogs and wheels, a human account of personality and circumstance. Conservatives, until Mrs Thatcher mutinied, were traditionally pragmatists captured only occasionally by principle, sea-anchors on the pirate ship of progress. "Programme?" as Churchill once said, "of course we have a programme. It is a sound belief in the British Constitution."

For most of her reign, Mrs Thatcher's personal sea-anchor was a self-made businessman with a misleadingly modest demeanour. Often obscured by the larger and grander Willie Whitelaw, John (now Lord) Wakeham was her chief whip and later, in a succession of Trollopian-sounding sinecures, lord privy seal and lord president of the council - jobs which left him free to be what amounted to Mrs T's man of business. He squared the party at Westminster, or tricky cabinet ministers, or conflicting policy ambitions, and occasionally warned her that it couldn't be done. Wakeham became a kind of prêt-à-porter version of Whitelaw.

"My ambition was to make the country run better. I am a facilitator, I make things work. I can take a programme of legislation, with everyone wanting something different, and I can end up delivering something everyone can live with."

But he had been out of government for the best part of five years and, as chairman of the Press Complaints Commission, lost to public view, when Tony Blair recruited him to sort out his growing political difficulties over the future of the Lords. He needed someone to chair the royal commission on reform, someone trusted by all sides who wouldn't push an agenda of their own, someone who would deliver a solution that would work.

Reform of the Lords is the last hole in his jigsaw of constitutional reform: Wakeham's job is to make a piece that fits. Next Thursday the report is published and Wakeham will reveal - with no advance notice to Blair, he insists - whether he has pulled it off. "The test of success," says Wakeham, "will be that people will say, 'well, a bit disappointing, not quite what I wanted, but we can live with it' ... because if it was wonderful for somebody it would be unacceptable to someone else."

What to some politicians would be a disastrous lack of conviction and fighting instinct, is to Wakeham the supreme virtue. Where others dream of redesigning the economic or social landscape, his dream is simply an engineer's desire to make things work. Trust is the lubricant of the Wakeham machine. "I don't think there are too many people who can move into one set of politicians or another set of politicians and be trusted enough to do deals with them. People trust me. They know I'll play straight and try to find a solution."

Tony Blair is not trusting Wakeham on his reputation alone. Less than two years ago, Blair's lord chancellor and his home secretary were at loggerheads over the impact of incorporating the European convention on human rights on press freedom. Lord Irvine argued it would have no effect. Jack Straw was a lot less confident and so was Wakeham. Then, as the legislation went through parliament, Irvine did a U-turn which enabled Jack Straw to change the bill in a way which the Press Complaints Commission is now confident will protect self-regulation. Wakeham is credited with being the key intermediary.

He has prospered by cutting deals and troubleshooting for most of his adult life, a skill acquired, his more snobbish critics claim, from his garage-owning father, Walter. But John Wakeham might have been a farmer (he now owns a farm in south west Wales), and a perfect day for him is to get up with the dawn, get the papers from the shop in the Hampshire village where he lives, go down to the Solent and motor his old fishing boat to Osborne Bay where he anchors, reads the papers and makes calls on his mobile. "I can talk to the people I need to. No one can reach me."

This is the independence his father, a powerful presence in his son's mind even 30 years after his death, told him to strive for.

"There was only one sort of materialistic ambition my father gave me, and that wasn't to be rich, it was to be independent. He thought you should do things in life which gave you as much freedom to move as possible. That's why I became an accountant. I was never quite sure whether he was a Conservative, but he used to say, 'you've got to give the elected government of the day the benefit of the doubt, until they've been proved wrong'. He was methodical, level-headed, he didn't get too excited. I'm quite methodical, and I don't get too excited."

Years later, lamenting the damage to political life caused by the antipathy between Margaret Thatcher and Neil Kinnock, a friend remembers John shaking his head sadly, as he said: "The trouble is they're different ages, different ideologies, different life experiences. Their lives scarcely touch at any point." At heart, Wakeham probably believes the prime minister and the leader of the opposition, whoever they are, are united by more than divides them, and that like Harold Macmillan and Harold Wilson they should, after a particularly bruising encounter at the despatch box, meet privately for a drink and a bit of mutual backslapping.

John Wakeham was born in 1932, the first of three children. His father came back from the war to the family garage in what was then the small market town of Godalming in Surrey, just in time to scrape together the money to send John off to Charterhouse, the nearby public school. Major Wakeham had firm views about education. He believed that 10 years of it was quite enough. That ruled out university. But, through what he regards as his father's sacrifices in sending him to public school, the young John slipped quietly through the conventional life pattern of the professional middle classes, leaving scarcely a ripple: Charterhouse School, the City, Westminster and the Carlton Club.

Eric Harrison, a master who taught him chemistry and became a friend, remembers him as "very receptive, very pleasant to deal with". Hardly the stuff of greatness. "No, I wouldn't have predicted great things from him. But it's often the ones who don't stand out at school who go on and do well."

Wakeham seems to have turned a tendency to anonymity into an asset. No need to airbrush him out of recent history as the Tories struggle to reinvent themselves. No one remembers he was there in the first place. His name is in the indexes of all those fat political memoirs of Mrs Thatcher's ministers but it's hard to find him in the narrative. "Subtle" and "wily" are the two adjectives most often attached to his name. Yet he was at the top table for many of the major events from the moment he became chief whip in 1983 until he failed to fix it for Thatcher in 1990, not as some Machiavellian string-puller, but as the team mechanic, the man with the oily rag who knew how to make things work.

It's said that he endeared himself to Thatcher because he'd passed his accountancy exams - qualifications her son Mark had failed to notch up. It seems more plausible that it was his subsequent business success that marked him out in his prime minister's eyes. He turned his accountancy training into a highly profitable flair for company doctoring, which had made him his first million before he was out of his twenties. Less than 10 years later, as well as a thriving accountancy practice, he had a controlling interests in half a dozen companies. By the time he married his first wife Roberta (they had met at an English Speaking Union party in 1962) and prepared to go into politics, he had 1,000 people working for him.

But Tory selection committees are notoriously sceptical of success. Or perhaps it was a lack of ideological zeal, showing through even then. (He is proud to boast that he is one of only three non-voting members of the Fabian society. The others are Sir Geoffrey Howe and John Maynard Keynes. "I didn't support Labour, I joined because I was interested in politics.") It took him nearly 10 years to find and win a safe seat: he was finally elected, for Maldon in Essex, in 1974, distinguished from the other new entrants, it's said, only by having his own driver and car phone.

"If you look at the 100 or so of that intake, there were obvious people like Leon Brittan and Nigel Lawson who were going to make it. But me? Not many would have forecast it." Not that he went into politics, he claims unconvincingly, to get on. "I felt I owed it to my father to have wider ambitions than just being an accountant. I felt I had to justify myself."

Political history is littered with the failed careers of people who, having been stars in their own world, sweep into politics to make a similar success only to lose their way in the arcane, contrary labyrinth of Westminster. Wakeham set out to learn. As soon as he had sorted out his business interests and made himself available for promotion, he was recruited into the whips' office. It didn't take him long to realise that his skills, honed in business, could be applied as usefully to the backstairs of Westminster politics.

"I was absolutely fascinated by how Westminster actually works, the interplay of all the different forces, the smoke-filled rooms, the nods and the winks. As a businessman, I found it more comprehensible than most politicians do. The driving force in my life is how you make things happen, what are the processes which make things move ahead. "One thing I learnt as chief whip," he goes on, "was the infinite capacity of human beings to absorb flattery. And that the one thing you have to be is trustworthy. If you sell someone a pup once, you'll never be trusted again."

Trust is Wakeham's secret weapon. "You could tell him anything, and I mean anything, and know it would never go any further," one old colleague reported. "And people on all sides of the house knew that. And you know where you stand, you always know what basis you're talking to him on, that he's not operating some secret scheme of his own." One ex-whip, Andrew Mitchell, remembers being recruited by Wakeham. "He was amazing. He said, 'I will tell you everything. Don't let me down'. Can you think of a better way of ensuring someone's loyalty? He's remarkably uncynical about people. If he thinks you're a good egg, he'll forgive you the crassest mistakes. If he doesn't, you're in outer darkness."

For all of Thatcher's second term, Wakeham was her chief whip, her capo di tutti capi, running the team responsible for keeping the leadership in touch with the troops, soothing egos, balancing interests, trying to make sure everyone who mattered got a little of what they wanted. In particular, he was careful to keep the wets, the refuseniks, on board (and out of the then flourishing SDP). Julian Critchley, one of the government's most devastating backbench critics, says he was formidable. "He was extremely well briefed," he says. "Once, when Francis Pym, who'd been chief whip himself, told him just as a courtesy that he was going to make a speech at the Oxford Union condemning Thatcher and all her works, Wakeham said, 'oh, I know all about that'. And he had part of Pym's speech in front of him on his desk."

Part of Wakeham's strength was that he was never "One of Us", but he and Thatcher remain close. "I was not impervious to her weaknesses," he says. "But I think she did a tremendous job at the things she had to do for this country. And I could help her. I got things delivered. I didn't go running to her with problems. She never wanted to trim. Sometimes you had to force her to. I used to give her my best advice, but if it was unpalatable I told it to her before a meeting, so that no one else knew and she could play the meeting how she liked; if she wanted to she could ask what I had thought. We achieved a lot of things that way."

He also had a huge majority. He exploited it to turn the whips' office into a political nursery, a test bed for talent. He was Thatcher's scout, and he spotted John Major, who wrote of him: "John Wakeham was subtle, reflective, a persuader, a fixer, fascinated by why something happened rather than simply what had happened... he played Mrs Thatcher like a master fisherman landing a prize salmon."

In 1984, his life was shattered, and his career stalled, when the IRA killed his wife Roberta and very nearly killed him. After seven hours trapped in the wreckage of the Grand Hotel in Brighton, he was left with such terrible crush injuries to his legs that he nearly lost them. "I can remember most of it... I was very clear that my responsibility was to bring up my sons, who were nine and 11. If I became bitter about it all there was no way I could make a happy home for them, and I had to force myself not to be bitter. You did your crying at night."

There is an agonising pause as he is suddenly overwhelmed with memories. "I've never dreamt about it, thank God. One of the most distressing things was when I talked to a girl who is writing a book about the fire brigade, and she played me an interview with the guy who was in charge that night." It is the magnitude of the fire chief's horror at his predicament which he finds devastating to hear. "'There's another guy in there, Wake-somebody...'" Wakeham breaks off abruptly. "No, I can't do this, it's not fair."

His life was put back together by his secretary, Alison Ward. They married in 1985 and, when they had a son together, she also adopted the two boys from his first marriage. They are now grown up: Jonathan is in advertising, but also writes (opera libretti and film scripts); Ben is an estate agent. Alison had worked for Thatcher and is by all accounts a powerful personality. "It's said of her that on a bad day she can turn milk to yoghurt at 50 paces," her husband announces.

The bomb is not a part of his life he can easily bring himself to revisit. He refuses to comment on the Northern Ireland peace process and the early release of the bombers. His tone suggests that if he did, it would not necessarily be in a spirit of forgiveness.

But Matthew Parris, a friend, agrees that he has succeeded in escaping bitterness. "Whereas Norman Tebbit grew angrier, it seems to me John Wakeham has grown more mellow."

He was back in the whips' office, on two sticks but miraculously walking, more quickly than anyone believed possible. By the 1987 elec tion, after four years as chief whip, he wanted a real role to play, his own powerbase, and preferably his own department to run, although he told friends he knew he couldn't take a job which would be too physically demanding. When Nigel Lawson asked him to be his number two as Treasury Chief Secretary, he said no. "He obviously hoped for something better", Lawson recorded in his memoirs.

But he had had a patchy 1987 election campaign, and Mrs Thatcher put him into another negotiating role, as Leader of the house. It was only after she needed his job for Sir Geoffrey Howe that he finally became secretary of state for energy. It was ideally suited for a businessman-fixer. The biggest and most complex of the privatisations, electricity, was running into the ground under Cecil Parkinson. Wakeham regards it as his finest hour. Stephen Littlechild, the economist who became the privatised industry's first regulator, agrees. "Much of the conceptual thinking had been done," he recalls, "but it was not clear that privatisation was actually going to go ahead. Wakeham did it, with charm, and without making enemies. He took each party separately, told them he understood their concerns but had to take account of others too. He won respect from all concerned. He put together a package which gave something to all the main players."

Matthew Parris agrees. "It is impossible to overrate him as a fixer. He is a master of never adding insult to injury. I don't see him as a political original, like Willie Whitelaw, but if I wanted somebody to break difficult news, or to persuade someone of something difficult to accept, I would go to John Wakeham."

Just as the climax of electricity privatisation approached in 1990, the crisis of nerve among Tory MPs over Thatcher's leadership reached its own climax, and Sir Geoffrey Howe sank the assassin's dagger between her shoulderblades. When the disastrous results of the first ballot came through, Thatcher turned to Wakeham, to try to rescue her doomed campaign. But he had been too absorbed in the privatisation to be up to speed with the state of mind of the cabinet, never mind the wider party.

Fatally, it was his idea that, since she could not stay without cabinet's support, she should ask her ministers for it, individually. Although only the most committed Thatcherites believe it was an act of disloyalty, it was a terminally serious misjudgment about how to play a desperate situation. As they trooped in one by one to tell her she couldn't win, she was left with no option but to resign.

At first it seemed he would prosper under the new regime: as chief whip he had, after all, talent-spotted the new prime minister . Instead his influence waned sharply. In 1992 he went to the Lords. "Cabinet ministers are like football managers. Everyone's endlessly discussing their prospects. When John Major asked me to be leader of the Lords, I said only for two years. That was my way of making sure my political career didn't end in tears."

But observers thought he looked uncomfortable in the Lords, that the difficulty of dealing with the unpredictable and undisciplined hereditary peers didn't suit his more mechanistic approach to deal-making. "Government Fixer Needs New Tool Kit", one headline writer claimed. "Past his sell-by date" they wrote when he went.

But Wakeham's reputation is built on the ability to see what's round the corner. Through the late 80s and into the 90s, as the details of the Prince and Princess of Wales' marriage came to the lascivious attentions of the tabloids, steam had been building behind demands for laws to control what the papers could print. Mrs Thatcher asked Wakeham to explore ways of making controls work. He reported (by then to John Major) that they couldn't. "I've always been sympathetic to a free press. It's very high on everyone's list of characteristics of a free society. I persuaded John Major that it was better to try to let self-regulation assert itself and the press took it on, and set up the Press Complaints Commission."

In 1995, "by a whole range of coincidences", Wakeham, newly out of government, became PCC chairman, and for the second time in his life, found the perfect playground for the intuitive negotiator, the man who likes to make things run smoothly. High on his list of priorities were the dire relations between the palace and the press. Wakeham carefully enumerated the areas for negotiation: a balance between the young princes' right to the same treatment as any other children and the press's legitimate interest in the way they were growing up; the palace's failure to find the right moments to present the princes to the press - and the danger of Prince Charles passing on his contempt for the media to his sons.

The answer to these problems seems to have been Wakeham's protege Mark Bolland, former director of the PCC but now a senior figure in Prince Charles's entourage and widely credited with transforming the relationship between St James's Palace and Fleet Street.

Piers Morgan, editor of the Mirror, says Wakeham is "magnificent". "He is one of the most adroit and adept managers and fixers I have ever dealt with. One of his great qualities is that he always calms everything down, he stops people acting on the spur of the moment. He makes everyone think they've got the best deal. He's a brilliant manipulator, in the best sense of the word."

If the royal story looks better though, there are plenty of critics of the PCC's clout in the more run-of-the-mill episodes of press manipulation. The number of complaints has doubled, and only a couple of months ago a tabloid was in the dock again over paying a witness in the Gary Glitter trial. "It's a complete waste of time," said one ex-colleague of Wakeham, not one of his admirers. "He's got absolutely no vision at all. He only ever asks how instead of why."

On the other hand, demand for legislation has gone quiet and, Wakeham says darkly, the tabloids have far more intrusive stories they could print and don't. He believes they are behaving more responsibly. You can see that the whole idea of the law being used to resolve disputes is unattractive to him. You go with the flow, he believes, tightening the voluntary code as he did, for example, after Princess Diana's death, when resistance is weakest, and do all you can to avoid challenges on points where you won't carry popular support.

But the Wakeham magic is not infallible. In 1996, he stepped into the poisonous brew of British horseracing. He became chairman of the recently-founded British Horseracing Board, set up to try to unite for the first time the diverse interests of bloodstock breeders, owners, trainers and racecourse owners. He was supposed to be using his influence in Whitehall to get some tax concessions. He failed: not only did he not win the concessions but he did not even get an agreed position to present to government.

"He hadn't taken on board how difficult it is to control a collection of sectional interests, some of whom are there only for their own ends," says one close student of his progress. "The BHB's founding principle was that everyone was united in seeking the greater good of the industry. But when it came to the crunch, they all fought like cornered rats for their own interests."

"He didn't handle himself very well," one of the grander grandees muses. "For the first time, probably, he found himself in a world without sanctions. He didn't have the authority to make people agree. So he walked out." In the view of the old Jockey Club types, he decided to protect his reputation rather than lay it down for the greater good of the sport of kings. Wakeham was bruised by the experience. He doesn't like to fail, even if he thinks it's everyone else who's in the wrong. It undermines his conviction that in the end, anything can be settled by a clever deal.

It was one of those deals which got him into racing in the first place. He wanted to sail. His first wife Roberta wanted to go racing. "So I used to put all those entrance badges you get each time you go racing into a little box on my desk, and every time we went sailing I'd take two out. As long as there were badges in the bowl, I felt it was OK to go sailing."

Sailing, Wakeham's lifelong passion only recently given up because he feels he's no longer nimble enough, is itself the ultimate negotiation between man and the elements, where your very life can depend on an accurate assessment of external factors and their influence on your chosen course. Of course sailing is much easier if you don't much mind where you make your landfall.

Wakeham, whose hero, oddly, is the uncompromising Admiral Nelson, now awaits judgment on what could be the most enduring of deals he has ever worked on, the future of the House of Lords. He has to navigate a course to a second chamber which doesn't challenge the role of the Commons (can't be all elected) or put unacceptable powers of patronage into prime ministerial hands (can't be all appointed) but which does, somehow, find a way of reflecting the constituent parts of the United Kingdom.

"The Lords has got to be complimentary to the Commons: the Commons has the democratic mandate but the Lords has to be the house of authority. And you can argue that part of that authority must come from the people. The politicians have got to have the final say because otherwise the report will just gather dust on the shelves the way royal commission reports do. And, if you're going to make constitutional advance it is infinitely better if you can get as broad a cross-section of support as possible."

So, don't hold your breath for radical ideas. Like devolution, the new House of Lords is more likely to be a process than an event. But if it's a success, John Wakeham will have built a fine memorial for himself as the man who could make things work.

Life at a glace

John Wakeham, Baron of Maldon in the County of Essex

Born: June 22 1932.
Education: Charterhouse School; chartered accountancy.
Married: 1965 Anne Roberta Bailey (died 1984), two sons; 1985 Alison Bridget Ward, one son.
Political career:
MP (Con) Maldon, 1974-1983, Colchester South and Maldon 1983-92;
Asst govt whip 1979-81
Parliamentary undersecretary, dept of industry, 1981-2
Minister of state, treasury, 1982-3
Chief whip, 1983-87
Lord Privy Seal, 1987-8
Leader of the House of Commons 1987-9
Lord President of the Council, 1988-89
Sec of state for energy, 1989-92
Minister responsible for coordinating the presentation of government policies, 1990-92;
Lord Privy Seal and Leader of the House of Lords, 1992-4.

Other appointments:
Chairman, British Horseracing Board, 1996-98
Chancellor, Brunel University 1998-.

Honours: Life peer,1992.

And there are those who see it as something altogether more subtle, a tale of deal-making and negotiation, cogs and wheels, a human account of personality and circumstance. Conservatives, until Mrs Thatcher mutinied, were traditionally pragmatists captured only occasionally by principle, sea-anchors on the pirate ship of progress. "Programme?" as Churchill once said, "of course we have a programme. It is a sound belief in the British Constitution." For most of her reign, Mrs Thatcher's personal sea-anchor was a self-made businessman with a misleadingly modest demeanour. Often obscured by the larger and grander Willie Whitelaw, John (now Lord) Wakeham was her chief whip and later, in a succession of Trollopian-sounding sinecures, lord privy seal and lord president of the council - jobs which left him free to be what amounted to Mrs T's man of business. He squared the party at Westminster, or tricky cabinet ministers, or conflicting policy ambitions, and occasionally warned her that it couldn't be done. Wakeham became a kind of prêt-à-porter version of Whitelaw. "My ambition was to make the country run better. I am a facilitator, I make things work. I can take a programme of legislation, with everyone wanting something different, and I can end up delivering something everyone can live with." But he had been out of government for the best part of five years and, as chairman of the Press Complaints Commission, lost to public view, when Tony Blair recruited him to sort out his growing political difficulties over the future of the Lords. He needed someone to chair the royal commission on reform, someone trusted by all sides who wouldn't push an agenda of their own, someone who would deliver a solution that would work. Reform of the Lords is the last hole in his jigsaw of constitutional reform: Wakeham's job is to make a piece that fits. Next Thursday the report is published and Wakeham will reveal - with no advance notice to Blair, he insists - whether he has pulled it off. "The test of success," says Wakeham, "will be that people will say, 'well, a bit disappointing, not quite what I wanted, but we can live with it' ... because if it was wonderful for somebody it would be unacceptable to someone else." What to some politicians would be a disastrous lack of conviction and fighting instinct, is to Wakeham the supreme virtue. Where others dream of redesigning the economic or social landscape, his dream is simply an engineer's desire to make things work. Trust is the lubricant of the Wakeham machine. "I don't think there are too many people who can move into one set of politicians or another set of politicians and be trusted enough to do deals with them. People trust me. They know I'll play straight and try to find a solution." Tony Blair is not trusting Wakeham on his reputation alone. Less than two years ago, Blair's lord chancellor and his home secretary were at loggerheads over the impact of incorporating the European convention on human rights on press freedom. Lord Irvine argued it would have no effect. Jack Straw was a lot less confident and so was Wakeham. Then, as the legislation went through parliament, Irvine did a U-turn which enabled Jack Straw to change the bill in a way which the Press Complaints Commission is now confident will protect self-regulation. Wakeham is credited with being the key intermediary. He has prospered by cutting deals and troubleshooting for most of his adult life, a skill acquired, his more snobbish critics claim, from his garage-owning father, Walter. But John Wakeham might have been a farmer (he now owns a farm in south west Wales), and a perfect day for him is to get up with the dawn, get the papers from the shop in the Hampshire village where he lives, go down to the Solent and motor his old fishing boat to Osborne Bay where he anchors, reads the papers and makes calls on his mobile. "I can talk to the people I need to. No one can reach me." This is the independence his father, a powerful presence in his son's mind even 30 years after his death, told him to strive for. "There was only one sort of materialistic ambition my father gave me, and that wasn't to be rich, it was to be independent. He thought you should do things in life which gave you as much freedom to move as possible. That's why I became an accountant. I was never quite sure whether he was a Conservative, but he used to say, 'you've got to give the elected government of the day the benefit of the doubt, until they've been proved wrong'. He was methodical, level-headed, he didn't get too excited. I'm quite methodical, and I don't get too excited." Years later, lamenting the damage to political life caused by the antipathy between Margaret Thatcher and Neil Kinnock, a friend remembers John shaking his head sadly, as he said: "The trouble is they're different ages, different ideologies, different life experiences. Their lives scarcely touch at any point." At heart, Wakeham probably believes the prime minister and the leader of the opposition, whoever they are, are united by more than divides them, and that like Harold Macmillan and Harold Wilson they should, after a particularly bruising encounter at the despatch box, meet privately for a drink and a bit of mutual backslapping. John Wakeham was born in 1932, the first of three children. His father came back from the war to the family garage in what was then the small market town of Godalming in Surrey, just in time to scrape together the money to send John off to Charterhouse, the nearby public school. "It's a complete waste of time," said one ex-colleague of Wakeham, not one of his admirers. "He's got absolutely no vision at all. He only ever asks how instead of why." On the other hand, demand for legislation has gone quiet and, Wakeham says darkly, the tabloids have far more intrusive stories they could print and don't. He believes they are behaving more responsibly. You can see that the whole idea of the law being used to resolve disputes is unattractive to him. You go with the flow, he believes, tightening the voluntary code as he did, for example, after Princess Diana's death, when resistance is weakest, and do all you can to avoid challenges on points where you won't carry popular support. But the Wakeham magic is not infallible. In 1996, he stepped into the poisonous brew of British horseracing. He became chairman of the recently-founded British Horseracing Board, set up to try to unite for the first time the diverse interests of bloodstock breeders, owners, trainers and racecourse owners. He was supposed to be using his influence in Whitehall to get some tax concessions. He failed: not only did he not win the concessions but he did not even get an agreed position to present to government. "He hadn't taken on board how difficult it is to control a collection of sectional interests, some of whom are there only for their own ends," says one close student of his progress. "The BHB's founding principle was that everyone was united in seeking the greater good of the industry. But when it came to the crunch, they all fought like cornered rats for their own interests." "He didn't handle himself very well," one of the grander grandees muses. "For the first time, probably, he found himself in a world without sanctions. He didn't have the authority to make people agree. So he walked out." In the view of the old Jockey Club types, he decided to protect his reputation rather than lay it down for the greater good of the sport of kings. Wakeham was bruised by the experience. He doesn't like to fail, even if he thinks it's everyone else who's in the wrong. It undermines his conviction that in the end, anything can be settled by a clever deal. It was one of those deals which got him into racing in the first place. He wanted to sail. His first wife Roberta wanted to go racing. "So I used to put all those entrance badges you get each time you go racing into a little box on my desk, and every time we went sailing I'd take two out. As long as there were badges in the bowl, I felt it was OK to go sailing." Sailing, Wakeham's lifelong passion only recently given up because he feels he's no longer nimble enough, is itself the ultimate negotiation between man and the elements, where your very life can depend on an accurate assessment of external factors and their influence on your chosen course. Of course sailing is much easier if you don't much mind where you make your landfall. Wakeham, whose hero, oddly, is the uncompromising Admiral Nelson, now awaits judgment on what could be the most enduring of deals he has ever worked on, the future of the House of Lords. He has to navigate a course to a second chamber which doesn't challenge the role of the Commons (can't be all elected) or put unacceptable powers of patronage into prime ministerial hands (can't be all appointed) but which does, somehow, find a way of reflecting the constituent parts of the United Kingdom. "The Lords has got to be complimentary to the Commons: the Commons has the democratic mandate but the Lords has to be the house of authority. And you can argue that part of that authority must come from the people. The politicians have got to have the final say because otherwise the report will just gather dust on the shelves the way royal commission reports do. And, if you're going to make constitutional advance it is infinitely better if you can get as broad a cross-section of support as possible." So, don't hold your breath for radical ideas. Like devolution, the new House of Lords is more likely to be a process than an event. But if it's a success, John Wakeham will have built a fine memorial for himself as the man who could make things work. Life at a glace John Wakeham, Baron of Maldon in the County of Essex Born: June 22 1932. Education: Charterhouse School; chartered accountancy. Married: 1965 Anne Roberta Bailey (died 1984), two sons; 1985 Alison Bridget Ward, one son. Political career: MP (Con) Maldon, 1974-1983, Colchester South and Maldon 1983-92; Asst govt whip 1979-81 Parliamentary undersecretary, dept of industry, 1981-2 Minister of state, treasury, 1982-3 Chief whip, 1983-87 Lord Privy Seal, 1987-8 Leader of the House of Commons 1987-9 Lord President of the Council, 1988-89 Sec of state for energy, 1989-92 Minister responsible for coordinating the presentation of government policies, 1990-92; Lord Privy Seal and Leader of the House of Lords, 1992-4. Other appointments: Chairman, British Horseracing Board, 1996-98 Chancellor, Brunel University 1998-. Honours: Life peer,1992.

webTitle: A selection of difficulties for England

fields.headline: A selection of difficulties for England
fields.trailText: An unerring sense of deja vu overwhelmed me during the fourth Test. Not because of England's oh-so-familiar batting collapse, but because of the ensuing brouhaha: bad pitches, the counties' self interest, too many players, youngsters not blooded early enough, and so on. It could have been any year since 1992. But instead of this serial proffering of explanations, why don't we actually do something about it?
fields.body:
An unerring sense of deja vu overwhelmed me during the fourth Test. Not because of England's oh-so-familiar batting collapse, but because of the ensuing brouhaha: bad pitches, the counties' self interest, too many players, youngsters not blooded early enough, and so on. It could have been any year since 1992. But instead of this serial proffering of explanations, why don't we actually do something about it?

English cricket clearly has a lot of problems. There are no quick fixes, but we've been saying this for over a decade now, so the long-term solutions haven't been up to much either. An outsider - in the sense of values as much as nationality - is clearly needed to take the long handle to cricket organisation in this country. Lord MacLaurin looked to be the man for the job, but even he seems to have been intoxicated by the conservative approach that pervades our cricketing culture. And it is pervasive, from the offices to the middle: when, for example, did we last see an English batsman attempt to hit a spinner out of the attack by going over the top a la Chris Cairns at The Oval?

Consistency of selection is a big problem. The balance between competition for places, and the confidence that is engendered by a sense of security, is so context-based (it may, for example, depend on which players are available at any one time) as to make it difficult to master. It's fair to say that even the best sides don't always get it right (Brad Hogg or John Commins, anyone?), but England do worse than most. The dropping of some players has clearly benefited them in the long run - Darren Gough in 1996, for instance - but it is the treatment of young players that is most perturbing. If a young player is to be selected for Test cricket, he should surely be given five Tests minimum, barring a bad trot of Rutherfordian proportions. To the England selectors, such logic seems anathema: in recent years, three of our most promising cricketers, Ben Hollioake, Andrew Flintoff, and Chris Read have all received shoddy treatment from the selectors.

Hollioake's situation, dropped for a 'dead' Test during the 1997 Ashes, was especially ridiculous, an omission from which he has arguably never recovered. Here is a player of outstanding natural ability, who has played just two Tests in two and a half years. Surely, in a period of transition (England seem to have been in transition since 1992), a run in the Test side would have facilitated the confidence to allow his talent to flourish. (And this isn't just a current selectorial problem - Mark Ramprakash was nonsensically omitted from the three Tests in New Zealand in 1991-92, with Dermot Reeve playing his only three Tests instead; as a result, Ramprakash had, up to August 1998, played just one Test against teams other than West Indies, Australia, South Africa and Pakistan.)

It seems that England's selectors only discover these newcomers' technical flaws in the Test arena (Chris Read standing up, for example, or Chris Adams outside off stump). If this is so, what exactly are they basing selection on? Even then, the only way these flaws are to be eradicated is to learn against the best players in the world. If Andrew Flintoff is too leaden-footed, as he was shown to be in his first two Tests in 1998, a year of smearing 60-ball centuries with no foot movement will only exacerbate the problem.

In this country, there is an inability to make brave judgements on a player's actual ability, rather than on their statistical performances. The media don't help: too often county form is used as a barometer of a player's suitability for the Test side, surely an oxymoronic notion given the pitiful state of the county game. The exclusion of Dean Headley, on the back of two genuinely heroic performances against the world's best side, for the first Test against New Zealand last summer was a classic example. And David Graveney, in justifying Hollioake's omission from this winter's tour parties, famously said that he should remember that 'runs and wickets in county cricket pay the rent'. If this was always the case, however, David Gower would have been homeless long before that glorious cover drive off Aqib Javed made him (then) England's leading runscorer.

Conflicting selectorial philosophies seem inexplicably interchangeable. There is a time and a place to pitch youngsters in: to do so en masse for the last Test against New Zealand, however, was flagrantly flawed. Surely the consequences of defeat were obvious? (This contrasts heavily with the summer of 1997, when winning the last Test of a dead series seemed more important than furthering the development of the career of our most naturally gifted young player.) And so it proved: Ed Giddins, Ronnie Irani (sort of) and Darren Maddy were the newcomers, the signal of our intent to build for the future. Only Maddy has played for England since, and he's hardly shone. Giddins must feel expecially grieved, as he did very little wrong in what may well be his only Test.

Selectorial error aside, the farce that is county cricket clearly has a lot to answer for. That we have too many players is irrefutable (it should be the case that almost all first-class cricketers should be able to do themselves justice at international level), and the self-interest of the counties means this is unlikely to change. It all comes down to priorities: the rhetoric is that the whole system is geared towards the national side, but this is plainly not the case. Until this changes - and ironically the 'solution' of two divisions hasn't helped, fostering as it does the current preponderance of result pitches (is it any coincidence that England's most capable seam bowler plies his trade at Taunton, one of the few grounds known for good cricket wickets in England?) - this period of transition will go on and on, moving as certainly towards three figures as Steve Waugh in the first Test of a series.

Anyway, no musing on the England cricket team is complete without a proposed XII, for the first Test against Zimbabwe. So here it is:

Atherton, Vaughan, Hussain, Thorpe, Stewart, Ramprakash, Flintoff, Caddick, Schofield, Gough, Silverwood, B Hollioake.

Rob Smyth is a student at Nottingham University

webTitle: East Timor may beat Britain into the eurozone

fields.headline: East Timor may beat Britain into the eurozone
fields.trailText: Which country will sign up for the euro first, Britain or East Timor? It may be a long shot but the odds are actually swinging towards East Timor.
fields.body:
Which country will sign up for the euro first, Britain or East Timor? It may be a long shot but the odds are actually swinging towards East Timor.

As the country seeks to rebuild its economy after the havoc caused by pro-Jakarta militias that followed East Timor's vote to end two decades of Indonesian rule, the main political grouping - the National Council for East Timorese Resistance - favours adopting the Portuguese escudo.

The Indonesian rupiah is still the most widely used currency - ahead of the Australian and US dollars - but is regarded as too unstable to be a viable long-term option. Portugal is the former colonial power and is already offering substantial economic support.

International Monetary Fund economist Luis Mendonca argued yesterday that the escudo is a part of the euro and the single currency would make a better option. "I think the East Timorese themselves consider three currencies for the future - the US dollar, the Australian and the euro."

The East Timorese will decide which currency to pick at the end of the year. When Britain will make its single currency decision is rather less clear.

Yesterday the former European Union commissioner Sir Leon Brittan warned that indecision was damaging Britain's influence in Europe.

"There is no doubt at all there is uncertainty and division, with cabinet ministers taking up contrasting positions in public," he said.

That was obscuring the government's position which meant "we lose influence in Europe and any hope of playing a central and indeed a leading role in Europe becomes more and more remote", Sir Leon said in a Radio 4 interview.

webTitle: Blair's 'single currency pledge to EU leaders'

fields.headline: Blair's 'single currency pledge to EU leaders'
fields.standfirst: Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair has told fellow European leaders in private that Britain will join the European single currency after the next general election, according to the former Brussels commissioner Lord Brittan.
fields.body:
Tony Blair has told fellow European leaders in private that Britain will join the European single currency after the next general election, according to the former Brussels commissioner Lord Brittan.

In a clear signal that the prime minister is sounding more enthusiastic about the euro behind closed doors on the continent, Lord Brittan said Mr Blair had given a "clear impression" that the pound was to be scrapped within a few years.

Downing Street played down Lord Brittan's remarks. The prime minister's spokesman said the government had made clear for two years that it would like to join the euro in principle. Mr Blair would hold a referendum after the election if economic conditions were met.

However, Lord Brittan, who retired from the European commission last year after 10 years, indicated that Mr Blair was planning to hold a referendum whatever happens to the British economy. He let slip Mr Blair's private remarks as he rounded on the government for appearing to go cool on the euro in the last few weeks.

"The apparently clear view of the government that it was giving to foreign governments, that they were gradually taking us forward and we would join after the next election, is utterly obscured," he told Radio 4's Today programme.

Lord Brittan, a former Tory minister who usually directs his fire at the eurosceptic opposition leader, William Hague, criticised the government after cabinet feuding over the euro broke into the open.

Robin Cook, the formerly eurosceptic foreign secretary, is leading the pro-euro wing of the cabinet, which is calling on Mr Blair to indicate now that Britain will hold a referendum after the election. His faction is opposed by the chancellor, Gordon Brown, who says the decision should be deferred until after the election, to concentrate Labour's campaign on his successful management of the economy.

Downing Street insisted yesterday that all ministers were in agreement over the euro. But Lord Brittan, who had regular contact with senior ministers until the end of last year, said: "There is no doubt that there is uncertainty and division, with cabinet ministers taking up contrasting positions in public."

He also lent weight to the argument that the chancellor's five tests, which Britain must pass before it can join the euro, are just a convenient way of allowing the government to wait. "The official test is so flexible it could mean anything," Lord Brittan said. "You can say today [the criteria] have been met, you can say they haven't been met in 10 years' time.

"If Tony Blair wants to have a leading role in the European Union he will have to personally assert himself among his divided cabinet and set out a clear role."

The prime minister's official spokesman said public figures were allowing themselves to be interviewed as part of a "wholly misinformed debate".

fields.headline: Islington schools chief named
fields.trailText: The chief education officer of one of England's top performing local education authorities has been hired to head the first "privatised" local authority schools service, it was announced yesterday.
fields.body:
The chief education officer of one of England's top performing local education authorities has been hired to head the first "privatised" local authority schools service, it was announced yesterday.

Vincent McDonnell, currently at Richmond upon Thames, is to take up the post of director of schools' services for Islington in north London in April.

The appointment was announced yesterday as the private firm, Cambridge Education Associates, signed an £11.5m a year contract to run support services for schools in Islington.

The department for education ordered intervention after a highly critical report by the schools watchdog, Ofsted, last May. The firm will receive a £600,000 management fee to run the schools service, but will lose part if it fails to meet a series of tough targets for test and exam results, which include significant improvements at GCSE. By contrast, Richmond is the highest achieving local education authority for key stage 1 and key stage 2 (for 7- and 11-year-olds) in national test results, with all its schools successfully inspected against Ofsted criteria.

Brian Oakley-Smith, managing director of Cambridge Education Associates, said: "CEA knows Vincent McDonnell well and is delighted that he has accepted this crucial position. With his track record at Richmond and with the experienced foundation team we are putting into Islington we know that we will be able to help raise standards."

Mr McDonnell said: "CEA's clear aim is to work in partnership with Islington LEA, head teachers, governors, staff, schools, parents and the community as a whole to help them achieve the challenging standards they have set themselves.

"I am confident we can make a difference for the young people of the borough."

webTitle: Setback for Labour on school selection

fields.headline: Setback for Labour on school selection
fields.trailText: The government's policy on school selection in England and Wales suffered an embarrassing setback yesterday, after the high court ruled that its admissions watchdog had acted unlawfully by ordering a cut in the number of pupils that three London secondary schools could select on the basis of academic ability.
fields.body:
The government's policy on school selection in England and Wales suffered an embarrassing setback yesterday, after the high court ruled that its admissions watchdog had acted unlawfully by ordering a cut in the number of pupils that three London secondary schools could select on the basis of academic ability.

The Tory-controlled London borough of Wandsworth, the local authority that challenged the adjudicator's decision last year, declared the ruling "a victory for the democratic decision-making of local government".

But new rules that came into force last September mean that, in effect, Wandsworth only gets a year's reprieve in which to continue its existing selection policy. Other local education authorities threatened with a similar ruling, such as Barnet in north London, are now considering whether to mount similar legal challenges.

In a landmark ruling yesterday, Mr Justice Sullivan said the government's admissions adjudicator, Peter Downes, was wrong to try to stop the three schools "creaming off" the brightest pupils.

He said the reductions - which were due to come into effect next September - would have resulted in "a substantial change in the schools' function" and that the adjudicator had acted outside his powers.

Malcolm Grimston, chairman of Wandsworth council's education committee, welcomed the judge's decision, but warned that the amendment in government regulations made last September had given the adjudicator increased powers to restrict partial selection in future years.

"London has been failing its children for years and years because of this leftwing idea that children have to be treated as identical units," he said. "This is a victory for the democratic decision-making of local government which clearly throws into doubt the authority of an unelected adjudicator."

Of the Wandsworth schools, Graveney and Ernest Bevin, which currently admit 50% of their pupils on academic ability, were told by the adjudicator to reduce that figure to 25%. The third school, Burntwood, faced having to cut back the proportion from 32% to 25%.

The adjudicator ordered the cuts last summer after governors of Honeywell infants and junior schools in south-west London, whose pupils are candidates for places, objected to the admissions policy proposed for the three secondary schools for the next academic year.

Mr Justice Sullivan said in his ruling that the adjudicator had lacked power under the relevant admissions regulations to either abolish partial selection or reduce the number of pupils chosen by ability if it resulted in "a substantial change in the schools' function".

The judge said: "All the indications are to the effect that it would result in such a change, and I am therefore satisfied that all three determinations [for each of the schools] must be quashed."

He stressed that his decision did not concern the merits of partial selection but was simply concerned with the procedures laid down for altering admission arrangements.

Chief adjudicator Sir Peter Newsam said yesterday that the issue decided by the judge no longer applied, as regulations delegating necessary powers to his office had come into force in September.

Normally, the objection raised by parents and other local schools could not be considered by his office again for a year, he said, in effect preserving admission arrangements at the schools in question until at least September 2002.

The shadow education secretary, Theresa May, said: "This case was all about Labour's plan to end selection by stealth. We oppose the appointment of unelected adjudicators, who make decisions that fly in the face of local people. Now government policy has been revealed for the sham that it is."
