webTitle: Dome's hi-tech toys fail to stand the pace

fields.headline: Dome's hi-tech toys fail to stand the pace
fields.standfirst:
The millennium: special report

After only two weeks, many robots and interactive games have broken down. But staff put much of the blame on 'heavy handed' public
fields.trailText: Barely two weeks after it opened its doors, many of the Millennium Dome's interactive games and computer displays have broken down or are not working properly.
fields.body:
Barely two weeks after it opened its doors, many of the Millennium Dome's interactive games and computer displays have broken down or are not working properly.

More than a third of the games and gizmos in the popular living island zone were out of order when the Guardian conducted an extensive audit on Thursday, and British Telecom's phone of the future in the nearby talk zone had given up the ghost.

Eighteen of the consoles in the less well used "digital orchard" of the learning zone were dead - roughly the same number that were inoperable when the Guardian visited just before the dome opened. In the work zone, a whole bank of computers had been switched off.

Five of the seven robots in the mind zone had broken down, leaving only the two least interesting ones, and the television screen which allows you to see into the nest of Trinidadian leaf cutter ants - the zone's most hyped attraction - had packed in as well.

The problems were not confined to the major displays. The zone's one proper interactive element, a sculpture called Smokey Joe by the artist Gavin Turk, was smoking no longer.

We found the play zone had the most popular and reliable games, although a spokesman for the dome admitted there had been problems there too. "There's a lot of software involved in something like the play zone and things will stop from time to time. But we do have maintenance teams working right through the night every night to try and sort things out," he said.

He claimed many of the faults were due to the public misusing the machines.

"The spend, spend, spend game in the money zone kept breaking down because people were ramming in the special credit cards they were given, rather than just slipping them in as you would do with a bank machine. We have put extra staff there now to show people how to use them properly and, by and large, the shopping trolleys are working OK now.

"Often when things get broken, it is a sign of their success," he added. "The gaming arcade of living island is a good example. There are some very strenuous games there and the machines take a lot of beating."

We found 11 of the games in the mock seaside arcade out of order, and 10 other interactive elements in the main exhibition.

"Things break down. It's the nature of all visitor attractions everywhere," the spokesman said. "The good thing is that we haven't yet had a fundamental failure. There is nothing that just does not work at all."

But Stephen Bayley, the former creative director of the dome who quit two years ago in protest at the proposed contents, said they were asking for trouble by relying so heavily on computers and interactive displays.

"Everyone who knows about exhibitions knows that you try not to use computers, because they break and they rarely end up doing what they were supposed to do. I, like anyone else who has worked in museums or has put on exhibitions, argued against their use but was overruled. There is this fetish for busy-ness in the dome, which says we must have computers and interaction, no matter how bad the quality."

The Guardian audit also found problems with several exhibits in the explore area of the body zone. One game was broken and the veincheck and iris scan futuristic identifica tion systems were not working properly.

The much-hyped face of the future stand was also initially closed. Of the five pressurised airgun machines we tried in the free-for-all fight at timekeepers of the millennium, two were broken. Even so the area was packed and it did not hamper the fun. There were also minor glitches with three exhibits in the shared ground zone, where one of the three active citizen quiz monitors was also broken.

Apart from the defunct phone of the future and video phone booths, only a handful of the more than 50 computer displays in the talk zone were not switched on, although some had a tendency to get hung up, and almost all the many monitors in the journey zone worked, although its model Eurostar trainset had broken down.

And not all zones rely on interactive elements. Several, such as faith, rest, self-portrait, home planet and our town have no games.

But broken computers seemed the least of the dome troubles when we visited. While officials declined to give visitor numbers for Thursday, staff on the floor said they thought there were possibly less than 8,000 - just over a third of the dome's target for this time of year and a quarter of its capacity, and some reports put attendance as low as 5,000.

Ironically, because it was less crowded, visitors seemed to be enjoying themselves more. Many walked straight into the body, where queues of up to 45 minutes had been reported over the New Year holidays.

But a spokesman for the dome, which is organising a series of free days to drum up interest, said there was no panic over numbers. "Poll after poll of people who have visited has proved that the vast majority were delighted with their day. Only a very small minority didn't like it. The message is getting out there. Maybe in the rush to get the dome opened and working, we have not concentrated enough on telling people what it is actually for and about, and what good fun it is."

fields.headline: New hitch threatens London wheel
fields.trailText: The merry-go-round of technical delays afflicting the Millennium Wheel took another turn last night when fresh doubts were raised about whether it would open next month.
fields.body:
The merry-go-round of technical delays afflicting the Millennium Wheel took another turn last night when fresh doubts were raised about whether it would open next month.

The launch of the £35m wheel on London's south bank was stopped on New Year's Eve by health and safety experts, much to the embarrassment of the prime minister, who had turned up to cut the tape.

Then a mid-January start was also scrapped and now the trouble-hit attraction is in danger of missing a February 1 deadline.

The fault in a clutch mechanism which held up the original opening is now thought to be much more serious than initially thought, and the devices on all 32 capsules will have to be replaced.

The clutches, a key safety feature, are supposed to stabilise capsules on the 450ft ride in the event of a power cut of major mechanical fault.

British Airways, who sponsor the wheel, which is also known as the BA London Eye, insisted the February 1 deadline would be met and claimed there might even be preview rides before then.

"There is no problem with the design of the clutch," a BA spokesman said.

"This has been a manufacturing fault.

"The German makers of the clutches are working as fast as they can with British engineers to rectify the situation."

He said that if it had been a design fault, it would have been much more serious. "This is not an insurmountable problem, it's relatively straightforward and quick."

However, yesterday's issue of New Civil Engineer magazine said remaking, fitting and testing the new parts could take up to a month, without taking teething problems into account.

No one at Stromag, the German engineering company which is making a new batch of strengthened clutches, was available for comment.

Despite its woes, the wheel is already a much loved feature of the capital's skyline. More than half a million tickets have been sold and BA hopes to carry 2.5m passengers on it in its first 12 months, although independent research indicates that this figure could reach 4m.

The 250 competition-winning guests who were due to ride the wheel on December 31 were given a champagne dinner by BA instead and the chance to travel anywhere in the world for free.

BA confirmed that when the new clutches are finished the wheel will be tested by John Roberts and his team of three engineers, the safety experts who cancelled the New Year's Eve opening.

The launch of the £35m wheel on London's south bank was stopped on New Year's Eve by health and safety experts, much to the embarrassment of the prime minister, who had turned up to cut the tape. Then a mid-January start was also scrapped and now the trouble-hit attraction is in danger of missing a February 1 deadline. The fault in a clutch mechanism which held up the original opening is now thought to be much more serious than initially thought, and the devices on all 32 capsules will have to be replaced. The clutches, a key safety feature, are supposed to stabilise capsules on the 450ft ride in the event of a power cut of major mechanical fault. British Airways, who sponsor the wheel, which is also known as the BA London Eye, insisted the February 1 deadline would be met and claimed there might even be preview rides before then. "There is no problem with the design of the clutch," a BA spokesman said. "This has been a manufacturing fault. "The German makers of the clutches are working as fast as they can with British engineers to rectify the situation." He said that if it had been a design fault, it would have been much more serious. "This is not an insurmountable problem, it's relatively straightforward and quick." However, yesterday's issue of New Civil Engineer magazine said remaking, fitting and testing the new parts could take up to a month, without taking teething problems into account. No one at Stromag, the German engineering company which is making a new batch of strengthened clutches, was available for comment. Despite its woes, the wheel is already a much loved feature of the capital's skyline. More than half a million tickets have been sold and BA hopes to carry 2.5m passengers on it in its first 12 months, although independent research indicates that this figure could reach 4m. The 250 competition-winning guests who were due to ride the wheel on December 31 were given a champagne dinner by BA instead and the chance to travel anywhere in the world for free. BA confirmed that when the new clutches are finished the wheel will be tested by John Roberts and his team of three engineers, the safety experts who cancelled the New Year's Eve opening.

fields.headline: Easing the way
fields.standfirst:
Chris Rofe - Visitor services chief at the dome
The millennium: special report
fields.trailText: Chris Rofe will tomorrow celebrate his 35th birthday: as senior visitor services manager of the Millennium Dome, he is a man of the future, at the pinnacle of his profession. Optimism exudes from him as he talks about his work. "I have always said to myself that as soon as a visitor comment or complaint annoys me or frustrates me, it is time to get out."
fields.body:
Chris Rofe will tomorrow celebrate his 35th birthday: as senior visitor services manager of the Millennium Dome, he is a man of the future, at the pinnacle of his profession. Optimism exudes from him as he talks about his work. "I have always said to myself that as soon as a visitor comment or complaint annoys me or frustrates me, it is time to get out."

Don't you sometimes feel you could scream at the sight of one more tourist, though? "You do get frustrated if there are things that patently should have happened and haven't. But any feedback is constructive as long as you act on it."

You know that slightly sinister sense that you get walking round any modern attraction or building that your every move has been scripted by a man with a spreadsheet and that everything the staff says to you has come from the same script: well, Chris Rofe was that man.

Before the dome he was head of customer operations for the Science Museum in London, so almost any London parent is already in his debt. "We're very similar to the Science Museum. At the Chessington World of Adventures, a family comes for pure enjoyment: a quick fix, and they leave just the same as when they started. But here, just for a moment, their thoughts, their impression of their selves and of the world should change in some shape or form."

He has rearranged the queues for the body zone so that they pass through more interesting territory. Apparently the queues for the body zone were exacerbated because people stopped after an hour or two when they came to the displays of human organs mocked up in perspex columns by the side of the entry ramp. "They were reading every word," he says. So now the columns are to be displayed further away, so that progress through the body itself will be quicker.

What would he have done had he not gone into leisure management? He took a degree in this subject from Loughborough university, and has worked in it all his life. "My family and my friends have always told me I should have gone into teaching. I would probably have been quite good at it - but I could never have stood doing the same thing over and over again." He gave another of his vivid smiles. "You mustn't print that. It's unfair on teachers."

fields.headline: It's unignorable
fields.standfirst:
The Dome exerts a firm hold on visitors, for all the complaints about its pointlessness
The millennium: special report
fields.trailText: A magazine article of 30 years ago famously asked "What is Princess Margaret for?" People are now asking the same about the Dome - a much fairer question. Even President Chirac, leader of a nation that has no embarrassment or qualms about great national projects, on being shown a display of models of the Dome in London two years ago asked: "But what is it for?"
fields.body:
A magazine article of 30 years ago famously asked "What is Princess Margaret for?" People are now asking the same about the Dome - a much fairer question. Even President Chirac, leader of a nation that has no embarrassment or qualms about great national projects, on being shown a display of models of the Dome in London two years ago asked: "But what is it for?"

I asked myself the same question the day I accepted the privilege of being involved in the Dome in the summer of 1997. Attempts to answer the question have struggled to be heard. My answer, and the answers of all of us associated with the creative process, have too often been drowned out by other debates, considered more "newsworthy", about whether the Dome is not religious enough, or too religious; whether it is too heavily subsidised by commercial sponsorship, or relies too much on Lottery money; whether it is too dumbed-down or too elitist - and even what the precise sex of the Body Zone should be.

The controversies along the way have given a lot of people a lot of fun, and provided a lot of newspaper columnists with a lot of material. But they have also sparked off some genuine debate about issues that are rarely aired - our national identity, the role of religion in our society, whether we do things as families any more, and whether we have anything to celebrate.

Let me explain our starting point. We have a lot to celebrate. Firstly, I believe that we are the most creative nation in the world - and much of our future prosperity will depend on our ability to turn our ideas into businesses and jobs. So the Dome - as a landmark national exhibition - is very much of its time. Through bringing together a talented team of different architects, designers, artists, musicians, software engineers and performers, it houses under one roof a collection of attractions that are as diverse as the nation itself. There is no single voice in the Dome.

Previous great exhibitions in this country have also been of their time. In those days, the great and the good created tableaux and then lifted the curtain for a moment to allow the public to gaze in awe at what their betters had achieved. That was then.

The Dome is designed to reflect the current reality of our society at the start of the 21st century. The here and now, a time when individuals are taking more and more responsibility for their own lives. We have therefore created an exhibition that doesn't preach and doesn't offer certainties.

Instead, each of the 14 zones covers a different aspect of human life and opens a window on the choices we must make for the future. We have tried to make them all fun and intriguing, and therefore entertaining. It is up to each visitor to decide which of these zones they would like to see, and to take away what they will from the experience. We have to appeal to all peoples of all ages. But the common theme is that our destiny is in our own hands - and that whether this millennium is better or worse than the last is up to all of us individually and collectively.

That unifying theme is explored from three starting points: who we are - covered in the Body, Mind, Self Portrait and Faith zones; what we do - in Talk, Journey, Work, Learning, Money, Play, Rest; and where we live - in Living Island, Shared Ground and Home Planet.

The zones are ranged around the vast central arena where up to 12,000 people at a time can see the Millennium Show. This is a fable of the human experience told through a spectacular love story with music by Peter Gabriel, in which the performers fly and dance 140ft above the ground.

This is the part of the Dome that everyone enjoys together. In an age when so much of what we do is solitary - working at a keyboard, surfing the internet or playing computer games, watching TV in our living rooms - there is still magic in the shared experience. And the Dome is deliberately conceived as a place where people come to learn, to have fun and to be excited - together.

T hat is something you can't get out of a book or on the world wide web. When the show starts the audience takes part, sitting and standing amongst the performers as they set up and as the props are put in place. Every zone is not just something you look at - you get inside, you play with toys, you leave your own mark.

When I joined the project I assumed that we were in need of a single creative director. The fact that we didn't go down that route has turned out to be a surprise bonus. However, to have entrusted creative custody of the entire project to a single pair of hands would have run counter to everything that we believe the Dome should stand for - namely inclusiveness and plurality. Nobody, no single person, owns the Dome. We've got a much greater variety on offer than would otherwise have been the case and a cacophony of different voices grabbing people's attention.

The Dome is a small town of different buildings each with their own colours, shapes and appeal. Zaha Hadid's angular, gravity-defying Mind Zone nestles between the graceful curves of Faith by Eva Jiricna and the Richard Rogers Partnership's Rest Zone, which is a giant technicolour lozenge with a dreamy sound and light show inside.

Variety and plurality, not uniformity and predictability, are the Dome's greatest strengths. In the City of London, Richard Rogers and Norman Foster sit side by side with Wren and Hawksmoor, and the Dome would not be of its age if it didn't reflect the diversity of the world we live in.

Each poll of visitors who have actually been to the Dome indicates that the exhibiton has relevance, meaning and value for all its visitors, whatever their age or background. The five independent polls so far show overwhelmingly positive reaction, with 80 to 90% of visitors saying they have enjoyed their day and around three-quarters saying they would recommend it to friends. It looks as if public opinion is one step ahead of the critics and the pundits - and not for the first time.

So come with an open mind. I am confident you will find something to savour inside the Dome. This is a new century and an age when the choice is ours - and no longer that of the great and good, the elites and the other self- appointed arbiters of taste who have told us what to like for so long. There may be some who find that idea a touch threatening.

Michael Grade is a director of the New Millennium Experience Company.

fields.headline: London commuters face rail strikes
fields.standfirst: More about transport
fields.trailText: Train drivers yesterday threatened the biggest rail strike since the industry was privatised with a series of six one-day stoppages on busy London commuter lines. The rail firm Connex, which operates services into the capital from the south-east, faces a ban on non-contractual overtime on January 25, February 2, 10, 18, 21 and 29.
fields.body:
Train drivers yesterday threatened the biggest rail strike since the industry was privatised with a series of six one-day stoppages on busy London commuter lines. The rail firm Connex, which operates services into the capital from the south-east, faces a ban on non-contractual overtime on January 25, February 2, 10, 18, 21 and 29.

The ban was announced by the train drivers' union, Aslef. It predicted a shutdown of Connex's two regions, south central and south eastern on the strike days.

The dispute brings to a head a long running dispute on hours. Aslef has been negotiating a 35-hour week with other train companies, but says there has been a "serious breakdown" of relations at Connex.

Mick Rix, Aslef's general secretary, said he believed the public would sympathise with the drivers and blame Connex for the dispute.

"Connex has a very bad reputation internally. You can see that from the way they treat the passengers. They treat staff in the same way." Mr Rix said he thought Connex would have to employ more drivers and stop relying on overtime. The other big rail union, the Rail, Maritime and Transport union, is holding a ballot of workers at Connex in protest at the company's industrial relations.

Connex said it was saddened that customers were threatened with disruption. Less than half the drivers had voted for industrial action, and it remained willing to talk to Aslef to resolve the dispute.

Lord Macdonald, transport minister, urged both sides to get together. The planned disruption was "regrettable and unhelpful", he said.

fields.headline: London to Dublin for £4
fields.standfirst: More about transport
fields.trailText: The airline price war reached a new level yesterday when the low-cost carrier Ryanair announced a million cheap seats to 21 European destinations, with a rock-bottom net return fare of £4 between Stansted and Dublin.
fields.body:
The airline price war reached a new level yesterday when the low-cost carrier Ryanair announced a million cheap seats to 21 European destinations, with a rock-bottom net return fare of £4 between Stansted and Dublin.

The total fare with airport taxes works out at £24.99, and was described last night by Ryanair's chief executive, Michael O'Leary, as little more than the price of a long taxi cab journey across London.

The cheapest equivalent to Dublin offered by British Airways is £55 plus airport taxes from Gatwick and a compulsory one-night stopover on a Saturday night.

Among Ryanair's other offers are a £24.99 return fare to Glasgow, including taxes, a £29.99 fare to St Etienne and Dinard in France, £39.99 to Genoa, Turin and Rimini in Italy, and £39.99 to Stockholm and Malmo in Sweden.

Useful links: www.ryanair.ie

fields.headline: The social insurance option
fields.standfirst:
The NHS debate explained
More about the NHS
fields.trailText: Governments are wedded to an NHS, funded by general taxation, that is free at point of access. Charges and compulsory insurance schemes are considered electoral suicide.
fields.body:
Governments are wedded to an NHS, funded by general taxation, that is free at point of access. Charges and compulsory insurance schemes are considered electoral suicide.

But there is a third way, and many who feel the NHS is underfunded point to countries such as France and Germany which have social insurance schemes and much greater spending on health. This will be one of the options considered by the British Medical Association as it reviews NHS funding.

The debate on how to pay for healthcare never goes away because the price rises as expensive new treatments come along. Doctors and patient groups point out that Britain is spending less on healthcare than comparable countries and achieving worse results.

At the moment, 11% of the UK population has private health insurance. These people are concentrated in the richest 25% of the population. Those whose policy is paid by their employer tend to be concentrated among the richest of the rich. Any thought of going down this road, as the US has, would be "unequal, inappropriate and inefficient" according to the King's Fund, the health policy think tank.

Alan Milburn, the health secretary, agrees. He told a recent conference in Harrogate: "We reject the private option as intrinsically flawed."

Charges would fall on those least able to pay - the poor, the chronically sick, the elderly and children who need the most treatment. Private insurance benefits only those able to pay.

Social insurance schemes are fairer. In Germany, people join one of several thousand different insurance plans through their work. They pay into it through what is in effect a tax on their salary, and the employer also contributes. But the unemployed have their contributions paid by the state, and the state also helps schemes that have a dispro portionate number of high-risk individuals, such as diabetics.

"They spend about 50% more than we do on healthcare," said Professor Alan Maynard, the director of the centre for health economics at York university. "But the German healthcare service is the most inefficient in the world."

In France, the GP bills the patient for their treatment on a scale of agreed charges. Patients are reimbursed for 70% and have to pay 30% themselves, "based on the theory that if you are charged you are a more careful consumer", said Prof Maynard.

webTitle: Call to boycott Stagecoach over 'anti-gay' donation

fields.headline: Call to boycott Stagecoach over 'anti-gay' donation
fields.trailText: Gay rights groups yesterday called for a boycott of all Stagecoach bus and train services after it emerged the company's chairman, Brian Souter, had given more than £500,000 to the campaign against lifting section 28.
fields.body:
Gay rights groups yesterday called for a boycott of all Stagecoach bus and train services after it emerged the company's chairman, Brian Souter, had given more than £500,000 to the campaign against lifting section 28.

The Scottish communities minister, Wendy Alexander, has pledged to repeal the law, which prevents schools and teachers from promoting the acceptability of homosexuality, in this term of the Scottish parliament.

The intervention of Mr Souter, a committed Christian and Labour supporter, comes as consultation on the executive's plans to lift the legislation north of the border draws to a close.

The multimillionaire businessman has given the cash to the Scottish school boards association to fund a TV and newspaper advertising campaign. The donation has been widely condemned by political parties and equal opportunities groups.

Peter Tatchell, spokesman for the gay rights lobby group, OutRage!, accused Mr Souter of using his millions to fan the flames of bigotry and prejudice.

"He is behaving like the business leaders in the deep south of America who funded the 1950s campaign to maintain racial segregation. I hope commuters, trade unionists, churches, politicians and companies that support gay hu man rights will boycott Stagecoach."

Mr Souter, who is notoriously unwilling to cooperate with the media, was yesterday unavailable for comment. His spokesman, however, denied the Stagecoach boss was homophobic.

"Mr Souter believes that this is an important issue of democracy. It is not homophobic. It is essential that all Scottish parents realise what the implications are of scrapping clause 28 and the kind of explicit material which could then be forced on their children in the classroom."

Mr Souter, the father of four school-age children, gave the money through his charitable Souter Foundation. His intervention is an embarrassment to the Scottish executive, which last year appointed him to a prestigious "champion of change" adviser post on local government.

Board members of the association, which represents 84% of Scotland's 2,400 school boards, plan to launch a campaign against the repeal of Section 2a of the local government act 1986 - widely known as clause or section 28 - on Wednesday.

"We view this as an issue of democracy," said the treasurer, Alan Smith. "We're trying to redress the balance and we will use the financial support to highlight what section 28 is about."

However the SSBA board has been criticised by equality groups for failing to consult members and launching the campaign unilaterally.

A spokesman for the Scottish executive said the campaign run by Mr Souter and the SSBA would not change its mind on the issue.

Moves to repeal section 28 in the forthcoming ethical standards bill enjoy cross-party support north of the border. The SNP said the clause should be repealed as soon as possible.

The Scottish Conservatives were the only party at Holyrood to back Mr Souter's donation. The education spokesman, Brian Monteith, said: "It is a brave decision in a politically hostile climate."

Both Childen First, the Scottish arm of the NSPCC, and Childline are in favour of repeal.

Mr Souter, who is notoriously unwilling to cooperate with the media, was yesterday unavailable for comment. His spokesman, however, denied the Stagecoach boss was homophobic. "Mr Souter believes that this is an important issue of democracy. It is not homophobic. It is essential that all Scottish parents realise what the implications are of scrapping clause 28 and the kind of explicit material which could then be forced on their children in the classroom." Mr Souter, the father of four school-age children, gave the money through his charitable Souter Foundation. His intervention is an embarrassment to the Scottish executive, which last year appointed him to a prestigious "champion of change" adviser post on local government. Board members of the association, which represents 84% of Scotland's 2,400 school boards, plan to launch a campaign against the repeal of Section 2a of the local government act 1986 - widely known as clause or section 28 - on Wednesday. "We view this as an issue of democracy," said the treasurer, Alan Smith. "We're trying to redress the balance and we will use the financial support to highlight what section 28 is about." However the SSBA board has been criticised by equality groups for failing to consult members and launching the campaign unilaterally. A spokesman for the Scottish executive said the campaign run by Mr Souter and the SSBA would not change its mind on the issue. Moves to repeal section 28 in the forthcoming ethical standards bill enjoy cross-party support north of the border. The SNP said the clause should be repealed as soon as possible. The Scottish Conservatives were the only party at Holyrood to back Mr Souter's donation. The education spokesman, Brian Monteith, said: "It is a brave decision in a politically hostile climate." Both Childen First, the Scottish arm of the NSPCC, and Childline are in favour of repeal. Useful links Outrage! Stagecoach

webTitle: Clutching at straws to avoid the obvious truth

fields.headline: Clutching at straws to avoid the obvious truth
fields.trailText: In our anguish about getting the racism issue right, we in this country are in danger of disappearing quickly up our own fundamental principles.
fields.body:
In our anguish about getting the racism issue right, we in this country are in danger of disappearing quickly up our own fundamental principles. There's the Ali G affair (my guess is that the whole thing is really an attempt to take the piss out of public people who are so mesmerised by the yoof cult that they daren't accuse his character of being completely idiotic) and now there's Jack Straw. Apoplectic right-wing commentators have demanded to know what the reaction would have been if Mr Straw had accused the Scots or Welsh, or any other ethnic group, of being inherently violent instead of just the English.

But the fact is that you're allowed to be offensive about your own kind. Jews are permitted to tell Jewish jokes. Men can be rude about men (though heaven help them if they make critical remarks about women.) I have often pointed out that it is a useful rule in life that you should never trust anyone called Simon.

And what Mr Straw said is plainly true. Why is it that we are not allowed to state what is obviously the case? English football fans are still the worst in the world, despite stiff competition from the Germans and Dutch. And he was quite right to point out that you don't found the largest empire the world has ever seen - with some help, it must be said, from the Scots and Welsh - without being prepared to employ some violence, even if we aren't taught about it in school. If we had a bit more self-confidence we wouldn't care so much, and we'd be a lot happier as a nation.

As I predicted last week, I've been subject to much jeering for my simple observation that the Millennium Dome is more enjoyable than the critics suggest. "Oh, yes, it's the PR man for the Dome," one colleague sneered when he saw me. So I'm delighted to see the results of the latest opinion poll, conducted by ICM, which shows that 80% of the visitors were either "very" or "quite" satisfied with their visit, and that 71% would recommend it to their friends. This confirms anecdotal evidence from my own friends and neighbours who've been there; they're all very positive.

As for the moans about queueing, it's clear that the loudest critics - those who would obviously be far happier eating confit de canard in a modest one-star restaurant in Gascony - have never been to Alton Towers, Thorpe Park, Chessington, or anywhere with the word Disney in the title. But there isn't much queuing at the River Cafe, or at the ROH, especially if you book your interval drinks beforehand.

It was curious to watch Shaun Woodward being received into the bosom of the Labour party this week, especially by Mo Mowlam. Ms Mowlam is no saint, and she has her faults, but the way she has been discarded by Downing Street like a used Kleenex would give anyone the creeps. Her main crime seems to be the fact that she is as popular as Tony Blair. You sense they'd prefer to treat her like those female stars who played opposite the dimunitive Alan Ladd, digging a trench for her to walk down, so as not to show him up.

A Labour MP I chatted to said that this was the same phenomenon as the parable of the prodigal son. Woodward, as a convert, was a hundred times more welcome than the poor elder brother, who had been loyal all the time and stayed working dutifully at home. Everything goes right for Tony Blair.

Even when his wife commits an offence, it increases his popularity. The other day I had to take an early train. The ticket office was open, but the queues stretched out into the street. The automatic machine was broken, as usual, and the permit to travel machine had been shut down because the booking office was open. So I took a chance. Naturally there were no ticket inspectors on the train, or at Waterloo, but there were 15-minute queues for tickets. Did I wait and pay? Of course not.

I dislike deliberate fare dodgers. But if I charged Mrs Gloag, the co-owner of Stagecoach, a realistic rate - say, what a plumber costs - for the hours she has kept me waiting with her vile train service, I would be billing her for several thousand pounds. Three quid isn't much compensation, but it is strangely satisfying.

I've just bought a great double CD for only £9.99 in the HMV sale. It's called Cheggers's Choice, and it's Keith Chegwin's selection of 40 of the worst pop records ever made - many of them former number one hits. Remember Chirpy Chirpy Cheep Cheep? Or Billy, Don't Be a Hero, Agadoo, and Son of My Father?

There are basically two kinds of utterly rotten record - those with pretensions and those without. Among the classic, awful, fully orchestrated errors, those great vinyl cowpats, are MacArthur Park, Neil Diamond's I Am I Said, and my own personal all-time hate, Where Do You Go To, My Lovely? ("Yes you do, ha ha ha!")

But a lot of novelty rubbish has considerable charm. Jonathan King made many of the best of the all time horrors, including Johnny Reggae ("e's a really tasty geezer"), nominally by the Piglets, and Leap Up And Down (Wave Your Knickers in the Air) allegedly by St Cecilia. I remember many happy times - well, two - bopping to that at parties where I had imbibed not wisely but too well.

If you have any thoughts on this vital matter, I'd be delighted to hear them.

webTitle: The squeaks and drips of everyday life

fields.headline: The squeaks and drips of everyday life
fields.standfirst: Wave riding
fields.trailText: Wave riding
fields.body:
The trouble with the science-fictional future is that it so often sounds like the past. You only have to listen to Margaret Atwood's The Handmaid's Tale , Radio 4's first Classic Serial of the millennium. Atwood's futurist fable is set in the state of Gilead, where right-wing religious evangelists flush women out of jobs and kidnap the fertile ones for re-education as breeders. But, as ever in sci-fi, there's a lone, courageous dissenter...

Haven't we heard it all before? Atwood's novel, written in 1985, may have been inspired by the alarmist, backlash mid-80s, but it adds little to Orwell, Huxley and Kafka. Part feminist nightmare (a lot of the baddies' speeches could have been lifted from Thatcher), Atwood's projected future is also a stew of religious fundamentalism and totalitarian centralism. In its thought-control 21st century, Gilead isn't much different from 50s Moscow, sans women truck-drivers.

But never mind the plot, feel the production, recorded on location in New York with documentary techniques (ie the mike following the actors, rather than vice versa) and a classy Broadway cast.

Now an awful lot of cant is spoken about location recording. Hear the authentic sound of a toilet flushing! Is that the genuine klaxon of a Range Rover that I hear before me? Most of the time BBC radio drama producers record on location because they can no longer afford to rent BBC studios. And the location sound on last year's Bleak House was so multi-layered that you couldn't follow the plot.

John Dryden, who produced that (along with Radio 4's memorable Fatherland), has also expertly dramatised and directed The Handmaid's Tale, with Nick Russell-Pavier as sound designer. I mention him because celebrity actors who come in for an hour to read a couple of lines in a radio play invariably get credited while back-room people devoting months to a project do not. (That's in radio; in film, even the second assistant trainee tea-boy gets a credit.) Yet with changing technology and costs, radio drama is no longer primarily made in a studio, from a fixed script. Increasingly it's a multitrack confection, created post-production by the Russell-Paviers of the world.

Here, Dryden and Russell-Pavier have created a wondrous soundtrack, with not only a convincing dripping toilet but also the squeak of credit-card transactions, shop doors opening and the panoply of sounds that make up American daily life. This roots the plot in the ordinary and everyday, lending it plausibility. Best of all, script, music and effects are fabulously knitted together, and the narrative line never lost.

There was more splendid drama in Three Women , Radio 3's adaptation of a Sylvia Plath poem about a trio of pregnant women, one accidentally and unhappily so - "I am drummed into use." Another revels in it: "When I walk out, I am a great event." A third miscarries, and there can rarely have been a more vivid account of the loss. All three must have been dimensions of Plath's own experience of pregnancy, as they are of most women's.

More strikingly than any other writer I've read, Plath identifies the connections between childbirth and death - the fear of the death of the self as well as that of the body - along with the intensity of the physical bond. The stunningly crisp text was beautifully performed by Lindsay Duncan, Amanda Root and Harriet Walter, while Robin Rimbaud, alias Scanner, provided an electronic score with a almost amniotic, womb-music power in Susan Roberts's fine production.

One can't help reading Michael Portillo's two-part examination of the Spanish Civil War, Legacy of Divisions (Radio 4), which he sees as the victory of extremism over the centre, as part of his own reincarnation as champion of the moderates. It seems a bit churlish to bring up his former SAS-loving, foreigner-bashing self. Hearing him, in the first programme, reading Spanish, one is reminded what a complex and intriguing chap he is. But he's in the wrong radio programme. Book him right away for In the Psychiatrist's Chair.

fields.headline: Underside
fields.trailText: Davos, the hot-air festival (sorry, "world economic forum") held annually at the Swiss ski resort, will this year be graced by the first rather than second lord of the treasury.
fields.body:
 Davos, the hot-air festival (sorry, "world economic forum") held annually at the Swiss ski resort, will this year be graced by the first rather than second lord of the treasury. With not a crisis in sight and the world economy a sea of tranquillity, Tony Blair is arriving to participate in a panel discussion on leadership in the 21st century. Computer tycoon Michael Dell will sketch the ideal political leader for the new era, and Mr Blair will do likewise for the ideal business leader. Gordon Brown - possibly repelled by the prospect of all this mutual backscratching - will not be attending, we hear. His boss, meanwhile, will have the chance to meet 29 heads of state and government and, more importantly, 1,200 people representing between 60% and 80% of global industrial production (trade union leaders? No - chief executives, stupid!);

 Back home, Sir George Mathewson, chief executive of the Royal Bank of Scotland, was spotted this week at London's Savoy with his youthful deputy Fred Goodwin, enjoying dinner after meetings with institutional investors to win backing for the bank's assault on NatWest. Who should arrive but NatWest top brass Sir David Rowland, Ron Sandler and new recruit Gordon Pell, all dining with their wives. Sir David told Sir George he was "delighted" to see his attacker, but peace talks did not follow. Meanwhile, Royal Bank's image as a ferocious predator is fast being undermined by its sponsorship department; envelopes printed especially for the bank declare it to be official sponsor of the National Cycle Path. A little herbivorous, surely, for NatWest's would-be savager?

 Peace, meanwhile, has broken out (sort of) on the bloody battlefield of French banking. For years relations between the country's private banks on the one hand and the mutuals and co-operative banks on the other have been sulphurous, with the former's lobby group - the Association Française des Banques - demanding an end to covert government backing for the non-commercial outfits. All that, however, belongs to the 20th century. At a dinner on Tuesday, in the presence of new finance minister Christian Sautter, association president Michel Freyche confirmed bankers of different stripes are to merge into the new Fédération Bancaire Française. The delicate prenuptial negotiations will fall to Mr Freyche's successor, Bernard Morel, whose Marseilles background may help him, er, break any log jams. Agenda item one is the HQ of the federation; gourmands are hoping for the existing association base in rue Lafayette in Paris's ninth district, with its hospitable dining room and agreeable views over the nearby Place de l'Opera;

 Elsewhere in European banking, the union's central bank - issuer of that multi-national Kleenex the euro - seeks translators with the following "mother tongue" lan guages: Danish, German, Greek, Spanish, French, Italian, Dutch, Portuguese, Swedish and Finnish. Is the absence of English another penalty for our euro-exclusion? Not exactly. The successful applicants will work on "the translation of texts principally from English";

 Back home, TransTec, the troubled engineer pushed into receivership last month after the discovery of an undisclosed £12m claim against the firm by customer Ford, did send one of two subliminal signals in its last annual report hinting at what may be to come. Regarding "payment of creditors, TransTec declared: "The company does not follow any code or standard on payment practice." Too right. In fact, TransTec paid £8m of Ford's claim without telling anyone. Then there is one of TransTec's few exceptions during 1997-98 to the combined code of best practice on corporate governance: "Until June 12 1998, the audit committee consisted of only two members", which may explain why the £12m did not show up in the audit. Finally, there is the section on "internal financial control", which warns: "[It] is to be noted that any system can provide only reasonable and not absolute assurance against material misstatement or loss." How very true;

 Finally, with the Y2K bug expensively squashed underfoot, BT made a flying leap this week into a new century of instant communication. Callers from London to the south coast at 10.20am on Tuesday were greeted with: "The telephone network is busy at the moment. Please try again later. You have not been charged for this call." Overwhelmed by nostalgia for the days of party lines and button B, our caller left it half an hour, only to learn at 10.50am that the entire Sussex network was apparently out of action. Alexander Graham Bell's mobile number, anyone?

fields.headline: Killing time
fields.standfirst: "The nearest George Bush Jr comes to mercy is to grant a request by one condemned man to be put to death on the night of the full moon"
fields.trailText: "The nearest George Bush Jr comes to mercy is to grant a request by one condemned man to be put to death on the night of the full moon"
fields.body:
I have problems with people who support the death penalty. I know that they cannot all be bad or unnatural, for they include a large number of the people of this country - and of the peoples of most other countries, for that matter. But I find capital punishment so abhorrent myself that it is difficult for me to understand how perfectly nice people can be in favour of it. I just have to accept the fact and to believe that they are not worse people as a result. All understanding deserts me, however, when I think about the governors of Texas and Florida, the sons of former president George Bush. George W Bush Jr, who is running for president, and his brother, Jeb, seem to be not just in favour of the death penalty, but in love with it.

During his five years as governor of the US's largest state, George W has presided over the executions of 111 men and one woman, far more than the governor of any other state. His policy is to ensure that, with almost no exceptions, death sentences are carried out. The nearest he comes to mercy is to grant a request by one condemned man, as he has just done, that he be put to death on the night of the full moon. Among the seven people due to be executed in Texas this month while George W is away campaigning for the presidency in Iowa and New Hampshire is a man who was only 17 when he committed his crime.

George W has achieved his position as America's most prolific executioner by speeding up appeal procedures and running a clemency system that a federal judge has described as excessively secretive and legally unsound. It has also been condemned by Amnesty International as violating international standards of human rights. As governor, George W cannot grant or deny applications for clemency without the agreement of an 18-member parole board, but all the board's members have been appointed by him and have never been known to disagree with him. The board operates without guidelines, does not explain its decisions, and does not even meet to discuss cases. Members review cases on their own and then fax in their votes. George W recently quashed an attempt to get clemency applications heard in public, saying this would only make people "rant and rail" and "emotionalise the process". He also killed off a bill in the state legislature, which would have banned executions of the mentally retarded. (It will be recalled that George W is not the first state governor running for president who is hard-hearted towards the mentally ill: Bill Clinton, then governor of Arkansas, interrupted his presidential campaign in 1992 to approve the execution of a murderer with brain damage.)

In Florida, Governor Jeb Bush has been looking on enviously at his elder brother's achievement. Although Florida is the third-ranking state after Virginia in the number of people it executes, it has only managed to kill 44 people in the 23 years since the Supreme Court allowed re-instatement of capital punishment, whereas Texas has killed a magnificent 199. So, last week, Jeb summoned a special session of the state legislature to approve a speeded-up, Texas-style appeals system, which, he says, should reduce from 14 years to five the average time between a murderer's sentencing and his execution. The legislators heard the evidence of a man who spent nine-and-a-half years on Florida's death row before being unconditionally pardoned when another man confessed to the murders of which he was convicted. They were unmoved when he pointed out that, under the new appeals system, he would have been dead long ago.

The reform of the appeals system was linked to another piece of legislation that changed Florida's method of execution from the electric chair to lethal injection. This was presented as a humane measure after some horribly bungled electrocutions in which two victims caught fire and one gushed blood from his nose. Its main purpose, however, was to pre-empt a Supreme Court review of whether Florida's use of the electric chair is "cruel and unusual punishment", which rather ignores that lethal injection is cruel and unusual, too, especially when administered, as it was in Texas last month, to a man who was saved from an attempted suicide in order to be formally put to death immediately afterwards. During his execution, the man vomited up a black charcoal liquid he had been made to drink to negate the effects of the pills he had swallowed.

Alas for that small minority of Americans who oppose the death penalty, there is no one else worth voting for, since there is not a single candidate, Republican or Democrat, who doesn't support it.
fields.bodyText: I have problems with people who support the death penalty. I know that they cannot all be bad or unnatural, for they include a large number of the people of this country - and of the peoples of most other countries, for that matter. I just have to accept the fact and to believe that they are not worse people as a result. All understanding deserts me, however, when I think about the governors of Texas and Florida, the sons of former president George Bush. fields.headline: Spice splice
fields.standfirst: Pairing off and having darling babies turned Scary and Posh into two greedy, grasping cows, selling their weddings to the highest bidder
fields.trailText: Pairing off and having darling babies turned Scary and Posh into two greedy, grasping cows, selling their weddings to the highest bidder
fields.body:
Well, now we know for sure - beat your wife up, and you're still a footballing hero. Wear her knickers, and you're a worthless, pussy-whipped wuss. Way to go, lads! The trouble is, I still don't want to have to write a piece called Why I Love Posh Spice, as several newspapers have suggested I do. Any more than I wanted to pen defences of Sarah Ferguson, Christine Hamilton or Paula Yates in their hour of need.

Why should I be expected to stand up for a woman who promised to "obey" at her wedding and went on to become a parasite par excellence ? Or a woman who wasted a perfectly good brain playing the eternal rock chick between bouts of writing books telling women that, if they didn't stay at home with their children all the time, they'd ruin their lives? Or a Tory cow whose life's work has been standing by her man? These women, whenever I've been unable to avoid them, have caused me nothing but annoyance but, more important, they all strike me as being the type of women who would recoil in horror at the very mention of the word feminism. Why, in the name of God, should I do the sisterly thing?

In the past, I always swore that, all things being equal, I would consistently support a woman against a man - or, in the case of these women, the largely male-controlled media. But there comes a point when doing the "right" thing doesn't make you good, just stupid - like those American blacks who supported OJ Simpson just because he was "one of ours".

Talking of which, I see that Mel G - B as was - will soon be B again. Oh dear! Didn't I predict this less than a year ago? Didn't I say that famous women who take their husband's names are actually working overtime at not wearing the trousers, and that any relationship that needs such petty little gestures is doomed from the start? I bet the breast-feeding didn't help, either. Remember how I was so roundly trounced by the Breast-Feeding Police for suggesting that their touting of the two Spice Girl mothers as great role-models for all new young mothers, simply because they had decided to breast-feed, was a little condescending and shallow? And that such a course of action, undertaken without sufficient thought, might put even more of a strain on women and on a relationship that has already had to make many adjustments? Well, Posh and Becks might still be together, but if she hasn't got an eating disorder, I'll eat my own head. Quite frankly, neither Scary nor Posh seem at all improved by the experience; I look forward to an apology from the BFP.

As we go into the next century, certain questions must be asked. Such as: what did happen to the 21st-Century Girls? Are they at this very moment ensconced in a secret billet in Maidenhead working on an image revamp, set to spring on us soon in the guise of 22nd-Century Girls? And did I really say that Wannabe was the greatest pop single ever?

Probably, though I can't be bothered to go back and check. (My New Year's Resolution: cut down on the research-heavy pieces. Learn to relax and trust own opinion.) However, I did until quite recently believe that mea culpa was a tapas bar, and, having discovered otherwise, I'm ready to pile in there with the self-accusation. I'll have to build up to Marshal Stalin, but I'll start with the Spice Girls. Why did I ever believe the Spice Girls were any good? I would say in my defence that, along with the above-mentioned Awful Women, I probably wouldn't have gone so overboard if the pop papers - the last bastion, along with the gents clubs, of naked, petulant misogyny - hadn't gone after them with such needless fury. I found it particularly sickening that men, who would recoil in horror from racial insults, seemed to have no such scruples about calling Geri "fat", "old" and "ginger".

"If you wanna be my lover/Gotta get with my friends/Make it last forever/Friendship never ends!" With those four simple lines, more female hearts and souls jumped with joy than at any time since the publication of de Beauvoir's The Second Sex, or at least since Madonna snogged that girl in that video. (As I said, I'm not prepared to labour over any more research-heavy theses, so forget it.) That video - those knowing, loving, sidelong glances, that hand-holding! It was enough to turn you queer, or post-modernist. Like I Should Be So Lucky and Shy Boy before it, Wannabe personified the optimism of the pop feminine, such a vital, usually absent balance to the morbidity of the pop masculine. (Why are there so many pop songs about men killing women, and so few about women killing men? It's not as though we don't have every provocation, and brute strength isn't really a pre-condition when you're just warbling about it. Could it just be because they've got filthy tempers ?)

Despite my vow not to demonise men in this century, I would still say that it has mostly been men and marriage that has ruined the Spice Girls. Pairing off and having darling ickle babies made Scary and Posh into two right greedy, grasping cows, selling their weddings to the highest bidder; while hanging out with the Red Hot Chili Peppers and other such relentless masculinists seems to have confused poor Sporty something rotten. Does she really believe that one can be an Antichrist and record duets with Bryan Adams?

As for Geri...well, if she sounds like a game 40-year-old divorcee (me) strutting her stuff at Amateur Night now, what's she going to sound like when she is a game 40-year-old divorcee? Dorothy Squires, probably. Marriage hasn't withered and cheapened Geri as it has Scary and Posh, but she does have male trouble of her own: why is George Michael her best friend? Mr Michael is a lovely man, no doubt, a veritable Titan in his chosen profession, but he's only human. And how many homosexual men of a certain theatrical type would have given their capped teeth to have had a ringside seat at the downfall of Judy Garland? Being bezzies with Geri, he's living the dream.

Which leaves us with Baby. Amazingly, only Baby - apparently the naffest of them all - leaves us with any hope for the future, with her habit of doing gorgeous covers with Tin Tin Out and dating black men younger than herself. Let's not forget that Baby's mum is her best friend, and that she herself is a karate black belt! Hmm . . . perhaps we can deconstruct "Baby" not as in "Baby Doll", but as pre-gender free spirit? "Baby: God or Demi-Tasse?" - certainly has a ring to it. Quick, someone, pass me my Pretentious Head; I feel a theory coming on...

fields.headline: Just taking liberties
fields.trailText: Your report (Legacy left Britain with worst deprivation in west, January 12) on the UK's poverty record puts into perspective the problems facing one of the poorest, most marginal, of groups in our society - asylum-seekers.
fields.body:
Your report (Legacy left Britain with worst deprivation in west, January 12) on the UK's poverty record puts into perspective the problems facing one of the poorest, most marginal, of groups in our society - asylum-seekers. The OECD findings show that, despite a benefit system reputed to be able to seduce people from all over the world, poverty affects 20% of the population a year. But the picture for asylum-seekers is even bleaker. They cannot usually draw upon savings and are often prevented from working by home office rules. This helps explain why a recent survey of clients at the Refugee Council's advice centre in Brixton revealed that 62% had slept rough and 61% said they did not have enough to eat on a daily basis.

And things are not going to get better. Yesterday saw the end of the consultation period on the government's proposal to force asylum-seekers and their children to survive on 70% of the official breadline. But even this meagre provision is further diminished by the fact it will largely be in the form of vouchers, which will not be able to be used in the best value shops and markets and from which change will not be given. It is difficult to see how social exclusion can be defeated and child poverty abolished if these plans to pauperise the most vulnerable and the poorest children in the country go ahead.
Nick Hardwick
Refugee Council, and Save the Children, UK Unicef, National Children's Bureau, Child Poverty Action Group, Children's Society, NSPCC, National Association of Citizens Advice Bureaux, Oxfam

The European Committee for the Prevention of Torture has stated that their recent visit to the UK "raises serious, questions about the independence and impartiality of the present procedures used to process complaints about police misconduct." With only 2% of recorded complaints substantiated, and criminal or disciplinary action taken in only 0.4% of cases during 1996-97 it is clear that investigation of the police by the police, even when supervised by the independent police complaints authority, is not working.

The committee notes that there appears to be little prospect of redress for complainants except through the civil courts and even in cases such as those of Shiji Lapite, where an inquest jury has reached a verdict of unlawful killing, disciplinary or criminal action has not been taken against the relevant police officers. The committee studied four cases where civil claims were substantiated, but only in one case was criminal or disciplinary action taken. It is no wonder that public confidence in the system is low - particularly amongst ethnic minorities, for whom the system has so regularly failed to deliver justice. The committee doubts that increasing the powers of the PCA alone would be sufficient to restore public confidence and recommends a "fully fledged investigating agency".
Mary Cunneen
Liberty

Jack Straw's reaction to critics of his plans to curb the right to jury trial (Peers revolt may wreck Straw's jury rights bill, January 14) is itself "knee-jerk" and based on false premises. He claims that choosing jury trial often backfires on defendants who face longer sentences in the crown court. Yet, under his plans, there will be no guarantee that those denied jury trial will be sentenced in magistrates' courts. Magistrates will retain the power, once having refused defendants' requests for jury trial, to send them to the crown court for longer sentences. This can hardly be described as "fair and effective". Rather than continuing to engage in slanging matches with his critics, perhaps Jack Straw should listen to some of the constructive alternatives to his proposals we have put forward.
Prof Lee Bridges
University of Warwick

fields.headline: Cornish way for regions
fields.standfirst: Devolution in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: Lord Baker says that "an English parliament is inevitable to counter the 'grossly unfair' post devolution settlement to Scotland and Wales" (Straw's English awakening, January 11). But an English parliament would be "grossly unfair" to the English regions.
fields.body:
Lord Baker says that "an English parliament is inevitable to counter the 'grossly unfair' post devolution settlement to Scotland and Wales" (Straw's English awakening, January 11). But an English parliament would be "grossly unfair" to the English regions, five of which are larger than Scotland, eight larger than Wales and all nine larger than Northern Ireland. A fair and just settlement would be elected assemblies for the English regions and a federal parliament for the UK.
Peter Tetley
Birmingham

There is no support for an English parliament in Cornwall either (Letters, January 12). Typically, amid the debate concerning British/English nationalism, Cornwall has again been marginalised or ignored. Unlike Yorkshire and Humber and the north-east, the Cornish do not want a south-west regional assembly, they want greater autonomy for Cornwall, which once boasted its own language and parliament. Cornwall is not England and those debating English nationalism would do well to remember this.
Ian Saltern
Stratton, Kernow

fields.headline: Making monkeys of Rome
fields.trailText: Unless the institutions of the Catholic church wake up soon to recognise that millions of committed Catholics like myself live out a daily testimony to the irrelevance of Rome, they will continue to simply put off the day when the wall will be breached
fields.body:
The basic human need to express dissent eventually overpowered the patriarchal institutions of Soviet-style communism. Unless the institutions of the Catholic church wake up soon to recognise that millions of committed Catholics like myself live out a daily testimony to the irrelevance of Rome, they will continue to simply put off the day when the wall will be breached (The nun who took on Rome, January 12). Sister Byrne deserves our gratitude for her bravery in drawing attention to this.
Dan Connolly
Croft-on-Tees, N Yorks
dan.connolly@cdtec.co.uk

When Duns Scotus was asked what would happen if a woman were ordained, he replied: "Nothing." The Catholic sacraments cannot be adminstered promiscu ously and no one may demand them as a right. You can no more ordain a woman than marry a pair of chimpanzees. But since Ms Byrne is already teaching at the Cambridge Theological Federation, which prepares Anglican, Methodist and United Reform students for ordination, I do not understand why she does not apply there for orders which she obviously believes are valid.
Stephen Hancock
Manchester

I hope Lavinia Byrne will continue to write and broadcast - hers is the voice of reason. The antediluvian attitudes of some of the old men at the Vatican only emphasise how greatly our church needs the input of holy, loving and intelligent women.
Val Rawson
Crawley, W Sussex

fields.headline: Cut rate
fields.trailText: A nine-member monetary policy committee is unnecessarily large (Bank raises interest rates again, January 14).
fields.body:
A nine-member monetary policy committee is unnecessarily large (Bank raises interest rates again, January 14). It appears to either raise rates a quarter, lower them a quarter or leave them the same. A majority in favour of any of these three strategies can always be found from five votes. Perhaps the savings from sacking four of the committee could be diverted to our hard-pressed hospitals.
Prof Andrew Henley and Prof John Cable

webTitle: Potent, not omnipotent Even in the US, the president is fettered

fields.headline: Potent, not omnipotent Even in the US, the president is fettered
fields.trailText: The presidency of the United States is enveloped in an aura of power which no other country or head of state can match. While a Chinese or a Russian president may wield awesome influence over citizens' lives, he lacks the legitimacy conferred by truly pluralist politics and free elections.
fields.body:
The presidency of the United States is enveloped in an aura of power which no other country or head of state can match. While a Chinese or a Russian president may wield awesome influence over citizens' lives, he lacks the legitimacy conferred by truly pluralist politics and free elections. Conversely, the powers of the president of a country like Ireland, who is appointed by popular vote, are constitutionally severely circumscribed. In Britain, some say we have a prime minister who thinks he is president. France, on the other hand, has a president who sometimes seems to think, to Lionel Jospin's annoyance, that he is prime minister. The Australians recently decided not to have a president at all.

In the US, these confusions are wholly absent. The presidency is, indisputably, the highest office in the land. Perhaps it is its trappings - the Oval office, the secret service, the armoured limos and speeding motorcades, Air Force One and the White House situation room - which beguile. Hollywood fantasies like Independence Day have ensured that such symbols have international currency. But more likely, the mystique derives from the sheer, unmatched clout - economic, technological, military - of the man at the helm of the planet's leading nation. America's president is, in the conventional wisdom, simply the most powerful man in the world.

The reality is somewhat different. The man (no woman being on offer this time round) who will emerge from the election process which begins on January 24 in Iowa and ends in November faces checks and balances limiting his political power extending far beyond anything envisaged by America's founding fathers. And the curtailment of the imperial presidency has accelerated in the past decade. It is a trend which is widening the gulf between the electorate's expectations and a president's capacity to deliver. As Republicans George W Bush and John McCain, Democrats Al Gore and Bill Bradley, and assorted independents scatter promise after promise on the campaign trail, it is as well to ask what they can actually achieve.

The traditional constraints are well-charted. For six of his eight years in office, Bill Clinton has been forced to negotiate, barter, and confront a congress where both houses and all key committees are dominated by his Republican opponents. This has severely handicapped his legislative agenda, the abandonment of his wife's ambitious healthcare reforms and his failure to enact tougher gun laws being but two examples. In November, control of the house of representatives, and possibly the senate, too, could pass to the Democrats. In which case, for example, Mr Bush, if he wins, will face Mr Clinton's problem in reverse. A president's freedom of action is also constrained by the independence of the federal reserve; by the supreme court; and by the considerable fiscal and legislative autonomy of the 50 states.

These limitations are not new. What has changed is the impact of a range of other factors. One is the way the current mood of detachment, some say neo-iso lationism, affects the conduct of foreign and defence policy, one area in which the president, as commander-in-chief, always leads. It is now hard to envisage circumstances in which the US would send 500,000 troops half way across the world, as President Bush did during the Gulf crisis in 1990-91. Even Kosovo-style campaigns and Haiti-type interventions may soon prove to be too politically problematic. This inward-looking trend should not be exaggerated, but it is plainly there, fuelled by the likes of the populist rabble-rouser, Pat Buchanan.

The growth of special interest groups and lobbyists has further restricted presidential room for manoeuvre. Republicans must deal with Christian fundamentalists, pro-lifers, and the big corporations; the Democrats with the labour unions and environmentalists. In similar vein, groups concerned solely with gender or race issues, such as the national organisation for women, can have an impact on an election and a presidency disproportionate to their numbers. Mr Clinton's proposal to admit gays to the military nearly wrecked his presidency in 1993 when it had hardly begun.

The media's less reverential, increasingly sceptical and invasive attitude to the White House is, as some see it, a healthy development. But as Bob Woodward, the Washington Post reporter, has described in a recent book, the conduct of every presidency since Richard Nixon's has to some extent been distorted by fear, justifiable or imagined, of damaging investigative revelations, allegations of wrongdoing, and personal disgrace. This trend has been exacerbated by congress's growing propensity to appoint special counsels to probe every aspect of a president's affairs. This phenomenon reached a sort of apogee, or low-point, with Kenneth Starr's investigation of the Lewinsky scandal and Mr Clinton's subsequent impeachment. The paralysing effect, in terms of policy and decision-making, of merciless media scrutiny and relentless opinion polling should not be underestimated.

It is no bad thing that the days when John Kennedy could entertain women friends at the White House without fear of exposure have passed; that scams like Iran-contra, executed by Oliver North during the Reagan presidency, are harder to conceal; that presidents are forced to respond to minorities' concerns; that the US is less likely to throw its military weight around; and that domestic consensus-building is now so highly valued by an electorate exasperated by Washington's endless partisan squabbling. The people's message to this year's candidates seems clear. Voters do not want dramatic but empty gestures. They do not want promises that cannot be kept. In Mr Clinton's wake especially, they want a president of good character, who means what he says, who will uphold the nation's interest abroad and speak for its values at home. They want a man who will listen to them but who can take tough decisions. Most of all, they want a man they can trust. It may not sound grand, but the president who can achieve this will be truly powerful.

webTitle: Moving on up: An ABC guide to promotion through self-promotion

fields.headline: Moving on up: An ABC guide to promotion through self-promotion
fields.trailText: A. Basic principles
fields.body:
A. Basic principles

Why some people get promoted and others don't has spawned many interesting theories. Popular ones include the Dilbert Principle (the most useless people are put where they can do least harm - in management) and the Peter Principle (people are promoted to their level of incompetence). If you feel either of those has relevance to your situation it could go a long way to explaining any lack of career advancement.

B. Like me

Internal promotion often has less to do with ability than how good you are at projecting an acceptable image. No club admits a person who sneers at its values or threatens the stability of a comfortable set-up. Those with the power to bestow favours see themselves as a success and inevitably measure others against that standard. The more in tune you are with existing management, the more likely they are to recognise your potential.

C. Ready, steady, go

To get on you need a firm understanding of your organisation's preferred culture and an ability to mould yourself to it in a way that exudes promise and conformity. Look at the characteristics of the meteoric risers and you should be able to determine common factors. Bet very few have ever gone out of their way to rock the boat. To improve your chances of moving up through the ranks you've got to get yourself noticed. Confine that to activities which show how well you'd fit in with those at the top. The first step to promotion is targeted and appropriate self-promotion.

fields.headline: Kiss goodbye to hum-drum working
fields.standfirst: Fallling in love with work will keep you young
fields.trailText: The celebrated Chinese philosopher Confucius once said: "Choose a job you love and you will never work a day in your life." With short-term contracts and flexible work opportunities an increasingly popular feature of today's job climate, there has never been a better time to live up to this ideal.
fields.body:
The celebrated Chinese philosopher Confucius once said: "Choose a job you love and you will never work a day in your life." With short-term contracts and flexible work opportunities an increasingly popular feature of today's job climate, there has never been a better time to live up to this ideal.

And if you genuinely have the passion for a particular vocation - not to mention patience and perseverance - there is no reason why desirable employers shouldn't sign you up.

In fact, with your passion and enthusiasm they'd be silly not to.

Capturing employees' hearts more than their minds is becoming crucial to an organisation's success, because the major reason customers take their business elsewhere and never return is indifferent and discourteous service, says Liz Simpson, author of Working from the heart: a practical guide to loving what you do for a living.

To find your true vocation start by asking yourself what you really enjoy doing and figure out what sort of career will enable you to indulge your passion. Think back to what your career aspirations were as a child, as this may be the very thing you would be doing now were it not for parents or teachers who encouraged you to be realistic.

Your favourite subjects or activities at university or school are also indicators of what you could transform into your dream career.

Gina, a fashion designer has wanted to work in fashion since she was 16.

"Needle work was my favourite subject at school and I really loved art and design," recalls Gina who, after doing a fashion degree at Middlesex University, worked as a fabric assistant, then left to design for Next and Warehouse before setting up her own business last year.

When it comes to pursuing a career, too often we drift into what others view as successful rather then what is in line with our true values. Elizabeth Wilkinson, of the University of Manchester and UMIST Careers Service, encourages graduates to look at their own values, assess the real risks but also consider their gut instincts.

"It's best to do something that you love, rather than doing something that is well paid but soul-destroying. And instead of seeing all the reasons why you can't change, creatively search for ways round the barriers and you will make it."

Anecdotal evidence suggests that people who love their work take fewer days off sick and look younger than their work hating counterparts. And doctors have found that people with life- threatening conditions do occasionally and "miraculously" get better once they have changed their jobs.

Fear of not having enough money to live on, often stops us from pursuing our passion. But as Simpson says: "When you find the work you truly love, you will be successful. You will enthuse co-workers and employers and that will lead to career and financial success."

Novelist Josie Lloyd left a relatively low-paid job in sales promotion to embark on her dream of becoming a novelist. Now she's reaping the rewards in terms of a better lifestyle and a better income.

The turning point came one evening at 11pm when she was still sitting in her office doing a Coca Cola promotion for service station toilets. "I suddenly wondered what I was doing," she remembers. "I decided then to write a novel. I think that happens to a lot of people. They suddenly wonder where their dream went," observes Lloyd, a graduate of Goldsmith's College.

Lloyd's second novel, a romantic offering entitled Come Again, was co-written by her husband Emlyn Rees. Much to her relief she no longer has to juggle waitressing with writing thanks to a substantial advance from publishers Heinemann.

"I now work much harder, but I don't regard this as work, because I love what I do."
