fields.headline: Sixty seconds in: Oil exploration
fields.standfirst: James Iliffe, an exploration geologist with Conoco UK, talks to Miles Brignall
fields.trailText: Every time we drill a hole into the ground it's a gamble whether we'll strike oil - the only problem is it's $20m a throw. Because oil "prospecting" is such an expensive business all the companies put huge efforts into reducing the odds and that's where I come in.
fields.body:
Every time we drill a hole into the ground it's a gamble whether we'll strike oil - the only problem is it's $20m a throw. Because oil "prospecting" is such an expensive business all the companies put huge efforts into reducing the odds and that's where I come in.

Put simply, my job is to predict where exactly the oil is, how much is down there, and the cost of getting it out. Although I'm based in Aberdeen and do a lot of work analysing the area off this coast, I am just as likely to be studying an option in West Africa.

I work as one of a team of six geologists and my speciality is three dimensional computer modelling. Oil will only be found where a certain set of circumstances occur and it's a case of establishing that each piece of the jigsaw is present. The information our decisions are based upon largely comes from three main sources - seismic surveys telling us which rock structures are present, satellite maps which identify faults and naturally forming slicks, and the data and information gained from previous drillings.

Some of this information is publicly available, or a rival company which has drilled a dry well may swap or sell the results. As the data arrives I'll analyse it and feed relevant information into the computer model and we'll start to build up a picture of where the reserves are likely to be.

What makes things more complicated is the fact that oil moves about. A lot of skill is predicting where it will migrate to within the structure - because it's lighter than water it can seep away entirely. Once we have all the information it's a case of coming up with the size of the reserve. A good find would be a billion barrels of which we would take out between 30% and 50%.

Equally important, I'm expected to establish the risks associated with its exploration. Oil can be four miles below the surface and we might find a huge reserve that is simply uneconomic to bring up. Conversely an easily accessed reserve may not have the required quantity. It's a question of weighing up the size of the find against the cost of its extraction.

The strange thing is that I'm doing the job I always wanted as a boy. I studied geology at Swansea before doing my Masters in South Carolina which took me to a small dustbowl near Suez. From 6am to 2pm I mapped the area to study how hydrocarbons became trapped - and there in the heat I was hooked.

I get a real buzz out of using the latest technology and the work is challenging. We recently drilled a well off New Zealand it was amazing to sit in our offices in Aberdeen and watch the results instantly flash on to our screens.

webTitle: Help: I'm always the one out on a limb!

fields.headline: Help: I'm always the one out on a limb!
fields.standfirst:
I'm a representative on our works council. Although we agree the approach to any contentious matters beforehand, I'm usually the one who ends up doing the talking and no-one ever backs me up.
- Graham T, cost engineer, Salford.
fields.trailText: Your colleagues are obviously more aware than you that bearers of bad news risk being tainted by it. Any position that brings you into potential conflict with your management is tricky, so the principle that you're representing the views of others, rather than your own, needs to be reinforced.
fields.body:
Your colleagues are obviously more aware than you that bearers of bad news risk being tainted by it. Any position that brings you into potential conflict with your management is tricky, so the principle that you're representing the views of others, rather than your own, needs to be reinforced.

That's not happening if they don't back you up; instead you come across as looking for problems others don't see. To be identified as a lone agitator is to mark yourself as a target for retribution.

Start by telling the silent majority how disillusioned you are with their lack of support. Perhaps they're unaware you feel vulnerable or even resent you hogging the limelight. Could it be that you're straying from the accepted script in a way that makes them uncomfortable and goes beyond their interpretation of what was agreed?

Be sure everyone is clear on the approach to any delicate matters. Make firm arrangements about who will raise what, and ensure you let others speak. Avoid appearing negative and confrontational - that makes people defensive. Realistic suggestions for improvement encourage more discussion. Messengers who bring solutions as well as problems are less likely to get shot.

If you can't combat the apathy of others, walk away and leave them to it. It's good to spread the responsibility of representation around.

webTitle: How to... find a cure for your itchy feet

fields.headline: How to... find a cure for your itchy feet
fields.standfirst: Perhaps all they need is a really good scratch
fields.trailText: There's nothing much worse than itchy feet. But instead of getting stuck in the "should I stay or go" dilemma, rejoice in the fact that you care enough about your job and your future to actually question the status quo.
fields.body:
There's nothing much worse than itchy feet. But instead of getting stuck in the "should I stay or go" dilemma, rejoice in the fact that you care enough about your job and your future to actually question the status quo.

Neasa MacErlean, author, says: "Many people review their lives in the New Year. Questioning what they are doing and how happy they are with that is much better than just staying put."

However, it's still hard to know when to stay and when to go. Many never stop to think beyond the "I've been in this job for x time, it's time to move on" or, "I'm bored" to actually think about why they want to leave and where they want to go to. Evidently the danger is the old 'out of the frying pan in to the fire' scenario.

A back to basics evaluation of your career wants and needs is then, a good idea.

You need to think about what motivates you and what sort of environment you would ideally wish to work in. Think about the skills that you have already acquired and those that you would like to master.

This should help you build a picture of your ideal job. From here you can now evaluate how well your current job matches that picture.

Dr Peter Hawkins, at the University of Liverpool's Graduates Into Employment Unit, thinks it's all about creating your own opportunities. He says: "You need to have helicopter mentality. Rising above the clouds allows you to see the bigger picture and spot dead ends. It also gives you the ideal vantage point to swoop down and seize opportunities in your current situation."

The most important thing is to be positive. Debra Allcock, head of campaigning at the Industrial Society, says: "Enjoyment of work is 90% attitude and 10% the job."

If you are positive and enthusiastic then you stand a better chance of growing in your existing job, should you decide to stay.

Most bosses are amenable to requests to take on additional responsibilities, learning new skills or secondments. Employees who make these requests obviously care about their contribution to the company and have taken the time to think about their job rather than just plodding on within their existing role. The basic reasons for wanting to leave a job nearly always resurface though. So make sure that any growth you negotiate within your current job, really does offer new opportunities.

You could also take an evening course or do some voluntary work that would help you in say, six months time.

Another alternative is to set yourself objectives within your current role and give yourself a time limit. This way of thinking means you're more likely to meet your targets and are less likely to slide into apathy.

The main thing is to avoid moving to a job that you are not 100% about, only to be restless again after a year. Although the job hopping theory carries less weight in these times of life long learning and flexibility, you do have to be careful.

Elizabeth Lumley, at Intelligent Resources recruitment consultants, says: "The average amount of time for people to stay in a job is around two years - anything under a year needs a clear reason for leaving."

That said, if you genuinely cannot think of anything positive that you could give to or receive from your company then it's time to move on.

Having made that decision you then need to have thought about each and every job that you apply to. Key questions to ask yourself about each and every application could include; what have I got to offer this employer and vice versa? How far does this position go towards meeting my current needs and wants and how will it help me to achieve my long-term goals?

The fact that you have spent some time thinking about your next move will make you a much stronger candidate, not only in terms of the skills and experience you can offer but perhaps more importantly, with regard to your attitude.

As Peter Hawkins says: "The crux is understanding what fulfils and motivates you. Most people devote more time to planning their holiday than thinking about a whole lifetime of work."

Clearly, careful thought and evaluation pays if you want to avoid getting into a rut in the first place and getting out of one if you need to.

Think about the skills that you have already acquired and those that you would like to master. This should help you build a picture of your ideal job. From here you can now evaluate how well your current job matches that picture. Dr Peter Hawkins, at the University of Liverpool's Graduates Into Employment Unit, thinks it's all about creating your own opportunities. He says: "You need to have helicopter mentality. Rising above the clouds allows you to see the bigger picture and spot dead ends. It also gives you the ideal vantage point to swoop down and seize opportunities in your current situation." The most important thing is to be positive. Debra Allcock, head of campaigning at the Industrial Society, says: "Enjoyment of work is 90% attitude and 10% the job." If you are positive and enthusiastic then you stand a better chance of growing in your existing job, should you decide to stay. Most bosses are amenable to requests to take on additional responsibilities, learning new skills or secondments. Employees who make these requests obviously care about their contribution to the company and have taken the time to think about their job rather than just plodding on within their existing role. The basic reasons for wanting to leave a job nearly always resurface though. So make sure that any growth you negotiate within your current job, really does offer new opportunities. You could also take an evening course or do some voluntary work that would help you in say, six months time. Another alternative is to set yourself objectives within your current role and give yourself a time limit. This way of thinking means you're more likely to meet your targets and are less likely to slide into apathy. The main thing is to avoid moving to a job that you are not 100% about, only to be restless again after a year. Although the job hopping theory carries less weight in these times of life long learning and flexibility, you do have to be careful. Elizabeth Lumley, at Intelligent Resources recruitment consultants, says: "The average amount of time for people to stay in a job is around two years - anything under a year needs a clear reason for leaving." That said, if you genuinely cannot think of anything positive that you could give to or receive from your company then it's time to move on. Having made that decision you then need to have thought about each and every job that you apply to. Key questions to ask yourself about each and every application could include; what have I got to offer this employer and vice versa? How far does this position go towards meeting my current needs and wants and how will it help me to achieve my long-term goals? The fact that you have spent some time thinking about your next move will make you a much stronger candidate, not only in terms of the skills and experience you can offer but perhaps more importantly, with regard to your attitude. As Peter Hawkins says: "The crux is understanding what fulfils and motivates you. Most people devote more time to planning their holiday than thinking about a whole lifetime of work." Clearly, careful thought and evaluation pays if you want to avoid getting into a rut in the first place and getting out of one if you need to.

fields.headline: Back to the future
fields.standfirst: Will it be any easier to find a good job in 2000?
fields.trailText: Will it be any easier to find a good job in 2000?
fields.body:
Just when you thought it was safe to open a newspaper ... the Millennium retrospective is back. Please indulge us: this is the first Rise of the 21st century and we're feeling a little nostalgic.

If your parents have ever said: "It wasn't like this in our day", they'd be telling the truth.

Graduates may still wear a cap and gown, but they're no longer the idealistic elite who waltzed into jobs 30 years ago. The polytechnics have disappeared, student numbers have more than doubled and Britain's economy has changed forever.

We spoke to three veteran graduates - from the seventies, eighties and nineties - and asked them to recall their experiences of entering the world of work. Finally, we asked a final-year student to tell us how it felt to be about to become one of the first graduates of the 21st century.

The seventies

Michael Wellin, 51, is a partner in management consultancy, Behaviour Transformation. He graduated from Sussex University in 1970 with a degree in psychology, following it with a masters in personnel development.

"If you were a graduate in the seventies, it wasn't a question of whether you'd get a job but which job to choose. Less than 10% of the young population went to university, compared to around 30% now. We did degrees for personal interest, not for careers.

"Unlike most of my peers who tried a bit of this and that, I knew what I wanted to do. Having decided to go into business psychology, I was sponsored to do my MA thesis and then found it relatively easy to get jobs at various companies until I set up my own business.

"Society wasn't focused like today: for many graduates the only career goal was to work with nice people and have a good time. Mrs Thatcher and the global economy changed all that. Companies have changed, too. In those days, you could go out boozing at lunchtime and be unproductive in the afternoon. We thought we'd find a job we liked and do it for life. That ethos has disappeared forever."

The eighties

Nicola Rossi, 37, is PR campaigns manager for BT. She graduated from University College London with a degree in English Literature in 1984.

"When people think of the eighties they imagine that everyone lived an affluent, yuppie lifestyle. It wasn't like that for students - there was a huge contrast between the 'greed is good' philosophy and the reality of living on a student grant.

"New graduates didn't get vast salaries, but it was relatively easy to get a job: everyone I know who took the milk round route got a placement quickly.

"Even those of us who went into more creative professions, such as journalism or PR, enjoyed a smooth career path, with no periods of unemployment. There were lots of opportunities and if you followed your dream you got there in the end.

"When I finished my degree I took a two-year sabbatical, becoming education and welfare officer for UCL and then student union president of ULU, representing more than 40,000 students. My first job was working on Time Out guides and I then got a job in a PR agency. The fact that I've stayed in PR for 15 years makes me feel I'm in the right career.

"Working on the student newspaper and in student politics taught me far more about the world of work than my degree. I studied English purely because I was passionate about it. I couldn't see any further than paying off my debts and doing something interesting, for a company I believed in. I think we cared more about company ethics than today's graduates."

The nineties

Karen John-Pierre, 28, is an information officer for a large medical charity. She graduated from Essex University in 1992, with a BA hons degree in English and European Literature.

"I was the first person in my family ever to go to university and I never dreamed it would be hard to find a good job when I finished. I enjoyed studying and, like most of my friends, didn't think too much about a career while I was a student. But none of us had anticipated that we'd be graduating right into the middle of the economic recession.

"In 1992 the milk round was cancelled and few companies were taking on graduate trainees. Out of 30 of my peers, only one person got a graduate job immediately. Everyone else - myself included - decided to go travelling or to apply for postgraduate courses.

"I signed up for the Work America scheme for six months. When I returned I tried to get a job in publishing, but it proved impossible. I got so fed up that I took a job as a sales assistant in a clothes shop so I could pay off my debts. When I'd saved some money I went back to the States. While there, I did some research into information work and decided to enrol on a postgraduate information management course on my return to England. Fortunately, I got a job as soon as I qualified.

"The early 1990s was the first time graduates were left on the shelf. I felt cheated - my degree wasn't worth what they'd promised at school. In retrospect, I should have been more organised and proactive. Students today are so much more sorted about their careers."

This year

Andrew Green, 21, is a politics student at the University of the West of England in Bristol. He'll graduate next June.

"I haven't yet got a job sorted, but I have looked into getting a clerkship in the Houses of Parliament. Alternatively, I might go travelling for a year or I might return to America to take up a job offer at a computer company where I worked last summer.

"Half of my fellow students don't have a clue what they'll do when they leave university - they're just doing a degree for the sake of it. The other half have already arranged interviews with blue-chip companies. Most of us are pretty sussed about what we need to do to get a job. We know the job market is competitive and that many degrees are not as valuable as they once were. We also know that we might have several careers - no-one goes into a job expecting a gold watch.

"If you're armed with a decent degree, I'd say it's a good time to be a graduate. The information revolution has really opened up the job market. I'm optimistic about the future. I just haven't made my mind up about what I want to do yet."

webTitle: Don't keep Hector waiting any longer

fields.headline: Don't keep Hector waiting any longer
fields.standfirst: You must submit that self-assessment return by the end of this month or face penalties. Patrick Collinson offers a payer-friendly guide
fields.trailText: You have 16 days left. Unless you return your self-assessment tax form by January 31 the Inland Revenue will hit you with a £100 penalty plus interest on any unpaid tax. Last year the Revenue earned a neat £74.8m from fining the 748,000 people who failed to meet the deadline - or around one in 12 of the 9m sent the forms. So here are some tips on filling in the return and avoiding throwing money at Hector the tax inspector.
fields.body:
You have 16 days left. Unless you return your self-assessment tax form by January 31 the Inland Revenue will hit you with a £100 penalty plus interest on any unpaid tax. Last year the Revenue earned a neat £74.8m from fining the 748,000 people who failed to meet the deadline - or around one in 12 of the 9m sent the forms. So here are some tips on filling in the return and avoiding throwing money at Hector the tax inspector.

Filling in the return

Get all your tax records together, such as bank statements, business earnings and expenses. You need documents supporting your income to complete the form, but do not send them in with your tax return. The essentials are your P60, P11D and interest certificates.

Don't treat the form as a speed trial. The accompanying Revenue notes are usually clear and helpful. "Above all, do not try to do the tax return from memory," says PricewaterhouseCoopers tax partner John Whiting.

Make sure you complete everything. The £100 penalty will still apply if you beat the deadline but don't fill in all the necessary information. Put in exact figures, although Peter Horsman of accountants Saffrey Champness says: "If you are uncertain of the figures, one is allowed to put in provisional figures so long as they are stated as provisional and a date is given when actual figures will be supplied."

Many benefits are taxable, with child benefit the key one that is not. If you are unsure, look at the Revenue's notes on the area.

Don't forget about pension income, including the state pension. "Apart from such awards as pensions for winning the Victoria Cross, pensions are taxable, even the state pension," warns Mr Whiting.

For dividends and interest, you need to put the net amount (cash actually received), the tax deducted (see the certificate/voucher) and the gross amount. Make sure they add up and that you put the amounts in the right boxes.

You have to send in your tax payable along with the tax return. As you have missed the September 30 deadline last year, you cannot elect to have the money deducted at source from your pay through Pay As You Earn.

Do not forget to sign the return. "It has been a common cause of rejection!" says Mr Whiting. Also take a copy of your return, and use last year's return to review against this year's. "For example, if rental income has dropped dramatically, explain why in the white space to save an obvious question later from the taxman," says Mr Whiting.

Rejection reasons

A tick has been entered in one of the questions 1 to 9 on page 2 of the return but the supplementary page has not been forwarded with the income tax return.

Failure to provide details for a 24-month period where the self-employed activity commenced before 6 April 1994.

Failure to fully complete the self-employed pages particularly after boxes 3.70/3.75.

Detailing information on separate schedules instead of including it on the self assessment income tax return.

Entering manuscript notes on the return eg "per P60" and/or "information to follow" instead of entering actual figures on the form.

Failure to sign and date the return.

Common queries

Do I have to pay more tax under Self-assessment?

Definitely not, says the Revenue. Self-assessment is "not a new tax and does not affect the amount of tax you need to pay" it says. But in reality the government has benefited substantially from self-assessment, as people have come clean on the tax they owe rather than sign a false declaration.

Must I employ an accountant?

It's entirely up to you. The majority of self-employed people already use accountants. "If you didn't use an accountant under the old system, you're unlikely to need one for self-assessment," says the Revenue.

Should I send in accounts with the tax return?

No. The Revenue says: "It is our view that accounts are unlikely to provide us with additional information unless your business is particularly large or complex. For this reason we only ask for accounts and computations for partnerships whose turnover is £15m or more."

Do you want my P60 or a copy of my form P11D/P9D?

No. Just put the details on the tax return, but keep the documents in case there are any queries about your return.

What do I do if there's information I think you need but I can't find the box?

The Revenue believes its form and notes should give sufficient guidance. But it says: "You can send in additional information if you consider that it is relevant to your tax liability, and it cannot be entered in the spaces and boxes provided in the return. We will accept any additional information sent in with the return, but recommend that you provide an explanation of why you think its relevant."

What do I do if I disagree with my employer or bank about the figures?

The Revenue states firmly that you are responsible for the accuracy of your return. "If you disagree with the information provided by your employer or bank, you should include the information which you think is correct. You should not delay in sending your return," it says.

Is there an electronic version of the tax return?

Yes, but it only includes the standard eight-page return and supplementary pages for employment. The electronic version of the tax return can be downloaded at www.inlandrevenue.gov.uk.

What can I expect after I've sent in the return?

Not much. You will only know that the Revenue has processed your return when you receive your statement of account, showing the tax due based on the figures you have declared. However, the Revenue will contact you if it has had to correct your return.

How will I know if you are going to make an inquiry into my return?

If they are going to probe your return, they will write to you no later than January 31, 2001. If you've heard nothing by then, your return is deemed "final," unless they later discover that you lied.

What if I realise I've made a mistake after I've sent the return in?

You have one year from the annual filing date (31 January) to make any changes.

What happens if I miss the deadline by just one day?

The final deadline, January 31, falls on a Monday. But the Revenue says that no late filing penalty will be charged where the return is either (a) received in the post at any time on Tuesday February 1, or (b) delivered by hand at any time on Tuesday February 1 or (c) found in the tax office letter box by 7.30am on Wednesday February 2.

Getting help

The best way to obtain last-minute assistance on filling in the form is to ring the Inland Revenue itself. The self-assessment helpline on 0645-000-444 is open evenings and weekends, with calls charged at local rates. You can also ring local Tax Enquiry Centres, listed in the telephone book under Inland Revenue. Most tax offices are open to the public from 8.30am to 4.30pm Monday to Friday. You can also call the Revenue's Orderline on 0645-000-404 for explanatory leaflets and booklets.

In addition the Inland Revenue operates an extremely comprehensive and easy to use website containing most of the information in its booklets on www.inlandrevenue.gov.uk. Lots of accountancy firms have also begun offering their services over the internet, and some say that they will still be able to complete your form and get it to the Revenue by the deadline.

Fees are either on a fixed basis for simple returns, starting at around £50, rising to £150-£200 for more complex returns for the self-employed. Sites offering these services include www.selfassess.com

webTitle: The child is father (or mother) of the plan

fields.headline: The child is father (or mother) of the plan
fields.standfirst: Rupert Jones, proud parent of five-week-old Eliza, thought long and hard about a long-term savings plan for his daughter
fields.trailText: A few months back, when my colleagues learned I was due to become a dad for the first time, I received lots of ribbing about the articles I'd soon be writing about kids' savings accounts, school fees planning and the best prams on the market.
fields.body:
A few months back, when my colleagues learned I was due to become a dad for the first time, I received lots of ribbing about the articles I'd soon be writing about kids' savings accounts, school fees planning and the best prams on the market.

I remember jokily pooh-poohing such suggestions as "new dad" typecasting, yet just five weeks after the birth of baby Eliza, above, here I am about to launch into an article on investing for children.

As a personal finance correspondent I thought my new millennium's resolution really should be to set up some sort of nest-egg for my 21st century babe.

But where do you start? Savings accounts, baby bonds, National Savings children's bonus bonds, unit trusts, investment trusts... the list of products seems endless. Our aim is to set something up that will produce a decent sum of money that Eliza can perhaps use to help her through university or for her first car or flat.

My wife Harriet and I are keen to go for a stock market-related investment rather than something like a bank or building society account, but want to explore all the options. A fund that allows us to put away a regular amount each month sounds like a good idea. But I don't want to commit myself to anything more than £20-£25 a month - a decision that limits our options, as many unit trusts have a minimum monthly contribution of around £50.

I decided to canvass the views of three independent financial advisers. My first was Andy Cowan at Edinburgh-based IFA Aitchison & Colegrave. He agreed that for a long-term investment such as we are contemplating the stock market was probably the place to be, and a unit trust may be a good bet.

Fairly solid, medium-risk UK funds with an emphasis on blue-chip companies are popular when it comes to investing for children, says Mr Cowan. The wish of many parents is best summed up as "reasonable growth with relative security", he adds.

Mr Cowan also picked out so-called baby bonds, savings plans offered by friendly societies allowing up to £25 a month to be saved free of income tax and capital gains tax. These are normally with-profits products, where your money is invested in a mixture of shares, bonds and property and the aim is steady growth and no nasty shocks. However, he warned that over shorter terms (say 10 years), charges on these plans can be prohibitive. Mr Cowan likes the baby bonds offered by Tunbridge Wells Equitable Friendly Society.

Two unit trusts singled out by Mr Cowan were Newton Income and Jupiter Income, but both are out of my price league as their minimum investments are £50 and £100 a month respectively.

I next picked the brains of James Dalby at Leeds-based IFA Bates Investment Services. He is also a fan of unit trusts. fields.headline: Mortgages on the move
fields.standfirst: Interest rates
fields.trailText: Housebuyers about to take out a mortgage have been left facing a dilemma following the latest rate rise.
fields.body:
Housebuyers about to take out a mortgage have been left facing a dilemma following the latest rate rise.

Borrowing costs are set to climb for millions as a result of Thursday's 0.25% base rate hike and economists expect further increases over the next few months. But the expectation is that come the end of this year or the beginning of 2001 interest rates will start falling as the UK begins to move into line with Europe.

So those thinking of taking out a mortgage now face a difficult decision. Do they go for a loan based on what we think will happen in the short term, or do they make their decision based on what the experts are predicting will happen later? "A short-term rate rise, followed by a [predicted] fall, is a tricky one for borrowers to call," says Ray Boulger at mortgage brokers John Charcol.

Despite the medium- to long-term predictions of rate cuts, some housebuyers, particularly those with tight budgets, will probably still prefer the certainty of a fixed-rate deal, he adds. With this you know exactly what your monthly payments will be and you won't suffer any nasty shocks.

Others will perhaps take the view that, even though interest rates are climbing now, it is still worth going for a discounted mortgage deal to benefit from the rate cuts which everyone seems to think are heading our way.

Just to add to the pressure on borrowers, you'll have to act quickly if you want to take advantage of the best deals currently available. "Following the move in base rates we are likely to see lots of attractive mortgage deals being taken off the market or revised," says Kevin Friend at online mortgage broker Emfinance (www.emfinance.com). Lowest fixed rates include Skipton building society, which is offering those able to stump up a deposit of 20%-plus a loan fixed at 5.45% until March 1 2002 (but you must take their buildings and contents insurance, and there is an early redemption penalty of 3% throughout the fixed period).

NatWest has a deal fixed at 5.99% until March 1 2002 which has no redemption penalties and is available to those who can only manage a 5% deposit and Britannia building society, has a mortgage fixed at 6.15% for three years (but the loan is only available to borrowers with a deposit of 25%-plus of the property's value and there are redemption penalties).

Tracker mortgages have been popular for some time. But some borrowers will be worried about going for one at a time when rates are rising. In response John Charcol is offering a combined tracker/capped mortgage, where what you pay is set at bank base rate plus 0.95% for the life of the loan, resulting in a current payment rate of 6.7%. The rate is capped at 6.99% for five years, so you won't pay any more than that during that period.

And if rates fall, of course, so does what you pay. It's available for house purchases and remortgages up to 90% of the property's value (95% for first-time buyers), but there is a redemption penalty of 180 days' interest during the capped rate period.

Perhaps the best deal on the discounted rate front is offered by the Halifax. It gives borrowers 2.25% off its standard variable mortgage rate until January 31 2002. It's available for loans of up to 95% of the property's value and there are no redemption penalties and no fee to pay.

Thursday's rate rise was the third in five months. A quarter point rise on a Halifax £60,000 repayment mortgage would mean a £9.18 increase in monthly payments from £420.26 to £429.44.

Ray Boulger anticipates another 0.25% base rate rise next month or in March, with rates starting to fall come 2001. Economists at HSBC say a further hike at February's meeting "appears likely," with base rates expected to peak at 6.5% by the end of June.

Moneyfacts says the typical mortgage rate currently stands at 7.17%, while the typical instant-access savings rate is just 1.21% net. Five years ago the differential was much narrower - the mortgage rate figure was only slightly higher at 8.11% but the typical saver was getting 3.06%, some two-and-a-half times what they are getting now.

Many commentators said the rate rise, though unpleasant for homeowners, will help to ensure that housing "hot spots" are kept in check. A survey this week from Nationwide building society revealed that these hot spots include the London boroughs of Hackney, Merton and Wandsworth, and Brighton. All four saw house prices shoot up 36%-37% last year. Close behind were Southwark and the East Sussex town of Hastings (both 34%).

webTitle: What to do if they get it wrong

fields.headline: What to do if they get it wrong
fields.trailText: As the last taxpayers scurry to complete their 1998/99 tax returns before January 31, you may feel quite complacent if you filed some months ago and have already received the Revenue's calculation. But are you sure that the taxman got the figures right?
fields.body:
As the last taxpayers scurry to complete their 1998/99 tax returns before January 31, you may feel quite complacent if you filed some months ago and have already received the Revenue's calculation. But are you sure that the taxman got the figures right?

I have worked in tax for more than 20 years and enjoyed a good relationship with my tax office, which has been friendly and efficient. I have always known that the taxman can make mistakes but somehow I never expected it to happen to me.

Like millions of others within self-assessment, I was lured by the promise that the Revenue would calculate my tax for me if I submitted the return by September 30.

So I duly filed in September, and within a few weeks I received my tax calculation. The amount due seemed higher than my own estimate, so I worked through the figures and was horrified to find two serious mistakes.

First, the tax taken off my salary was understated by exactly £1,000. Second, the taxman had left out the married couple's allowance, worth £285. While the first mistake might have been an unfortunate human error, the second seemed unbelievable since I had confirmed that I was married on two separate pages of the form - boxes 16.5 and 21.3.

My tax office apologised and put things right, but I was outraged. Millions of taxpayers rely upon the Revenue to get things right and cannot afford to pay a tax adviser to double-check all the figures. How many people are overpaying tax without realising it?

Under its "Service Commitment" the Revenue invites us to complain when things go wrong so I asked my tax office for an explanation and what procedures are in place to protect taxpayers.

A week later I received the rather bland reply that "there is a system in place for making regular checks on a random sample of tax returns to check the accuracy of data captured. In the vast majority of cases, the data captured is accurate. Mistakes are however, unfortunately sometimes made." It enclosed a copy of Code of Practice 1 - Mistakes by the Inland Revenue, outlining service standards and compensation available.

The booklet says that I can claim compensation for any costs arising from serious or persistent errors by my tax office, and "consolatory payments" available for worry or distress, but I did not suffer too badly on either score.

My main concern was how often this might be happening to other taxpayers, and whether people even realise that their tax office may have made a mistake. The Revenue's head office told me there are reviews of work in processing returns, but there are no statistics to tell how often these are done. The National Audit Office also revealed that they have not yet checked the quality of the Revenue's work in this area.

Charlie Gordon, head of the adjudicator's office, which reviews complaints about the Revenue, says they have received a number of similar complaints, but suggests it is not a widespread problem. He points out that errors don't always result in a larger tax bill; there are cases where people receive tax refunds not actually due and later have to repay them.

My advice is to check the Revenue's figures against those you put on your tax return so keep a photocopy of the form for this purpose. If you have any doubts about the Revenue's figures, ask your tax office to double-check its work, but if you are still unhappy, ask your tax office for its free booklet IR167 Charter for Inland Revenue Taxpayers or telephone the Adjudicator's office for a booklet which explains how to complain (0171-930-2292).

David Brodie is director of TaxAid, the charity which provides free tax advice to individuals who cannot afford professional fees. Phone 0171-624-3768 between 10 am and 12 midday, Mondays to Thursdays.

fields.headline: Small firms escape stakeholder rules
fields.standfirst: Hundreds of thousands of workers may now miss out on the chance to provide for their old age, writes Rupert Jones
fields.trailText: The government has been accused of watering down its plans for low-cost "stakeholder" pensions by effectively excluding hundreds of thousands of workers in small companies.
fields.body:
The government has been accused of watering down its plans for low-cost "stakeholder" pensions by effectively excluding hundreds of thousands of workers in small companies.

Ministers have dropped their original proposal that all firms would have to offer employees a company pension scheme or give them access to the new breed of personal pension. Small companies have now been let off the hook.

Labour has been banging on about the stakeholder pension since it was in opposition but it is only now that all the pieces of the jigsaw are finally falling into place.

Stakeholder pensions will be available from April 2001 and the government promises they will be good value and user-friendly. The aim is that they will encourage millions more people to put money aside for their old age.

Anyone will be able to take one out, but their target market is the millions of low to middle-income earners with no private pension provision.

Social security secretary Alistair Darling this week announced that firms with fewer than five staff - around two-thirds of all Britain's employers - will not have to make stakeholder pensions available to their workers. He made this change after small firms claimed they were already buckling under the weight of a raft of new legislation, from the working time directive to the minimum wage, and having to give workers access to these new schemes was an administrative headache they could well do without.

People who work for small companies will still be able to obtain stakeholder pensions, but they will have to buy them direct from pension companies. However, the Consumers' Association suspects that, faced with sorting things out themselves, many of these people are likely to simply do nothing. Under the original plans, the boss of a small firm with no pension scheme would have had to select a stakeholder plan for staff to pay into if they wished, and arrange for pension contributions to be deducted from their earnings if requested.

The GMB union blasted the decision, saying that by "excluding" hundreds of thousands of workers in this way, the government was "undermining the whole basis of stakeholding". The change seriously affects the accessibility of the new pensions, and makes their success far less likely, says GMB national pension officer Bill Day.

Companies operating group personal pension schemes will also be exempt from the requirement to make stakeholder plans available, provided employers contribute the equivalent of at least 3% of employees' earnings to the GPP scheme.

In addition, the government has announced it is raising the minimum contribution that someone can make to a stakeholder pension. Previously it said people would be able to open one for as little as £10 but this has now been doubled to £20 - a change which the CA warns is not going to help when it comes to trying to encourage low earners to take the pension plunge. "It's disappointing," says Philip Telford, senior policy adviser at the CA. "We would favour it being as low as possible."

However, pension companies insist it is simply not realistic for people to think they can end up with a decent-sized pension on contributions of £10 a month.

"If you paid £10 a month for your entire working life you'd get a pension in real terms that would be about half the value of the basic state pension. That's not much of a top-up," says Adrian Boulding at insurer Legal & General. He adds that £20 is "a more realistic starting level".

In order to call themselves stakeholder pensions, schemes will have to meet a range of minimum standards. The main one is that the maximum a company can charge for managing the fund is 1% a year. This figure was finally confirmed this week after months of umm-ing and ahh-ing by ministers, and has been hailed as good news for the consumer. However, this 1% charge will cover only the cost of receiving basic financial advice - those people wanting more detailed advice tailored to their particular circumstances may have to pay an extra fee which could amount to several hundred pounds.

Stakeholder pensions will be offered by all the usual providers - insurers, banks, investment houses and financial advisers - but will also be available from organisations such as trade unions.

They may not go on sale for another 15 months but there are already some pension plans available offering stakeholder-style low charges and flexibility. Wolverhampton-based independent broker Torquil Clark (0800 0561836) has linked up with insurer Friends Provident on a personal pension with an all-in annual management charge of 0.95% with no minimum contribution level.

Those keen to find out more about the stakeholder concept can now log on to a new website specifically dedicated to the subject. The site has been launched this week by Interactive Investor International (iii), an online personal finance service, and can be found at www.iii.co.uk/stakeholder

webTitle: Becoming a landlord can ease cash crunch

fields.headline: Becoming a landlord can ease cash crunch
fields.standfirst: As loans replace grants undergraduates are feeling the pinch. But, as Patrick Sherwen reports, some are going into the property game
fields.trailText: Life is getting harder for students. The government is scaling back mandatory grants and replacing them with student loans, with the result that four out 10 students are taking term-time jobs and three out of 10 are missing lectures because of work commitments. Much of the money earned goes to paying rent, now half of a typical student's spending.
fields.body:
Life is getting harder for students. The government is scaling back mandatory grants and replacing them with student loans, with the result that four out 10 students are taking term-time jobs and three out of 10 are missing lectures because of work commitments. Much of the money earned goes to paying rent, now half of a typical student's spending.

First year undergraduates have an easier time since virtually all universities offer them subsidised accommodation in halls of residence or flats. But from the second year most have to fend for themselves. A recent National Union of Students survey found that rent was the second biggest financial burden after socialising and entertainment and the single largest cost per year.

But anecdotal evidence suggests the rents paid by students are pretty stable. One reason is that rents are fixed annually by each new wave of students. Jeremy Wood, a director of Nationwide, says even the boom in buying to let has had little effect on student rents in the past 12 months.

"As a landlord you are only going to get the rent the market is prepared to pay," he says, and with students this is capped by an increasingly limited income. The package for a student living away from home is £3,450 a year, or £68.08 a week.

The average weekly expenditure on accommodation is £44.98, which leaves £23.10 a week for food, books, clothes and everything else. But rents across the country vary considerably. In Newcastle upon Tyne a room in the Fenham area may cost as little as £22 a week. In Bristol students can shell out up £55 a week for a similar deal. Most expensive is London, where average rent under a private landlord is £87.03.

Between the academic years 1996-97 and 1997-98 (the latest period researched by the NUS) the smallest increase in private sector student rents was 0.9% in the north-east while London students were hit hardest by a jump of 6.2%.

One alternative is for the student to become landlords themselves. Stuart Goff, owner of Goffs Estate Agents in Sheffield which specialises in the student market, says: "Now that the mandatory grant is no longer around, people are looking at ways of making living at university more financially viable." An increasingly popular way to do this is for a student, backed by parents, to buy a house to live in and let the other rooms out. Mr Goff says the number of people doing this through his firm increased from about 30 in 1998 to more than 45 in 1999.

Private sector student rents in Sheffield vary between £36 and £45 a week, so a four-bedroom house could generate income of £432 a month, while the student landlord would have no rent to pay. With a £50,000 mortgage monthly repayments might be £285 before insurance, leaving £145 to save or spend. Mr Goff says as long as the property costs less than £100,000 there is a fair chance of generating a decent capital sum which could be used to pay off debts.

Another way to avoid the rent problem is to persuade your parents to take out a buy-to-let mortgage and buy a property for you. Buyers need to put up at least 15% of the purchase price. Ray Boulger, technical director of John Charcol, the UK's largest mortgage broker, says it is best to have all the students in the house as co-signatories on the same tenancy agreement. This puts the onus on the residents to find a replacement for anyone who moves out since they are jointly responsible for the total rent payment.

One danger is that some mortgage lenders prefer properties not to be used for investment purposes. So if you do plan to earn extra from the property check the terms of the loan with the product provider first.

webTitle: What it will mean to be a big city light

fields.headline: What it will mean to be a big city light
fields.standfirst: Elizabeth Langton looks at the property scene and facilities in the towns leading the chase for a change of status this year
fields.trailText: The good burghers of Britain's largest towns have spent the new year stepping up their campaigns to become the first new city of the millennium.
fields.body:
The good burghers of Britain's largest towns have spent the new year stepping up their campaigns to become the first new city of the millennium.

Councillors from 39 towns are busily promoting their patch for all they're worth in a bid for a higher profile and status. The winner will be announced early this year by the Queen to mark the 21st century.

Bookie William Hill caused a stir when it announced the favourites - Brighton and Hove, Luton, Reading, Milton Keynes and Guildford are the front-runners to date.

In the south-east, home to all the leading towns, house prices are rising by around 20% a year and estate agents say city status will attract even more buyers to these already booming local markets.

At one time a town needed to have a population of at least 300,000 to be officially declared a city. The presence of a cathedral used to be enough to make even medium towns grand. But towns no longer need to meet any official criteria.

Brian Raggett, president of the Royal Town Planning Institute, says city status tends to mean more to the people who live there than to anyone else. "Whether status makes the place a bit more special and allows them to attract investment is debatable," he says.

Prices in Brighton and Hove have already soared - last year it was the town with the fastest growth anywhere outside London, increasing by 36%. Brighton is running one of the most robust campaigns in the race and the bookies have made it the out and out favourite. From a corner of Kemptown, a trendy area of Brighton known for its new media and arts businesses, David Flack, manager of Bonetts estate agents, has watched demand soar. London buyers, he says, can't keep out of his shop. With regular trains into Victoria or the City and a 50-minute journey time, Brighton has become almost a suburb of London, he adds. A season ticket costs £2,640 and there are five trains an hour in the morning.

Brighton resident Brian Williams doesn't believe city status would make a difference to the residents. "Brighton is a lively bustling place and feels like a city already, with the difference that getting around is much easier than in London. For example, during the millennium celebrations we didn't need to get trains or buses. We all strolled down to the beach to watch," he says.

Mr Williams, who travels into London every day, says the commuting is bearable. "It's the only place you can easily commute from on the south coast. I wouldn't want to come up from Littlehampton or Hastings."

And house prices, although rising steadily, are still cheaper than London. Bonetts is offering a two-bedroom terrace 15 minutes from the station for £129,950. Families attracted by the sea air and easygoing atmosphere can pick up four-bed family homes from £190,000 upwards, although anything with a sea view commands a higher price.

The third favourite, Milton Keynes, was conceived as a city 30 years ago and has called itself a city ever since, says council marketing man Peter Heaton. "We don't have a problem attracting international companies or people to live here but city status would help," he says. It has roughly the same number of trains running to London as Brighton does and has grown considerably on the back of its proximity to the capital. But the city is keen to point out that it has attracted businesses and investment in its own right.

Milton Keynes now has a theatre and two multi-screen cinema complexes. Residents are looking forward to the opening of a real snow indoor ski slope. Estate agents say the market is thriving. There are three-bedroom semis available for £80,000 and large new-build homes with a double garage for £300,000. There are also many shared ownership properties for those on lower incomes.

There are plans too for extra homes on a large scale. Already areas on the fringes of the town have been earmarked by planners to take up to 8,700 new homes between now and the year 2011.

The new building is having an impact on the housing market, says Annie Ho who moved to Milton Keynes 20 years ago and has seen it change beyond recognition. "The problem for people like me who want to trade up is that buyers are going for new houses where they get services like landscaping thrown in and they are less interested in buying older houses like mine."

There are many advantages to living in Milton Keynes, but it is a car-driven city, says Ms Ho. "If you have children at different schools you need two cars to get them there."

Sunderland tried and failed four times to become a city before its successful bid in 1991. The local council says this had a substantial impact and "raised the aspirations of Sunderland and its citizens".

Since then the city has said goodbye to coal and shipyards and hello to foreign investment and Nissan. The city is now the nation's fastest growing automotive centre. Call centres too have opened up and citizens are looking forward to a new metro train.

Sunderland's renaissance is not entirely due to its city status, says the council, but the result of the "vision and drive of key individuals... who have used the achievement of city status as a catalyst to move Sunderland forward".

The sceptics say city status is little more than a boost for local dignitaries but the competing councils, convinced of the advantages it will bring, are pulling out all the stops to become the first city of the new millennium.

Links: www.mkweb.co.uk, www.brighton.co.uk

webTitle: Go for security in era of change

fields.headline: Go for security in era of change
fields.standfirst: Robin Stoddart looks at the wider impact of this week's rise in base rates not just on mortgages and savings but on the bonds and gilts markets
fields.trailText: This week's 0.25% rise in the base rate to 5.75% doesn't just affect mortgages and savings. Rising interest rates create havoc in the bond markets, which soon trickles down to the new generation of investors who have bought corporate bond Peps and Isas.
fields.body:
This week's 0.25% rise in the base rate to 5.75% doesn't just affect mortgages and savings. Rising interest rates create havoc in the bond markets, which soon trickles down to the new generation of investors who have bought corporate bond Peps and Isas.

The first market impact of higher rates is on fixed-interest issues. Where an interest yield of 5% looked quite generous against an inflation rate of only around 1% a few months ago, better rates on building society and bank deposits are now inexorably pushing up required returns, at least in line with the bank base rate. It sounds good news - but a rise in yields translates into an automatic fall in the capital value of a gilt, so the existing investor loses out.

Safe as they are thanks to the government guarantee of repayment at due date, gilts are now spurned as long-term investments.

Whereas shares have generally proved hugely rewarding, gilts have generally been disastrous at times of high inflation, although they may be a good speculation when, as now, yields are a good deal higher than the likely future inflation rate.

For example, anyone who sold the Treasury 13.75% 2000-2003 issue near its peak of £113 for every £100 nominal of stock last spring (at the end of a run of interest rate falls) very probably took a good profit on top of the income received from what is the highest interest issue remaining from the runaway inflation era of the 70s.

Now the price has fallen back just below £104. At this level it is a low-risk buy again, providing an income of just over 6% a year allowing for the loss of capital on the final redemption rate just over three years hence.

If the official interest rate kept on rising to 7% or more this would not be so attractive. That still seems unlikely, except perhaps in the strongest economy, the US. Anyway, capital gains, which, unlike the income on gilts, are not subject to tax for UK residents, are the prime attraction for larger private investors.

Consequently, issues with longer to redemption, such as the 5.75% 2009 Treasury issue now back down near the low point of last year at a fraction above the par £100 redemption price are sounder bets. The price was as high as £115 nine months ago, reflecting a wildly optimistic view about the likely trend of inflation and interest rates, though it seemed reasonable at the time. Real interest rates of 4% are very much better than what was available for much of the last century.

Safe yields of 6.5 % are now available on short-dated gilts, dipping to around 5.7% on issues with just over 10 years to run. Long-dated and undated issues appear ridiculously over-priced merely because they are now scarce, while high coupon issues are relatively less favoured because of the loss on redemption.

Seekers of really high yields last year went for fixed-interest and corporate bond issues, often through unit trust offerings. They have had a fairly torrid time over the last nine months as perceptions of the safety of corporate loans, particularly in the US, dimmed.

Losses of around 10% on holdings bought when interest rates were falling are not uncommon. Present conditions are not particularly encouraging even if corporate failures and default on debt are limited by rising prosperity.

Because of the especially high yield that they provide, high yield corporate bond issues became particularly sought after by personal equity plan subscribers. Yields of 8% or more brought strong demand from quite small savers. Advertisements noted that such bonds could entail high risk. But a spread of "junk" bonds could still be quite rewarding, as duds could be offset by a re-rating of winners.

M&G's High Yield Corporate Bond Fund was launched at a low point of the market in September 1998, but along with the others it has been hard put to hold its own over the last nine months. Withdrawal charges might leave a worrying loss, though they reduce over the years. Aberdeen Fixed Interest, an older and still larger fund, applies an initial charge of 4.5% and the normal annual levy. It has the highest running yield of over 8%.

But the capital value has declined steadily over recent months. Convertibles are favoured, but this form of capital is not very common among growth companies.

Many of the corporate loans unit trust managers invested in were mobile communications operators, whose multi-billion expenditure on infrastructure and marketing required high market penetration. So it has proved as the popularity of mobile phones and their use, particularly among the young, exceeds most expectations.

On top of that the takeover of Orange, a leading borrower, and the bid for its German acquirer, Mannesmann, by the UK pioneer and international giant Vodafone, puts the Orange debt up in about the safest category in the private sector.

But while interest rates are rising, cash deposits and some government-guaranteed savings offer complete security and a reasonable income.

fields.headline: Moves by managers worry investors
fields.standfirst: The star names behind top investment funds are falling by the wayside. Patrick Sherwen looks at the consequences
fields.trailText: The manager of one of the UK's most popular investment funds, the £1.5bn Jupiter Income, shocked investors and City-watchers by announcing this week that he is to step aside from the day-to-day management because of exhaustion.
fields.body:
The manager of one of the UK's most popular investment funds, the £1.5bn Jupiter Income, shocked investors and City-watchers by announcing this week that he is to step aside from the day-to-day management because of exhaustion.

Many financial advisers have encouraged small investors to buy the Jupiter Income fund largely because of the skills of William Littlewood. Now he's no longer managing the fund (for three months at least), what should investors do?

Not only Jupiter investors are worried. Last week Scott McGlashan, Perpetual's Japan guru and the well-regarded manager of its AA-rated £183m Far Eastern Growth unit trust and £23m Japanese investment trust, announced his resignation. And Hugh Everitt, manager of the £1.4bn CGU's AA-rated PPT Monthly Income Plus fund resigned this week.

Andrew Callender, another well respected fund manager who was in charge of Invesco Asset Management's Japan funds - the AA-rated £124.9m Invesco GT Japan Growth and the the £210.3 million GT Japan investment trust - is to give up his fund management duties and return to the UK from Tokyo in the next six months. Potentially, this leaves more than 670,000 investors to decide whether a change of manager on their fund is sufficient reason to reinvest elsewhere.

The answer depends on two factors: the management style of the company and the replacement manager. Since Peter Young embarrassed Morgan Grenfell with the scandal over his management of the apparently successful European Growth in 1996, management companies have been wary of the star fund manager concept.

A few companies still allow particular managers some leeway - Jupiter is one example - but most operate a team-structured strategy. In such companies the loss of a manager may not make much difference.

At Jupiter Mr Littlewood's day-to-day duties will be taken over by Prakesh Rajasekaran, his assistant on the fund since 1996. He also manages several specialist pension funds including a private unit trust called the Whitehall Growth unit trust.

Mark Dampier, head of research at Hargreaves Lansdown, says: "It should be remembered that the Jupiter Income trust is a flagship fund for the Jupiter group and we therefore feel that Prakash must be viewed extremely highly within the group to be allowed the day-to-day responsibilities of running what for Jupiter is their most important fund."

Will Mr Dampier continue recommending the fund? Until he has a chance to meet the new manager face to face, he will reserve judgment about what to do with clients' money. "As with most changes, be they temporary or permanent, we do like to take time to evaluate the situation before rushing to make any decisions. Our own view at the present is that investors should not panic out."

Jason Hollands, at independent financial advisers Best Investment, says: "Our view is to hold on to existing units but not to place new monies into the fund until Mr Littlewood's sabbatical period comes to an end.

"We did meet Mr Littlewood in December and he did indeed look 'exhausted'. The pressures of running such a large trust in a market which places so much emphasis on short-term performance are huge and the last quarter was William Littlewood's worst ever."

In the 10 years to January 10 the Jupiter Income has grown by 389% compared with only 191% for the UK equity income sector average. But in the last six months Mr Littlewood has slipped, with the fund dropping by 8.4% against an average fall in the sector of only 3.8%.

"The real question is whether or not the three month sabbatical ends up in a fundamental rethink on his career. He is rumoured to have exercised anything up to £20m in his share options which matured in December. Clearly the guy may decide he wants - and can afford to - do something different," says Mr Hollands.

Little is known about Akira Hiramine, Mr Callender's replacement who joins Invesco from Daiichi Life in Tokyo. But as a new arrival to the company he may lack the familiarity with its style and funds that might reassure investors whose money is now in the hands of Mr Rajasekaran at Jupiter.

Mr McGlashan's replacement, Paul Chesson, has a similar advantage as an existing member of the Japanese team. He has been at Perpetual for seven years.

Mr Everitt's replacement at CGU is Mark Gull, who has been there for about a year. Before this he managed the Gartmore Corporate Bond fund.

Jason Hollands, at independent financial advisers Best Investment, says: "Our view is to hold on to existing units but not to place new monies into the fund until Mr Littlewood's sabbatical period comes to an end. "We did meet Mr Littlewood in December and he did indeed look 'exhausted'. The pressures of running such a large trust in a market which places so much emphasis on short-term performance are huge and the last quarter was William Littlewood's worst ever." In the 10 years to January 10 the Jupiter Income has grown by 389% compared with only 191% for the UK equity income sector average. But in the last six months Mr Littlewood has slipped, with the fund dropping by 8.4% against an average fall in the sector of only 3.8%. "The real question is whether or not the three month sabbatical ends up in a fundamental rethink on his career. He is rumoured to have exercised anything up to £20m in his share options which matured in December. Clearly the guy may decide he wants - and can afford to - do something different," says Mr Hollands. Little is known about Akira Hiramine, Mr Callender's replacement who joins Invesco from Daiichi Life in Tokyo. But as a new arrival to the company he may lack the familiarity with its style and funds that might reassure investors whose money is now in the hands of Mr Rajasekaran at Jupiter. Mr McGlashan's replacement, Paul Chesson, has a similar advantage as an existing member of the Japanese team. He has been at Perpetual for seven years. Mr Everitt's replacement at CGU is Mark Gull, who has been there for about a year. Before this he managed the Gartmore Corporate Bond fund.

fields.standfirst: Guardian Weekend, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER. Email: weekend@guardian.co.uk. Fax: 020-7239 9935. Letters should reach us by Tuesday afternoon for inclusion on Saturday, and may be edited.
fields.trailText:
Where I work, in a telephone call centre, the team exists purely as a means of coercion (Us, January 8). My every movement is monitored and printed up for all to see, and if I take an unauthorised trip to the toilet or stretch a 10-minute break to 12, my colleagues are encouraged to shame me into compliance. Hardly a spirit of togetherness, and more a product of the 80s, I'd say, than a reaction against it.
Name and address supplied

Hardly a spirit of togetherness, and more a product of the 80s, I'd say, than a reaction against it.
Name and address supplied

It was wrong of Jonathan Freedland to suggest that the Countryside Alliance exemplified the 'right' to become caught up in the 'new communalism'. It has been the very democratisation of country sports over the past 30 years that has enabled CA to bring tens of thousands of people on to the streets for pro-hunting demonstrations. It has been politicians, on both the right and the left, who have played political football with country sports, not an inherent tendency of those who hunt, shoot and fish to be right-wing in their world view.
David Stocker
Lancaster

What prompted you to have an article of such length on the 'us' society and fail to mention the role played by the retail co-operative societies in keeping alive the flame of mutualism? Perhaps the fact that the societies have their base in northern protestant non-conformism is why they have become almost unmentionable in the 'London Guardian'.
Eric Youd
Royton, Oldham

Regarding 100 Ways To Make The World A Better Place: No 61, Write letters of complaint. Surely under No 72 (Even say hello to a policeman ), police officers of the 'other' gender are at least equally eligible for a greeting?
Carl Mason
Liverpool

There is an error in your worthy 100 ways list. No 13: while tea is a valuable addition to garden compost, teabags do not rot.
Mrs M Thorne
Sevenoaks, Kent

Share Options (Home, January 8) certainly promoted the concept of 'us' if, by 'us', you mean the middle-class media types pouring into Shoreditch. You ignore the problems confronting 'them' - that is, the area's working-class residents. After all, we live here, too. Or isn't our lifestyle of any interest to you?
Terry Jeffery
Hackney

I do wish that you had included a photograph of the 'derelict residents' as well as their gardens (caption, p31, Our Mutual Friend, January 8).
Jeanne Swift
Brentwood, Essex

In your edition dedicated to Us, Julie Burchill made 15 statements containing the I word, finishing with 'I hope to get more out of the next [century]'.
Martin King
Hull

Ludovic Tolhurst-Cleaver (Letters, January 8) espouses the causes of Ancient Greece and Rome as the birthplace of democracy with the phrase, 'every citizen was a member of the legislature'. Slaves, who made up the vast majority of the population, were not citizens.
Brian Robinson
Brentwood, Essex

Christianity = soft target (A Suitable Boy, December 18).
Margaret Worrall
Plymouth, Devon
