fields.headline: Over-50s suspicious of internet
fields.trailText: One in four people over 50 is so wary of new technology that they would refuse to use the internet or telephone advice lines to access public services, research for the government has established.
fields.body:
One in four people over 50 is so wary of new technology that they would refuse to use the internet or telephone advice lines to access public services, research for the government has established.

The finding has prompted ministers to qualify their enthusiasm for "electronic government", accepting that older people's attitudes may take a long time to change - if at all.

Ian McCartney, cabinet office minister overseeing the drive to modernise government, said yesterday: "We must ensure that the use of new technology to improve our public services does not isolate older people, who may prefer to get their questions answered in person rather than over the phone or through the internet."

The call for caution on technology comes in response to survey data from the "people's panel", the government's sounding board of 5,000 people who are canvassed for views on public services.

Analysis of the responses of more than 2,000 panel members aged over 50 has revealed some marked differences from the views of the panel as a whole. In particular, only 34% of the older group said they were optimistic about the effects of new technology, compared with 52% of the entire panel and some 70% of those aged 16-24.

A quarter of those over 50 said they would not be prepared to use any form of new technology to get information or advice, buy products or deal with government in any way.

All parts of government, national and central, are under instruction to introduce electronic forms of administration. But ministers are conscious that older people represent an increasingly important section of the electorate: by 2031, 41% of the population will be over 50.

Moreover, older people are more likely to exercise their vote in elections and traditionally have been less likely to support Labour.

Officials believe that older people's resistance to new technology tends to reduce sharply once they have experience of it, however. Four in 10 panel members over 50 said they had no experience of computer or phone services in the previous 12 months.

The panel survey, conducted by Mori, also indicated that older people may be growing less tolerant of sub-standard public services.

Although it is commonly supposed that people who came through the second world war and post-war rationing continue to be grateful for public services, whatever their quality, only 25% of over-50s surveyed agreed such services were efficient, 29% hard working and 36% friendly.

These findings differed hardly at all from those of the panel as a whole. But over-50s did still respond more favourably on most public services when asked about satisfaction with them.

The survey results will be used to shape policy decisions affecting older people in the next three-year spending round, now under discussion.

 The North Wales village with the longest name in Britain has set a new world record with the lengthiest address in cyberspace. Internet sites normally have a maximum of 28 letters but the rules have been bent for the Anglesey village of Llanfairpwllgwyngyllgogerychwyrndrobwll Llantysiliogogogoch - known locally as Llanfair PG .

Visitors to the site can even log on to a sound file to brush up on their pronunciation of the 58-letter name - which when translated means "St Mary's church in the hollow of the white hazel near a rapid whirlpool and the Church of St Tysilio of the red cave".

According to the website, until the 19th century the village was known as Llanfair Pwllgwyngyll - St Mary's church near the pool by the white hazels. To encourage train travellers to stop, a cobbler came up with the marketing ploy of lengthening the name.

But local author John Williams credits a tailor with coining the tongue-twisting name to confuse the English.

The website is at: http://llanfairpwllgwyngyllgogerychwyrndrobwllllantysiliogogogoch.co.uk/

fields.headline: Training saved crash Briton's life
fields.standfirst: Survivor tells of escape from Libyan plane crash that killed at least 17
fields.trailText: A Briton rescued from a plane crash off the Libyan coast in which 17 people died told yesterday how survival training had saved his life.
fields.byline: Julia Hartley-Brewer and  Peter Capella in Geneva
fields.body:
A Briton rescued from a plane crash off the Libyan coast in which 17 people died told yesterday how survival training had saved his life.

David Wilkinson, 47, an oil refinery worker, was among seven Britons who survived when the Swiss-owned Shorts SD-360 jet carrying 41 passengers and crew ditched into the Mediterranean. The plane was five miles from its destination, an oil refinery in Marsa Al-Brega in northern Libya.

The foreign office last night named the dead Britons as Patrick Cox from Co Durham, Thomas McNeilly from Coatbridge, near Glasgow, Ronald Jarred from Middlesbrough, John Morton from Birkenhead and Roy Parfitt from Cheshire.

Hope was fading last night that five men still missing - one Briton, three Libyans and a Filipino - would be found alive after rescuers were hampered by bad weather.

The British ambassador to Libya, Richard Dalton, said: "It is looking very unlikely that any more survivors will be found now."

He said one of the British survivors suffered a broken leg but the others received only minor injuries, adding: "Of course they are also all very shocked by what has happened. It is a very close-knit community and many people have worked here for a long time. It has hit them very hard."

The bodies of the five Britons known to have died were flown to Tripoli yesterday, Mr Dalton said, and arrangements were being made to return them to families in the UK as soon as possible.

The 19 survivors - seven Britons, 10 Libyans and two Indians - were plucked from the Mediterranean by local fishing boats.

Mr Wilkinson, one of 13 British oil workers on board, escaped from the wreckage only after using survival skills he learnt during his preparation to become an oil rig worker. He used both feet to kick in the reinforced window of the aircraft next to his seat and swam to safety.

The twin-propeller aircraft is believed to have vanished from radar screens two hours after taking off from Tripoli. Five minutes before the crash, the pilot radioed air traffic control to say he was attempting an emergency landing on water after both engines had failed.

British air crash investigators were due to arrive in Libya today to join a team of Swiss and Libyan experts.

Both pilots survived, and salvage workers were last night preparing to recover the wreckage of the plane, which Swiss officials said was resting at a depth of 2000ft.

Investigations are likely to centre on whether fuel problems caused the engines to fail. The Shorts plane - which has an excellent safety record - was leased from the Swiss company Avisto AG and was 10 years old.

The escape of Mr Wilkinsonfrom Hartlepool, was described as a miracle by his brother Alan.

Mr Wilkinson was returning from a Christmas break with his family on Teesside. In a phone call to his brother, he said: "Everything seemed to happen so fast. The plane went down and I knew I had to get out and the only way was by smashing the window and swimming for my life."

Alan Wilkinson, 45, said: "My brother is deeply upset about losing some of his workmates but he's relieved that he is safe and well. He went on a survival course about 10 years ago which you have to have before you can work on oil rigs. He was shown how to react when a helicopter ditches in the water and he's certain that training saved his life because he knew exactly what to do.

"This has been a terrible or deal for him and we just want him back with his family and friends."

Another survivor, Stewart Bonar, a 59-year-old oil worker from Limavady, Co Londonderry, called his wife to say he was being treated in hospital for broken bones.

Mrs Bonar said: "I asked him how did he get out of the plane, but he just said he really didn't want to talk about it, he just said, 'I'm alive.' "

A third survivor was last night named as James McKay.

Another survivor, Stewart Bonar, a 59-year-old oil worker from Limavady, Co Londonderry, called his wife to say he was being treated in hospital for broken bones. Mrs Bonar said: "I asked him how did he get out of the plane, but he just said he really didn't want to talk about it, he just said, 'I'm alive.' " A third survivor was last night named as James McKay.

webTitle: Spin doctors operate on Lord Winston

fields.headline: Spin doctors operate on Lord Winston
fields.standfirst:
The NHS debate explained
More about the NHS
fields.trailText: Downing Street yesterday launched a carefully orchestrated operation to discredit the fertility pioneer Lord Winston after he unleashed a devastating attack on the government's handling of the NHS.
fields.body:
Downing Street yesterday launched a carefully orchestrated operation to discredit the fertility pioneer Lord Winston after he unleashed a devastating attack on the government's handling of the NHS.

Amid fury at the disloyalty of the Labour peer, the prime minister's official spokesman held talks with Lord Winston early yesterday.

Alastair Campbell sprung into action after the Labour peer accused the government, in a New Statesman interview, of failing to live up to its promises on the NHS and of being "quite deceitful" about its desperate state.

In a passage that was said to have upset Cherie Blair, Lord Winston disclosed that the prime minister's wife would undergo a caesarean section at a London hospital.

As damaging headlines hit the news-stands, Mr Campbell arranged with Lord Winston to issue a statement categorically denying that he had ever discussed Mrs Blair's birth plans.

Within an hour of Lord Winston's statement, the New Statesman allowed the BBC to play a tape of his remarks about Mrs Blair on Radio 4's The World at One. The tape was inaudible - Lord Winston was said to have covered the magazine's tape recorder during his interview - but the BBC confirmed that his remarks were on the tape.

Armed with evidence that Lord Winston had appeared to break medical convention by discussing the personal details of a patient, ministers then embarked on a media offensive against him.

His claims that the NHS had deteriorated since the election, and that ministers were deceiving the public about the state of hospitals, were described as "fanciful".

Lord Winston, a political novice who failed to realise the impact his remarks would have, also issued a less than convincing statement claiming he had not meant to attack the government.

"I believe that the basic direction of NHS policy is right under this government," he said.

The Conservatives were scathing about the Downing Street operations against Lord Winston.

Liam Fox, the shadow health secretary, said: "The Alastair Campbell press machine seems to be more capable of getting heretics to recant than the Inquisition."

The Intensive Care Society, which represents 1,500 doctors and nurses, accused the health secretary, Alan Milburn, of misleading the public when he said that more intensive care beds had been provided.

The society yesterday said that it had been "unable to identify accurately the additional 100 intensive care beds that are stated to have opened".

webTitle: Dobson adds to the agony as row escalates

fields.headline: Dobson adds to the agony as row escalates
fields.standfirst:
The London mayor: special report
Sky Sports - Boxing
fields.trailText: The home secretary, Jack Straw, was last night under fire not only from the Tories but also from his former cabinet colleague, Frank Dobson, for allowing Mike Tyson into Britain despite the boxer's conviction for rape.
fields.body:
The home secretary, Jack Straw, was last night under fire not only from the Tories but also from his former cabinet colleague, Frank Dobson, for allowing Mike Tyson into Britain despite the boxer's conviction for rape.

After one of his worst weeks in office, Mr Straw ordered a review of immigration rules to clear up inconsistencies over whether to allow people with convictions into the UK.

The shadow home secretary, Ann Widdecombe, said the U-turn was just part of a "howler" of a week for "hopeless" Mr Straw. Mr Dobson made it plain that he strongly disagreed with the decision. "I am sorry to say that it seems my good friend Jack Straw got it wrong, and I think Mike Tyson should have been kept out of the country," he told BBC Radio 4's Any Questions. "It must have been a great dilemma but it is the case that other famous felons have been kept out of the country."

The former health secretary's intervention - as he seeks to underline his independence from the Labour hierarchy in the London mayoral race - came at a bad time for Mr Straw.

Miss Widdecombe said: "On Monday he accused the English of being thugs. Then he concluded Pinochet was unfit to stand trial but announced he was only 'minded' to release him. Finally he dithered over whether to let Mike Tyson fight in Britain, first saying one thing and then doing another. He hid behind immigration officials for the first half of the week and then intervened when it looked like their decision wouldn't suit him."

The government was also facing questions about whether the U-turn was connected to Tony Blair's links with media tycoon Rupert Murdoch, whose BSkyB holds TV rights to the fight on January 29 in Manchester.

Liberal Democrat broadcasting spokesman Norman Baker said: "There are serious concerns that Tony Blair is in Rupert Murdoch's pocket." The prime minister's official spokesman said he was not aware of BSkyB having made any direct representations to the government about the issue.

fields.headline: Treasure discovered in Irish cave
fields.trailText: A tourist guide picking up litter has found coins and silver jewellery dating back more than 1,000 years in a cave which was the site of a Viking massacre.
fields.body:
A tourist guide picking up litter has found coins and silver jewellery dating back more than 1,000 years in a cave which was the site of a Viking massacre.

The find was made at Dunmore Cave, in Co Kilkenny in the Irish republic, by the guide at the end of the last tourist season.

As many as 1,000 people, mostly women and children, were slaughtered in the incident in the year 928. Bones have been found over the years.

Officials of the Irish government's heritage service yesterday described the find as "very exciting and of major significance".

It included unique silver wire Viking-age items.

Experts believe they may have formed the personal wealth of an individual.

The cave has been sealed off, and the artefacts have been transferred to the National Museum in Dublin for further examination, cleaning and restoration.

They are expected to go on show to the public later this year.

fields.headline: Bank worker's £500,000 sting
fields.trailText: A merchant bank worker, who swindled her employers out of £550,000 because of the harassment she claimed she received at work, was jailed for 18 months yesterday.
fields.body:
A merchant bank worker, who swindled her employers out of £550,000 because of the harassment she claimed she received at work, was jailed for 18 months yesterday.

Julia Cotton, 36, who earned £30,000 a year with City bankers Robert Fleming had now lost everything, the Old Bailey heard.

She had twice tried to commit suicide since her crimes were uncovered, said her lawyer, Carl Hargan. "She was put under great stress at work. She was the only non-graduate in her department of 30. She was also the only woman bar secretaries.

"She was the butt of jokes and harassment from male colleagues. She had to work long hours, sometimes seven days a week. Her crimes were an attempt by her to get back at her employers."

Cotton, of Kingston, Surrey, pleaded guilty to five charges of deception and one of attempted deception.

The court heard that she was transferred in 1996 from the euro bonds settlement department to the capital markets department, where she was assistant to the financial director. She opened a bank account under the name of MC International, for which she was sole signatory.

She began writing cheques to herself in October 1997. The first sum was for £14,950. This rose to a £250,000 cheque in September 1998.

"She told police that the financial director would just sign anything that she put in front of him," said Janet Boston, prosecuting. In all she paid in six cheques to her account totalling £542,295.

Cotton was trapped by her employer's bankers when they queried a £100,000 payment to her bogus account.

She realised that an investigation would be launched and confessed to her boss that she had stolen the money. But she did not initially admit stealing the five other sums.

The court heard that she spent the money on first class air tickets and a trip to Australia to attend her father-in-law's funeral.

Mr Hargan said: "She has now repaid every penny including Robert Fleming's legal expenses and 8% interest.

"She has lost everything. She has twice tried to take her own life and has a history of depression."

webTitle: Detectives reconstruct student's death in France

fields.headline: Detectives reconstruct student's death in France
fields.trailText: Two Staffordshire detectives have flown to France to help French police investigating the murder of the Birmingham university student Isabel Peake to reconstruct the moments leading up to her death.
fields.body:
Two Staffordshire detectives have flown to France to help French police investigating the murder of the Birmingham university student Isabel Peake to reconstruct the moments leading up to her death.

The reconstruction, planned for today, comes four days after the arrest in Lisbon of the suspected serial killer who is alleged to have thrown Ms Peake to her death from the Brive-Paris overnight express last October 13.

Sid Ahmed Rezala, 20, an Algerian-born Frenchman, is also wanted in connection with the murders of Corinne Caillaux and Emilie Bazin.

A Portuguese judge has ordered him to be held in jail pending the arrival of a formal extradition request and detailed case dossier from France.

Police Detective Sergeant Peter Sharratt-Freeman and Detective Constable Diane Mahon said they had been invited to observe the reconstruction to "help their understanding of the case". Isabel, who had just started an exchange programme at Limoges university, came from Barlaston, Staffs.

webTitle: Boost for Dobson as union vote ban is upheld

fields.headline: Boost for Dobson as union vote ban is upheld
fields.standfirst: The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: Frank Dobson's London mayoral campaign received a boost yesterday when the high court upheld a Labour party ban on letting a pro-Ken Livingstone trade union vote in the selection process.
fields.body:
Frank Dobson's London mayoral campaign received a boost yesterday when the high court upheld a Labour party ban on letting a pro-Ken Livingstone trade union vote in the selection process.

In a ruling hailed by Labour, a judge declared that the party's ruling body had the right to decide how to run internal elections.

Six members of the Manufacturing Science and Finance union had tried to overturn the party's decision to ban their union from voting in the selection of the Labour candidate for mayor. The party's ruling national executive committee had imposed the ban after the union's London executive failed to pay its party subscriptions on time.

Mr Justice Jonathan Parker described the trade unionists' claim as "misconceived". In any event, he added, they had no legal standing to bring the case as individual members of the union.

Mr Livingstone needs to secure a convincing majority in the trade union section of Labour's electoral college if he is to defeat Mr Dobson.

There had been speculation that a majority of MSF's 15,000 London region members would have backed Mr Livingstone, along with substantial numbers from two other disenfranchised unions - the Rail Maritime and Transport, with 7,000 London members, and the train drivers' union Aslef, with 3,000.

The Labour leadership, which is alarmed by the strength of Mr Livingstone's challenge, welcomed the result.

Jim Fitzpatrick, chairman of the London Labour party, said: "This is a decisive ruling and the judge has determined that Labour's rules for the electoral college are fair and proper. It is now time to draw a line under procedural wrangling and focus on the policies which will make a real difference for Londoners."

Roger Lyons, general secretary of MSF, said he was pleased that the episode had been brought to an end. "The responsibility for MSF's 15,000 members in London being excluded from the ballot lies solely with the MSF London executive," he said. "Their failure to pay the Labour party subscription in time for three years running disenfranchised our members."

Mr Dobson, who was beaten last week by Mr Livingstone by a margin of 12 to one in the Transport and General Workers' Union's ballot, used the high court ruling to criticise his rival. "It's now time for Ken Livingstone to start coming clean on his policies, his tax plans and his attitude towards the Labour party," he said. "The debate has to be about what the mayor will do in office, now that this stunt has backfired so badly for him."

The six MSF members were ordered to pay the Labour party's £7,000 costs in addition to their own costs of £13,000. They are Hugh MacGrillen; Jim Mortimer, a former general secretary of the Labour party; his wife Pat Mortimer; Sue Mitchie; Glen Sutherland; and Ian Rez.

fields.body:
In his first public reaction after his stay of execution, the Kurdish rebel leader, Abdullah Ocalan, said yesterday that he was determined to work for peace.

In a written statement from his Turkish prison cell, he said the govern ment's decision was a step towards democracy.

He pledged that his Kurdistan Workers' party (PKK) would not exploit the move, and said he now believed that the PKK's war for a Kurdish state was a "historic mistake".

fields.headline: White' s week
fields.standfirst: Jim White explores the wider, weirder world of sport:  Time to swallow our pride and admit the awesome greatness of Diego
fields.trailText: During the rush of retrospective programmes that furred up the millennium television schedules, my seven-year-old son caught sight of an apparition. He had been watching a programme about the sporting century and came hurtling upstairs to tell me he had seen the greatest, no question about it.
fields.body:
During the rush of retrospective programmes that furred up the millennium television schedules, my seven-year-old son caught sight of an apparition. He had been watching a programme about the sporting century and came hurtling upstairs to tell me he had seen the greatest, no question about it.

"This bloke, right," he said, "ran the whole length of the pitch, past everyone, no one could stop him, then he scored. It was brilliant. It was the best goal I've ever seen."

"Who was it?" I asked.

"I think he was called Madonna," he said. "How come I've never heard of him before?"

Good point. As he lies in his hospital bed, pushed to the brink of self-destruction by habits almost as prodigious as his talent, perhaps it is time for the rest of us in this country to put into perspective at last the genius that was Diego Maradona. Only in England do we churlishly belittle the man, only in England (and the United States, but then what do you expect?) was his name absent from lists compiled to celebrate the century's greatest sportsmen, only in England is his awful decline depicted as some sort of divine retribution for having the audacity once to cheat against us. And all because of a sly piece of gamesmanship involving the hand of God.

"You've got to say that was brilliant," sighed Barry Davies on the television commentary after Maradona had left Peter Reid, Terry Butcher, Terry Fenwick and Peter Shilton bewildered in his wash that day in 1986, proving he was even more adept with his feet than his hands. And the grudging tone has been evident ever since. When Eric Cantona came to England, his answer to the inevitable question about his greatest footballing hero was always Maradona. Cantona said he was surprised that, whenever he said this, his questioner would raise an eyebrow and look askance as if the choice indicated an awful moral deficiency on his part.

In Argentina the population is certainly aware of what Maradona means. Outside the hospital in Buenos Aires in which he is being treated for cocaine-induced heart problems, a large crowd stands vigil. This week one bystander asked English reporters to imagine what the reaction in Britain would be if it was Paul Gascoigne in hospital.

Well, not quite. However popular Gazza may once have been, he has never single-handedly taken his country to a World Cup victory, or driven an unfashionable club side to the Italian championship, or roused his battered, shattered limbs to steer his nation to another World Cup final.

In England we are happy to deify a teenager who scored a good goal in a defeat in the last-16 stage of the World Cup. Imagine how we would have reacted to a man who brought us what Maradona brought Argentina, the international prestige, the excuse to puff out its collective chest on the global stage, the sheer pleasure of ultimate victory.

As everyone else in the world seemed to recognise, Maradona, to achieve what he did, was simply astonishing. Not only did he have more skill in his left foot than the entire Premiership added together, he had guile, balance, strength, courage and the ability to deliver on the big stage. As a child he was rescued from drowning in an open sewer in the barrio where he grew up. He played as if he knew he was on borrowed time, determined to make his mark.

His tragedy was that after making a mark none had matched before, Maradona had nothing to offer. As Jorge Valdano, the former World Cup winner turned writer, puts it: "Nobody who has lived the exciting adventure of being Maradona can return to being a normal person."

A few years ago Maradona came to address the Oxford Union. He gave an awful speech: rambling, incoherent, pointless. As he was walking out of a hugely disappointed chamber, someone threw a golf ball at him from the balcony. His entourage ducked, but he trapped the tiny missile on the instep of his absurd high-heeled court shoe, then played keepy-uppy for what seemed like five minutes before volleying it back exactly whence it came. The hall erupted. But that was Maradona: he could be someone only with a ball at his feet.

The medical reports from Buenos Aires this week suggest he is gravely ill. He has been warned that if he snorts any more of the cocaine which he has used constantly since retirement in an attempt to put a high back in his life, his damaged heart will pack it in. But it may already be too late. And the time for this country to recognise he was the greatest of the modern era is before he goes. Afterwards it is always easy.

It's a funny old game

Now that apparently we are not allowed to laugh at Ali G and his wonderful take on the would-be hip, it seems there is only one group of people left at whom we can safely titter: footballers. In the Independent this week, the novelist and Norwich City fan DJ Taylor suggests we can safely laugh at players only because they are so comically rich. He has a point: Darren Anderton's pay demands can only be viewed as the highest form of satire. But it can't last. It won't be long before some po-faced correspondent writes to the Guardian complaining that footballers are becoming a persecuted minority and cautioning against the growing scourge of Beckham-ism in comic material. Then suggesting that if we substituted the word Jew or Irishman for the words Chris and Sutton, that Chelsea match report just wouldn't be funny at all.

"I think he was called Madonna," he said. "How come I've never heard of him before?" Good point. As he lies in his hospital bed, pushed to the brink of self-destruction by habits almost as prodigious as his talent, perhaps it is time for the rest of us in this country to put into perspective at last the genius that was Diego Maradona. Only in England do we churlishly belittle the man, only in England (and the United States, but then what do you expect?) was his name absent from lists compiled to celebrate the century's greatest sportsmen, only in England is his awful decline depicted as some sort of divine retribution for having the audacity once to cheat against us. And all because of a sly piece of gamesmanship involving the hand of God. "You've got to say that was brilliant," sighed Barry Davies on the television commentary after Maradona had left Peter Reid, Terry Butcher, Terry Fenwick and Peter Shilton bewildered in his wash that day in 1986, proving he was even more adept with his feet than his hands. And the grudging tone has been evident ever since. When Eric Cantona came to England, his answer to the inevitable question about his greatest footballing hero was always Maradona. Cantona said he was surprised that, whenever he said this, his questioner would raise an eyebrow and look askance as if the choice indicated an awful moral deficiency on his part. In Argentina the population is certainly aware of what Maradona means. Outside the hospital in Buenos Aires in which he is being treated for cocaine-induced heart problems, a large crowd stands vigil. This week one bystander asked English reporters to imagine what the reaction in Britain would be if it was Paul Gascoigne in hospital. Well, not quite. However popular Gazza may once have been, he has never single-handedly taken his country to a World Cup victory, or driven an unfashionable club side to the Italian championship, or roused his battered, shattered limbs to steer his nation to another World Cup final. In England we are happy to deify a teenager who scored a good goal in a defeat in the last-16 stage of the World Cup. Imagine how we would have reacted to a man who brought us what Maradona brought Argentina, the international prestige, the excuse to puff out its collective chest on the global stage, the sheer pleasure of ultimate victory. As everyone else in the world seemed to recognise, Maradona, to achieve what he did, was simply astonishing. Not only did he have more skill in his left foot than the entire Premiership added together, he had guile, balance, strength, courage and the ability to deliver on the big stage. As a child he was rescued from drowning in an open sewer in the barrio where he grew up. He played as if he knew he was on borrowed time, determined to make his mark. His tragedy was that after making a mark none had matched before, Maradona had nothing to offer. As Jorge Valdano, the former World Cup winner turned writer, puts it: "Nobody who has lived the exciting adventure of being Maradona can return to being a normal person." A few years ago Maradona came to address the Oxford Union. He gave an awful speech: rambling, incoherent, pointless. As he was walking out of a hugely disappointed chamber, someone threw a golf ball at him from the balcony. His entourage ducked, but he trapped the tiny missile on the instep of his absurd high-heeled court shoe, then played keepy-uppy for what seemed like five minutes before volleying it back exactly whence it came. The hall erupted. But that was Maradona: he could be someone only with a ball at his feet. The medical reports from Buenos Aires this week suggest he is gravely ill. He has been warned that if he snorts any more of the cocaine which he has used constantly since retirement in an attempt to put a high back in his life, his damaged heart will pack it in. It's a funny old game Now that apparently we are not allowed to laugh at Ali G and his wonderful take on the would-be hip, it seems there is only one group of people left at whom we can safely titter: footballers. In the Independent this week, the novelist and Norwich City fan DJ Taylor suggests we can safely laugh at players only because they are so comically rich. He has a point: Darren Anderton's pay demands can only be viewed as the highest form of satire. But it can't last. It won't be long before some po-faced correspondent writes to the Guardian complaining that footballers are becoming a persecuted minority and cautioning against the growing scourge of Beckham-ism in comic material. Then suggesting that if we substituted the word Jew or Irishman for the words Chris and Sutton, that Chelsea match report just wouldn't be funny at all.

webTitle: Beware the operators and their pocket calculators

fields.headline: Beware the operators and their pocket calculators
fields.standfirst: Lost in music
fields.trailText: It's far too early to hang a personality on the 90s, but one thing that already distinguishes the decade for me is the noxious, persistent noise that followed me around for much of its duration.
fields.body:
It's far too early to hang a personality on the 90s, but one thing that already distinguishes the decade for me is the noxious, persistent noise that followed me around for much of its duration. The distinguishing features of The Noise are its conveyor-belt beats, its vacantly repetitive lyrics (or, in many cases, lyric), its ability to effortlessly insinuate itself into any background yet contaminate your every action, and its tendency to make you feel like you're part of some grand, eternal Pac-Man game. The Noise is dangerous because it can envelop you like a cloud of acid mist - while you sip a pint in your local theme pub, or circumnavigate hovering shop assistants in The Gap, before you've even registered its hand sneaking towards your cerebral off-switch.

There are, of course, lots of different Noises, manufactured by lots of different major record companies, but let's not dignify them with fake individualism; this is all part of the same void - a mind-control musical metronome made with computers for people sitting in front of computers. It means nothing, says nothing and won't put you off by asking you to over-extend your powers of concentration when you're on that tricky third level of Junior Purse Snatcher with the Ninja grannies. The more Playstations sell, the more The Noise dominates the charts, the more any top 40 artist with even a vague semblance of humanity (Robbie Williams) begins to resemble an "alternative" for the passive music fan.

Growing up in the 80s you were a comic kid or a children's TV kid, then you were a music kid or a ZX Spectrum kid - barriers were clearly defined and respected. Abandoning computers and enlisting with the music gang was, at my school, a coming-of-age event offering brave new worlds of non-vicarious experiences including Having More Friends and Getting Laid. Pop and computers were arch enemies, and all the better for it.

The pop music of the 80s might have been computer-dependent, but those were the days when the musician was still in control, using technology as a portal, rather than a substitute, for their own imagination. In 2000, the chart, drained of all human life, seems like the product of a much more sinister, technological force: the transient, ersatz "icons" it chunders out are an increasingly redundant part of the process, and will soon surely be replaced by an army of singing Lara and Larry Crofts. We no longer need a stereo system to listen to a song, or a person with real emotions to sing it to us. How long before we don't need a brain or ears to interact with it? How long before we're all walking around with iMacs for heads, experiencing all the same things we could have done as humans in a state of semi-sensuality, all because, back in the early-21st century, we were seduced by the power of The Machine?

When a friend tells you about a download or an MP3, it's so much easier to nod and pretend you know what they're talking about than actually question what it can do to enhance your life. Similarly, because we don't understand how a lot of modern electro pop is made, we tend not to question why it's so crap. The direct and side effects of the internet, a supposed intelligence factory, are actually making music fans switch off every time they switch on. Intimidated by technology, we're currently doing our best to create an artform governed by computers. At the moment, they're just relatively submissive jumbles of plastic sitting in the corner of our studies, but one day they'll be holding court in the middle of our living rooms, ordering us about, forcing us to listen to the new Steps single, and we'll only have our own frailty of mind to blame.

fields.headline: Smallweed
fields.trailText: There has been such a spate over the past few weeks of sage Conservative heads shaking themselves till the dandruff falls over the wretched state of the party that some on the right have begun to suspect collusion.
fields.body:
Kenneth Clarke, Lord Howe, Lord Hurd, Edward Heath, Gillian Shephard, Norman Fowler - there has been such a spate over the past few weeks of sage Conservative heads shaking themselves till the dandruff falls over the wretched state of the party that some on the right have begun to suspect collusion. At first, they blamed the connection with Europe, their usual culprit for everything from the slump in the pig trade to their children's advanced impetigo, but Fowler and Shephard are not pro-Europeans, so that cannot stick. They are right, though, in deducing that orchestration is taking place.

The whole campaign, Smallweed can proudly disclose this morning, is being directed from a disused munitions factory in St Albans by a former acrobat, missionary and Tranmere Rovers centre back, Dr Ghareth Ghoul, who last October took up the post of secretary-general of the Department for the Education of Ageing Tory Has-Beens in Elementary Disruption (Deathbed). "Our movement is ghoing ghreat ghuns," Dr Ghoul enthuses, "and is well on course to revive this ghrand old party, or finish it off, one or the other."

The materiel for this offensive - speeches, pieces for Prospect and other salvos - is tailored to a strict pattern devised by the doctor.

1. Make it abundantly clear that though the party is in a terminal mess, this is not William's fault.

2. Instead, blame the people around him. (For an upmarket audience, like readers of Prospect, you may use the word "acolytes".) Who surrounded him with all these incompetent acolytes? He did, of course. But you don't need to say that.

3. Try to find at least four nouns or adjectives which portray the leader in a favourable light.

"Gillian was particularly ghood here" Dr Ghoul enthuses. "She talked of his courage, intelligence, persistence and consistency. I have a lot of these words inscribed on balls, which I churn about in a machine like the one in the national lottery and we see what comes out." So saying, he activated the monster, which after much agitation and flashing of lights produced balls inscribed with the words "novenary, eleemosynary, ptochocratic, Junoesque". "It seems to be in one of its intellectual phases this morning," the doctor ghrowled with a ghrimace, giving it a most ghruesome kick.

"Oh, and by the way," he added as Smallweed made ready to leave, "I have missed out point number 4 in Deathbed's agenda: when the party's ratings slump immediately after you've said your piece, express total amazement at this inexplicable turn of events."

"Yes, it is a drop in the ocean, but it is also the thin end of a very exciting wedge" - the Welsh agriculture minister, Christine Gwyther, on the resumption of beef sales to Holland, Today programme, Tuesday.

Jack Straw says he is minded to let Pinochet go home to Chile, just as he was earlier minded to let Mr Kalejs go to Australia. How I love this grand old word, which bangs to a gentle, courteous age now otherwise all but forgotten. There is no Stravian copyright in its use: another government minister, possibly young Mr Byers, was minded to do something or other just before Christmas.

I am minded to try to reintroduce it into our national life. "I am minded to go to Winsford," I shall tell my children and dog, "where the local team, recently buoyed by Smallweed's support, has taken to losing again." "Take care," they will no doubt reply; an expression invariably used by everyone under 40, and some a shade over, to meet any eventuality.

The European Central Bank is looking for a terminologist. The terminologist's duties, an advertisement says, will be to co-operate with a senior terminologist in terminology management, to carry out research into terminology and to compile terminology. To get the job you will need to have a university degree in terminology and two years experience in the field of terminology. Since I lack the qualifications I shall not apply. Indeed, I am sorry to say that until I read this advertisement I had no idea that terminology was something that offered degrees and that people made their careers in, let alone that it had a field. I seem to remember that Winston Churchill once described a lie told in his presence as "a terminological inexactitude", but that's about it.

A terrible sense of deprivation invaded Smallweed this week, which I am minded to compare to the feelings that might envelop a man who realises at the age of 87 that all the milk he has drunk in his life has been sour. My attention was drawn to a passage in J Mordaunt Crook's The Rise of the Nouveaux Riches. This reprints a note made by Lord Crawford after tea at the house of the painfully rich MP for Hythe, Sir Philip Sassoon in 1927. "Some wonderful grouse sandwiches arrived," he recorded. "The king refused them; he could not stop eating haddock sandwiches." Later there was chocolate cake, handed round in quarter-pound slices. How these people used to cosset themselves! One might even assume...

An inspector writes: In the aforegoing I think I detected the use of the banned term "pound". I have to point out that this term is now illegal. It is all the more unacceptable when, as in the case to which you have animadverted, a monarch is present. Kindly convert it into the appropriate number of grammes.

Smallweed protests as venomously as if he were Norman Tebbit: But this is preposterous. What is wrong with the good old world "pound"? Why, we even have an MP who uses it as his surname.

An inspector retorts: Not any more, chummy. The member for Ealing North has now been renamed Stephen 453.6- Grammes. But back to your haddock sandwiches.

Smallweed resumes: But of course. Yes, it suddenly struck me reading these words that in the course of a long and eleemosynary life, I had never once been offered, let alone been able to eat, a haddock sandwich. Do they sell them in Prêt-à-Manger? Are there cod sandwiches, rock salmon sandwiches, guppy sandwiches and minnow sandwiches too? I am minded to venture out later today and investigate.

fields.headline: Judgment of Paris
fields.standfirst: French theatre is on a roll, says  Michael Billington
fields.trailText: French theatre is on a roll, says Michael Billington
fields.body:
Who is the key influence on modern British theatre? Paradoxically, it is Peter Brook, who left these shores almost 30 years ago. A whole generation of directors - including Declan Donnellan, Simon McBurney, Deborah Warner, Katie Mitchell, Tim Supple and Mick Gordon - perpetuate the Brook principles: a belief in story-telling, in imaginative complicity between actor and audience, in the importance of found spaces. Even a great classical production, such as Michael Boyd's current RSC Midsummer Night's Dream, is a reaction to Brook's landmark version of 1970, despite the fact that hardly anyone involved is old enough to have seen it.

Brook, who will be 75 in March, continues his quest for the essence of theatre at the Bouffes du Nord in Paris. Recently he has been fascinated by the mysteries of the human mind: L'Homme Qui was an Oliver Sacks-inspired exploration of neurological disorder; Je Suis un Phénomène was about the curse of indiscriminate memory. But his latest production, Le Costume, is a poetic South African fable, staged in London in 1995 by Johannesburg's Market Theatre, about a husband's strange revenge on his unfaithful wife. What Brook brings to it is his own brand of evocative simplicity - a delight in the act of theatre as an alternative to the mundane realism of TV and cinema that, in various ways, ran through everything I saw in Paris.

Brook creates a definable world on stage, in this case that of 50s Sophiatown, a township in Johannesburg, where Can Themba's original story and Mothobi Mutloatse's adaptation are set. We see vividly coloured rush matting, a pair of suit racks serving as doors and windows, a double bed - the pivot of the action in which Philemon, a young husband, almost discovers his ex-showbiz wife, Matilda, in flagrante. The key trace of the disappearing lover is his grey suit, which Philemon turns into a domestic totem. The suit is fed at meal-times, taken for walks and turned into an honoured guest at a party - a form of silent revenge that eventually destroys Matilda in the manner of Heywood's A Woman Killed with Kindness.

Without minimising the story's cruelty, Brook deftly suggests the contradictory festivity of township life. Music dominates the action: at a party, Bakary Sangare's Philemon and two guests do the most elegant soft-shoe shuffle over and around the double bed; Marianne-Jean Baptiste's Matilda is haunted by memories of her showbiz past as she gaily sings My Little Yellow Basket. Even the suit is equivocal - both a reminder of Matilda's guilt and, as she puts her hand through the sleeve to caress her thighs and breast, a symbol of remembered sensual delight.

Nothing is overstated. Through the use of vivid primary colours, orange sunsets and exuberant drumming, Brook shows us that domestic tragedy erupts in a world of communal gaiety and that township life is a source of gregarious entrapment. He also reminds us that it takes a lifetime's work to achieve such simplicity.

At the opposite end of the scale, Paris is also a source of spectacle, and spectacles don't come much bigger than Robert Hossein's staging of De Gaulle - Celui Qui a Dit Non, which re-creates the general's intransigent wartime belief in a "Free France" before 3,000 spectators a night at the vast Palais de Congrès. We get film footage of the German occupation and of Marshal Pétain's Vichy regime. We get tableaux vivants of key moments of the war. We get running battles in the aisles. But beneath the pageantry we get a series of confrontations between Jacques Boudet's imperious De Gaulle and Robert Hardy's growling Churchill.

It would be easy to mock the show's kitsch grandeur. But the main story, written by Alain Decaux and Alain Peyrefitte, expresses a central truth, that there was a strange, grudging, symbiotic kinship between De Gaulle and Churchill. As historian Eric Hobsbawm once wrote, the former was a reactionary Catholic who had " une certaine idée de la France ", the latter an imperialist Conservative with a profound sense of England. Even the recent revelations that Churchill was overruled by his wartime Cabinet in seeking to ditch De Gaulle are acknowledged. At one point Churchill actually tells him that "the worst moment for France was the hour that you were born". But, spiritually the two men were blood brothers, and I don't think it is mere chauvinism that makes me feel that Hardy's wily, devious and heroically cussed Churchill is every bit as fascinating as Boudet's single-minded, unyielding De Gaulle. It may be spectacle on the scale of the Royal Tournament, but there is something oddly moving about seeing the French turning their wartime history into popular theatre.

Paris, in fact, seems to delight in the theatricality of theatre, and you could hardly have a better example than in the work of Ariane Mnouchkine's Théâtre du Soleil at the Cartoucherie at Vincennes, in the east of the city. In Britain we have seen only her 1789 at the Roundhouse and Les Atrides in Bradford. But she is one of the great European directors, and her current production of Hélène Cixous's Tambours Sur la Digue is an astonishing amalgam of ideas from Gordon Craig, Bertolt Brecht and Japanese No and bunraku.

Cixous has come up with an oriental fable, the story of a patriarchal community faced with a moral dilemma about whether to save the city or the countryside from destruction by rising flood-water. Partly through its own internal power squabbles and partly through structural defects in its dyke, the community ends up totally engulfed.

The characters, though played by live actors, are portrayed as marionettes manipulated by the masked, black-garbed figures of bunraku theatre. The result is visually hypnotic and intellectually arresting. It implies that all the characters are in the grip of determining external forces. But it also offers a vivid demonstration of Brechtian alienation: we focus on the story rather than individual psychology, yet we are riveted, even moved, by the technique of the actors. When one of the emperor's daughters, dies prematurely, we watch her stylised physical collapse - all jerks and twitches - and the deep anguish in the veiled eyes of her manipulator.

When you add thrilling music on flutes, pipes and gamelans, fever-pitch drumming and expertly choreographed movement, you have a show that knocks the Lion King into several cocked hats and that, as so often in Paris, allies political content to a peculiar joy in the act of creating theatre.

Le Costume is at the Bouffes du Nord (00 33 1 46 07 34 50) till January 29. De Gaulle - Celui Qui a Dit Non is at the Palais de Congrès (00 33 1 40 68 00 05) till February 6. Tambours Sur la Digue is at the Cartoucherie (00 33 1 43 74 24 08) till March 30.

Without minimising the story's cruelty, Brook deftly suggests the contradictory festivity of township life. Music dominates the action: at a party, Bakary Sangare's Philemon and two guests do the most elegant soft-shoe shuffle over and around the double bed; Marianne-Jean Baptiste's Matilda is haunted by memories of her showbiz past as she gaily sings My Little Yellow Basket. Even the suit is equivocal - both a reminder of Matilda's guilt and, as she puts her hand through the sleeve to caress her thighs and breast, a symbol of remembered sensual delight. Nothing is overstated. Through the use of vivid primary colours, orange sunsets and exuberant drumming, Brook shows us that domestic tragedy erupts in a world of communal gaiety and that township life is a source of gregarious entrapment. He also reminds us that it takes a lifetime's work to achieve such simplicity. At the opposite end of the scale, Paris is also a source of spectacle, and spectacles don't come much bigger than Robert Hossein's staging of De Gaulle - Celui Qui a Dit Non, which re-creates the general's intransigent wartime belief in a "Free France" before 3,000 spectators a night at the vast Palais de Congrès. We get film footage of the German occupation and of Marshal Pétain's Vichy regime. We get tableaux vivants of key moments of the war. We get running battles in the aisles. But beneath the pageantry we get a series of confrontations between Jacques Boudet's imperious De Gaulle and Robert Hardy's growling Churchill. It would be easy to mock the show's kitsch grandeur. But the main story, written by Alain Decaux and Alain Peyrefitte, expresses a central truth, that there was a strange, grudging, symbiotic kinship between De Gaulle and Churchill. As historian Eric Hobsbawm once wrote, the former was a reactionary Catholic who had " une certaine idée de la France ", the latter an imperialist Conservative with a profound sense of England. Even the recent revelations that Churchill was overruled by his wartime Cabinet in seeking to ditch De Gaulle are acknowledged. At one point Churchill actually tells him that "the worst moment for France was the hour that you were born". But, spiritually the two men were blood brothers, and I don't think it is mere chauvinism that makes me feel that Hardy's wily, devious and heroically cussed Churchill is every bit as fascinating as Boudet's single-minded, unyielding De Gaulle. It may be spectacle on the scale of the Royal Tournament, but there is something oddly moving about seeing the French turning their wartime history into popular theatre. Paris, in fact, seems to delight in the theatricality of theatre, and you could hardly have a better example than in the work of Ariane Mnouchkine's Théâtre du Soleil at the Cartoucherie at Vincennes, in the east of the city. In Britain we have seen only her 1789 at the Roundhouse and Les Atrides in Bradford. But she is one of the great European directors, and her current production of Hélène Cixous's Tambours Sur la Digue is an astonishing amalgam of ideas from Gordon Craig, Bertolt Brecht and Japanese No and bunraku. Cixous has come up with an oriental fable, the story of a patriarchal community faced with a moral dilemma about whether to save the city or the countryside from destruction by rising flood-water. Partly through its own internal power squabbles and partly through structural defects in its dyke, the community ends up totally engulfed. The characters, though played by live actors, are portrayed as marionettes manipulated by the masked, black-garbed figures of bunraku theatre. The result is visually hypnotic and intellectually arresting. It implies that all the characters are in the grip of determining external forces. But it also offers a vivid demonstration of Brechtian alienation: we focus on the story rather than individual psychology, yet we are riveted, even moved, by the technique of the actors. When one of the emperor's daughters, dies prematurely, we watch her stylised physical collapse - all jerks and twitches - and the deep anguish in the veiled eyes of her manipulator. When you add thrilling music on flutes, pipes and gamelans, fever-pitch drumming and expertly choreographed movement, you have a show that knocks the Lion King into several cocked hats and that, as so often in Paris, allies political content to a peculiar joy in the act of creating theatre. Le Costume is at the Bouffes du Nord (00 33 1 46 07 34 50) till January 29. De Gaulle - Celui Qui a Dit Non is at the Palais de Congrès (00 33 1 40 68 00 05) till February 6. Tambours Sur la Digue is at the Cartoucherie (00 33 1 43 74 24 08) till March 30.

fields.headline: Last days of Orwell
fields.standfirst: Fifty years ago, the creator of 1984 and Animal Farm was fatally ill but also newly wed, at the peak of his fame, and bursting with book ideas.  DJ Taylor  reconstructs the author's final weeks
fields.trailText: Fifty years ago, the creator of 1984 and Animal Farm was fatally ill but also newly wed, at the peak of his fame, and bursting with book ideas. DJ Taylor reconstructs the author's final weeks
fields.body:
Books Unlimited author page

In January, 1950, small procession of visitors could be seen each afternoon making their way singly and severally through the cheerless north Bloomsbury squares towards University College hospital. Many of them were literary - the immensely tall figure of Stephen Spender with his mop of curly hair, Anthony Powell and Malcolm Muggeridge, both of whom lived in nearby Regent's Park. Others came from the BBC or from left-wing newspapers. Occasionally, a small boy was brought in and allowed to remain for a moment or so before a patient so terrified of communicating the disease from which he suffered, that he would never allow his adopted son to touch him. The most regular visitor was a spectacularly pretty, brown-haired girl with a newly acquired wedding ring gleaming on her finger.

By January, 1950, Orwell had been at UCH for nearly four months, and in hospital since the start of the previous year. Two decades of chronic lung trouble had finally produced a diagnosis of tuberculosis. At a sanatorium in Gloucestershire, six months before, he had nearly died, but recovered enough to be transferred to London and the care of the distinguished chest specialist Andrew Morland. Morland, recommended to Orwell by his publisher Fred Warburg, didn't anticipate a cure: but he thought that, with sufficient care and treatment, he might reach the status of "good chronic", able to potter about and undertake a few hours' sedentary work a day. Orwell, desperate to pick up his pen once more, was told that he had a "relatively" good chance of staying alive.

Morland had taken Orwell on as a private patient: little more than a year since its inception, Bevan's NHS had barely begun to exist. Fortunately money, the absence of which had troubled Orwell for most of his adult life, was no longer a problem. Nineteen Eighty-Four, published the previous June, had been a huge success on both sides of the Atlantic. 25,000 copies had already been sold in England. US royalties, fuelled by selection as a Book of the Month Club choice, were rolling in. Orwell was famous and well off. In the last month of his life, the value of his estate was put at around £12,000 (the average weekly wage was well below £10). He was also, despite the rigours of his hospital routine, unexpectedly happy.

Orwell had known Sonia Brownell, who had worked on Cyril Connolly's monthly magazine Horizon, for several years. Sixteen years younger than Orwell, with a string of previous lovers that included the artists Lucian Freud and William Coldstream, Sonia looked an unlikely candidate for the role of second Mrs Orwell, a vacancy the widower had seemed anxious to fill during the late 1940s. Her reasons for accepting a desperately sick man, with whom she was fairly obviously not in love, will always be obscure. Subsequent accusations of gold-digging are unfounded. There was no guarantee when she married him that he was about to turn into the titanic figure of literary legend. Anthony Powell always maintained that Sonia married him simply because her mentor, Cyril Connolly, told her to.

The marriage took place by special licence in Orwell's room on October 13, 1949. David Astor, proprietor of the Observer and a long-term supporter, gave away the bride in the presence of the hospital chaplain, the Reverend WH Braine, Sonia's friend Janetta Kee, Powell, Muggeridge and one of Orwell's doctors. The guests then went off for a celebratory dinner at the Ritz. The bridegroom remained in bed. Several of his friends noted how much the marriage raised his spirits. According to Powell, it "immensely cheered him ... In some respects he was in better form than I had ever known." Despite his cadaverous state - he had lost so much weight that the doctors had trouble finding enough spare flesh to insert hypodermic needles - Orwell looked unexpectedly perky in it. Sitting up in bed, Powell remembered, he had an "unaccustomedly epicurean air".

The plan had been that, as soon as Orwell showed faint signs of improvement, he could be sent to a sanatorium in the Swiss Alps to take advantage of the rarefied mountain air. But he remained horribly unwell, losing even more weight and suffering from high temperatures. The new American wonder drug streptomycin had been tried on him the year before, and Fred Warburg had petitioned his US publishers to help in speeding up a delivery of auromycin, but these were early days for TB cures. Among other side-effects, the streptomycin had made Orwell's fingernails fall out - and the prognosis grew worse.

Orwell, though, was convinced he would live. Full of ideas for books - a study of Conrad's political fiction and a novella set in the far east, provisionally titled A Smoking-Room Story - he believed that a writer who has a book left in him to write will not die. Despite his poor state, Morland thought that the promise of the Swiss trip would have a beneficial effect and sanctioned it for January. A fishing rod, brought by a friend for his convalescence, lay at the end of the bed.

By this stage, few of his visitors expected him to live. Some of the saddest visits were the few allowed to his adopted son, Richard. Orwell was so anxious about passing on the disease to the four-year-old that he pushed the boy away if he came too close. Sonia came every day, looked after his business affairs, and occasionally annoyed people by her assumption of the role of officious nurse. One day, Sonia told Orwell that she had to go to a cocktail party and wouldn't be back that evening. Orwell protested faintly, but she bustled off. Others noticed a progressive deterioration. Arriving with Powell on Christmas Day, Muggeridge found him "very deathly and wretched, alone, with Christmas decorations all around". His face looked practically dead, Muggeridge recorded, oddly like a picture he had once seen of Nietzsche on his death-bed. He detected a kind of rage in his friend's expression, as though the approach of death made him furious. They talked about Orwell's exploits in the Home Guard, his time in Spain in the civil war, the prospect of Switzerland, "and all the while the stench of death was in the air, like autumn in a garden".

The new year came. A departure date had been set for January 25. Orwell's companions on the trip, by privately chartered plane, would be Sonia and Lucian Freud. Visiting again on the 12th, Muggeridge thought him "more deathly than ever, very miserable," complaining that the doctors would not even allow him aspirin. A week later, though, Julian Symons found him eagerly anticipating the Swiss trip, and keen to talk about long-delayed literary schemes.

There was a chance that the doctors might let him start writing again, he explained, and he was anxious to get on with the novella and the Conrad book. "I shall go to Switzerland next Wednesday," Symons recalled him saying, laughing as he did so, "if I don't catch cold." Another friend, the anarchist poet Paul Potts, called on him the next afternoon, Friday January 20, bringing a small packet of tea as a present. Looking through the glass square cut into the door, he saw that Orwell was asleep. Judging it best not to disturb him, he left the tea propped up against the lintel and stole away.

Sonia spent the evening at a nightclub with Lucian Freud. In the small hours of Saturday Janu ary 21, she was tracked down by telephone to be told that Orwell had died of a massive lung haemorrhage. The news spread throughout the weekend. "G Orwell is dead and Mrs Orwell, presumably, a rich widow," Evelyn Waugh noted in a letter to Nancy Mitford. Muggeridge, told of his friend's death early on the Saturday morning, compared it to the passing of another recent literary casualty, Hugh Kingsmill.

Orwell's death was the sadder, however, "because he passionately wanted to go on living, and there was no sense of peace or relinquishment in him." Muggeridge, then working on the Daily Telegraph, wrote a couple of memorial paragraphs for the Peterborough column. "Thought of him, as of Graham [Greene], that popular writers always express in an intense form some romantic longing..."

The dead man turned out to have made a will three days before his death, in the presence of Sonia and his first wife's sister, Gwen O'Shaughnessy. Materially, it transferred his literary estate to Sonia. A substantial life insurance policy would provide for his adopted son, Richard, then being looked after by his aunt, Orwell's sister Avril. Orwell directed that he should be buried according to the rites of the Church of England and his body interred (not cremated) in the nearest convenient cemetery. The task of arranging all this fell to Powell and Muggeridge. A Warren Street undertaker was quickly brought on board.

Then the two tried to engage the services of the Rev Rose, Vicar of Christ Church, Albany Street NWI. Astor influence secured a plot in the graveyard of All Saints church at Sutton Courteney in Oxfordshire. Muggeridge noted in his diary the fact of Orwell dying on Lenin's birthday and being buried by the Astors, "which seems to me to cover the full range of his life".

The funeral was set for Thursday January 26. The evening before, Powell and his wife, Lady Violet, called in at the Muggeridges after supper, bringing Sonia with them, "obviously in a poor way". On their last meeting, the day after Orwell's death, Sonia had been overcome with grief. Muggeridge decided that he would "always love her for her true tears..." He left a detailed account of the next day's events: Fred Warburg greeting the mourners at the church door, the chilly atmosphere, the congregation "largely Jewish and almost entirely unbelievers" who had difficulty following the Anglican liturgy. Powell chose the hymns - "All people that on earth do dwell," "Guide me, 0 thou great Redeemer" and "Ten thousand times ten thousand" ("Why, I can't remember," Powell later wrote, "perhaps Orwell himself had talked of the hymn, or because he was, in his way, a sort of saint, even if not one in sparkling raiment bright.")

Both Powell and Muggeridge found the occasion hugely distressing. Muggeridge, in particular, was deeply moved by the lesson, chosen by Powell from the Book of Ecclesiastes: "Then shall the dust return to the earth as it was, and the spirit shall return to the God who gave it."

He went back to his house near Regent's Park to read through the sheaf of obituaries filed by, among others, Symons, VS Pritchett and Arthur Koestler, seeing in them already "how the legend of a human being is created".

webTitle: Has compensation culture gone too far?

fields.headline: Has compensation culture gone too far?
fields.standfirst: Yes: Ruth Lea, Institute of Directors | No: John Hendy, Employment rights barrister
fields.trailText: Yes: Ruth Lea, Institute of Directors | No: John Hendy, Employment rights barrister
fields.body:
Dear John,

I'm sure that you and I agree on one thing: that it's quite wrong for employers to dismiss their employees unfairly, or to discriminate on grounds of race or gender. The system of employment tribunals is a good one and, in many cases, can right situations where employers have breached the rules. So why am I worried about the developments in compensation payouts that are now taking place?

Employees already bring many frivolous cases against employers. Taking average figures for recent years, I understand that about 45% of cases are either withdrawn before reaching the tribunal, or fail at the tribunal. In other words, nearly half of all the cases are frivolous, if not capricious. But, whether frivolous or not, the employer has to prepare his or her case, frequently incurring legal costs, in order to defend himself or herself. This can be hugely time-consuming, expensive and damaging, especially for small businesses. And there's no compensation for the employer if he or she "wins": today's compensation culture is strictly one-way.

Given the explosion in employment regulations, media coverage of huge compensation payments and increasing litigiousness, I fear these frivolous cases will rise dramatically. How are employers - especially small employers - going to cope?

Yours sincerely,

Ruth Lea
Head of Policy,
Institute of Directors

Dear Ruth,

You're right! I do agree that employers should obey the law. You're troubled by the burden on employers of frivolous employment tribunal cases. You have perhaps forgotten that an employment tribunal can and will order the costs of one side to be paid by the other where the latter has acted "frivolously, vexatiously, abusively disruptively or otherwise unreasonably".

But two things trouble me about the special exemptions granted to employers, especially in the area of unfair dismissal. First, no matter how unfair the dismissal, an employee dismissed within a year of starting work with an employer is barred from bringing an unfair dismissal claim. Second, an employer cannot be obliged to take back an unfairly dismissed employee where a tribunal has ordered it.

You refer to "today's compensation culture", but surely employers and their insurers must be rejoicing in the government's decision to abolish legal aid for personal injury cases? This will mean that thousands of workers will no longer be able to sue their employers for injury or death caused by breach of health and safety laws. True, unions will take these cases for free - as in the case of the gipsy site worker who received damages this week - but most workers aren't in unions. Lawyers can do these cases on a no-win, no-fee basis, but they will only take the risk in the very strongest cases.

You can rest assured that the courts and tribunals are assiduous in throwing out frivolous cases. The real injustice is not a compensation culture, but a culture in which innocent people suffer injury and loss by lawbreaking employers and yet cannot get compensation for it.

Yours,

John Hendy QC
Institute of Employment Rights

Dear John,

I hadn't forgotten that costs can be awarded to employers in some very specific circumstances, but such costs can never meet the damaging disruption to businesses - especially to small businesses - that frivolous cases cause. There is no adequate compensation for such damage. And the fact that tribunals are "assiduous" in throwing out frivolous cases does not invalidate this point.

But the "compensation culture" is all too vigorous. Recent estimates suggest that it costs the country £7.5bn a year, and some recent payouts have been extraordinarily inflated. Moreover, there has been an explosion of tribunal cases faced by employers. In 1998/99 there were 136,000; 31% higher than the previous year. As Acas has acknowledged, the rapid rise reflects increased litigiousness and extended employment rights, and there are more to come. Small employers feel powerless in the face of such an onslaught.

As for industrial injuries cases, lawyers can do them on a no-win, no-fee basis, as indeed you say, insofar as public funding has been withdrawn for them. If lawyers believe a case has a good chance of winning then they would surely take it on. If not, it shouldn't go to court. If lawyers are responsible and rational people - and, in my experience, they are - then no innocent person who has suffered injury and loss by a lawbreaking employer should fail to get his or her compensation.

Yours sincerely,

Ruth

Dear Ruth,

You accept that tribunals throw out frivolous claims and that employers can get costs orders; remember also that tribunals can strike out vexatious claims at any stage. Employers are well-protected against the costs and disruption of fighting vexatious cases. What you're really seeking, it seems, is the removal of unfair dismissal claims altogether: that would certainly stop vexatious ones, but it would stop justified ones, too.

I hope the lawbreaking of employers doesn't cost the country £7.5bn a year! That cost should fall fairly and squarely on the shoulders of employers who flout the law. The real significance of this figure - and of the increase in the number of cases fought and won - is that it shows the massive extent of bad employers. And don't forget that because of limits on compensation for unfair dismissal, redundancy, failures to consult and the like, £7.5bn is nowhere near the total financial losses caused to employee victims. What your figure reveals is not a compensation culture, but a culture of lawlessness among employers.

As for injury cases - yes, lawyers are rational people: they will not take on cases where they think there is a significant chance of not being paid. So injured people with good but not overwhelming cases - people, that is, with a 50-70% chance of success - will find it difficult, and in some cases impossible, to get compensation.

Yours,

John

Dear John,

May I start by repeating that there is no adequate compensation for the damaging disruption caused to businesses, especially small ones, by frivolous tribunal cases. Every case has to be dealt with, and until the tribunal makes a decision, no businessman or woman knows whether or not it will be stopped. Coping with such cases can have huge opportunity costs, and almost cripple small and vulnerable firms. Incidentally, you imply I am seeking the removal of all claims. Not so.

Concerning the £7.5bn, I'm afraid you misunderstood the nature of the figure. It refers to the total costs to the country of the compensation culture, and includes £4bn paid by the NHS, emergency services and local government. Legal fees totalled £1bn - a nice little earner! - and less than 20% was attributed to the private sector, hardly a culture of lawlessness among employers.

I was surprised, if not amazed, that you implied that only dead cert cases - or near as dammit dead cert - would be handled by lawyers. Such a stance seems quite extraordinarily restrictive and unjust. Some people may think lawyers should adopt a less risk-averse - and more generous - approach.

Yours,

Ruth

Dear Ruth,

You complain of inadequate compensation for employers faced with frivolous cases, but I've spent nearly 30 years doing employment cases and I just do not believe there are many frivolous ones. The fact that many cases are withdrawn before hearing is because settlement is often reached, frequently when the employer agrees to pay because the employee's case is strong. And the disruption caused by claims against employers is nowhere near comparable to the distress caused to employees who are unfairly treated.

I don't understand your figure of £7.5bn as the cost of the "compensation culture". Compensation is only payable when someone has broken the law; if you break the law and someone else suffers loss, or is injured, why shouldn't you pay compensation? I find it hard to believe that the NHS, emergency services and local government have paid out £4bn in compensation and costs for their own wrongdoing. Maybe you are referring to the cost of attending to accidents in which compensation has later been recovered by victims; if so, I agree that the wrongdoer should compensate those bodies too.

In 1994, the health and safety executive estimated that the net cost to individuals of work-related accidents and ill-health was £5bn; the cost to employers £1.5bn. The cost to society was between £11bn and £16bn. It would be much better economics for employers to comply with law than to whinge about frivolous tribunal cases. Many lawyers take many deserving cases in tribunals and courts free of charge, but you can't expect them to run their businesses at a loss. Wasn't your starting point the need to protect small businesses from irrecoverable costs?

Yours,

John

fields.bodyText: Dear John, I'm sure that you and I agree on one thing: that it's quite wrong for employers to dismiss their employees unfairly, or to discriminate on grounds of race or gender. The system of employment tribunals is a good one and, in many cases, can right situations where employers have breached the rules. So why am I worried about the developments in compensation payouts that are now taking place? Employees already bring many frivolous cases against employers. Taking average figures for recent years, I understand that about 45% of cases are either withdrawn before reaching the tribunal, or fail at the tribunal. In other words, nearly half of all the cases are frivolous, if not capricious. But, whether frivolous or not, the employer has to prepare his or her case, frequently incurring legal costs, in order to defend himself or herself. This can be hugely time-consuming, expensive and damaging, especially for small businesses. And there's no compensation for the employer if he or she "wins": today's compensation culture is strictly one-way. Given the explosion in employment regulations, media coverage of huge compensation payments and increasing litigiousness, I fear these frivolous cases will rise dramatically. How are employers - especially small employers - going to cope? Yours sincerely, Ruth Lea Head of Policy, Institute of Directors Dear Ruth, You're right! I do agree that employers should obey the law. You're troubled by the burden on employers of frivolous employment tribunal cases. You have perhaps forgotten that an employment tribunal can and will order the costs of one side to be paid by the other where the latter has acted "frivolously, vexatiously, abusively disruptively or otherwise unreasonably". But two things trouble me about the special exemptions granted to employers, especially in the area of unfair dismissal. First, no matter how unfair the dismissal, an employee dismissed within a year of starting work with an employer is barred from bringing an unfair dismissal claim. Second, an employer cannot be obliged to take back an unfairly dismissed employee where a tribunal has ordered it. This will mean that thousands of workers will no longer be able to sue their employers for injury or death caused by breach of health and safety laws. True, unions will take these cases for free - as in the case of the gipsy site worker who received damages this week - but most workers aren't in unions. Lawyers can do these cases on a no-win, no-fee basis, but they will only take the risk in the very strongest cases. You can rest assured that the courts and tribunals are assiduous in throwing out frivolous cases. The real injustice is not a compensation culture, but a culture in which innocent people suffer injury and loss by lawbreaking employers and yet cannot get compensation for it. Yours, John Hendy QC Institute of Employment Rights Dear John, I hadn't forgotten that costs can be awarded to employers in some very specific circumstances, but such costs can never meet the damaging disruption to businesses - especially to small businesses - that frivolous cases cause. There is no adequate compensation for such damage. And the fact that tribunals are "assiduous" in throwing out frivolous cases does not invalidate this point. But the "compensation culture" is all too vigorous. Recent estimates suggest that it costs the country £7.5bn a year, and some recent payouts have been extraordinarily inflated. Moreover, there has been an explosion of tribunal cases faced by employers. In 1998/99 there were 136,000; 31% higher than the previous year. As Acas has acknowledged, the rapid rise reflects increased litigiousness and extended employment rights, and there are more to come. Small employers feel powerless in the face of such an onslaught. As for industrial injuries cases, lawyers can do them on a no-win, no-fee basis, as indeed you say, insofar as public funding has been withdrawn for them. If lawyers believe a case has a good chance of winning then they would surely take it on. If not, it shouldn't go to court. If lawyers are responsible and rational people - and, in my experience, they are - then no innocent person who has suffered injury and loss by a lawbreaking employer should fail to get his or her compensation. Employers are well-protected against the costs and disruption of fighting vexatious cases. What you're really seeking, it seems, is the removal of unfair dismissal claims altogether: that would certainly stop vexatious ones, but it would stop justified ones, too. I hope the lawbreaking of employers doesn't cost the country £7.5bn a year! That cost should fall fairly and squarely on the shoulders of employers who flout the law.
