As for injury cases - yes, lawyers are rational people: they will not take on cases where they think there is a significant chance of not being paid. So injured people with good but not overwhelming cases - people, that is, with a 50-70% chance of success - will find it difficult, and in some cases impossible, to get compensation. fields.headline: Friends who sleep together
fields.trailText: Oh my God. Oh. My. God. Friends is back on Sky 1, and the only thing that has changed is that David Schwimmer's goo-goo eyes have got even more goo-goo.
fields.body:
Oh my God. Oh. My. God. Friends is back on Sky 1, and the only thing that has changed is that David Schwimmer's goo-goo eyes have got even more goo-goo. When Ross pouts at Rachel, why doesn't she just sock him on the jaw and then kick him repeatedly when he's down? Why?

Don't tell me women don't do that kind of thing. They do on US TV. And it can only be a matter of time before they do it here, though probably not on Hetty Wainthropp Investigates. In the new ER (Sky 1), for instance, some guy triggers the fire alarm just because he can't get any treatment for his palpitating bonce and gets thumped as a result. The irresponsibility! The white coats are flapping around trying to deal with the carnage after a truck collides with a gourmet coffee shop and he's worried about a headache!

The cafe crash had indeed produced some horrible injuries: "What's that burn look like to you, Dr Benton?" "Er, that's a double double mocha burn, Dr Ramano." "Lucky I'm here then isn't it, Peter? That's a skinny vanilla latte burn. Nurse, prep him. We're going inside. Now, cue up some fast-paced house music while I make the incision." This is the kind of dialogue they never have in ER, but I'm quite prepared to write more along these lines for the right fee. Quite prepared.

So the woman nurse flattened the guy who nixed the fire alarm. No matter that he was built like Beachy Head and she like a Princess Di figurine. This confirms two things: one, that in ER the medical profession are gods, and that mortals should delay them never; two, that it's OK, perhaps even empowering and sexy, for women to hit men on TV.

And during the pilot for The West Wing (Sky 1), a drama series set in the White House, Mandy, a senator's assistant and full-on hardass (I don't really know what this amounts to in practical life, but I won't be inviting her round for tea and pressing her to a cucumber sandwich any time soon), said to a former lover: "I want you at your fighting weight when I start bitch-slapping you around the Beltway."

Bitch-slapping. That's no way to carry on. When women fought in the bar of Cheers (as often as not over Sam Malone's cunningly combed piece ), Norm would attract Cliff's attention with an excitable "Cat fight! Cat fight!" Cliff, wiping froth from his moustache, would assess the situation more coolly. "Kitten fight," he would say, before returning to his beer. Men love to see women fighting - it comes second only to lesbian sex scenes in the canon of the male heterosexual's voyeuristic delights. Bitch slapping, I fear, will never have such appeal.

American men run in terror of symbolic castration. In The West Wing, for instance, when Mandy told Josh that she was dating her senator boss, he immediately had to claim his rival was gay. "He's very athletic. Plenty masculine," retorted Mandy, plenty defensively. "I think he's a woman," said Josh, mucho aggressively.

The West Wing promises much, particularly from its writing. The press corps stood waiting for a briefing to begin: "They're holding four column inches above the fold," said one. "They're going to be wrong," sneered another. I, as you can see, don't get out of bed for four inches above or below the fold, no doubt because I too fear symbolic castration. The West Wing is every bit as well-written and morally engaging as LA Law or Murder One.

I'll be returning to it in future weeks. And to Friends, too, since the latest series is the culmination of a journey from sitcom to unwitting dramatic critique of celebrity incestuousness. No one was good enough for the Friends to have relationships with except the Friends themselves. In the new series, the writers have taken this truth to its conclusion: Ross and Rachel are married; Monica and Chandler have plighted something. It only remains for Phoebe to plump Joey's barrel chest seductively for the unwholesome sixsome to be conjugally felicitated. As if to confirm that life imitates art, the actors who play Ross and Monica (brother and sister in the series) have wedded. "For Courteney and David, who did get married," read the caption at the end. For one horrible moment I thought it was to each other. Oh my God. Oh. My. God.

fields.headline: Don't look back
fields.standfirst: The art world's cellars have been emptied for the Royal Academy's show of work from 1900. Most of it should have stayed where it was, says  Jonathan Jones
fields.trailText: The art world's cellars have been emptied for the Royal Academy's show of work from 1900. Most of it should have stayed where it was, says Jonathan Jones
fields.body:
It's Oscar night in hell. Or that's what it feels like at the Royal Academy exhibition 1900: Art at the Crossroads. History handed out the prizes to the generation of 1900 long ago. Now the RA has grabbed the trophies back and forced the best to smile politely at the worst in a ceremony where everyone gets an award.

You can almost feel Cézanne grit his teeth as he watches the award for Most Kinky Painting of Bathers go to mediocre British artist (and Royal Academician) Henry Scott Tuke, who specialised in painting naked young men in ways that were innocent to the untutored, more suggestive to the initiated, and, to us, are entertainingly erotic. Ho ho ho, we chuckle, and walk past a small, obscure painting of bodies glimpsed through a pixillated visual field by Cézanne.

The only reassuring thing about an event like the Oscars, or any institutional event that glorifies mediocrities and ignores the brilliant subversives, is that it doesn't really matter. The only judge of art is time. But what happens if we go back in time, in an art nouveau time machine, to the official salon art of 1900? This is what the RA has done with 1900: Art at the Crossroads - a partial reconstruction of the Exposition Universelle held in Paris in the spring and summer of 1900. This was a huge event celebrating electricity, empire and art nouveau, but the part of the Exposition that the RA is interested in is the international exhibition of painting and sculpture. The exhibition did not include any of the modernist artists at work in the city, though a separate show of impressionism was held in a centennial exhibition of French art. This "official" painting was the last gasp of 19th-century naturalism and romanticism, a hypocritical, conservative art of harems and sentimentalised workers. These painters did all they could to keep the modernist upstarts down.

Now they're back, their paintings retrieved from cellars all over the world. No one could bear an undiluted show of conservative official art from 1900 though, so the RA has displayed a selection of Exposition Universelle paintings alongside work by their modernist contemporaries. The curators claim it will make us see the art of 1900 in a new way, and so it does.

It must have taken a real effort for the curators to persuade themselves that these Modern masters were really not that special - that when you look at Cézanne, Degas, Toulouse-Lautrec, Gauguin, Matisse and the teenage Picasso next to the bloated establishment artists of the late 19th century what you see are equally valid ways of making art.

If the Exposition Universelle sanctified the fin-de-siècle establishment, this exhibition is the reductio ad absurdum of deconstructive art history. Since the 80s art historians have been chipping away at the canon of Modern art. You can see this as necessarily subversive and disruptive, but there are limits. "Are there ways of seeing oil-and-water contemporaries like Bouguereau and Cézanne that might bridge the gap between them?" asks art historian and co-curator Robert Rosenblum in his catalogue essay. Only if you look through academic glasses that stop you seeing what's in front of your eyes. Bouguereau's paintings, which had pride of place in the Exposition Universelle, are enjoyed today as greeting-card images. At the RA you can smile at his Admiration (1897), a coy soft-porn painting of nymphs with semi-revealed breasts around a wicked little cupid. Ugh.

And then look at Cézanne, Degas, Munch, Rodin, Gauguin, Matisse and Klimt - who showed the one great modernist painting that slipped into the Exposition, his dionysian Pallas Athene - and you're in another world. Our world. Bouguereau belongs to a weird, fruity past. The modernists of 1900 belong to our time. The historian of science Thomas Kuhn argues that revolutions in knowledge are not evolutionary but seismic - and that's how modernism looks in this exhibition. Because perversely, this is a great celebration of Modern art. By forcing Modern masters to share wall space with the likes of Alma-Tadema, it does modernism an accidental favour. The Modern masterpieces - about 50 paintings out of 250 in the exhibition - are like oases in the desert. Content, narrative, genre - these are the props they kick away. It doesn't matter whether Munch is painting a portrait or a landscape; what you get is his visionary shattering of the world. When you see Degas's bronze of a woman drying herself in the bath, the beautiful awk wardness of it, the bath as a clumsy physical presence, breaks out of the elegant fin-de-siècle into a brutal modernist physicality.

Did the artists in this exhibition see themselves at a "crossroads", able to choose between what co-curator MaryAnne Stevens calls "options"? I doubt if any good artist ever sees art as a matters of options. In any case, the crossroads had been passed back in the middle of the 19th century. The modern world was up and running in 1900, cities exploding, anarchists throwing bombs, middle-class culture disintegrating. When the official artists of 1900 painted society portraits and cloying religious scenes (check out Bouguereau's Regina Angelorum, 1900) they were reasserting the order of things against revolution.

The Modern artists were single-minded about the revolution they were making. They had a world to imagine, as you see from their hyper-intense, troubled self-portraits - Matisse in colours of his mind; the German expressionist Emil Nolde disappearing in darkness. The terrible thing about this exhibition is that lots of people will enjoy it. It's amusing and easy to look at Bouguereau. It's hard to look at Cézanne. But it's not the art of 1900 that is being judged here, it's us. The desire to muddy the waters of art history, to level the Modern masters with mediocre contemporaries, suggests an anxiety about our own time. We have plenty of good, interesting artists. But how do we compare with 1900? How do we compare with Picasso, Matisse, Cézanne, Degas? I suppose it's tempting to knock when you're scared you can't measure up.

fields.headline: The last word on   History
fields.standfirst: To remain ignorant of what happened before you were born is to remain always a child. - Cicero
fields.trailText: To remain ignorant of what happened before you were born is to remain always a child. - Cicero
fields.body:
This week saw the beginning of an action for libel brought by one historian against another over a question of history. The right-wing historian David Irving says the Holocaust was not as bad as has been claimed; he is suing American historian Deborah Lipstadt for calling him "a dangerous spokesman for Holocaust denial." The case, and its explosive content, remind us that history matters.

But what is history? There is ambiguity in the very name. "History" can either mean past events, or writings about past events. But what if the former is a creation of the latter? The past, after all, has ceased to exist.

Here in the present we find documents and other objects which, we suppose, survive from the past, and we weave interpretations round them. These objects, and our interpretations, belong to the present. If history is different narratives constructed in the present, is it any wonder that historians disagree among themselves?

The idea that the past is another country, spread out behind us, which we could visit if we had a time-machine, is naive. Yet our realism is offended by the claim that the past is created in the present, and we oppose the latitude thus accorded those who, for example, deny that the Holocaust happened.

What, then, is history? Is it an art that creates, or a science that discovers? Either way, is there - can there be - such a thing as historical truth? And if so, to what extent can it be known?

"History" derives from the ancient Greek word istoria, meaning enquiry. But even in antiquity the fatal ambiguity arose; by the fourth century BC the historikos - reciter of stories - had supplanted the historeon - the enquirer. Into which category should we place the great early historians - Herodotus, Thucydides, Polybius, Livy, Sallust, Tacitus?

They too understood the problem. Thucydides attacked Herodotus for his expansive and anecdotal history - made up of an artfully arranged collection of anecdotes, facts, legends and speculations - of the great east-west struggle between Persia and Greece. Thucydides began his history of the Peloponnesian war with the claim that history should be "contemporary history", restricting itself to what can be verified by personal observation. He served in the Athenian army, and wrote as he fought.

Art outweighed science in most historical writing as far as the Renaissance. But from the 17th century, the possibility of scientific history emerged from work on sources. Benedictine monks established principles for authenticating medieval manuscripts, thus inaugurating the systematic treatment of materials. By the time Leopold von Ranke (1795-1886) summoned historians to record the past "as it actually happened", the project seemed possible.

Other "Positivists" like von Ranke claimed that there are inductively discoverable historical laws. The great Victorian, John Stuart Mill, agreed, adding that psychological laws count among them. On this view history is truly a science: good data and general laws pave the way to objective truth.

But the Positivists were opposed by the Idealists, such as Wilhelm Dilthey (1833-1911). Idealist arguments show that this aim is easier to state than achieve. The Irving case, in turn, shows that the argument matters.

fields.headline: Alfred Nzo
fields.standfirst: A lifetime of work, prison, exile and suffering in service of the African National Congress
fields.trailText: Alfred Nzo, who has died aged 74, was a veteran of the African National Congress. He had impeccable struggle credentials, starting as a 20-year-old member of the militant new ANC Youth League (founded by Nelson Mandela and others) and serving as ANC secretary-general from 1969-91; but he never had star quality, he was solid rather than sparkling.
fields.body:
Alfred Nzo, who has died aged 74, was a veteran of the African National Congress. He had impeccable struggle credentials, starting as a 20-year-old member of the militant new ANC Youth League (founded by Nelson Mandela and others) and serving as ANC secretary-general from 1969-91; but he never had star quality, he was solid rather than sparkling.

He was one of a family of five children, from Benoni, east Witwatersrand, where his father was a clerical worker for a gold mine. He went through the (officially-suspect) missionary education in the eastern Cape (certificate at Catholic school, matriculation at Healdtown missionary institute), before enrolling at that breeding ground for black activists, Fort Hare university college, where he dropped out in 1946, in his second year of a science degree.

Nzo was such a low-profile figure that in his (not very scholarly) history of the ANC, Francis Meli scarcely mentions him. Yet without Nzo to do the spade work, the ANC, struggling to resist apartheid, would not have notched up early spectacular strikes and boycotts. Nzo concentrated his activities on Alexandra township, north of Johannesburg, becoming secretary of the bus boycott, which lasted from January to March 1957 and shook the city's white establishment. In 1958, he was elected to both the Transvaal and national executives of ANC.

He was 12 years working on the hardest issues of black under-privilege and became more active, taking part in the May Day strike of 1950 and the nationwide strike that June. He helped to mobilise supporters for the 1952 defiance of unjust laws campaign, which in turn led to the Congress of the People and the adoption of the famous freedom charter in Kliptown in 1955.

Nzo qualified educationally through part-time studies at a Johannesburg technical college, completing a sanitary (health) inspector's course in 1951. Then he based himself in Alexandra, working as a health inspector. Sacked for his political activities, he lost his right to residence in Alexandra, and afterwards was the victim of banning orders and frequent arrests. In 1961, he was imprisoned for five months; then restricted to a limited area; and in November 1962 was placed under 24-hour house arrest, following his involvement in an All-In Africa conference in Pietermaritzburg. From June 1963, he was detained for 238 days, released twice for a few minutes, and immediately re-detained, a game security police played to keep nominally within the law.

He was released in February 1964, with no charges against him, and the ANC underground leadership instructed him to leave South Africa to join President Oliver Tambo's external mission, established in 1960. He served as the ANC's deputy representative in Cairo 1964-67 and then as its chief representative in New Delhi. In 1969, he was elected ANC secretary-general and transferred to the headquarters at Morogoro, Tanzania.

Like many leading ANC members at the time, he had communist connections: in 1985, the Soviet Union awarded him the order of friendship amongst peoples, and he was a contributor to the World Marxist Review.

In 1989, one year before President FW de Klerk unbanned all political organisations and ANC members were released from exile and prison, Tambo suffered a stroke, and Nzo took over many of his duties, including taking part in negotiations with SA internal groupings, which led to the unbanning and, in 1994, to the country's first nonracial elections. The ANC was voted into office with almost a two-thirds majority. Nzo was part of the ANC's talks delegation.

By then, young Turks in the ANC were readying themselves for an internal power struggle. Mandela's choice as his successor was Cyril Ramaphosa, former general secretary of the National Union of Mineworkers and now a businessman; Thabo Mbeki was organising his support base. Ramaphosa stood against Nzo for the post of ANC secretary-general at the 1991 Durban conference and defeated him. It was the beginning of Nzo's public decline. In recognition of his contribution to the liberation struggle, he was elected to the ANC's national executive committee and appointed deputy head of the organisation's security department, then head of its directorate of intelligence, and from 1993-94, a member of the intelligence sub-council of the all-party transitional executive council.

In the 1994 general election, Nzo was only 44th on the ANC's parliamentary list. He became an MP and Mandela graciously appointed him minister of foreign affairs. Diplomacy at this level was not his forte. The media joked about his doziness, calling him Alfred Nzzzzzz. With Mbeki's man, Aziz Pahad, steering the way, Nzo presided over South Africa's integration into the organisation of african unity, the non-aligned movement and the Commonwealth.

When Mbeki was elected president in June last year, he quietly dropped Nzo from the cabinet, as everyone knew he would. The young guard had taken over.

Nzo had married Regina Vuyelwa; they had one son.

Alfred Baphethuxolo Nzo, ANC secretary-general, born June 19 1925; died January 13 2000

fields.headline: Phillip Carrick
fields.standfirst: Just six runs short of the great Yorkshire double
fields.trailText: Phil Carrick was the last, if far from the best, of a famous tradition of Yorkshire slow-left arm bowlers. The succession sustained Yorkshire for more than a century. Only for Carrick did the rewards not automatically follow. He never quite played for England, although late in his career he came close, and he had a period of failure in Yorkshire cricket that his predecessors would have found impossible to fathom.
fields.body:
Phil Carrick was the last, if far from the best, of a famous tradition of Yorkshire slow-left arm bowlers. The succession sustained Yorkshire for more than a century. Only for Carrick did the rewards not automatically follow. He never quite played for England, although late in his career he came close, and he had a period of failure in Yorkshire cricket that his predecessors would have found impossible to fathom.

When Carrick, who has died of leukaemia, aged 47, made his Yorkshire debut in 1970, it coincided with the end of the county's dominant decade. By the time of his retirement, 23 years later, Yorkshire had won only another two one-day trophies and the leanest period of its history had been darkened by internal conflict.

Mention the achievements of past Yorkshire bowlers to him, and Carrick's frown would be earnest and immediate. But none bore their obligations more stoutly, whether as one of the most economical slow bowlers in the country, as a dedicated, serious-minded captain, or a man with a vast respect for the game, striving to heal rather than destroy.

Events conspired against him. The enforced retirement of Yorkshire's England off-spinner, Geoff Cope, because of an illegal action, the advent of covered pitches, and a Yorkshire side in decline, all prodded him towards negativity. Only rarely did he manage to win by bowling sides out on turning pitches; but when the pitch was flat, and the opposition was cutting loose, every curmudgeonly Carrick over pronounced that Yorkshire would never lose its self-respect. The game was deserving of dignity, but beneath it all was a sense of fun.

His batting, while neither elegant nor strikingly courageous, could be highly effective, never more so than during his maiden championship century against Lancashire, the Roses rivals, at Headingley in 1978. On a pitch declared by the umpires to be unfit, Carrick carved 105, most notably against the West Indian fast bowler, Colin Croft, enabling Yorkshire to win by an innings with a day to spare.

Fergie (a dressing-room nickname derived from the Irish town, Carrickfergus) narrowly missed the coveted Yorkshire double of 10,000 runs and 1,000 wickets in first-class cricket. He fell six runs short, a desperate disappointment.

Needing 20 more, he was recalled for the final match of his retirement season against Surrey at the Oval in 1993. Rain ruined the match; although he opened the innings, the final day was a washout with the prize in sight. The following summer, he pondered over a one-off return at Scarborough, but the offer never materialised. He had become a minor counties umpire by the time his illness was first diagnosed, and never achieved his ambition to graduate to the first-class list.

Just as Raymond Illingworth had tempered the intuitive captaincy of Brian Close in the last great Yorkshire side, so, to a less- renowned degree, Carrick calmed the ebullience of David Bairstow. Although poles apart temperamentally, they were both proud Bradford lads. Following Bairstow's suicide two years ago, and the subsequent deaths of Billy Sutcliffe and Ronnie Burnet, Yorkshire has lost four post-war captains.

Carrick succeeded Bairstow as captain in 1987. In his first season, Yorkshire began with unexpected splendour, leading the championship until midsummer and winning the Benson and Hedges Cup, beating Northamptonshire by losing fewer wickets. Typically, for a county upon which tradition weighed heavily, the headline in the following season's county yearbook, Yorkshire's Golden Year, was discovered upon closer examination to refer to 1938.

Carrick is survived by his wife Ellie and two daughters.

Phillip Carrick, cricketer, born July 16 1952; died January 11 2000

fields.headline: The rise and rise of Microsoft
fields.standfirst: Microsoft on trial: special report
fields.trailText: April 1975: Bill Gates and Paul Allen found Microsoft
fields.body:
April 1975: Bill Gates and Paul Allen found Microsoft

May 1983: Microsoft introduces the mouse

November 1983: Microsoft unveils Windows

September 1985: Microsoft picks Republic of Ireland as the site of its first production facility outside the US

March 1986: Microsoft stock goes public at $21 a share rising to $28 by the end of the first trading day, raising $61million

May 1990: Microsoft launches Windows 3.0

June 1992: Bill Gates accepts the national medal of technology for technological achievement from president George Bush

March 1993: Microsoft Encarta, first encyclopedia designed for a PC, is unveiled

August 1995: Microsoft launches Windows 95

November 1995: Microsoft releases Internet Explorer 2 for Windows 95

April 1997: Microsoft signs an agreement to acquire Web TV Networks, which gives users access to the internet via TV

October 1997: Justice department files a motion in federal district court alleging that Microsoft had violated a 1994 decree dealing with licensing the Windows system to computer manufacturers

November 1999: Judge Thomas Jackson rules that "Microsoft enjoys monopoly power"

January 2000: Bill Gates steps down from being chief executive to become chief software architect

fields.headline: Microsoft empire facing breakup
fields.standfirst: Microsoft on trial: special report
fields.trailText: Bill Gates is standing down as chief executive of Microsoft as the company he founded and has managed for 25 years faces the very real threat of being broken up.
fields.body:
Bill Gates is standing down as chief executive of Microsoft as the company he founded and has managed for 25 years faces the very real threat of being broken up.

The legal battle between the world's largest company and the US government is a landmark anti-monopoly case. The outcome could define the corporate history of the next century, as the US courts decide whether the company abused its stranglehold over one market to gain access to the internet.

As Bill Gates, who has been largely blamed for Microsoft's uncompromising approach during negotiations with the government, stands back from the day-to-day management of the company the two sides seem no nearer settlement.

There is a fundamental disagreement about how to remedy the situation. The justice department and the 19 states suing Microsoft are said to be increasingly leaning toward a severe "structural" remedy - breaking up the company, to make it difficult to gain control over any one business area. Microsoft has publicly rejected any such suggestion and Steve Ballmer used his first public comments as chief executive to say: "I think it would be absolutely ridiculous and irresponsible for anyone to try and break up this company. I think it would be the greatest disservice that anybody could do to consumers in this country."

He noted the paradox of a government trying to break up Microsoft in the same week that America Online launched the world's biggest takeover bid, with its offer for Time Warner. Although Mr Gates will remain a member of the executive team directing the negotiations, Mr Ballmer will now lead it.

The government's hand was strengthened in November, when federal judge Thomas Penfield Jackson ruled that Microsoft had abused its monopoly position to harm consumers and stifle innovation. Microsoft is to publish its official response next week. If the mediation talks collapse, both sides will return to the federal court in Washington next month for final arguments.

Although the case is seen as a landmark in the internet age, the legal action has its roots in an investigation by the federal trade commission in 1991, years before the significance of the internet was realised. The commission began investigating after rivals complained that Microsoft was using its stranglehold on world operating systems to shut them out of the software market.

The investigation resulted in Microsoft signing a so-called consent decree for the government in 1995. This narrowly focused document tried to stop the company using its licensing agreements to bully computer manufacturers, but two years later, the justice department charged Microsoft with violating the decree. The company's relationship with the regulatory authorities has been increasingly acrimonious ever since.

When Netscape, the upstart web browser company, wrote to the trustbusters complaining about Microsoft, government lawyers again found Microsoft unyielding - setting the tone of legal battles that followed the decision to prosecute in 1998.

Unless Bill Gates's new job really does lead to a different stance, few observers believe the two sides will be able to reach a settlement. Both are likely to appeal against any ruling. If so, the final act of this case could still be a long way off.

fields.headline: Gates's loud alter ego
fields.standfirst: Microsoft on trial: special report
fields.trailText: Steve Ballmer has often been described as Bill Gates's alter ego. Whereas Mr Gates is softly spoken, Mr Ballmer's voice booms across crowded gatherings. And just as Mr Gates is intensely focused and reserved, so Mr Ballmer cuts a charismatic figure with his shiny bald dome and strapping physique.
fields.body:
Steve Ballmer has often been described as Bill Gates's alter ego. Whereas Mr Gates is softly spoken, Mr Ballmer's voice booms across crowded gatherings. And just as Mr Gates is intensely focused and reserved, so Mr Ballmer cuts a charismatic figure with his shiny bald dome and strapping physique.

The son of a Ford executive, he has travelled a long way since his upbringing in a Detroit suburb. A close friend of Mr Gates from their days at Harvard, Mr Ballmer joined Microsoft five years after it was founded. He has since run its finance, recruiting and sales operations, amassing a fortune that Forbes magazine says makes him the fourth-richest American, mostly from his nearly 5% stake in Microsoft.

Having graduated with a degree in applied mathematics and economics, Mr Ballmer joined Procter & Gamble - considered a tough finishing school. He left the firm to go to Stanford business school, but dropped out to join Microsoft.

fields.headline: Hunger strike at Unesco
fields.standfirst: The UN body's new broom has whipped up a storm, but remains set on his reforms
fields.trailText: Unesco's new director-general has embarked on the Herculean task of reforming the bloated and notoriously inefficient body he inherited from his predecessor - and not everyone seems to appreciate his efforts.
fields.body:
Unesco's new director-general has embarked on the Herculean task of reforming the bloated and notoriously inefficient body he inherited from his predecessor - and not everyone seems to appreciate his efforts.

Two employees at the UN's much-criticised educational, scientific and cultural organisation have gone on hunger strike in protest at the alleged heavy-handedness of Koichiro Matsuura, the Japanese career diplomat confirmed as director-general last November.

"When people try to restore order there is a real chance you get authoritarian rule, not to say dictatorial rule," said one of the hunger strikers, Bruno de Padirac. "Let us say that Matsuura's time in office has not started well."

Mr De Padirac is one of 71 people promoted by the former director-general, Federico Mayor, in the final month of his mandate. Mr Mayor also made 27 new appointments in the same period, most of them - like the promotions - in breach of Unesco's rules, at a cost of $11.8m (£7.4m) to its $800m total biennial budget.

Mr Matsuura, who has vowed to transform Unesco into an efficient and transparent organisation, has suspended all of Mr Mayor's last-minute promotions and appointments, including Mr De Padirac's, pending an examination by a task force.

The second hunger striker, Brenda Runghen, a Canadian, is among 16 employees whose temporary contracts were not renewed.

A devastating independent audit obtained by the Guardian last year said that nearly half of Unesco's appointments and promotions - many the result of crude nepotism - did not come anywhere near meeting the organisation's own criteria for fair and open competition.

It condemned the UN body's practice of appointing legions of ill-defined consultants and special advisers, and said that many Unesco activities were inadequately planned and insufficiently monitored. It highlighted numerous examples of incompetence and mismanagement within its secretariat.

In an interview, Mr Matsuura defended his reforms and said he had expected that some of his moves would be unpopular.

"Unesco's internal oversight has not been strong. The organisation has to have guidelines, and they have to be observed," he said. "It is inevitable that some people who are adversely affected will criticise me."

Among his other early moves, Mr Matsuura said that he had terminated the contracts of 20 special advisers and senior special advisers who were hired by Mr Mayor.

"I targeted them because they formed a small circle of advisers around the director general who were taking decisions that should have been taken by the full secretariat," he said.

He has also asked for a full audit of one of Unesco's most controversial funds, the $40m Participation Programme, and removed the programme's director. Mr Matsuura said that Unesco programmes, often criticised as vague, utopian and wasteful, should be concentrated in those areas where the organisation had a strong advantage compared to other international bodies.

"We have to think very hard to have better coordination, to avoid duplication," he said. "Our activities have been far too thinly spread."

He said the organisation's priority areas under his administration would be basic education, particularly literacy programmes, science and ethics, and, in the age of the internet, communication and ethics.

"We organise big international conferences and adopt big, important declarations, and then sit back," he said. "That's not enough. There must be a properly organised follow-up to ensure something actually gets done. Unesco tends to place more emphasis on organisation than implementation."

He was particularly critical of one of Mr Mayor's pet projects, the vast and ill-defined Culture for Peace programme. "Talking in general terms about a culture of peace is not enough," he said.

"We have to move on to concrete action. For example, taking the lead in organising dialogue on political issues that could lead to greater cooperation in the political arena. It's no good just saying, 'Peace is good, we need a culture of peace.' Everyone knows that already."

Despite staff protests, Mr Matsuura said that he intended to carry out his reforms with the cooperation of the 2,500 employees at Unesco's headquarters. The organisation's information director, Helene Gosselin, said it was "sad that two individuals should take such an extreme step without exhausting all the negotiating possibilities".

In a letter to the staff yesterday, Mr Matsuura appealed to reason, saying that while all periods of transition generated anxiety, it was imperative that Unesco "rubbed out the debts of the past".

He said that he regretted the "totally irresponsible attitide" of the two hunger strikers, and described their claim to be defending justice and democracy as fallacious.

webTitle: Turkish villagers mobilise against nuclear plant plan

fields.headline: Turkish villagers mobilise against nuclear plant plan
fields.trailText: Akkuyu bay is where Turkey wants to build its first nuclear power plant. Local people estimate that 80% of them are opposed to the plan.
fields.body:
"Who's going to want to buy these?", asked Mehmet Bey as he reached out to pluck lemons from a row of trees heavy with the fruit. "Once people know they come from the nuclear village, they'll look elsewhere."

Buyukeceli nestles in a valley on a remote stretch of Turkey's Mediterranean coast. Apart from the occasional lorry which rumbles through from Syria on its way to Ankara and Istanbul, nothing much disturbs the peace. But just beyond the wooded hill above the village is a compound surrounded by barbed wire.

Akkuyu bay is where Turkey wants to build its first nuclear power plant.

Local people estimate that 80% of them are opposed to the plan. Some of the opposition seems to be based on a misunderstanding of how a nuclear plant operates. There is a fear that there will be automatic contamination of the surrounding area, and that tourists will stay away.

The main concern though is the possibility that there could be a terrible accident. If there is one subject on which everyone in Turkey can claim to have some knowledge, it is shattered buildings and crumpled concrete. The damage caused by the two massive earthquakes which killed nearly 20,000 people last year has left a deep scar.

People believe it could happen again. "The earthquakes affected everyone here", said Ummet Buyuk, Buyukeceli's mayor. "There's a fault line close to Akkuyu, and are all really nervous about it. That's why we don't want this plant."

Turkey's nuclear lobby, which is backed by powerful business interests,claim that their opponents are spreading scare stories. They point out that the plan to build a nuclear plant in Akkuyu was proposed more than 30 years ago, and say exhaustive studies of the site have been carried out. "It is probably the most geologically stable region in Turkey," said Lutfi Sarici, director of the nuclear programme.

Environmental activists disagree. They say one particular fault line is a cause for concern, and that building a nuclear plant anywhere in a country prone to earthquakes is deeply irresponsible. Many Turks are already worried about the safety of former Soviet reactors in Bulgaria and Armenia. But Mr Sarici insisted that the comparison was meaningless. "The plant we build will be one of the most modern designs in the world," he said. "It will have the highest safety standards."

But his soothing words have failed to quell the concern. Neighbouring countries, especially Cyprus, are nervous and have appealed for a rethink.

Undaunted, three international consortiums are bidding for the contract. They ex pected to hear who had won the tender at the end of last month, but at the last moment the government delayed the announcement.

Anti-nuclear campaigners claim the delay is a sign that the government may be wavering. They believe that the prime minister, Bulent Ecevit, has misgivings, but both his coalition partners and President Suleyman Demirel are strongly in favour of the nuclear strategy.

Environmental groups accept that Turkey will face a dramatic increase in the demand for domestic and industrial power over the next few years, but argue that nuclear power is not the answer at a time when other European countries are beginning to decommission their plants.

Greenpeace Mediterranean says that Turkey should invest heavily in alternative sources, such as solar and wind power, and should spend much more time reducing energy losses in its grossly inefficient system.

"There is no need for a nuclear plant," Melda Keskin, a Greenpeace spokeswoman, said. "Because of safety issues it's not competitive any more. It's just a waste of money and it could be dangerous. Why take the risk?"

webTitle: Death in pursuit of the American dream

fields.headline: Death in pursuit of the American dream
fields.standfirst: US officials are stunned by the surge of illegal immigrants from China, three of whom lost their lives this week in a ship's cargo container
fields.trailText: US officials are stunned by the surge of illegal immigrants from China, three of whom lost their lives this week in a ship's cargo container
fields.byline: Duncan Campbell in Los Angeles and John Gittings in Hong Kong
fields.body:
For two weeks they had been living on a diet of rotting vegetables, using a bucket as a lavatory and lying entombed in vomit in the darkness of a ship's container as they set sail for the brave new world. And for three seekers of the American dream, the result this week was a slow and painful death on the high seas.

China may have got the green light to join the World Trade Organisation to secure a larger market for their goods but, for the past two months, its most publicised export to the west has been human beings.

Immigration officials on the North American coast from Long Beach, California, to Vancouver, Canada, have been stunned by the extent of the recent human smuggling explosion. In the past two months, they have seized eight container-loads of Chinese stowaways, including the tragic cargo on board the Cape May at Seattle this week. Between 4,000 and 5,000 Chinese are now attempting to enter the US illegally every year.

"They have an image of America, of the American dream," said Anna Ip of China Outreach in Los Angeles. "They have heard that everything is so good, everyone is so well off. But they only have half the picture."

Many of the would-be immigrants, she said, had little idea of what awaited them when they signed on with the smugglers in their home province of Fujian, on the south coast of China.

The stowaways from Fujian believe in the popular local saying that "one person goes abroad; the whole family makes money".

Tales of untold wealth

The "snakeheads" who organise the trips beguile them with stories of untold wealth in the US. And in Fujian's villages they can see the evidence: families with a member abroad have tiled balconies, walled patios and satellite television, those who do not often live in relative squalor.

The stowaways will pay around 6,000 renminbi (£440), a year's wages, as a down payment and will agree to pay back a further fee of between $30,000 to $60,000 in indentured labour on their arrival.

"Those who organise for them to come over get them to work in sweatshops to pay off those fees," said Ms Ip. She said that even when they have paid off their fare, stowaways face problems finding legal work. "They may try to get a fake green card from downtown or work in restaurants as black market labour," she said.

Rumours sweep the villages about the best destinations. There was a brief vogue for Guam as a good stepping stone to the US and currently there is the belief that Australia would be a good choice because it is thought everyone is guaranteed a job at this year's Sydney Olympics.

Last week, Xinhua, China's official news agency, reported the repatriation of 246 stowaways from the US to Fujian's provincial capital, Fuzhou, but there has been little coverage of the human interest side of the story, merely reports of tough actions taken against would-be migrants.

Increased penalties

China's public security ministry said that 2,975 defectors had been arrested attempting to leave the mainland in the first four months of last year. An increase in penalties for such attempts has also been announced and official slogans painted on the walls call on local authorities to "crack down on illegal emigration".

The three deaths on the Cape May are the first the US immigration and naturalisation nervice (INS) knows of, but it accepts that others may have happened; the traffic shows little sign of abating.

The day after the fatal discovery, 19 more young men were found aboard the Hanjin Yokohama, which had sailed, as the Cape May had, from Hong Kong.

The conditions for the journey vary. The 18 Cape May stowaways - 15 survivors are being treated in Seattle - shared a space 12 metres (40ft) long by 2 metres (7ft) wide, and their only light came from torches.

The three who died are thought to have perished at least three days before they reached the shore, probably from dehydration. They had to wait for a number of days before being loaded on to the ship that left Hong Kong, and endured a very rough crossing during which many of them vomited frequently. This would have made them more vulnerable to dehydration when their water ran out.

Some containers have holes punched in their tarpaulin tops for air and may even have furniture and lighting, but immigration officials are on the lookout.

Virginia Kice of the INS said that the first discovery of a container smuggling humans was in April 1998 and there has been a steady increase since. She said that pictures of stowaways arriving neatly dressed and with mobile phones were misleading: "The ones who died were in a container under four others. They were virtually entombed."

Immigration officials who had received a tip-off from Hong Kong had to shift 35 containers to find the Cape May stowaways. Some freighters can carry as many as 5,000 containers, making the search for human beings almost impossible even with the use of well-trained sniffer dogs.

Those fortunate enough to reach the US shore are entitled to an asylum hearing.

"Many of them have been coached and they know the kind of things to say," said Ms Kice. "But we want to err on the side of caution because we have a human rights tradition in this country."

The Hong Kong government has promised to try to crack down on the human smuggling trade. They have tipped off immigration officials in the US and Canada when they have information of container-loads of stowaways, although the amount of container traffic from the port is enormous: around 15m containers moved over its cranes last year.

Yesterday, under the afternoon sun in Long Beach, hundreds of containers from China were being unloaded. Near by, as if as a reminder to aspiring stowaways, is Terminal Island, where illegal immigrants are held when they are caught.

Immigration officials are on high alert now for the new cargo and 143 have been found in the past year at the twin ports of Long Beach and Los Angeles.

However, some arrivals from China will always be welcome. Legislation passed in 1991 granted legal immigrants status to any foreigner prepared to invest $1m in a business that would create full-time jobs, and hundreds of Chinese immigrants from Hong Kong have taken advantage of this.

However, their arrival tends to be in a first-class cabin rather than lying starving in darkness beside a dying friend.

webTitle: Belgium accused of killing African hero

fields.headline: Belgium accused of killing African hero
fields.standfirst: Author urges parliamentary commission to quiz those involved in Patrice Lumumba's murder
fields.trailText: Evidence of direct Belgian government complicity in the execution of the Congolese leader Patrice Lumumba must be made public and those implicated questioned, a historian demanded yesterday.
fields.body:
Evidence of direct Belgian government complicity in the execution of the Congolese leader Patrice Lumumba must be made public and those implicated questioned, a historian demanded yesterday.

Lugo de Witte, a Flemish expert on Africa, called for a parliamentary commission of inquiry to hear testimony under oath from former officials involved in the 1961 killing of one of Africa's most charismatic post-colonial leaders.

His 400-page book, just published in French, throws new light on one of the darkest chapters in Belgium's long and rapacious relationship with Congo, and establishes clear state responsibility for a brutal political murder.

Lumumba - popular, articulate and a hero of the anti-colonial struggle - was just 36 when he became the first prime minister of the inde pendent Congo in June 1960.

But within a month a civil war erupted, provoked by the attempted secession of the copper-rich Katanga province, led by Moise Tshombe. Tshombe recruited Belgian, French and South African mercenaries to fight the government. United Nations forces intervened in the biggest peacekeeping operation the UN had mounted since being founded, but they did little more than maintain the status quo.

Lumumba was deposed and an unknown colonel called Joseph-Desire Mobutu took control of country, which he renamed Zaire, and remained a faithful friend of the west until his overthrow in May 1997.

The United States saw the militant nationalist Lumumba as a communist sympathiser; CIA involvement in plans to kill him has been long established by senate hearings and declassified documents.

But Mr De Witte's research showed that by the time Lumumba was killed Washington had little ability to operate on the ground in Congo and had given way to Brussels. "Belgian officers had direct resposibility for his assassination," he insisted yesterday.

A document signed by the then Belgian minister for Africa, Harold Aspremont Lynden, in October 1960, said explicitly: "The main objective to pursue, in the interests of the Congo, Katanga and Belgium, is clearly the final elimination of Lumumba."

On January 17 1961, Lumumba, under arrest by Mobutu's forces, was transferred to Katanga on a Sabena plane on the orders of Aspremont Lynden and the Belgian foreign minister, Pierre Wigny.

He was assaulted in the presence of Belgian officers and tortured in a villa guarded by Belgian troops, before being shot by an execution squad supervised by a Belgian captain. His body was exhumed by a Belgian police commissioner, Gerard Soete, and dissolved in acid.

In a macabre twist, Mr Soete admitted on Belgian television last year that he had kept two of the victim's teeth, prompting calls for their return to Congo. But he insisted he had later thrown them into the North Sea.

Much is now known about this 40-year-old mystery, but crucial information remains buried in Belgian government files, including the records of a secret Congo committee which met under the chairmanship of then prime minister, Gaston Eyskens.

Last month the government approved the creation of a parliamentary commission to investigate the episode, but its precise terms of reference have yet to be decided.

"Any inquiry must have the power to conduct new research," Mr De Witte said. "It is often assumed that the Belgian officials involved in the affair are dead, but that is not so. These people must be questioned under oath, and if that can be done there will be many more revelations."

After his death Lumumba became a powerful symbol of the anti-colonial struggle. A university named after him was established in Moscow and became a magnet for students from the third world.

In his political testament, written in jail shortly before he was killed, he reflected: "One day history will have its say, but it will not be the history they teach at the UN, in Washington, Paris or Brussels, but the history they teach in countries freed from colonialism and its puppets.

"Africa will write its own history, and it will be one of glory and dignity."

 L'Assassinat de Lumumba, Ludo de Witte, editions Karthala Paris

The United States saw the militant nationalist Lumumba as a communist sympathiser; CIA involvement in plans to kill him has been long established by senate hearings and declassified documents. But Mr De Witte's research showed that by the time Lumumba was killed Washington had little ability to operate on the ground in Congo and had given way to Brussels. "Belgian officers had direct resposibility for his assassination," he insisted yesterday. A document signed by the then Belgian minister for Africa, Harold Aspremont Lynden, in October 1960, said explicitly: "The main objective to pursue, in the interests of the Congo, Katanga and Belgium, is clearly the final elimination of Lumumba." On January 17 1961, Lumumba, under arrest by Mobutu's forces, was transferred to Katanga on a Sabena plane on the orders of Aspremont Lynden and the Belgian foreign minister, Pierre Wigny. He was assaulted in the presence of Belgian officers and tortured in a villa guarded by Belgian troops, before being shot by an execution squad supervised by a Belgian captain. His body was exhumed by a Belgian police commissioner, Gerard Soete, and dissolved in acid. In a macabre twist, Mr Soete admitted on Belgian television last year that he had kept two of the victim's teeth, prompting calls for their return to Congo. But he insisted he had later thrown them into the North Sea. Much is now known about this 40-year-old mystery, but crucial information remains buried in Belgian government files, including the records of a secret Congo committee which met under the chairmanship of then prime minister, Gaston Eyskens. Last month the government approved the creation of a parliamentary commission to investigate the episode, but its precise terms of reference have yet to be decided. "Any inquiry must have the power to conduct new research," Mr De Witte said. "It is often assumed that the Belgian officials involved in the affair are dead, but that is not so. These people must be questioned under oath, and if that can be done there will be many more revelations." After his death Lumumba became a powerful symbol of the anti-colonial struggle. A university named after him was established in Moscow and became a magnet for students from the third world. In his political testament, written in jail shortly before he was killed, he reflected: "One day history will have its say, but it will not be the history they teach at the UN, in Washington, Paris or Brussels, but the history they teach in countries freed from colonialism and its puppets. "Africa will write its own history, and it will be one of glory and dignity."  L'Assassinat de Lumumba, Ludo de Witte, editions Karthala Paris

fields.headline: Malaysian politicians held
fields.trailText: Two prominent supporters of Malaysia's jailed former deputy prime minister, Anwar Ibrahim,and his lawyer were charged yesterday in a move against opposition politicians.
fields.byline: K. Baranee Krishnaan in Kuala Lumpur
fields.body:
Two prominent supporters of Malaysia's jailed former deputy prime minister, Anwar Ibrahim,and his lawyer were charged yesterday in a move against opposition politicians.

The lawyer, Karpal Singh, who is also a former MP, was charged with making seditious remarks while defending Mr Anwar in court. He had accused "people in high places" of trying to poison Mr Anwar.

Marina Yusoff, vice-president of the opposition Keadilan (National Justice) party, was said to have accused the United Malays organisation, the party of the prime minister, Mahathir Mohamad, of triggering race riots in 1969.

Mohamed Ezam Mohamed Nor, Mr Anwar's former top political aide, faces a charge of violating Malaysia's official secrets acts for releasing classified documents to reporters.

Prosecutors said that Mr Karpal and Ms Marina could be jailed for up to three years, while Mr Ezam faced up to seven years. All three pleaded not guilty and were given bail.

Mr Anwar was instrumental in gains won by the Barisan Alternativ (BA), the opposition alliance which includes the Keadilan, in last November's general election.

"The BA will not tolerate our leaders being victimised as the scapegoat of the ruling parties' internal problems," said Chua Tian Chan, another Keadilan vice-president.

"We call upon all people to act in their individual and collective capacity to protest such injustice and inhumanity."

He threatened a "nationwide mass mobilisation to defend our rights" if the situation got worse.

Mr Anwar's sacking from government in 1998 and subsequent arrest and indictment on sex and corruption charges led to unprecedented street protests against Mr Mahathir.

The editor and printer of the newspaper of the Parti Islam SeMalaysia (PAS), Harakah, have also been arrested and pleaded not guilty to sedition charges on Thursday.

The deputy prime minister, Abdullah Ahmad Badawi, is in charge while Mr Mahathir is in Argentina on holiday. Reuters

fields.headline: International news in brief
fields.trailText: Russia retracts Chechen ban
fields.body:
Russia retracts Chechen ban

The Russian military has reversed its border ban against Chechen males aged 10 to 60 on the eve of its second wave of house-to-house searches aimed at rooting out rebel fighters in Chechnya

The ban was on "fighting-age" males, but it had been criticised by the UN and the head of neighbouring Ingushetia. "We have received the order to let them through," said an Ingushi policeman at the border crossing with Chechnya. Reuters, Nazran, Russia

Jail urged for illegal loggers

The Cambodian prime minister, Hun Sen, yesterday publicly accused government officials of involvement in illegal logging, calling for them to be charged with treason.

He accused officials in the north-east province of Mondulkiri of aiding the illegal export of 1,600 logs to Vietnam in November and December. "Handcuff them and throw them in jail," he said. "No one should be forgiven." AP, Phnom Penh

Aid workers slain in Sudan

Eight aid workers have been killed in southern Sudan after their vehicle was set on fire, apparently by rebels from Uganda, a Norwegian relief group said yesterday.

"There were 11 people in the vehicle and seven died immediately, while another died this morning," Norwegian Church Aid said in a statement. It added that rebels of the Lord's Resistance Army were believed to have carried out the attack. Reuters, Oslo

Hizbullah frees allies of Israel

Hizbullah guerrillas freed two pro-Israeli militiamen yesterday, one day after Israel and its allied militia released 27 Lebanese guerrilla suspects.

However, there was no let up in the fighting between the two sides. Israeli warplanes raided suspected guerrilla hideouts in southern Lebanon, in response to an attack by pro-Iranian Hizbullah guerrillas against an outpost near Sidon manned by Israeli troops and their South Lebanon Army allies. AP, Beirut

webTitle: Chile bowled over by God's technocrat

fields.headline: Chile bowled over by God's technocrat
fields.standfirst: A rightwing economist with powerful backers looks a surprise winner in tomorrow's presidential poll
fields.trailText: A rightwing economist with powerful backers looks a surprise winner in tomorrow's presidential poll
fields.body:
A little known mayor has transformed Chilean politics in just six months and positioned himself as the candidate to beat in tomorrow's closely contested presidential election.

Joaquin Lavin, 46, an economist and author, is a long-time supporter and collaborator of the Pinochet regime which ruled Chile from 1973 to 1990. But more important to most Chileans, he is an alternative to the ruling Christian Democratic government.

In a shrewd move, Mr Lavin has ignored discussion of the need to "restore democracy" in Chile, or whether Augusto Pinochet should be tried in Spain on torture charges stemming from his military dictatorship in the 70s.

Instead, his focus has been on things like fixing streets, cracking down on crime and integrating remote provinces into the Chilean government.

"There has been a campaign of terror and lies against me," Mr Lavin told a euphoric crowd in his final campaign speech on Thursday night. "This is an effort to stop my social programmes."

In the campaign's final stretch, Mr Lavin has demonstrated an apparently inexhaustible reservoir of personal energy - and of funding. In the past 10 days he has visited 81 Chilean cities by organising a network of commercial jets, private helicopters and four-wheel drive vehicles.

Even in far-flung villages, Lavin campaign propaganda appears on lamp posts, fishing boats and bus stops. "When he started this campaign some of the traditional right thought Joaquin was a strange bird with no chance to win," said one of the candidate's main strategists, German Concha, 31. "But the people who work with him know he can win, he is like the Energizer Bunny."

In the first round presidential vote held last December, Mr Lavin polled 47%, surpassing all expectations.

Many political commentators had predicted that the Socialists' candidate, Ricardo Lagos - from the governing coalition known as the Concertacion - would cruise to victory in that first round. Now Mr Lavin has succeeded in defining himself as the candidate promoting "change", and Mr Lagos is scrambling to catch up.

"Chile has a tradition of politicians who stand on a balcony and address the masses below," said Mr Concha of the Lavin campaign. "The citizens were used to being kept apart from their leaders, now Mr Lavin has changed that. He's down with them in the streets."

Given Chileans' miserable salaries and the fact that their country has the second worst income distribution in Latin America (only Brazil is worse), such tactics are powerful.

Should Mr Lavin win, he would be the first rightwing president elected since the 1950s. But regardless of which candidate wins, Chilean politics has been altered.

Mr Lavin's technocratic style is in line with the approaches of other Latin American leaders who have shunned the dogma of traditional parties and talked instead about the dull but serious problems of Latin America's inadequate infrastructure.

Critics like to compare Mr Lavin to President Alberto Fujimori of Peru, but a more accurate model would be Venezuela's wildly popular commando president Hugo Chavez.

Like Mr Chavez, Mr Lavin oozes energy while he derides his opponents as corrupt and inefficient. "They had their chance," he says of the current coalition's 10 years in power. His election platform blends populist Mr Fixit solutions and conservative social stands.

In person, Mr Lavin projects the image of an easy-going executive, a nerdy but effective administrator. His pretty wife Estella and some of his seven children joined him on parts of the campaign trail, and for various rallies he hired a pop star, Miriam Hernandez.

At the last campaign event, Hernandez and Mr Lavin sang "The Force of Love", creating the aura of a religious revival.

As a member of the ultra conservative Catholic group Opus Dei, Mr Lavin has the backing of the Roman Catholic church in Chile and numerous business executives who share his moral stands. He campaigned against legalising divorce, which his staff described as "an attack against the innocent third-party victims [children] and the family." His TV ad used images of choirs intercut with scenes of him leaving a rustic church.

"Mr Lavin has a special responsibility to do his work with Christian perfection and united with God," said Francisco Javier Silva, the spokesman for Opus Dei in Chile. Although there are only 5,000 Chilean members, the group includes powerful business leaders - the men who have financed and pushed Mr Lavin as the ideal president for their extreme free-market platform.

webTitle: Mexican pop icon arrested in Copacabana

fields.headline: Mexican pop icon arrested in Copacabana
fields.trailText: A bedsit in a shabby beige building one block from Copacabana beach staged the humiliating final chapter of the scandalous career of Gloria Trevi, Mexico's most famous pop star.
fields.byline: Alex Bellos in Rio de Janeiro
fields.body:
A bedsit in a shabby beige building one block from Copacabana beach staged the humiliating final chapter of the scandalous career of Gloria Trevi, Mexico's most famous pop star.

On the run for more than a year, charged along with her manager, Sergio Andrade, of corrupting young girls as part of an itinerant sex cult, the couple were arrested with another woman, Maria Portillo, in the Rio flat late on Thursday.

Trevi, known as the "Mexican Madonna" for her sexually provocative stage persona, disappeared in 1998 shortly before allegations surfaced that, along with Andrade, she kidnapped and sexually enslaved young singers.

Interpol last year issued an international search warrant, which raised the stakes in a scandal that had burned hot for months in Central America, exposing a darker side of the Latin entertainment industry.

Trevi, Andrade and Portillo are being held in custody as Mexico begins extradition proceedings against them for the corruption of minors, aggravated rape and kidnapping. The three deny the charges.

Brazilian police said they were asked by Mexico to investigate the singer when The Guardian published a story in September last year that she might have fled to Brazil.

Police discovered that Trevi and her entourage had moved to Copacabana in December. She was tracked down when she renewed her tourist visa under her own name.

According to neighbours, four women moved into the fourth-floor flat on Domingos Ferreira Street shortly before New Year's Eve. They brought with them guitars, keyboards and a sound system, although the flat was always quiet.

"When they arrived, I thought they were a bunch of dirty hippies," says Severino Ramos, the porter of the building next door."They had long, unkempt hair and wore T-shirts, ripped jean shorts and flip-flops. It looked like they had been living on the street. Everything about them was horrible."

In the flat next door, guitarist Claudio Bedran was surprised to hear of his neighbours' notoriety. "They were quiet and minded their own business. If only I knew they were musicians. We had something in common!"

The Rio bedsit is a world away from the life she was living before her fall from grace. Her first three albums sold more than 5m copies in the early 90s. Her image as a rebellious and sexually confident woman was popular with teeny-boppers and with intellectuals who respected her playful challenges to Mexico's Catholic mores.

The first charges against Trevi came from the parents of Karina Yapor, one of her and Andrade's protegees, who alleged that Andrade had kidnapped their daughter and fathered her baby by force.

webTitle: Germans in song and dance over snowberry bush

fields.headline: Germans in song and dance over snowberry bush
fields.trailText: A row between neighbours in a small east German town has spiralled into a media tragi-comedy of insane proportions. Regine Zindler's objections to a snowberry bush have so far inspired a number one hit, made her rich, driven her abroad, and set off a battle between TV companies.
fields.body:
A row between neighbours in a small east German town has spiralled into a media tragi-comedy of insane proportions. Regine Zindler's objections to a snowberry bush have so far inspired a number one hit, made her rich, driven her abroad, and set off a battle between TV companies.

The farce began last October when Mrs Zindler, a 51-year-old unemployed secretary from Auerbach in Saxony, appeared on television. She featured as a plaintiff in Judge Barbara Salesch, an American-style show in which a genuine judge rules on petty disputes.

And disputes do not come much pettier than the one between Mrs Zindler and her neighbour. Gnther Ebert's bush touches her wire mesh fence and, as she indignantly told the TV court, it rusts it.

Saxon is to German roughly what Brum is to English and Mrs Zindler's rural version of the Saxon accent is as thick as it gets. It is not the ideal means for pronouncing convoluted German compound nouns.

The sight of Mrs Zindler struggling to wrap her tongue around the word for a wire mesh fence, "Maschendrahtzaun", so amused a German comedian, Steffan Raab, that he used a clip from the programme in his own TV show. He later wrote a song of which the chorus runs:

"I was the sexiest man In the whole damned town, Till I ripped my balls On the Maschendrahtzaun."

The ridicule heaped on the dispute has not yet helped to solve it. On the contrary, the mothers of the two protagonists recently came to blows.

But the song has at least brought Mrs Zindler a windfall. It went to the top of the charts at the end of November and has so far sold 800,000 copies. Mrs Zindler, who gets 10 pfennigs for every single, has received around £24,000 - a handsome sum by the standards of economically depressed rural east Germany.

But fame and fortune have come at a price. Souvenir-hunters have clipped out pieces of the mesh, a prankster has put it up for sale on the internet, and groups of Steffan Raab fans have taken to gathering near the fence to drink beer and sing increasingly slurred versions of the Maschendrahtzaun ballad.

Reports this week suggested that Mrs Zindler had been close to nervous collapse before a TV channel stepped in to help her. Network bosses assigned a security man to guard her fence and paid for Mrs Zindler, her husband and their cat to fly to Paris where the unlikely star is said to be receiving professional counselling.

The station's generosity just happens to have spiked the guns of a rival channel which had been planning a reconciliation between Mrs Zindler and Mr Ebert, to be televised from Auerbach.

fields.headline: 'Hanoi Jane' finds the Lord
fields.trailText: Conservative speculation is mounting that Jane Fonda, for 30 years a hate figure of the American right, has become a born-again Christian.
fields.body:
Conservative speculation is mounting that Jane Fonda, for 30 years a hate figure of the American right, has become a born-again Christian.

Internet and now newspaper reports claim the woman they once called "Hanoi Jane" for her embrace of the Vietnamese cause in the 1960s now regularly attends church services and Bible study.

Fonda has refused to talk to the press about her private life since the announcement earlier this month of her separation from her husband, CNN founder Ted Turner. But a friend was quoted as saying the conversion was "very real, very deep". And the pastor of the church she attends said: "I am extremely impressed with the genuineness and sincerity in her search for spirituality and wholeness."

Fonda appears to have gone from chic sex symbol, to radical anti-war icon, to workout video queen, to caring capitalist, to born-again Christian during her 62 years.

Friends of Mr Turner have said his unhappiness with her new-found Christian faith was one of the principal reasons for their separation. He has been an outspoken critic of the Christian church for many years, calling it "a religion for losers" and ridiculing the Pope.

fields.headline: 'Drug dealer' sneaks into Maradona's room
fields.trailText: A suspected drug dealer disguised as a doctor has been caught trying to sneak into the room where Argentine soccer legend Diego Maradona is recovering from cocaine abuse, his doctor said yesterday.
fields.byline: Robert Elliott of Reuters, Buenos Aires
fields.body:
A suspected drug dealer disguised as a doctor has been caught trying to sneak into the room where Argentine soccer legend Diego Maradona is recovering from cocaine abuse, his doctor said yesterday.

"Yesterday we detected the entrance of a false doctor who had a stethoscope and hospital clothing. From all the information I gathered it was a [drug] peddler," said Carlos Alvarez, a cardiologist.

The intruder escaped after being discovered by staff at the Sacred Heart clinic in Buenos Aires, where Maradona, 39, has been convalescing after collapsing in Uruguay 10 days ago, suffering from hypertension and an irregular heart beat.

"His sickness is caused by cocaine. This is like giving kilos of salt to a hypertense person so he has a cardiovascular attack," said Mr Alvarez.

This week doctors said the Argentine star, an admitted cocaine addict, had flirted with death by taking such a quantity of drugs that his heart rate was reduced to 38% of capacity.

webTitle: Army accused of killings during Venezuela's floods

fields.headline: Army accused of killings during Venezuela's floods
fields.standfirst:
More about Venezuela floods
Executions reported in the wake of Venezuela's floods
fields.trailText: In the wake of the deadly floods and mudslides that rocked Venezuela last month, human rights groups have now uncovered a series of executions and beatings allegedly carried out by the Venezuelan military in an attempt to stop widespread looting.
fields.body:
In the wake of the deadly floods and mudslides that rocked Venezuela last month, human rights groups have now uncovered a series of executions and beatings allegedly carried out by the Venezuelan military in an attempt to stop widespread looting.

Eyewitness reports from the coastal state of Vargas have been compiled by human rights groups and investigators for the Venezuelan government are now reluctantly conceding that about 60 people were killed between December 17 and 30.

According to the reports, the majority of the murders were carried out with rifles equipped with silencers, or with blunt instruments.

The use of blunt instruments is thought to have allowed the corpses to mix with the mass of mangled bodies created by the worst natural disaster in Venezuelan history.

Roger Cedeno, the state ombudsman, told a news agency: "Since December 17, we have received estimates that more than 60 people died in mass executions."

He said that various branches of the armed forces were involved in "grave excesses", and added that "the worst were committed by the army's soldiers".

The issue is particularly delicate as the Venezuelan president, Hugo Chavez, a former paratrooper who has been involved in more than one military uprising, is reluctant to criticise any of his former colleagues.

When the respected Venezuelan human rights group, Provea (Venezuelan Programme for Action on Human Rights), first made the allegations in early January, Mr Chavez lambasted the group as "irresponsible and superficial".

Since then, however, Mr Chavez has been forced to back down, especially after the Catholic church weighed in with the opinion that Provea was a "credible organisation" and called for an investigation of the charges.

The foreign minister, Jose Vicente Rangel, later conceded: "I think [Provea's charges] should be investigated - if there are human rights violations, they should be punished with the full weight of the law."

General Francisco Rangel, Mr Chavez's chief of staff, met human rights groups at the presidential palace on Monday and, in a token gesture, the Venezuelan newspaper El Nacional reported this week that Mr Chavez had expelled three soldiers from the national guard on charges that they had participated, not in executions, but looting.

"I will not lower my head" before the human rights issues, Mr Chavez said, while still insisting that thus far there was "nothing that can be considered proof" of the military's involvement in the alleged executions.

It is estimated that 10,000 to 20,000 people died in last month's torrential rains and the subsequent mudslides that devastated the capital Caracas and Vargas state, the regions worst hit by the floods.

webTitle: I had that killer dentist in the front of my cab

fields.headline: I had that killer dentist in the front of my cab
fields.trailText: The 'Capital Letters' column: This week, the view from a Moscow taxi
fields.body:
Misha's opening gambit was mildly disarming. "See you've got problems with your teeth," he grinned as I joined him in his battered old Lada which served as a taxi.

My cabbie turned out to be an out-of-work dentist, and I couldn't quarrel with his diagnosis. But his next revelation was more worrying.

"Just got out of jail, five years for armed robbery. Terrible in there. Dying like flies. Do you speak Italian? I taught myself Italian in jail."

Turned out that Misha was warm and generous. In short, a typical Muscovite following the new rules of the road which decree that if you've got a car, you've got a taxi.

On the mad, bad roads of Moscow, there's no point taking a registered taxi. Back in communist times, the city's taxis were state-owned, all 2,000 of them. Just 150 of them still are; the rest have been "privatised"' and then rented out to the drivers.

But since the rouble went through the floor 18 months ago, destroying savings overnight, thousands of males have taken to cruising Moscow, picking up fares in an attempt to make ends meet. Two dollars will take you halfway across the city. Two seconds by the side of the road will get you a cab.

An ambulance stopped for me the other day. A police car the week before.

Alyosha, a charming champion Dagestani kick-boxer, picked me up at 2am, eager to reminisce about his glory days competing in Miami and Melbourne. "Ever been to New York? What a place."

Or Sergei, burly in a sheepskin, eking out his pension of £17 a month after 28 years as an Aeroflot pilot.

Or Sasha, a police captain with a wife and baby to support. He drives all night and sleeps all day at the police station, where he earns £30 a month. "On a good night, I can make that," he said.

Like cabbies everywhere perhaps, there's not a driver in Moscow without a ready recipe for putting Russia to rights. "Know what's wrong with this country?" roared Sergei. "There's not a single Russian in the Russian government. They're all Jews and cosmopolitans."

This was the day before Boris Yeltsin told the Israeli president over dinner in Jerusalem that anti-Semitism in Russia was dead.

Driving in Moscow is like dodgems for grown-ups, very dangerous, thoroughly criminalised, but free of road rage since it is assumed that every Muscovite male is entitled to drive like a maniac. He loves his car. A recent poll put the car as the Moscow male's number one desire, ahead of vodka, sex, and Vladimir Putin (in that order).

Time was when the lane down the middle of the broad thoroughfares was reserved for the communist elite's Chaika and Zil limousines. They may be gone, but the perks multiply. The lane remains reserved for bigshots, these days in Mercedes, BMWs and Landcruisers, on a list of approved pampered drivers published this week by the government.

Red plates signify foreign diplomats, yellow plates identify foreigners, and endless combinations of digits and letters are deciphered by the ubiquitous traffic cops to translate into perks and "indulgences".

Special passes, papers, and flashing lights legalising driving like a madman without fear of police interference are theoretically reserved for state officials. But nouveau riche Russians snap them up from the traffic police for up to $10,000. "It just takes a bit of money and imagination," said a Moscow banker.

A gang has taken to ramming yellow-plated foreigners on the roads and then instantly extorting large sums of cash "for repairs".

The police advice to their victims? Park your car in the middle of the road and ask a passing driver for help.

 Capital Letters is a regular Saturday column rotating between Guardian writers in three of Europe's most vibrant cities: Moscow, Berlin and Rome

fields.headline: Cybersquatter beaten
fields.trailText: The World Wrestling Federation was declared the winner yesterday in the first case decided under a new global system to curb "cybersquatting" - the abuse of trademarks on the internet.
fields.body:
The World Wrestling Federation was declared the winner yesterday in the first case decided under a new global system to curb "cybersquatting" - the abuse of trademarks on the internet.

Michael Bosman of Redlands, California, was ordered to hand over to the WWF the domain name www.worldwrestlingfederation.com or see his internet registrar give it to the federation anyway.

The WWF filed its complaint with the UN's World Intellectual Property Organisation.
