webTitle: Big cat still causes a purr

fields.headline: Big cat still causes a purr
fields.standfirst: Brand values Jaguar
fields.trailText: It began in a northern seaside town, with a young entrepreneur, a £1,000 overdraft and a man making motorcycle sidecars. Today it is Formula One racing, has a showcase in Detroit in the heartland of the global automotive industry and an ambition to turn out 200,000 cars a year. Oh, and there is the small matter of its own woodland of walnut trees in the new National Forest in the Midlands.
fields.body:
It began in a northern seaside town, with a young entrepreneur, a £1,000 overdraft and a man making motorcycle sidecars. Today it is Formula One racing, has a showcase in Detroit in the heartland of the global automotive industry and an ambition to turn out 200,000 cars a year. Oh, and there is the small matter of its own woodland of walnut trees in the new National Forest in the Midlands.

Roll out Jaguar - long a by-word for British engineering chic, now owned by a company whose founder once said his customers could have any colour of car they wanted - provided it was black.

But back to Blackpool, famous for its tower but also rather less well known as the starting place for the business career of a young man in a hurry. Indeed, William Lyons was in such a hurry that the Swallow Sidecar Company was formed on his 21st birthday.

Swallow - Lyons in partnership with another William (Walmsley) - quickly took off. The break into the car business, however, had to wait until 1927 when another legend of the British motor industry, Herbert Austin, launched the Austin Seven, the baby Austin.

In a move which foreshadowed today's industry obsession with more models on fewer platforms Lyons decided his firm could build a stylish two-seater body to sit on the Austin seven chassis. The resulting Austin Seven Swallow sold for £175 and or £185 for the hard-top version.

Swallow quickly began fitting its tops to others bottoms, from the Morris Cowley to the Wolseley Hornet; then and soon moved to Coventry in the heartland of British motor manufacturing.

Three years later, in 1931, Swallow took space at the London Motor Show to unveil the company's own car (albeit with a chassis built by the Standard Motor Company) to Swallow design - the SS1. It had a low slung look and long bonnet that characterised Lyons approach to design. Four years on, and a year after Walmsley had bowed out at Swallow - Lyons introduced a brand new four-door car and, reluctantly, he allowed himself to be persuaded by the com pany's advertising agency that it should be called the Jaguar.

The rest, as they say, is history. The company emerged from the second world war with expertise in aeronautics, an understandable desire to drop the SS tag and not much by way of new model development. But within five years Jaguar - it was adopted as the corporate name in 1945 - was heading for Le Mans. In 1951 it clocked up the first of seven victories there.

It was not until the start of the next decade, however, that Jaguar launched what is arguably its most famous model, the E-type, symbolic of the playboy end of the swinging sixties.

Though the cars retained the trademark Jaguar look, behind the scenes times were changing. In 1966 Jaguar joined up with BMC and then with Leyland. By the end of 1968, Jaguar had become part of a group that included Austin, Daimler, MG, Riley, Rover, Triumph and Wolseley.

The extended BL family arrangement was not an altogether happy experience. By the time Jaguar was floated on the stock market in 1984 it had already been operating semi-autonomously within BL for some time. Though the initial post-flotation period was promising, recession and a strong pound meant that by the end of the decade Jaguar was again looking for a partner. Ford, on the look-out for a top marque, fitted the bill.

A decade on Jaguar is setting new sales records, joining Formula One where it will face old rivals like Ferrari and Mercedes, and is set to boost its model range, perhaps with its sporty F-type concept unveiled at Detroit this week and certainly with the X400, the so-called baby Jag which is due to be launched next year and which Jaguar hopes will spearhead the push to the 200,000 sales mark. It will cost more than the baby Austin.

And the woodland? The company is spending £150,000 on the development of its bit of the 200 square mile national forest. A special variety - the Jaguar walnut is being developed - as the company, along with other car makers, seeks to demonstrate environmental credentials. And in a few years time it should have a handy supply of the raw material for its dashboards, too.

Useful links

http://www.jaguarcars.com/

http://www.ford.com/

fields.headline: A Country Diary
fields.trailText: North Pembrokeshire
fields.body:
North Pembrokeshire

We have moved through downpour days of high winds; cold golden days of constant sunshine and back to rain. The ground cannot hold the water. So trudge, trudge has led the eye upwards.

One sunny day we climbed Foel Eryr to the indicator top. North, west and south the sparkling sea gave a good and just peninsular feel to our location. Then we saw two ravens soaring above the Gwaun valley, unhurried black wings against the blue sky.

However, a buzzard decided to interrupt this pleasant flight taken by two birds probably mated for life. It was a determined buzzard. The ensuing action developed into a leisurely approach and retreat until another pair of ravens appeared. The buzzard peeled off to find some other matter for a January morning.

The new year took us to Shropshire, a glorious sunny walk over the Long Mynd and another indicator. Clarity was not so good but our guided eyes moved easily over hills and valleys in England and Wales.

Returning with our friends in the dusk, we heard a scolding wren. It was high up on the side of the house. As we watched, it popped in and out of old martins' nests - the first time any of us had seen this recorded wren behaviour of roosting in deserted nests.

On our way home we spot ted two red kites soaring over woodland just east of Aberystwyth. They wheeled and turned with rushes earthwards that suddenly became boring so they used the wind to flare back into the open sky. They're so light, large and distinctive, yet still quite rare, that seeing them is always a joy.

Back home to flocks of long-tailed tits busy calling and bustling through Tycanol woods. And the mystery of wood-burning stoves: fill an iron radiator with hot water, and an iron stove with burning wood and feel the difference. Of course we all know that we heat ourselves at least twice with wood. If you go out, gather it, saw it and burn it, the warmth created is quadrupled. So is the joy.

webTitle: Showbiz values come to the City

fields.headline: Showbiz values come to the City
fields.standfirst: World markets
fields.trailText: It has been a week for displays of affection in the market. The darlings of the entertainment industry have long been accustomed to hugging and kissing in public - anyone who has watched the Oscars ceremony knows this only too well. Now, this tendency towards overtly physical contact has spread into the financial world. The latest way to convey to the market that a deal is truly wonderful is for the leading figures to share a moment of intimacy.
fields.body:
It has been a week for displays of affection in the market. The darlings of the entertainment industry have long been accustomed to hugging and kissing in public - anyone who has watched the Oscars ceremony knows this only too well. Now, this tendency towards overtly physical contact has spread into the financial world. The latest way to convey to the market that a deal is truly wonderful is for the leading figures to share a moment of intimacy.

The chief executives of Time Warner and AOL were photographed cuddling up after announcing their tie up. Chris Evans was even seen planting a smacker on his accountant after pocketing a cool £75m, when Scottish Media Group bought out Ginger Productions. Of course, if I had made £75m I might even be tempted to kiss my accountant - despite the fact that he still hasn't completed my income tax return and the January 31 deadline is getting ever closer.

Perhaps the highly paid advisers to NatWest and its potential predators, the Bank of Scotland and the Royal Bank of Scotland, should take a leaf out of the entertainment world's book.

The protagonists should have a weekend away together focusing on group hug therapy. The hostile bid situation might not end in tears after all.

The visual reinforcement of the deal could be seen as a high profile but nevertheless desperate attempt to persuade the market that the tie-ups were a great idea. However, they obscure a deeper question over content.

Just how should you value companies where the majority of their assets are some form of intangible? Intangibles cover a multitude of sins including software, research and development, brandnames, trademarks, patents, copyrights and even advertising.

This problem is not unique to media firms, of course. The same sort of problems bedevil the valuation of firms such as Coca-Cola or Kellogg's (brand name issues), or Chorion, which holds the publishing rights to Agatha Christie and Enid Blyton (copyright issues). After all, how do you place a value on Miss Marple, Hercule Poirot, Noddy and Big Ears?

Never ones to be defeated, stock analysts have come up with a multitude of complex methods for imputing the value for intangibles - frequently these techniques come under the impressive sounding umbrella of valuing "intellectual property rights". However, I am not at liberty to reveal their secrets.

Working with analysts is a little like being a member of the Magic Circle or the freemasons - those who know how to perform these masterful sleights of hand or arcane rituals are forbidden from ever revealing them to outsiders. Of course, thealternative is that I can't reveal them because I don't understand them myself - I'll let you decide.

The scale of the potential impact of an intangible upon a share price should not be underestimated. One simple way of illustrating this is to look at how the stock market treats a firm with a recognised brandname against a generic competitor.

The value of a brand can be established by looking at the market capitalisation (the value the stock market places on a firm) divided by its sales and subtracting the same ratio from a generic competitor, and multiplying by sales. The resulting number can be divided by the market capitalisation to show how much of the firms value is accounted for by its brand name.

In the case of Kellogg's the brand name accounts for over two thirds of the total value of the company. In the case of Coca-Cola, the value of the brand accounts for 80%.

It is not only at the stock level that intangibles can have dramatic effects on valuation. If research and development costs could be treated as an investment (and thus depreciated over the life of the project) rather than treated as an expense (with all the costs borne immediately) then the US market would be trading on a price-earnings multiple of only around 16x rather than the current 30x. If intangibles are a serious part of the US economy, then if investors are valuing them correctly, the natural result could be the sky high price-earnings ratios the Cassandras keep warning us about.

Only time will truly tell if the two media deals from this week will actually have true content in terms of shareholder value. However, investors at all levels need to get to grips with the realities of valuing equities in a weightless world.

The darlings of the entertainment industry have long been accustomed to hugging and kissing in public - anyone who has watched the Oscars ceremony knows this only too well. Now, this tendency towards overtly physical contact has spread into the financial world. The latest way to convey to the market that a deal is truly wonderful is for the leading figures to share a moment of intimacy. The chief executives of Time Warner and AOL were photographed cuddling up after announcing their tie up. Chris Evans was even seen planting a smacker on his accountant after pocketing a cool £75m, when Scottish Media Group bought out Ginger Productions. Of course, if I had made £75m I might even be tempted to kiss my accountant - despite the fact that he still hasn't completed my income tax return and the January 31 deadline is getting ever closer. Perhaps the highly paid advisers to NatWest and its potential predators, the Bank of Scotland and the Royal Bank of Scotland, should take a leaf out of the entertainment world's book. The protagonists should have a weekend away together focusing on group hug therapy. The hostile bid situation might not end in tears after all. fields.headline: Movers
fields.trailText: A fresh bout of merger mania in the form of the rekindled Glaxo Wellcome/SmithKline Beecham deal propelled the London market higher again yesterday, with late support coming from Wall Street as "tech" stocks roared back into fashion on Nasdaq.
fields.body:
A fresh bout of merger mania in the form of the rekindled Glaxo Wellcome/SmithKline Beecham deal propelled the London market higher again yesterday, with late support coming from Wall Street as "tech" stocks roared back into fashion on Nasdaq.

By the close in London, the FTSE 100 was showing a gain of 126.7 points at 6,658.2.

Logica ended the day at £18.54, up from £17.09, while ARM Holdings surged from £34.98 to £37.02 as investors moved back into these computing heavyweights.

Similarly, there was heavy demand for telecoms issues, putting Energis about 9% higher at £31.97 and British Telecom up 50p at £12.79.

TeleWest Communications, the cable group which is working on building up its content with the takeover of Flextech, added 29p to 369p.

But the really notable mover among media-related stocks proved to be BSkyB, closing at £12.66, up from £11.21. Dealers reported plain old speculative interest in the company after this week's AOL-Time Warner deal in the US.

Against this, Eidos resumed its decline, with another 227p sliced off the price to £36. In mid-December the shares were trading above £60.

In the banking sector, as part of the drawn-out tussle for control of NatWest , Bank of Scotland continued to whine that repeated buying by CGU of Royal Bank of Scotland's shares was influencing the price.

"What will happen to Royal Bank of Scotland's shares when CGU stops buying them?" asked BoS.

BoS calculated that CGU has spent £103m buying almost 9.6m Royal Bank shares in recent days, a third of the £300m of purchases it pledged to make under an agreement with Royal Bank.

However, Royal Bank - which yesterday revealed it had acceptances for its offer from fewer than 2% of NatWest's shareholders - lost ground yesterday to close 19p lower at £10.33 BoS fell 10p to 654p while their prey, NatWest, fell 12p to £12.12.

Among the purer mortgage lenders, some bullish figures from Standard Life Bank were said to have rattled investors in Alliance & Leicester and Woolwich , with followers again discussing shrinking margins in the sector. A&L fell 29p to 640p and Woolwich gave up 17p to 306p.

webTitle: A master of umbrellas and golden parachutes

fields.headline: A master of umbrellas and golden parachutes
fields.trailText: When Sir Peter Davis dared to appear in television adverts with his trousers rolled up, on the back of a motorbike and under umbrellas, it seemed almost certain he was heading for a fall.
fields.body:
When Sir Peter Davis dared to appear in television adverts with his trousers rolled up, on the back of a motorbike and under umbrellas, it seemed almost certain he was heading for a fall.

As the personification of the Man from the Pru, he was surely taking a chance by sticking his head above the parapet in an industry which at that time was increasingly known for misselling pensions as well as other, lower level scams.

Mr Davis arrived at the Pru with a controversial background.

He had quit the global media group Reed Elsevier after failing to be named as outright chief even though he had been instrumental in marrying the British magazine and information company with the Dutch scientific and law publisher. He left with what was then regarded as as record golden handshake in corporate UK of about £2.8m.

But his boardroom dust-up was a mere echo of an earlier fracas when he had failed to secure the top job at Sainsbury's where he had been an outstanding marketing director but the interests of the founding family meant no outsider was likely to secure the position of chief executive.

Despite that boardroom setback - and Mr Davis's involvement in the decision to buy Shaw's in the US as well as establishing the DIY business Homebase in Britain - he and his wife are still dedicated shoppers at their local branch of Sainsbury's in Stevenage.

A bon viveur as well as an opera and ballet fan, Mr Davis boasts an enviable track record in terms of share price performance.

During the 10 years in which he was marketing director, Sainsbury's enjoyed a period of supremacy in the UK grocery sector; when he was running Reed Elsevier it became a global publishing force, although it probably failed to react adequately to the impact of the internet.

As head of Prudential he has transformed a stuffy old life assurance business with a legacy of misselling into a born-again financial services contender with the addition of an internet banking operation as well as the acquisition of investment manager M&G and Scottish Amicable.

fields.headline: Telecom chief gambles salary
fields.standfirst: New move to discredit Vodafone strategy
fields.trailText: Mannesmann chief executive Klaus Esser yesterday put his salary on the line when he promised to give back half his pay if the German company remains independent and its share price fails to hit €350 by the end of 2001.
fields.body:
Mannesmann chief executive Klaus Esser yesterday put his salary on the line when he promised to give back half his pay if the German company remains independent and its share price fails to hit €350 by the end of 2001.

The telecom boss made the promise as he delivered a fierce attack on Vodafone-AirTouch's strategy in an attempt to dissuade shareholders from accepting the Anglo-American company's £85bn bid.

Mr Esser also ruled out the option of seeking a "white knight" to rescue Mannesmann and said the company is considering plans to float its internet interests separately to make their value more explicit. He added that the business could also seek a partner or acquisition in the US too.

Mr Esser reiterated claims that Mannesmann is worth €350 a share against the Vodafone offer - now worth around €285 a share - launched at the end of last year and said the management of the company would sacri fice a quarter of their salaries if the target is not reached by July 2001. If €350 is not hit by the end of next year, the senior management team will forefeit half their salaries. "This is not because we are gamblers but because we believe in the price." he said.

The nine strong management board earned €5.7m between them last year.

The shares though continued to track each other, both recording an increase of around 3%, suggesting the market believes the deal will be done. Mannesmann, which last year acquired Orange, closed at €250 and Vodafone at 316.5p.

Mr Esser said he was reluctant to spin the group's internet business off into a separately listed business but would consider doing so at the request of shareholders. He said the likely option would be to float just 20% of the division to give it a more transparent value.

Mannesmann claims its internet service provision business is the third largest in Europe with 2.6m customers.

The chief criticisms against Vodafone centered on its lack of majority control in many of its overseas subsidiaries and its resistance to the fixed line market.

"We agree that scale is important," Mr Esser said. "But scale should not be judged by small stakes and number of countries you are present in. Real scale is about controlled stakes in major markets. Fiji, Uganda, Malta and New Zealand [all Vodafone territories] are nice places for a holiday but they aren't where you earn money."

Advisers to Vodafone said they were "fairly relaxed" after publication of the 40-page defence document. Vodafone chief executive Chris Gent noted: "There is nothing new in Mannesmann's document. Once again, Mannesmann has failed to address the choice its shareholders are being asked to make. Nothing addresses the outstanding opportunities for growth that Vodafone and Mannesmann will have together."

They also dismissed criticisms that Vodafone's lack of majority control devalued many of its assets. "We have 45% of the biggest US network by some margin and to say that is immaterial is missing the point."

webTitle: OFT calls last orders for 'beer orders'

fields.headline: OFT calls last orders for 'beer orders'
fields.trailText: A shudder passed through the brewing sector last night as the office of fair trading said it would take another look at controversial regulations introduced a decade ago which limit the number of pubs big brewers can tie into their own brands.
fields.body:
A shudder passed through the brewing sector last night as the office of fair trading said it would take another look at controversial regulations introduced a decade ago which limit the number of pubs big brewers can tie into their own brands.

Although a review of the "beer orders", which were so punitive to national brewers, could be positive for the big beer firms such as Scottish & Newcastle, Bass and Whitbread the shares were largely marked down because of the uncertainty that a new government inquiry will involve.

The beer orders were introduced in an attempt to improve competition. The government felt the so-called "beer tie" meant consumers suffered a narrower choice of ales in pubs as well as higher prices.

But since the big brewers were forced to cut the size of their tied estates, beer prices have risen above the price of inflation and consumption levels have fallen. That is despite a transformation in the dynamics of the market which has seen the number of national brewers cut in half, and the largest chains of pubs fall into independent control, while many regional brewers have disappeared. The new pub chains have the buying power to negotiate big discounts with national as well as regional brewers. These price cuts have not always been passed on to consumers.

In the 10 years since the beer orders were introduced the share of pubs owned by big brewers has fallen from about 53% to only 15%.

Terms of the review will be published within the next few weeks and Sir Ian Prosser, chief executive of Bass said he welcomed the chance that the beer orders would be updated.

Camra, the campaign for real ale, gave the review a cautious welcome even though many in the industry claim the cause of real beers was undermined rather than aided by the move away from brewer-tied pubs.

webTitle: Takeover rumours that just won't lie down

fields.headline: Takeover rumours that just won't lie down
fields.standfirst: Who's in the market for a famous chain?
fields.trailText: Sainsbury used to be considered unassailable due to its 35% family shareholding, but in recent months there have been regular suggestions that the family may be willing to sell out - at the right price.
fields.body:
Sainsbury used to be considered unassailable due to its 35% family shareholding, but in recent months there have been regular suggestions that the family may be willing to sell out - at the right price.

The bulk of its shareholding is now held in a blind trust after the appointment of former chairman Lord David Sainsbury as a minister at the department of trade and industry. The trustee, solicitor Judith Portrait, could sell without reference to the minister if she thought the shares' prospects were limited. Other family members are also said to be keen to cut ties with the firm now that no members of the founding dynasty are employed as executives.

Yesterday the family and Miss Portrait confirmed their support for the new chief executive, but the takeover speculation is unlikely to go away in the short term, if only because Sir Peter Davis has a reputation as a dealmaker - but the rumours might turn to other possible links.

 Ahold: The Dutch Group Ahold is often named as a potential bidder for a UK supermarket chain. It is the eighth largest grocery retailer in Europe and the fifth largest US supermarket group, operating 3,480 stores worldwide.

It is committed to geographical expansion and generally allows acquisitions to continue to operate as stand-alone stores under their own name.

However, many analysts believe no foreign retailer is likely to risk a takeover before the outcome of the competition commission enquiry into the UK grocery business is known later this year.

 Marks & Spencer: Putting together two bad retailers does not sound like a recipe for one good one. But this idea has its fans - and there are whispers that Sainsbury's has done its own sums on the possibilities in recent months.

There are reasons why the two should consider a get together - they share the same high-quality, middle England image - although both have taken a battering in the past couple of years. Sainsbury could probably fit well into M&S food halls and the two could find huge savings by sharing a distribution network.

 Knutsford: The Knutsford group - set up by former Asda boss Archie Norman together with property developers Nick Leslau and Nigel Wray and hi-fi retailer Julian Richer - has big ambitions. The men, dubbed the "awesome foursome", intend to target an ailing retailer and use their combined expertise to turn it back into a big name. Money, they say, is no object.

Sainsbury certainly fits the bill but recently the men have said they might start with something smaller, to hone their talents before they target the really big prize. Also, could Archie Norman really take on a group whose intention would have to be to hammer his old company - Asda?

 Somerfield: Another example of two sad cases. But there is also merit in this idea. Somerfield is in even worse shape than Sainsbury. It has put its 140 big stores up for sale - and Sainsbury is known to be a bidder - in order to concentrate on being a convenience store group. At the same time Sainsbury is committed to building a huge chain of local convenience stores in the coming years.

fields.headline: Microsoft boss overlooks obvious trick
fields.standfirst: Why Gates should instigate break-up
fields.trailText: There is something sad about the fact that, when a man who has played a pivotal role in shaping the way the developed world lives and works announces he is hanging up his executive boots, the knee jerk response is "oh, yeah?" The immediate assumption is that Bill Gates' move from chief executive officer at Microsoft to the freshly-fashioned post of chief software architect has something to do with the anti-trust case and splitting the company into two or three, or the competi tive threat posed by the transposition of the internet into the wireless world, or both at the same time. The debate is about who or what this company is planning to crush, rather than the moment being used to reflect on what Mr Gates and his colleagues have created so far.
fields.body:
There is something sad about the fact that, when a man who has played a pivotal role in shaping the way the developed world lives and works announces he is hanging up his executive boots, the knee jerk response is "oh, yeah?" The immediate assumption is that Bill Gates' move from chief executive officer at Microsoft to the freshly-fashioned post of chief software architect has something to do with the anti-trust case and splitting the company into two or three, or the competi tive threat posed by the transposition of the internet into the wireless world, or both at the same time. The debate is about who or what this company is planning to crush, rather than the moment being used to reflect on what Mr Gates and his colleagues have created so far.

So what is the man up to? There is no evidence that he is attempting to do anything out of the ordinary. Mr Gates wants to see off all possible threats to Microsoft's existing business and become a leader (or even dominate) every other sector it feels it can attack successfully.

Leaving the anti-trust case aside, Microsoft is facing substantial competition, certainly the biggest threat since Jim Clark and Marc Andreessen created the Netscape web browser five years ago and added a fourth dimension to desktop computing.

On that occasion Microsoft's response was two-pronged. On the one hand, Mr Gates moved back into the software lab and marshalled the creation of a rival product, Internet Explorer. And at the same time (it was alleged during the Department of Justice hearings) Microsoft executives flew down to see Netscape and threatened to flatten the company unless Microsoft was allowed to buy a piece of the action.

So Mr Gates is now back in the lab to oversee what is being slated as Next Generation Windows Services. Microsoft is losing its grip in the operating system market and is also in serious danger of failing to get a handle on the computing at the heart of the new wave of mobile applications. It has to respond.

Although, this time around, we can safely assume that the temptation to send corporate heavies simultaneously flying round the world threatening to flatten someone has been avoided. Microsoft is, after all, still awaiting sentencing at the hands of the American state.

Unsurprisingly, the company does not want to be broken up and Steven Ballmer, Mr Gates's successor at the helm, is still labelling any attempt to do so as "absolutely reckless and irresponsible". But its attempts to avoid this have, to date, amounted to little more than a few bits of crass PR involving the Gates charitable foundation and a few software-tools-for-schools initiatives.

Microsoft and its founder are missing the obvious trick. A break-up should be welcomed and willingly instigated by the company. Then Mr Gates really could step back into the lab and leave others to recount a great source of good.

Touch of humour

Mannesmann chief executive Klaus Esser at least managed to prove one point yesterday. Despite the imprudent comments made by Vodafone-AirTouch chief executive Chris Gent in a South African cricket commentary box over Christmas, he does have a sense of humour.

Vodafone places much value on its global proposition but how valuable are Fiji, Malta or Uganda? he asked. Mannesmann would like to go to them for a holiday but would prefer to make money in Europe.

Yet Mr Esser managed to prove very little else and the market is now almost treating this as a done deal.

fields.headline: Old Mutual eyes Gerrard
fields.standfirst: £540m on the table for UK's last discount house
fields.trailText: Insurance group Old Mutual is poised to become the biggest private client fund management group in the country after it was revealed yesterday it was involved in £540m talks with Gerrard, the 150-year-old discount house.
fields.body:
Insurance group Old Mutual is poised to become the biggest private client fund management group in the country after it was revealed yesterday it was involved in £540m talks with Gerrard, the 150-year-old discount house.

South Africa's largest financial firm was bounced into announcing that it was involved in "discussions" when Gerrard's shares rose steeply to hit 670p. Gerrard's shares jumped by 72p to end at 648p, a healthy increase on the 500p with which they started the year.

Old Mutual, which was listed on the London stock exchange six months ago, has secured the backing of the 13% of shares owned by Gerrard's senior directors and arranged to retain key staff, including chief executive Mark Davies, who stand to share in a £70m windfall.

The former mutual insur ance group, which has listings in four other markets in addition to London, insisted that the acquisition was not about cost reductions, which might imply large scale job cuts, although the groups' back office operations are likely to be integrated.

Old Mutual is keen to merge Gerrard's Greig Middleton private client fund management operation with its Capel Cure Sharp business. But it will also retain the GNI futures and commodity broking outfit as well as Gerrard & King, the last remaining discount house in the UK.

Mike Levett, chairman and chief executive of Old Mutual, said it had not yet been decided whether to rename Gerrard's Greig Middleton unit or to keep it as a brand in its Capel Cure Sharp operation - which itself unites Capel Cure and Albert E Sharp.

The group intends to pay for the acquisition in cash - it is thought to have a £1bn war chest and has made no secret of its desire to buy fund management operations. It admits to being interested in buying Gartmore, the fund management arm being jettisoned by NatWest.

Eric Anstee, finance director, said the price offered for Gerrard was justified by the technology developed by the firm for executing and managing trade for private clients over the internet.

The combined business would target wealthy individuals and offer them asset management businesses in person, over the phone and via the internet.

The profits of Gerrard & King, which deals directly with the Bank of England in the money markets, fell sharply in the first six months of its financial year although the GNI broking operation achieved an improvement in profits.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Oil production curbs may stay
fields.body:
Oil production curbs may stay

Production curbs that have caused the price of oil to double over the past year could be set to continue beyond the expected March expiry date.

Oil ministers from three key Opec states met in Vienna yesterday and are expected to recommend that the production cuts should remain in place.

"It depends on the situation in the market. If conditions stay as they are we will extend [the curbs] from March," Venezuelan oil minister Ali Rodriguez said.

The prospect of continued curbs pushed the oil price to $27.28 (£16.70) a barrel in New York last night, its highest level for nine years.

Esat takeover faces challenge

Ireland's electricity supply board yesterday began legal action to block BT's planned £1.3bn acquisition of Ireland's Esat Telecom Group.

The board said the agreed bid breached the terms of its joint venture with BT in Ireland.

It said agreement prevented BT from undertaking any business in Ireland which was in competition with Ocean Communications, a subsidiary of the electricity company.

L&G breaks £500m barrier

Legal & General yesterday reported bumper new business figures which it said helped support its case for independence after the collapse of its planned takeover by NatWest last year.

The first of the big life companies to report such figures for last year, L&G, which stole a march on its rivals with low-cost "pre-stakeholder pensions", said its new business in Britain exceeded £500m of equivalent premium income, the main industry measure, for the first time in 1999. Last year L&G warned that margins were narrowing, but the group said yesterday that margins were stable. Its global EPI rose 27% to £628m. It won a record £13.1bn of new funds last year, taking the total to £104bn.

Morrison posts festive cheer

Wm Morrison, the supermarkets group, turned in a sparkling Christmas performance with sales up 19.5% in the seven weeks to January 9.

Although 4.4% of that came from new stores, the underlying 15.1% sales growth put the cut-priced grocery group towards the top of the high street performers and the company said its market share had grown to 5%.

Morrison, which will create 2,000 new jobs in the eight new shops it intends to open this year, says it is determined to resist the mania for mergers in the retail sector and intends to stay independent.

The sales figures were a record for the group and mean that revenues in the 49 weeks of the financial year to date are running at a total of 17.9% ahead of the corresponding period last year and are up by 9.6% on a like-for-like basis, which excludes the impact of new stores and extended outlets.

United News ready to deal

United News & Media said yesterday its shareholders have approved the proposed merger with independent TV company Carlton Communications and, subject to the merger becoming unconditional, the increase in and allotment of the share capital.

fields.headline: Drugs merger revived
fields.standfirst: Glaxo chief is expected to pay ultimate price if talks with SmithKline produce deal
fields.trailText: Glaxo chief is expected to pay ultimate price if talks with SmithKline produce deal
fields.body:
Sir Richard Sykes, head of GlaxoWellcome, is expected to be forced to quit by major investors once he secures the long-awaited merger with SmithKline Beecham to create the world's biggest pharmaceuticals company and Britain's biggest corporation.

A deal to create a £120bn drugs combine was signalled yesterday when both firms confirmed they were in talks. The announcement comes almost exactly two years after Glaxo and SmithKline held merger talks that fell apart because of a personality clash between the two top executives.

Now that Jan Leschly, the UK's highest-paid public company chief, has stepped down and left SmithKline in the hands of former chief operating officer Jean-Pierre Garnier the way has been opened for a no-premium merger between the two British companies. That would create a world leader in scale, but probably mean thousands of job losses.

Institutional investors said last night they were unlikely to forgive Sir Richard for scuppering the previous negotiations, thus denying them some £13bn of merger benefits.

Some of that value was added to the share prices of the two companies yesterday when SmithKline rose 53p to 847.5p and GlaxoWellcome put on 76p to end at 1,818p.

The merger talks come at a time of intense consolidation within the drugs industry. Pfizer, the world's largest pharmaceuticals company, has just succeeded in forcing Warner-Lambert into talks, breaking up that company's plans to tie the knot with American Home Products, a medicines company which had earlier held merger negotiations with SmithKline and Monsanto. It is estimated that the SmithKline/Glaxo combine could cut costs by £1.2bn a year - 8% - although the outlay for redundancies could top £1.5bn over the next three years.

Driving the industry consolidation is the trend for health services around the world to cut budgets while drugs groups are still having to spend enormous sums on research and development as well as distribution. Joining forces means they can cut costs in order to conform to government spending rules.

Although big investors welcomed the reopening of talks between Britain's two biggest drugs companies they were scathing about the fact that they had missed out on two years of cost savings because of the personality clash between Mr Leschly, a former tennis star, and Sir Richard, the bluff northern scientist.

"We thought this looked a good deal a couple of years ago and we still think so in terms of research and development, selling power, the limited overlap of the two businesses and the products," one investor said. "If anything it is more compelling now, particularly as Glaxo has been so disappointing in the interim, and we would resist anything which stood in the way.

"There is a good possibility that Sykes will be asked to go, particularly if the idea of this is to be sold to staff as a merger of equals."

A link-up between Glaxo and SmithKline would create the world's largest prescription drugs group with some 7.5% of the market. The next biggest player is Novartis and Merck with 4.2%. A merged company would be on a par with Pfizer if it manages to scoop up Warner-Lambert.

Although Sir Richard is expected to become chairman of the combined company in the short term, he is tipped to return to academic science shortly. That would leave Jean-Pierre Garnier at the helm with John Coombe and James Niedel as directors of finance and research.

A history by prescription

Glaxo was founded in 1873 as a general trading company in New Zealand by Joseph Nathan. Burroughs Wellcome & Company was established in 1880 in London by two American pharmacists.

In 1936 Sir Henry Wellcome left sole ownership of The Wellcome Foundation to a UK medical research charity, now called The Wellcome Trust. The two companies came together in 1995 when Glaxo took over Wellcome in a £9bn deal. It currently employs 59,000 people worldwide, including 13,400 in the UK In 1998 it made pre-tax profits of £2.67bn on sales of £7.98bn. Its drugs include cold-sore treatment Zovirax, asthma drug Ventolin and Aids treatments Retrovir and Epivir .

SmithKline Beecham's earnings growth has been better than GlaxoWellcome's since the original merger talks, partly thanks to the success of its new Avandia drug for diabetes. Its biggest business is prescription medicines, but the company also makes Panadol, and Aquafresh and Macleans toothpastes, and Nicorette anti-smoking patches In its last full year it made pre-tax profits of £902m against turnover of £8bn. It employs 47,000 staff worldwide, with 8,200 workers in the UK at 10 sites.

fields.headline: Curryoke night
fields.standfirst:
Balti Kings
Lyric Hammersmith,London/ touring
***
fields.trailText: Tamasha Theatre Company always comes up with bright ideas: recently they have given us East is East, a play about Indian partition and a pastiche Bollywood musical. Now they turn their attention to the cut-throat competition among Birmingham's balti restaurants, and the result is funny, lively and engaging, even if it took me (and others) time to work out who was who: programmes that fail to list characters in order of appearance are a playgoer's nightmare.
fields.body:
Tamasha Theatre Company always comes up with bright ideas: recently they have given us East is East, a play about Indian partition and a pastiche Bollywood musical. Now they turn their attention to the cut-throat competition among Birmingham's balti restaurants, and the result is funny, lively and engaging, even if it took me (and others) time to work out who was who: programmes that fail to list characters in order of appearance are a playgoer's nightmare.

Essentially this is our old friend, the work-based play. Like Wesker in The Kitchen, Sudha Bhuchar and Shaheen Khan take us behind the scenes in a restaurant to show how private dramas collide with public catering. Here, one restaurant has come up with a gimmick to beat off competition: Shahab, younger son of the ailing Punjabi proprietor, has planned a "curryoke" night - to be graced by Bollywood stars - where you fill your plate for less than a fiver. What we see is the relentless strain this places on the kitchen staff, whose private lives are coming to the boil at the same time as the 35 dishes they have to prepare.

It wasn't only the confusing cast-list that made the play initially impenetrable: too many plot-lines are hurled at us too quickly, and the dialogue is sometimes buried under the banging of pots, vats and tureens as the lamb kebabs and sheep's trotters are cooked. But we do learn that the owner's two sons are at loggerheads, that the stars may not show up, that the prima donna chef may leave and that there is sexual tension over a Bosnian Muslim girl who is fought over by two of the staff and fiercely protected by her brother.

What draws one in, however, is the play's insistent good humour. The kitchen may be a source of grumbles and grievances, but there is wit in the off-stage arrival of a pair of showbiz lookalikes who are "famous in the West Midlands" and in the owner's reverence for the fact that his establishment was once patronised by Loyd Grossman.

Food becomes a potent symbol of Asian communality: not only are there no secrets in the kitchen but the Pakistani and Indian diners are contrasted with the British, who order only "individual small ones".

Staged in the round by Kristine Landon-Smith, the show wins you over with its energy, charm and the vivacious performances of Kriss Dosanjh as the temperamental chef, Antony Zaki as the patriarchal proprietor, Zelda Tinska as a Bosnian Delilah and Indira Joshi as the widowed samosa lady still smarting over ancient wrongs.

At the Lyric Hammersmith (0181-741 2311) till February 19 and then on tour

fields.headline: Colours from a cello
fields.standfirst:
PLG's Young Artists
Purcell Room, London
***
fields.trailText: Two performances of solo Dutilleux works were the highlights of Tuesday's concerts in the week-long series by the Park Lane Group's Young Artists - which ended last night. There was scintillating drama in the dazzling colours that cellist Alice Neary created in the Trois Strophes sur le Nom de Sacher. Dutilleux's invention transforms the instrument into everything from a guitar accompanying its own serenade to a furious cannonade of snapped strings.
fields.body:
Two performances of solo Dutilleux works were the highlights of Tuesday's concerts in the week-long series by the Park Lane Group's Young Artists - which ended last night. There was scintillating drama in the dazzling colours that cellist Alice Neary created in the Trois Strophes sur le Nom de Sacher. Dutilleux's invention transforms the instrument into everything from a guitar accompanying its own serenade to a furious cannonade of snapped strings.

Waka Hasegawa's account of one of Dutilleux's piano preludes, Le Jeu des Contraires, was a keenly delineated play of opposites, as if the textures of Debussy's piano music had been fantastically enhanced. In Martin Butler's Piano Sonata, another work of strikingly contrasted moods, Hasegawa captured the souped-up syncopations of the faster sections as well as the limpid stillness of the work's reflective centre.

The sparsity of Kurtág and Holliger allowed Brigitte and Yvonne Lang to demonstrate their impressive concentration and command in a concert of violin and piano music. Adam Gorb's Violin Sonata, on the other hand, gave them the opportunity to indulge in a post-romantic wallow of Prokofiev-like violence and saccharine modality.

The eclecticism of the programmes was both their greatest asset and most obvious weakness. The Beaumont Reed Trio premiered Richard Lannoy's Fabric'n'Phrazed - the unfortunate progeny of a supposedly cutting-edge crossover of drum'n'bass and classical. Its limp, literal "fusion" amounted to no more than an anaemic dance track over-dubbed by predictable riffs from the instrumentalists.

But Luke Stoneham's Ubiquitous Hums was an effective vehicle for Matthew Sharp's polyvalent talents as cellist, singer and actor. Sharp and his accompanist, Dominic Harlan, hummed and hammed magnificently through Stoneham's repetitive, obsessive textures and games of false endings.

Showing that the quality of performance was sometimes higher than that of the music chosen, Christian Immler gave an amazingly committed account of Aribert Reimann's uncompromisingly dreary song-cycle Shine and Dark. The bitter nostalgia and pastoral evocations of Geoffrey Poole's Five Brecht Songs provided a more winning revelation of Immler's svelte baritone.
fields.bodyText: Two performances of solo Dutilleux works were the highlights of Tuesday's concerts in the week-long series by the Park Lane Group's Young Artists - which ended last night. There was scintillating drama in the dazzling colours that cellist Alice Neary created in the Trois Strophes sur le Nom de Sacher. Dutilleux's invention transforms the instrument into everything from a guitar accompanying its own serenade to a furious cannonade of snapped strings. Waka Hasegawa's account of one of Dutilleux's piano preludes, Le Jeu des Contraires, was a keenly delineated play of opposites, as if the textures of Debussy's piano music had been fantastically enhanced. In Martin Butler's Piano Sonata, another work of strikingly contrasted moods, Hasegawa captured the souped-up syncopations of the faster sections as well as the limpid stillness of the work's reflective centre. The sparsity of Kurtág and Holliger allowed Brigitte and Yvonne Lang to demonstrate their impressive concentration and command in a concert of violin and piano music. Adam Gorb's Violin Sonata, on the other hand, gave them the opportunity to indulge in a post-romantic wallow of Prokofiev-like violence and saccharine modality. The eclecticism of the programmes was both their greatest asset and most obvious weakness. The Beaumont Reed Trio premiered Richard Lannoy's Fabric'n'Phrazed - the unfortunate progeny of a supposedly cutting-edge crossover of drum'n'bass and classical. Its limp, literal "fusion" amounted to no more than an anaemic dance track over-dubbed by predictable riffs from the instrumentalists. But Luke Stoneham's Ubiquitous Hums was an effective vehicle for Matthew Sharp's polyvalent talents as cellist, singer and actor. Sharp and his accompanist, Dominic Harlan, hummed and hammed magnificently through Stoneham's repetitive, obsessive textures and games of false endings. The bitter nostalgia and pastoral evocations of Geoffrey Poole's Five Brecht Songs provided a more winning revelation of Immler's svelte baritone.

webTitle: Return of the man from the Pru

fields.headline: Return of the man from the Pru
fields.standfirst: Appointment Sir Peter Davis drafted in as Adriano axed
fields.trailText: Supermarket chain Sainsbury yesterday axed its chief executive and drafted in Sir Peter Davis, chief executive of the Prudential insurance group, in a dramatic bid to halt the slide in its fortunes.
fields.body:
Supermarket chain Sainsbury yesterday axed its chief executive and drafted in Sir Peter Davis, chief executive of the Prudential insurance group, in a dramatic bid to halt the slide in its fortunes.

Sir Peter, 58, is to pick up a guaranteed £1m in his first year as he attempts to turn around the troubled supermarket group and in future could earn up to £1.13m in pay and bonuses. He has also been awarded £8m of share options, which will pay out in 2003 if the group meets its targets.

The Pru's chief executive, who was on the verge of stepping down to a part-time role as chairman at the insurer, admitted the potential cash rewards had been a big incentive to take the job. "They made it attractive," he said.

The new job means Sir Peter is finally achieving an old ambition. He worked for Sainsbury for 10 years between 1976 and 1986 and was its first marketing director, but he quit when it became clear he was not going to be made chief executive. At the time the business was still run by the Sainsbury family, but yesterday they made it clear they supported the appointment.

"There's a bit of completing the circle here," said Sir Peter yesterday. "I have an affinity with the company."

He said he thought it was "unrealistic" to set a target of returning Sainsbury to its former position as the number one British grocery chain, but added: "I want to make shopping at Sainsbury a pleasure again. The staff have been battered in recent years and I want people to be proud to work here once again."

In corporate terms, Sainsbury's is a far smaller job than Prudential. The insurance firm is valued at £21bn, compared with Sainsbury's £5.9bn. But shareholders will be keen to see if he can repeat what he has achieved in recent years. In his five years at Prudential its shares outperformed the FTSE 100 by 95%. At the same time Sainsbury has underperformed the index by 65%.

The outgoing chief executive, Dino Adriano, who has worked for Sainsbury for 35 years and held the top job for the past two, will leave after a handover period with more than £1m. During his tenure the share price has collapsed from 580p to less than 300p, although yesterday they closed up 15.5p at 319.5p as investors cheered the appointment of Sir Peter.

The share price rose despite Sainsbury's also issuing a new profit warning, telling investors to expect annual profits of only £560m-£610m - the lowest end of City estimates - against last year's £720m.

Chairman Sir George Bull - who had been criticised for not axing Mr Adriano - said he had decided to replace his chief executive after speaking to dissatisfied shareholders.

"Dino is a stalwart and excellent man", he said. "This is not a criticism of Dino, it is just a way of beefing up and speeding up the pace of change."

As the supermarket price war has hotted up, Sainsbury has been losing sales and market share to Tesco and Asda. Last year the group admitted its stores were shabby and required investment, and the company, which is still 35% owned by the Sainsbury family has become a regular focus of takeover speculation. Yesterday Sir Peter said it was not possible to guarantee the company would remain independent, but that he intended to grow the business.

A series of other new appointments at the chain were also unveiled yesterday, including a new marketing director, Sara Weller, who joins from Abbey National.

webTitle: Borrowers hit as Halifax and Nationwide lift rates rates

fields.headline: Borrowers hit as Halifax and Nationwide lift rates rates
fields.trailText: The largest mortgage lender and the largest building society were the first to inflict 0.25% increases on their standard variable mortgage rates yesterday, in line with this week's Bank of England base rate increase.
fields.body:
The largest mortgage lender and the largest building society were the first to inflict 0.25% increases on their standard variable mortgage rates yesterday, in line with this week's Bank of England base rate increase.

Nationwide, the largest remaining building society, was first to announce an increase for mortgage customers to 6.95%, coupled with the same rise for holders of Nationwide savings accounts. A borrower with a £50,000 repayment loan will now pay an extra £7.36 a month bringing the total up to £339.92, while an interest only borrower with the same size mortgage will suffer a £9.79 increase to £272.21.

Halifax followed swiftly with news that it will raise its rates from 7.24% to 7.49%. Cheltenham & Gloucester, which handles the mortgage busi ness for Lloyds TSB, the UK's third largest lender, will also lift rates by 0.25% to 7.49% But Northern Rock, another lender in the top ten by mortgage assets, bucked the trend by leaving mortgage rates pegged at 7.29%.Homebuyers suffered further misery yesterday as a top endowments company revealed sharply lower returns on its with-profits policies which back thousands of mortgages.

And experts say there is worse to come with policy payouts likely to fall further over the next years - adding to the woes of endowment mortgage holders, many of whom have already been told to boost monthly premiums if their policies are to pay off their loans in full. The falls will impact on future pay-outs whose levels depend on present and past bonuses.

Life insurer Norwich Union announced yesterday that it had cut bonus rates on with- profits policies for the fourth consecutive year. The downward moves echo Friends Provident's falling bonus rates announced earlier this week and are set to be followed by other big endowment names.

Despite last year's big stockmarket advances, payments to holders of Norwich Union's maturing 25-year endowment policies - frequently used for home loan repayments - fell by 8.7%. A £50-a-month policy taken out by a 29-year-old man in January 1975 is now worth £89,518; a similar plan, started in 1974 and maturing 12 months ago, £98,037.

Holders of £50-a-month ten- year endowments - often used for savings plans - saw their final payouts fall by 4.5% to £9,479. The annual endowment bonus fell from 2% to 1.5% of the sum assured while the bonus paid on past bonuses dropped from 3.25% to 2.75%. Bonuses on newer style "unitised" with profits policies are also lower.

webTitle: An end to the embellishments on your CV...

fields.headline: An end to the embellishments on your CV...
fields.trailText: Job applicants who dress up their CVs with fake qualifications or inflated grades are in for a nasty surprise.
fields.body:
Job applicants who dress up their CVs with fake qualifications or inflated grades are in for a nasty surprise.

Experian - a credit reference agency which already holds files on 44m Britons - plans to make computer records supplied by the higher education statistics agency available to employers. The deal has the blessing of the Committee of Vice Chancellors and Principals.

The database will hold details of all degrees awarded by British universities since 1995. Experian says it plans to add school qualifications later.

To comply with data protection rules, employers will have to seek an applicant's permission before consulting Experian but to refuse may reflect badly on a job candidate.

Nottingham university's vice-chancellor, Lord Dearing, said: "The door of employment is wide open to unscrupulous job applicants and this situation makes a mockery of educational qualifications."

In the past credit reference agencies have been accused of holding inaccurate data that has blighted people's lives. Experian says it will open a help desk to correct any errors and for a fee individuals will be able to obtain a copy of their details.

It is believed that only one in three employers check academic results because the process is laborious and expensive.

In a survey of 1,500 employers commissioned by Experian this week, 71% said they had encountered "serious lying".

"A common theme is the people who have not actually completed a course, but award themselves the qualification," said Steven Edwards of Q-Check, a CV verifying company that is Experian's partner on the database.
